column2: Judge Sidney Squire has been sworn in for a second nine-year term on the State Court of Claims. The swearing-in was at private ceremonies in Albany conducted by Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld of the Court of Appeals.
A four-and-a-half-ton shipment of Mexican garlic was stolen yesterday from the Hunts Point Market in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Franklin L. Orth, executive vice president of the National Rifle Association, said today that President Johnson's proposed firearms legislation was "not only unsound and unreasonably restrictive but also contrary to the interests of the American people."
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP)--Virtually all parts of the country were beginning to feel today the cutoff of regular truck deliveries because of the lockout of teamsters by Trucking Employers, Inc.
Trading moved slowly in wheat futures yesterday, perhaps because speculators were waiting for a look at the Government's crop report, due after the close of trading.

IF anyone doubts that the shimmering metals, shiny vinyls, bold patterns and brilliant colors being shown in furnishings are taking hold in decor, they have only to look at what some of the young up-and-coming decorators are doing.

MADRID, April 10 Millions of Spanish fans anxiously followed today the condition of Sebastian Palomo, the 18-yearold bullfighter known as Linares, who was seriously gored yesterday during a performance at Castellon in eastern Spain.

WASHINGTON April 10 A Presidential commissions set the stage today for modification or withdrawal of President Johnson's 18-month-old proposal that "all the nations of the world join us in the creation of an international fund" to solve their need for pure and plentiful water supplies.

The Lighthouse, the New York Association for the Blind, at 111 East 59th Street, will be the setting for the 15th "Amateur Needlework of Today" exhibition, a benefit for the Friendship Fund of The Lighthouse.

The Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee is an organization close to dissolving; its treasury is empty and its membership is declining. Its national chairman, Stokely Carmichael, is a romantic young man who busies himself speaking mainly to white audiences who are intrigued by his inflammatory rhetoric.
A vice president of the International Typographical Union, John Pitch, is assisting the deadlocked negotiations between the printers and The Daily News, the union announced yesterday.

BRUSSELS, April 10 The Foreign Ministers of the six countries in the European Atomic Energy Community (Euratom) moved closer today toward resolving their objections to a treaty that would prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
George Whitmore Jr.'s conviction a year ago for attempted rape was reversed yesterday on the ground that his discredited "confessions" to other crimes had been unfairly excluded at the rape trial.
A 13-week course in shorthand, part of a training program for office work, will be televised by three stations here starting next Monday.
TRENTON, April 10 Gov. Richard J. Hughes reaffirmed his commitment against building a jetport in Hunterdon County before more than 1,000 anti-jetport demonstrators in front of the State House today.

BALDWIN, L.I., April 10 Mr. and Mrs. Wilbur Hampton Benjamin Jr. of Baldwin and Westhampton have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Louise Benjamin, to George Francis Chelius of Centerport, son of Mr. and Mrs. Andrew George Chelius of Rego Park, Queens. A summer wedding is planned.

THE University of Pittsburgh football team held its spring practice so early that it completed the "warm weather" practice last Saturday. During the 19 sessions, the team had to work a couple of times in 18-degree weather. But enough was accomplished to have the coach,...
BONN, April 10 A major shake-up of top management appears to be in the making at the Friedrich Krupp concern in the wake of the company's financial crisis.
MOSCOW, April 10 (UPI) The two space dogs that rode through the earth's Van Allen radiation belt have fathered normal pups, the Soviet news agency Tass reported today.

The 13-day strike of the American Federation of Television and Radio Artists against the three major networks ended at 8:05 last night after the union's national board ratified a settlement agreed to earlier in the day.
ATLANTA, April 10 A vivid picture of the plight of 14 million American women living in poverty was presented here today in a special report to the National Council of Jewish Women.

WASHINGTON, April 10 In the presence of the President of the United States, his entourage and a paying crowd of 44,382, the New York Yankees opened the 1967 baseball season with unforeseen potency today. They routed the Washington Senators, 8-0, as Mel Stottlemyre pitched a twohit shutout and Bill Robinson and Elston Howard hit home runs.

NEW ORLEANS, April 10 (UPI)--Criminal District Judge Bernard J. Bagert ordered Mrs. Sandra Moffett McMaines today to return to New Orleans from Omaha to answer questions before the Orleans Parish grand jury Wednesday about the Kennedy assassination investigation.
WASHINGTON, April 10 The Treasury bill rate dipped further at today's auction, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
Prices dropped sharply yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, the second straight Monday marked by widespread declines.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for banknotes at New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by banks.

ALBANY, April 10 The boycott that had kept Aqueduct Race Track closed for five days ended tonight when horsemen accepted a purse-increase plan proposed by Governor Rockefeller and legislative leaders. Starting tomorrow, the call of "They're Off!" will sound again at the $33-million track in Queens.
For years amateur tennis has been crying for a full-time paid executive to improve its image and sales appeal and do the job that Joe Dey Jr. has performed with such success for golf.
TORONTO, April 10 (AP) The British freighter Manchester Commerce was the first ocean-going vessel of the year to reach Toronto Sunday.

The directors of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People voted unanimously yesterday against the proposal by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. to merge the civil rights and peace movements.
BOSTON, April 10--The United States Court of Appeals for the First Circuit held unconstitutional today the amendment to the Selective Service Act that forbids the burning of draft cards.
The voters of the 18th Congressional District are expected to decide overwhelmingly today to send Adam Clayton Powell back to the House seat he held for 22 years.
A 20-year-old Bronx man, who was despondent over the death of his mother, jumped from the window sill of his 17th floor apartment yesterday but landed safely in a net set up by the police.
The New York County Lawyers Association asked the State Supreme Court yesterday to enjoin further sales of the best-seller "How to Avoid Pro bate," by Norman F. Dacey.
PARIS Where have everyone's eyebrows gone?

WASHINGTON, April 10 President Johnson went out to watch the Washington Senators this afternoon, left after five innings and fled to South America. No one can blame him for that, but he will not find the situation south of the border much more encouraging than it was at D.C. Stadium, where the Senators staked a reasonable claim to last place in the first game of the season.
The Bendix Corporation announced yesterday in Detroit the election of Charles E. Heitman to the new post of executive vice president of its automotive and automation groups.

ST. LOUIS, April 10--The need for an effective, integrated intermodal transportation system that can assure maximum efficiency for container shipping operations was stressed today by a ranking official of the Federal Maritime Commission.
Retailers of men's sportswear, disturbed by a generally disappointing season last fall, are returning to traditional and classic looks in their purchasing for fall, 1967.

Tonnages poured by steel mills in the seven days ended Saturday declined for the fourth week in a row and fell to the lowest level since early February, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported yesterday.

PHILADELPHIA, April 10 (AP) The musical play, "The Fantasticks," opened at the Forrest Theater tonight but not before 20 local musicians walked on stage, played "The Star Spangled Banner" and walked off.
The General Electric-Company announced yesterday that it would build a $50-million gas turbine manufacturing plant between Greenville and Spartanburg, S.C.
T. Arthur Nosworthy, a trustee of the Bronx Savings Bank and its president from 1941 to 1962, died yesterday in his home, 25 Oriole Avenue, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 83 years old.
PEORIA, Ill., April 10 A controversy over fingerprints as evidence led today to the first flash of anger in the trial of Richard Speck, accused of murdering eight nurses in Chicago last July 14.
The body of a man with multiple stab wounds was found yesterday in the trunk of a car that had been in a parking lot at Kennedy International Airport for the last seven weeks.
WASHINGTON, April 10 The Supreme Court upheld today the right of 4,100 JapaneseAmericans to recover funds confiscated by the Federal Government early in World War II.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Supreme Court agreed today to review a lower court holding that a striker's right to reinstatement in his job is contingent on the need for a worker at the time he offers to return to work.
LONDON, April 10 (UPI) Mark Cox will make his Davis Cup debut against Canada in the first round of the European Zone match at Bournemouth, England, May 4 to 6.
Manhattan's leading private nonprofit hospitals, including major medical centers, were reported yesterday to have widespread repair and safety problems just as the 21 municipal hospitals do.

Dog-owners and dogs wearing picket signs ("Stolen Pets May Be Sold to Laboratories") went to Police Headquarters at 240 Centre Street yesterday to protest what the owners termed an alarming rise in the number of dogs that are being stolen.

Herman Licht, a retired partner in Licht Associates, 60 East 42d Street, insurance brokers and advisers, died Sunday in Mount Sinai Hospital, Miami. He lived in Hollywood, Fla., and formerly resided in Freeport, L.I.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) The Supreme Court cleared the way today for retrial, or possibly even release, of two Negro men sentenced to death 14 years ago for the rape of a white woman in Louisiana.
LONDON, April 10 Mark Rothko, the American abstract painter, is considering donating about 20 of his pictures to the Tate Gallery, Norman Reid, director of the Tate said tonight.

Two months ago, on the basis of the incomplete evidence then available, we suggested that the Apollo catastrophe had taken place because "many men miscalculated grossly." The official report of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's review board suggests that that conclusion was too kind. Taken literally, the dry technical prose of the report convicts those in charge of Project Apollo of incompetence and negligence.
There is drama as well as practical importance in the conference of the International Planned Parenthood Federation being held in Santiago, Chile, this week.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) John C. O'Brien, chief of the Washington bureau of The Philadelphia Inquirer, died early today at Georgetown University Hospital. He was 72 years old and had been ill about a month.

Benton Bowles, Inc., the advertising agency, has taken a 20-year lease on the 12 top floors of the 32-story office building under construction at 909 Third Avenue. The aggregate rent will be about $40million.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 9 President Eduardo Frei Montalva says that the Latin-American nations will either revolutionize their lives voluntarily in the next 10 years or totalitarian revolutions will be forced upon them.

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) The Supreme Court left standing today a lower court ruling that the Agriculture Department had the power to decide when chicken soup is chicken soup and not just chicken-flavored soup.
THESE astute and sharply edged essays on literature, scholarship and criticism range from Milton to the Pre-Raphael- ites, from C. S. Lewis to D. H. Lawrence.
The election of Charles A. Anderson to the board of Cutler-Hammer, Inc., was announced yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting in Milwaukee.
PHILADELPHIA, April 10 About 660 longshoremen staged a wildcat strike in the Port of Philadelphia today in a dispute among union members over distribution of an $850,000 royalty fund.
SALEM, Ore., April 10 James C. Drury, professor of marketing at New York University's School of Commerce, died yesterday in Salem General Hospital at the age of 64.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 98.1 on Friday from 98.3 on Thursday.

The newly formed American National Opera Company will tour three productions around the country for 10 weeks next fall, beginning Sept. 25. After that tour is over, two more presentations will be rehearsed and added to the original three for a spring tour. Plans for the Spring tour, are not complete.
LONDON, April 10 The drawn-out negotiations over the price of North Sea gas to be delivered to Britain were reported today to be approaching a conclusion and at a relatively low figure.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (UPI) The Supreme Court ruled today that the merger of the Seaboard Air Line and the Atlantic Coast Line Railroads, in progress since 1958, may be completed.
Long Island University rallied from a 3-0 deficit to defeat New York University, 6-4, yesterday in a Metropolitan Collegiate Baseball Conference game on the winner's field.

RALEIGH, N.C. April 10 A leading authority on waterway transport predicted today that the transportation needs of the nation would grow at a greater rate than industrial production in the next 25 years.

The marriage of Mrs. Gail MacDermott of New York, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George J. Zipp of Mamaroneck, N.Y., to Laurence R. Kamm, son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert Kamm of 15 West 72d Street, took place here yesterday afternoon.
Federal Judge Constance Baker Motley ruled yesterday that a pupil suspended from public school had a right to be represented by a lawyer at a hearing before a Board of Education district supervisor.
WASHINGTON, April 10 Even during bombing runs on the most hazardous missions over North Vietnam American pilots remain remarkably cool, judging from a study of their heart rates in combat.
LONDON, April 10 Joan Littlewood's version of Barbara Garson's "MacBird!" got a cold reception from London" newspaper reviewers.

Sixteen men, straining like bell ringers, raised the circus rigging to the roof of Madison Square Garden Sunday night as the clowns and tigers gave way to the New York Rangers and Montreal Canadiens for tonight's National Hockey League Stanley Cup playoff game.
WHITE PLAINS, April 10 Westchester County welfare workers were banned from further picketing of the County Office Building here today in their dispute over wages and working conditions.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 10 Strict security measures were imposed in Punta del Este today. With most of the hemisphere's chiefs of state gathering here tomorrow, the soldiers and secret service agents of all their nations have made things so tight that a person without a badge and identity papers can be arrested on the shot.

GENEVA, April 10 Dr. Manuel Perez-Guerrero of Venezuela, chairman of the threeman United Nations commission on Aden, indicated today that it would go to London in a few days for further talks with Foreign Secretary Brown.
The stock market went through an old-fashioned read'em-and-weep session yesterday.
Mrs. Susan Train Hand, an active church and charity worker who was the widow of Augustus Noble Hand, the Federal judge, died yesterday at her home, 11 East 68th Street. She was 95 years old.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 10 First-quarter earnings of E. I. du Pont de Nemours Co., Inc. are expected to be about 24 per cent below net income for the corresponding period of 1966, the company's annual meeting was told here today.

A convict who reportedly led authorities to what might be a Mafia burial ground in New Jersey was sentenced yesterday to 10 to 14 years in prison for conspiracy to commit extortion and to 20 to 30 years more for extorting money from two stock brokers.
A Yale graduate and aspiring actor entered the Harvard Club, 27 West 44th Street, yesterday to help raise money for the New York Shakespeare Festival this year.
WASHINGTON, April 10 The Supreme Court took the following actions today:
BALTIMORE, April 10 (UPI) Back in Paris and Persian Intirgue, running as an entry for Trainer J. Bowes Bond, finished one, two today in the $5,000 featured allowance race at Pimlico.

The last meeting of the Presidents of the American republics took place in Panama in July, 1956, to commemorate the 130th anniversary of the first pan-American conference. President Eisenhower attended that meeting, which was largely ceremonial.

Sikorsky Aircraft started a new way of delivering helicopters yesterday. It flew a 10-passenger craft to a Hudson River pier for sea shipment to Taiwan. The company said it was the first time it had made such a delivery from its plant in Trumbull, Conn., to shipside.

NACHABHUAZU, Bolivia, April 10 I have just returned from a four-day jungle patrol with the First Battalion, Fourth Division, of the Bolivian Army, which discovered a strongly fortified base of Castro-type Communist guerrillas deep in the Bolivian jungle.

MEXICO CITY, April 10 (Reuters) The Mexican Government and Mexican private businessmen plan to buy up to 55 per cent of the stock in the sulphur mining company La Compania Exploradora del Istmo, S.A., a subsidiary of the Texas Gulf Sulphur Corporation, it was announced here today.

Major league baseball will return to New York today when the Mets open the season at Shea Stadium against the Pittsburgh Pirates, a team widely rated the most likely to succeed in the National League.

MIAMI BEACH, April 10 Mrs. Bessie Meyers Wien, mother of Lawrence A. Wien, an owner of the Empire State Building in New York, died at Mount Sinai Hospital here today. She was 92 years old and was the widow of Joseph Wien, a silk merchant, who died in 1939.
Three of New York City's largest banks reported their earnings for the first three months of 1967 yesterday.

A legacy of 30-odd paintings three by Renoir and two by Matisse several pieces of primitive art and decorative objects has been left to the Brooklyn Museum by Mrs. Albert C. Barnes, widow of the collector.
"CHOCOLATES," which opened last night at the Gramercy Arts Theater, is a puzzling play that never quite manages to be an intriguing one.
WASHINGTON, April 10 The Supreme Court was told today that statutes prohibiting intermarriages between whites and Negroes were "slavery laws" held over from a bygone era.
The Securities and Exchange Commission postponed yesterday hearings into charges by its staff that the Delaware Fund, Inc., and the Decatur Income Fund, Inc., had incurred ...

BERKELEY, Calif., April 10 Dr. Clark Kerr, removed as president of the nine-campus University of California by the Board of Regents in January, will take a teaching and research post at Berkeley next fall. He expects to spend onethird of his time at this work and looks upon it as a permanent arrangement.

WASHINGTON, April 10 The House of Representatives approved today the purchase of $4.5-million worth of Washington real estate for two diplomatic enclaves intended to relieve the acute shortage of office space in the international community here.
SAIGON, April 10 (AP) Two American news correspondents and a Vietnamese cameraman were among six persons who were injured by a mine today near Rachkien in the Mekong Delta.

PARIS, April 10 The United States protested officially to the French Government today over the burning of an American flag and an attack on two marines during Vice President Humphrey's visit here last Firday.
MT. VERNON, N.Y., April 10 A three-way race for Mayor this fall was shaping up today after a Baptist Minister announced that he would become the first Negro to seek the job.

Thomas S. Lamont, retired vice chairman of the board of the Morgan Guaranty Trust Company and one of the last links to the era of J. Pierpont Morgan, died yesterday at Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, where he had undergone open-heart surgery. He was 68 years old.
JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 10 (Reuters) Black coal miners will now be able to perform certain jobs previously reserved for whites, according to a mining agreement announced today.

A jury award of $275,000 to the victim of a college prank nine, years ago at Syracuse University was reduced to $150,000 yesterday by State Supreme Court Justice Samuel A. Spiegel, who presided at the trial last week.
BALTIMORE, April 10 Mayor Theodore R. McKeldin urged a Congressional commitee studying draft law revision today to consider military deparments for policemen serving in large cities.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 10 A new oral contraceptive that combines a high level of fertility control with, minimum unpleasant side effects for women users attracted medical attention today at the world Planned Parenthood assembly.
"Mirror, Mirror on the funhouse wall, which was the fairest of all the dances performed by the Paul Sanasardo Dance Company at the Village Theater last night?"
DENVER, April 10 (UPI) Possibly the worst earthquake in the city's history rocked the Denver area at noon today, followed by more than a dozen smaller shocks.
Mayor Lindsay is expected today to appoint a top aide as Commerce Commissioner in an effort to bring new industry to the city and hold industry already here.

LONDON, April 10--Foreign Secretary George Brown clashed with the opposition Conservatives today over whether Britain should promise protection to the Government of the South Arabian Federation when it is given independence.
Cooling winds, with gusts up to 46 miles an hour, buffeted the city early yesterday afternoon, but caused few problems other than interrupting perfect spring weather.
The National Cash Register Company showed a decline in first-quarter consolidated net earnings to $4,964,792, from $5,370,012 in the initial three months of 1966, despite increased...

LIKE Mother Hubbard's cupboard, the apartment was bare. The thieves had methodically removed clothing, high-fidelity equipment and the color-television set. They vanished without a trace before the dweller returned from an out-of-town business trip.
DETROIT, April 10 (AP) The United States auto industry, which has plenty of troubles of its own, faced some new outside ones today by highway and rail.

ANAHEIM, Calif., April 10 (UPI) Jimmy Piersall was given a contract today to begin his 18th major league season, but the California Angels cut four other players to reach the American League player limit.

JACKSON TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 10 Federal Bureau of Investigation agents resumed digging here this afternoon in what they believe is a Mafia graveyard in a chicken farm where they recently found the remains of two men.
The Hebrew University in Jerusalem will be the beneficiary of the 26th annual dinner dance to be given by the Jordan Group of Hadassah on Saturday at the St. RegisSheraton Roof.
NEW ORLEANS, April 10 (AP) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit refused today to recall or delay its order for total school integration in six Southern states.

WASHINGTON, April 10 Edward F. Sullivan, who managed the finances of Senator Thomas J. Dodd's 1964 campaign, has told the Senate ethics committee that he paid bills sent to him from the Senator's office without considering whether they were for compaign or personal expenses.
A mediation plan to settle the dispute that has shut down most classes at the Brooklyn center of Long Island University for a week was rejected by the university's Board of Trustees last night.
Short-term interest rates fell again yesterday in a continued reaction to last Thursday's reduction in the Federal Reserve discount rate.
JERUSALEM (Israel), April 10--Israeli farmers who came under Syrian fire last Friday resumed work today without interference in the same fields east of the Sea of Galilee.

Jon Kimche, former editor of the influential Jewish Observer and Middle East Review of London, said on his arrival here Sunday night that the Israeli press "is failing to carry out its true functions" in an open society.
SARAJEVO, Yugoslavia, April 9 Grand Master Boris Ivkov of Yugoslavia and Leonid Stein, the chess champion of the Soviet Union, tied for first...

WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Retail sales soared to a record of $26,474,000,000 during March, 3 per cent above February's $25,636,000,000 and 4 per cent above the $25,536,000,000 of March of last year, the Department of Commerce reported today.

ALBANY, April 10. An effort by the Democratic leadership to commit the Constitutional Convention to work toward the drafting of a new basic charter for the state has provoked the first partisan skirmish of the convention.
TRENTON, April 10 The Assembly voted overwhelmingly tonight to establish a statewide public defender system to offer free legal counsel to poor people accused of serious crimes.
WASHIGNTON, April 10 The United States Court of Appeals declined today to hold an immediate hearing on Mr. Powell's contention that he should have a seat in the 90th Congress.

MOSCOW, April 10 Igor A. Moiseyev, a leading Soviet choreographer, charged today that the future of Soviet ballet was threatened by its preoccupation with classical themes of "princes and princesses."
Ingrid Bergman will return to Broadway next fall, after an absence of 21 years, in Eugene O'Neill's last play, "More Stately Mansions."
WASHINGTON, April 10 President Johnson asked Congress today for a joint resolution to delay a threatened nationwide railroad strike for 20 days. Approval was expected tomorrow.
NEW DELHI, April l0--Vice President Zakir Hussain, a Moslem educator, was chosen today as the governing Congress party's candidate for President.
A tour of the homes of five art collectors has been arranged for Saturday from 1 P.M. to 5 by the Barnard College Club of New York.
The Consolidated Edison Company was accused yesterday of keeping an excessive amount of money in three banks with which it has a "special relationship."

PARIS, April 10 (Reuters) The French foreign trade deficit rose to 860 million francs (about $172-million) in March, from 669 million ($133.8-million) in February and 355 million ($71-million) in March, 1965, according to provisional figures released here today by the Finance Ministry.
Miss. Lucinda Josephine Gosling of 500 East 77th Street and Jean-Louis Pauzat of Chicago plan to marry in June.
PITTSBURGH, April 10 (AP) Maury Wills's new-style baseball shoes, banned by the National League president, Warren Giles, will come under the scrutiny of the Baseball Rules Committee.
DOYLESTOWN, Pa., April 10 The Bucks County Arts Foundation was started today "to foster, promote, nurture and support the fine arts."

WASHINGTON, April 10 If President Johnson was more interested in conversation than the ball game at the season's opener today, no one could blame him. It was not the sort of affair that could command the attention of the President, or anyone else. After five innings of nonwatching, the Chief Executive made his escape from the ball park, heading tonight for South America. It was not far enough away.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 10 Less than 24 hours after he was honored for outstanding achievement in harness racing, William (Bud) Gilmour was indicted today on eight counts of first-degree perjury by the Nassau County grand jury.
The spot rate on the British pound rose in moderate trading on foreign exchange markets here yesterday. The final rate of $2.7990 was four points higher than the closing quotation on Friday.

FEW new ballets have such explicit titles as Ron Sequoio's "Just Songs," given last night by the Manhattan Festival Ballet at its home base, Theater 80, St. Mark's Place. The ballet is as simple and unpretentious as its title, but it has a true originality and a natural charm.

AURORA, Ill., April 10 (AP) The 1967 stockholders' meeting of the Crucible Steel Company of America was postponed indefinitely today by Chief Justice Roy J. Solfisburg of the Illinois Supreme Court. The company has been the object of a control struggle.

The second annual International Motorcycle Show will open in the Teaneck Armory on Teaneck Road in Teaneck, N.J., on Friday. The show, which will feature the offerings of 50 manufacturers, will run through Sunday.

WASHINGTON, April 10--James E. Webb, head of the nation's space program, told sharply critical Congressional investigators today that the men of the Apollo project could correct their errors and fulfill their goal of placing a man on the moon by 1970.

WASHINGTON, April 10 House Republicans proposed today a $1.7-billion plan of their own to replace the Administration's embattled antipoverty program. The Re publicans, members of the Education and Labor Committee, said they had the backing of many poor people.
WASHINGTON, April 10 (AP) Dry weather in the central and southern Great Plains cut-nearly 10 per cent from the winter wheat crop by April 1, despite a 26 per cent increase in plantings.
Mr. and Mrs. Francisco de Sola of San Salvador have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Leonora de Sola, to Paul L. Saurel. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul Saurel of New York.
Two new American-built jetliners one small and one big have made their maiden flights.

WASHINGTON, April 10--The Republican party's top policy committee called on Congress today to stop passing programs of Federal financial aid to the states and order all existing programs halted within five years.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 10 Mr. and Mrs. James Conyers Sayen have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Kate Randolph Sayen, to James Lewis Leader, son of Dr. and Mrs. Abel Jay Leader of Houston.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 11 --The Association of the New Jersey Neuro-Psychiatric Institute will hold its April Annual the 25th on the institute's grounds in Skillman. The event includes a bazaar, luncheon and fashion show.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 11--Mrs. Florence Tynan Crowley, who had taught retarded and physically handicapped children in the New York City school system for 30 years, died today in Doctors Hospital, 170 East End Avenue, Manhattan. She was the widow of George B. Crowley and lived at 250 Bronxville Road.

NATCHEZ, Miss., (UPI)--A crowd of 300 Negroes demonstrated at the county courthouse tonight to protest a mistrial declared earlier in the day. A biracial jury had said it could not reach a verdict in the murder trial of James L. Jones, accused in the slaying of a negro.

THE importance of a wellestablished partnership un derstanding is often debated in expert circles. The predominance of the Italians in world championship competition is often attributed to their well-trained partnerships, one of which has been in action for more than a decade.
"It's like being home," said Ray Caputo, an apartment house maintenance man from Brooklyn. "I was so homesick I even began going to the trots."
This is the first time I step on South American soil. It is my privilege that it should be the land of Artigas [the leader of the Uruguayan independence fight].

The manufacturers long hoped-for spring upturn in new-car sales may be here. The Lincoln-Mercury Division of the Ford Motor Company announced yesterday a 16 per cent increase in new car sales in the first third of April.
Many medium-sized tax-exempt bond offerings reached the market yesterday as investors watched to see how far yields might decline and how the issues might sell at lower yield levels.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP) --The Federal Aviation Agency is looking into possible use in airliners of individual passenger smoke hoods as a safeguard against inhaling of gases and fumes in an emergency.

Eight compact linen parcels containing $420,000, all but $60,000 of which was in United States currency of small denominations, disappeared over the weekend from a strong room in the Air France cargo building at John F. Kennedy International Airport.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)--The Securities and Exchange Commission proposed a schedule of fees today to cover costs of additional regulatory duties for registered brokerdealers who are not members of the National Association of Securities Dealers.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 12 (AP)-- Enemy forces attacked a United States airstrip with a barrage of 30 to 40 mortar rounds early this morning, killing one American and wounding 37, the United States Command reported.
AUGUSTA, Ga., April 11-- William Shivers Morris, chairman of the board of Southeastern Newspapers Corporation, died today. His age was 64.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- Brig. Gen. Frederick William Coleman 3d, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Coleman have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Laura Tyler Coleman, to Nelson Botts Janes. He is the son of Col. Ernest L. Janes, U.S.A., and Mrs. Janes of Arlington, Va., and Lexington, Ky.

"Perhaps half" of the still small number of physicians participating in the Medicaid program in the city have quit because their payments have been delayed, the Citizens Committee for Medicaid said yesterday.
The head of the local printers union put additional pressure on the Daily News yesterday to settle the deadlocked newspaper dispute.
A ship captain and his seaman who knew exactly what to do in an emergency were honored yesterday by the marine section of the National Safety Council.

TORONTO, April 11 (AP)-- The Toronto Maple Leafs, with another excellent job of goaltending by Terry Sawchuk, walloped the Chicago Black Hawks, 3-1, tonight to take a 2-1 edge in the four-of-seven-Stanley Cup semi-final series.
Federal mediators sought yesterday to avert a strike by Local 517 of the Brotherhood of Railroad Trainmen against the Long Island Rail Road.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)--The Howard Johnson Company announced today it would develop a new self-service restaurant with food served in disposable containers and with no item on the menu costing more than $1.

Works by Robert Russell were played and sung in a concert at Town Hall last night. Mr. Russell, who is 34 years old, studied at Long Island University and at the Manhattan School of Music, from which he received undergraduate and graduate degrees in musical composition.

SAINT BRIEUC, France, April 11 (Reuters)--French fishermen started today to move millions of young oysters from hundreds of acres of cultivation beds threatened by oil from the sunken tanker Torrey Canyon.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 11--Harvey King Conner, a former deputy sheriff on trial in Federal court here in connection with the death of a Negro, testified today that he used only enough force to protect himself while arresting the man for "highway intoxication" last Nov. 20.
A section of a new labor bill awaiting Governor Rockefeller's signature may seriously hamper the city's plans to set up machinery for collective bargaining with its employes.

ST. LOUIS, April 11 (UPI) --Bob Gibson struck out the first five batters and checked the San Francisco Giants with five hits tonight as he pitched the St. Louis Cardinals to a 6-0 victory in the National League opener for both teams.
KHANHVAN, South Vietnam, April 11--Pacification came to this fertile hamlet today--for the fifth time in 10 years.
Fordhan University announced yesterday the establishment of its first chair in urban education at the School of Education, Lincoln Center.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- Unemployment did not rise in March, despite the continued slowdown in the economy, the Labor Department reported today.

Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer, Inc. achieved the highest half-year revenues and earnings since 1959 when the film company was separated from theater operations since conducted by Loew's Theaters, Inc., the report of Robert O'Brien, president of M-G-M, disclosed yesterday.

Because present legislation is inadequate, however, the crisis stage is often reached before real bargaining begins. Settlements arrived at under the gun are invariably more costly to the public than they should be.

Shaking off the most rattling body blocks the Rangers could deliver, the Montreal Canadiens skated to a 3-2 victory last night in the first Stanley Cup playoff game in Madison Square Garden in five years.
CHICAGO, April 11 (AP)-- A double steal and Lee Thomas's pop single nudged across two runs in the sixth inning after two out, enabling the Chicago Cubs to down the Philadelphia Phils, 4-2, today.

ENUGU, Nigeria, April 11-- The Military Governor of Nigeria's Eastern Region warned today that the breakup of the country was inevitable unless the Federal Government agreed to mediation by key African heads of state.
FORT WORTH--The old rivalries between Texas cities are not dead, but can it be that the are mellowing? The feel ing between Fort Worth and Dallas used to be especially intense.
The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. has accepted an invitation to become a co-chairman of Clergy and Laymen Concerned About Vietnam, the national peace organization announced yesterday.
Because of the flood of sales promotions aimed at the drugstore trade, many wholesalers are picking and choosing just which ones they'll promote themselves.

CAPETOWN, April 11-- Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster announced today that he was prepared to bend South Africa's policy of apartheid, or racial separation, in sports sufficiently to allow the inclusion of nonwhites on visiting international teams.
Vice President Humphrey came to New York City last night, a day after his return from Europe, to attend two receptions and to go on television.
Buyers crept back into the stock market cautiously yesterday. Prices recovered part of the substantial losses sustained in Monday's broad decline.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 11-- At least 1.5-million Latin-American women are using contraceptive pills, which have become the largest selling pharmaceutical product in this region medical delegates to the world Planned Parenthood assembly said today.

WASHINGTON, April 11--United States officials said today that the Soviet Union and Communist China had apparently worked out an understanding to speed the flow of Soviet military supplies to North Vietnam across China.

BALTIMORE, April 11 (UPI) --Brooks Robinson walloped a two-run homer in the first inning and turned in three spectacular plays at third base today as the world champion Baltimore Orioles began the defense of the American League pennant with a 6-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- The Supreme Court ruled today that judges have absolute immunity from damage suits brought by individuals who contend the judges' decisions violated their civil rights.

TIBERIAS, Israel, April 11-- Syrian gunners opened fire on an Israeli border settlement with mortars and artillery today. The firing sent 200 American tourists at a nearby settlement to underground shelters.

Stocks turned around yesterday on the American Stock Exchange and recovered much of the ground lost on Monday. Bargain hunters, encouraged in part by several better-thanexpected, first-quarter reports on earnings, came into the market and kept the list moving up throughout the day.

HOUSTON, April 11 (UPI) --Eddie Mathews's run-producing triple started a six-run seventh-inning rally against his former teammates tonight and led the Houston Astros to a 6-1 triumph over the Atlanta Braves.
PEORIA, Ill., April 11--A police expert testified here today that three fingerprints found in the Townhouse where eight nurses were slain last July were the same as recorded prints of Richard Speck.
The demand for space in new Manhattan office buildings, rising steadily in the last few years, has set a record in the first three months of this year, a real estate survey shows.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan charged yesterday that certain milk companies had "defrauded the city and her milk consumers of millions of dollars by rigged bids and price-fixing over a long period of time."
Gimbel Brothers, Inc., which operates the Gimbel department stores and the Saks Fifth Avenue chain of specialty stores, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended Jan. 31.

BANGKOK, Thailand, April 11--Southeast Asia is moving "fairly rapidly" toward economic, cultural and political cooperation free from the "dictation" of the great powers, Foreign Minister Thanat Khoman declared today.
GENEVA, April 11--Another snag has developed in the attempt to work out a compromise treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.
New York State's code of criminal procedure "furnishes inadequate protection against false confessions" in criminal cases, a state agency declared yesterday.
Four developing nations that produce 40 per cent of the nonCommunist world's copper were cautioned yesterday against setting unreasonably high prices in this period of strong demand.

The opening of commercial air service between New York and Moscow has moved a step nearer with the recommendation of the chief examiner of the Civil Aeronautics Board that the Soviet state-owned airline, Aeroflot, be permitted to operate into Kennedy International Airport.
TROY, N.Y., April 11 (AP) --Maj. Gen. Thomas F. Farrell, retired but long active in public projects, died today. He was 75 years old.
AVALON, N.J., April 11 (AP)--At least 1,500 wild ducks were dead or dying today as thick black oil drenched the birds in their feeding grounds several miles off the South Jersey coast.
NASHVILLE, April 11 (UPI) Peace apparently returned tonight to a 30-bloc college area that had been rocked by three nights of racial violence.
Johnny Carson continued to stay away from the "Tonight" show yesterday as almost everyone else in the broadcasting industry went back to work.
Industrial issues were narrowly mixed yesterday on the London Stock Exchange where traders awaited publication of the British budget after the close of the market.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 11--They came one by one, almost furtively, so that the biggest of them all was virtually sneaking onto the continent whose love he covets the most. No crowds, no cheers for the Presidents of the Americas--and without them the bands and empty artillery rounds were merely routine.
MADISON, Wis., April 11 (AP)--Students staged a noisy but orderly demonstration today against job recruiting on the University of Wisconsin campus by the Central Intelligence Agency.
LOUISVILLE, April 11--The largest civil rights demonstration here in six years brought a citywide police mobilization and a series of downtown traffic jams here tonight.

BONN, April 11--The two parties forming the West German coalition Government are considering whether to make a bid to the ruling Communist party of East Germany on an easing of relations between the German states.

The Democratic-controlled Board of Estimate and City Council yesterday overrode all 20 of Mayor Lindsay's vetoes of changes they had made in his record $1-billion capital budget for the 1967-68 fiscal year.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 12--Premier Nguyen Cao Ky made a positive response today to a Ceylonese proposal for peace talks.
Le Pavillon will remain open for supper beginning next Wednesday when an "April in Paris" gala champagne supper under the sponsorship of the American French Foundation will be given.

IN the case of "Illya Darling," which is a song-and dance version of the film "Never on Sunday," I think they've made a slight mistake. They've left the show in Detroit, or wherever it was last warming up, and brought in the publicity stils.

Four members of a betting syndicate, which was alleged to have won more than $500,000 on the twin doubles at Yonkers Raceway, were indicted yesterday by a Federal grand jury on charges of conspiring to defraud the Government in taxes due on the winnings.
BY way of celebrating the arrival of spring fishing weather, Abercrombie and Fitch, the sporting goods store at Madison Avenue and 45th Street, has a fishing clinic running there through Friday.
BIMINI, the Bahamas, April 11--The special election in the 18th Congressional District sent Adam Clayton Powell to bed early tonight.

BEDFORD HILLS, N.Y., April 11--A gray-haired woman celebrated a birthday today with what she calls "my children"--New York's 2,966 state troopers. And she recalled a murder that led to her becoming the "mother" of the state police. The legislation setting up the organization was signed 50 years ago today by Gov. Charles S. Whitman, largely as a result of her actions.
WASHINGTON, April 11--The United States is preparing to resume the shipment of military equipment, at first mostly spare parts for weapons to Pakistan and India.

Joseph H. Braverman, manager of engineering for the Tishman Realty Construction Co., has been elected an assistant vice president of the concern. Mr. Braverman, who joined Tishman in 1955, will continue to supervise the design and installation of mechanical and electrical facilities in all Tishman buildings.

Melvin Deane Southworth of Springfield, Mass., chairman and former president of the Southworth Company, paper manufacturers of West Springfield, died Monday at the Neurological Institute of the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 83 years old.

KANSAS CITY, April 11 (UPI)--A costly blunder by the Cleveland first baseman, Fred Whitfield, and the strong pitching of two right-handers, Jim Nash and Jack Aker, carried the Kansas City Athletics to a 4-3 victory over the Indians tonight in an American League opener played under protest.

After Jose Torres lost his world light-heavyweight championship to Dick Tiger last Dec. 16 in Madison Square Garden, the New York State Athletic Commission put the displaced titleholder on its "ill and unavailable" list for his poor performance.

PARIS, April 11--Gen. Pierre Gallois was trying to explain why France had seemingly turned her back on the Atlantic Alliance and had chosen to rely on a small, independent nuclear force to protect her interests.
LONDON, April 11--The Spectator, a British weekly magazine, is to be sold to a machine-tool manufacturer.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- The Senate moved today to assure a Supreme Court test of the constitutionality of Federal aid to church-supported schools and colleges.

A trial for $11-million in damages for the "wrongful deaths" of 11 Navy men killed in the crash on July 6, 1960, of the Navy dirigible Reliance into the Atlantic off the New Jersey coast opened yesterday in Federal Court.

BONN, April 11--A West German Raman Catholic weekly, Echo der Zeit, has reported a Vatican protest that West German plans to convert parochial schools to public schools are a violation of the 1933 concordat between the Holy See and Germany.

With the gasp of approval that ordinarily greets a successful moon shot, the audience at the State Theater last night welcomed Edward Villella in the City Ballet's first performance of "Prodigal Son" this season.
ROME, April 11--An Italian Deputy called today for the destruction of all pigs in the Rome region to prevent the spread of a fatal African swine fever that has already taken a toll of 25,000 animals.
The Columbia-Presbyterian medical center said yesterday that 46 violation items reported Monday by the Buildings Department posed no major problems to patient safety.
ROCHESTER, April 11--Industrial and religious leaders here formed a corporation today to guarantee 1,500 jobs for unemployed Negroes.

GREENVILLE, Miss., April 11--Two Senators investigating the antipoverty program saw evidence today of extreme deprivation and malnutrition, if not the starvation they heard about in hearings yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 11--A top official of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation testified today that the only document the corporation's board had before it when it tentatively approved a merger with the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., was one that promised a big increase in I.T.T. profits if the merger took place.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 11 --Howard M. Abbott, who retired last year as a vice president and director of the Harchem division of Wallace Tiernan, Inc., chemicals producers, died of a coronary occlusion today at Lawrence Hospital, Bronxville. He was 66 years old and lived here at 7 Cotswold Way.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- Congress gave President Johnson today the special legislation he had requested to delay a nationwide railroad strike deadline for 20 days.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- The State Department said tonight that photographs taken by journalists who accompanied an army patrol into Bolivia's jungle "tend to confirm" reports of guerrilla activity in Bolivia.

Students who have been boycotting the Brooklyn center of Long Island University for seven days suspended their walkout yesterday to study their position and to try for an accord with the university's administration.

Allison R. Maxwell Jr., president of the Pittsburgh Steel Company, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Pittsburgh that the company was negotiating to acquire other steel processing concerns, He declined to identify them.
Geraldine Stutz, president of Henri Bendel, Inc., made a trip from fashionable 57th Street to financial-minded Wall Street yesterday to speak about the business of fashion.
FREEPORT, L.I., April 11-- Eugene F. Brockhaven, who retired in 1965 as editor of the Pictorial Review section of the Hearst Sunday newspapers, died here today at his home. He was 71 years old.

As amazing as ever, the Mets committed five errors yesterday, dissipated a formidable pitching performance by Don Cardwell and lost the opening game of New York's baseball season to the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-3.

WASHINGTON, Wednesday, April 12--The teamsters' union and major trucking companies announced this morning a tentative agreement on a new labor contract that would end the industry's three-day-old shutdown.

ATLANTA, April 11 (AP)-- A sharp increase in malaria in the United States has been delayed infection in American traced to a Vietnamese parasite that apparently causes a servicemen, a Federal health official said today.

PARIS--Anyone in Paris who wants to buy a French racehorse, visit French cement factories or golf courses, see the Christian Dior collection, write a letter in Turkish, or tour the city with a pretty girl who drives her own car should telephone 553-55-72. The number operates weekdays until 7 P.M.
WASHINGTON, April 11 (UPI)--Mr. and Mrs. Patrick J. Nugent have purchased a pink brick, French provincial house in Austin, Tex. It is priced at $70,000.

The city announced yesterday that plans for converting the 646-acre World's Fair site in Flushing Meadow, Queens, into a huge sports and recreation center had been submitted by three prominent architects.
The Erie-Lackawanna Railroad's business in this year's first quarter trailed that of the comparable 1966 quarter by 6 per cent to 8 per cent.

BROOKVILLE, L.I., April 11 --Leonard H. Berliner, a partner in Ivy Lee, Ltd., manufacturers of children's dresses, died Sunday after having been taken ill on the golf course here. He was 50 years old and resided at 26 Town Path, Roslyn.

A fashion show titled "Lark in the Park" will be given tomorrow evening at 8 P.M. in the auditorium of the nurses' residence of New York Hospita, at York Avenue and 70th Street.

Mr. and Mrs. Mario Cooper have made known the engagement of Mr. Cooper's daughter, Miss Patricia Ellen Cooper, to Jerry Cohen, son of Mrs. Max Cohen of New London, Ohio, and the late Mr. Cohen. A June 24 wedding is planned.

A hearing officer for the Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor has recommended that a fine of $125,000 be imposed on a major stevedoring company charged with what the commission views as commercial bribery. No fine this large has ever been imposed by the New York-New Jersey agency.

WASHINGTON, April 11 (AP)--The House today passed, 379 to 29, the first complete revision of the nation's copyright laws in 58 years, after easing a controversial provision relating to jukeboxes.
CHICAGO, April 11--The $26billion packaging industry is gearing up for the future--and its exhibits at the National Packaging Exposition here this week reflect it.

Fordham rallied in the late innings to defeat the Columbia baseball team yesterday, 5-3, at Baker Field.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- Oliver Weerasinghe, the Ambassador of Ceylon, and Mrs. Weerasinghe have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Menakka Weerasinghe, to Stuart Yeatman McDougal. He is the son Mr. and Mrs. Murray McDougal of Pasadena, Calif.
A thief stole a red-tailed hawk, a peregrine falcon and a sparrow hawk here yesterday, but passed up a harpy eagle.

THAT beautiful bubble burst again yesterday for the New York Mets. For more than half of the ball game that was played in the Shea Stadium refrigerator, the darlings of the New Breed appeared on their way to carving out a chunk of history. But the bubble shattered and the Mets were grasping at empty air.

Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that the city's new Economic Development Administration, if approved by the City Council, will be headed by Richard Lewisohn with Barry H. Gottehrer as his chief deputy.
A two-day trial on the city's rights to accept $90,000 for a children's farm in Prospect Park ended in State Supreme Court yesterday with everyone handing down opinions except the judge.

The cutoff of truck deliveries in many parts of the country affected the metropolitan area last night when 3,000 automobile assembly workers were laid off by the Ford Motor Company plant in Mahwah, N.J. Ford said its plant in Metuchen, N.J., which employes about 2,500 persons, would operate today.

Trying to stop the Port of New York Authority is like trying to stop a juggernaut. The Board of Estimate, which has the power to halt the work already under way on the site of the Authority's proposed World Trade Center, is the latest body to be bowled over. It has withdrawn its cease and desist resolution, with the result that clearance of the site for construction continues unimpeded.
Western Union International, Inc., reported yesterday that 1966 operating revenues totaled $21,943,000, a gain of 20 per cent over the $18,215,000 reported a year earlier.

WARSAW, April 11--The United States and Poland agreed today to ease the burden of Polish indebtedness to the United States by allowing Poland to finance a joint program of training Englishlanguage teachers in lieu of repayment of $9.5-million.
PARIS, April 11--Six large banks in six countries announced today that they would create a new financial company to stimulate investment in and by European industry.

STOCKHOLM, April 11 (Reuters)--Canada and the United States were still searching for their first victory in the world table tennis championships here tonight, but they provided two of the closest matches of the day.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 11 --Although Stanley Dancer had said that any "reasonable handicap" imposed on Cardigan Bay in the 11-year-old gelding's next outing would be all right with him, it developed today that the word "handicap" was not part of the lexicon of Cardigan Bay's owners.

LONDON, April 11--Dr. Immanuel Jakobovits declared tonight on his installation as Chief Rabbi of Britain that he was resolved to maintain British Jewry as a community predominantly faithful to Orthodox Judaism.

Edward Swayduck, president of Local 1, Amalgamated Lithographers of America, said yesterday that the projected Graphic Arts Center on Manhattan's Lower West Side would be the city's first industrial coldominium.
MADRID, April 11--Several hundred university students demonstrated in midtown Madrid today to protest plans to try a group of their Barcelona colleagues.

BAUNSSUM, Holland--When General de Gaulle expelled NATO headquarters from France he quite literally kicked the alliance's most vital command post from a palace to a pit. AFCENT, military gobbledygook for Allied Forces, Central Europe, used to be located in the splendid Fontainebleau residence of King Francois I. Now it has moved into a Dutch coal mine.
WASHINGTON, April 11-- Miami Beach emerged today as the leading contender for the site of both the Democratic and Republican national conventions in 1968.

New Yorkers are depositing slugs in parking meters almost 15 times more often this year than they did five years ago, the city Investigation Commissioner said yesterday.
ALBANY, April 11--A bill setting June 20 as the date for the 1967 primary election has been signed into law by Governor Rockefeller, the Governor's office announced today.

JACKSON TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 11--A search for the body of Barbara Delmar, a 35-yearold Danbury, Conn., woman who disappeared in June, 1963, was called off by the Federal Bureau of Investigation here ' today after agents had dug up a concrete-floored patio on a chicken farm near here.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- The question of whether noncommercial television stations enjoying Federal support should come under civil rights laws was raised today at the opening of a hearing by the Senate Commerce Committee on President Johnson's proposal to create the Corporation for Public Television.

POTTSTOWN, Pa., April 11 --Of all the problems facing our emergent dance companies throughout the country, that of providing a decent classic repertory is the most pressing.

Earnings of the Polaroid Corporation rose 34 per cent in the first three months of this year while sales gained 31 per cent, Edwin H. Land, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting yesterday in Waltham, Mass.

Richard Stiegler, who developed and owned shopping centers in the Northeast, died of a heart attack Saturday aboard his yawl, Enchanta, off St. Martin in the Netherlands Antilles. He was 58 years old and resided in Greens Farms, Conn.

A champagne fashion show for the benefit of the Boys' Club of New York will be held on Tuesday in the Park Avenue Room of Saks Fifth Avenue. Mrs. Edward B. Meyer Jr. is chairman of the arrangements committee.

Adam Clayton Powell swept to an effortless victory in the 18th Congressional District yesterday, trouncing his two opponents in a special election by almost 7 to 1.

MIAMI BEACH, April 11 (AP)--Undefeated Joe Frazier stopped Jeff Davis of Houston in the fifth round of their scheduled 10-round heavyweight bout tonight.

THE Appalachian region may be economically de pressed, but some sophisticated and expertly made brooms, baskets, wall hang ings, candles, dolls, bowls and pillows emanate from there. A show of crafts from the re gion goes on display today at Georg Jensen.

WASHINGTON, April 11-- Julie London, Mitch Miller, Bobby Troup, Red Foley, Stan Kenton, Bonnie Guitar and the first violinist of the Boston Symphony Orchestra testified before a Senate subcommittee today in favor of a change in the copyright law.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12--An 18,000-ton British tanker was partly sunk by an explosive charge this morning off Nhatrang, about 200 miles northeast of Saigon.
The taxpayer was a wellpaid professional who had enough time and energy to add to his income by freelance work.

Prices will be raised by the United States Steel Corporation on some structural-steel shapes and on some sheet piling, effective Saturday, the company said yesterday. Other producers had no immediate comment.
SAIGON, Thursday, April 13 (AP)--South Vietnamese Government leaders are considering a plan to remove cicountry's northern-most province, Quangtri, because of the enemy menace in the area.
John F. McKenna, long active in the lumber, banking and realestate businesses in Brooklyn, died Tuesday in his home at 73 83d Street, Brooklyn. Mr. McKenna was 87 years old.

Leading figures in banking, finance, education, letters and journalism were in the congregation that filled St. James' Episcopal Church at 865 Madison Avenue yesterday morning for the funeral service for Thomas S. Lamont, the banker and long-time partner of J. Pierpont Morgan.
If the Supreme Court's Clorox decision hit the advertising business like a bomb yesterday, it was a noiseless explosion. But rest assured there were plenty of vibrations.

The Federal Aviation Administration will appoint 10 radiation biology experts to study the radiation aspects of supersonic transport operation, Gen. William M. McKee told the Civil Aviation Medical Association in Washington this week.
Moscow, April 12--Chronic alcoholics will face labor camp terms up to two years under a law passed by the Supreme Soviet (Parliament) of the Soviet Union's Russian Republic.

The school boards in two New Jersey cities--Roselle and Pompton Lakes--have decided that high school girls' miniskirts are getting too short, and the boys' hair too long. They plan to halt the fashions.

Earnings of the General Electric Company declined for the second successive quarter in the three-month period ended March 31 despite record sales, according to the report yesterday of Fred J. Borch, president of the world's largest electrical and electronic manufacturer.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)--The United States intends to reduce drastically its direct, bilateral aid to African countries, shifting the emphasis to multinational solutions.

DURING the second round of the recent Grand Prix International in Monte Carlo, Guy Mazzoni, the French champion, confounded the commentators when he sacrificed a knight early with 13 NxP in a Sicilian Defense against Bobby Fischer.

BIENHOA, South Vietnam, April 12 (AP)--Only 3,200 prisoners--roughly 4 per cent of the thousands captured by South Vietnamese forces and their allies--have been sent to prisoner of war camps, United States and Vietnamese military officers said today.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 12--The meeting of American Presidents that began in this seaside resort today is an expression on the highest level thus far of the 150-yearold dream of Pan-Americanism.

RADU LUPU, a 21-year-old Rumanian pianist who has studied for the last three years at the Moscow Conservatory, was the winner of the second Van Cliburn International Piano Competition held in Forth Worth,...
WASHINGTON, April 12--The nation's output of goods and services did not grow at all in the first quarter of this year, the first time that has happened in six years, the Government estimated today.

An electronic computer for the sale of tickets to entertainment events was unveiled yesterday by Ticket Reservation Systems, Inc., at the Gotham Hotel. At the same time, it announced that a pilot operation will be initiated in the metropolitan area in May.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to advance strongly in brisk trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.

"She and He" began a commercial engagement yesterday at the Fifth Avenue Cinema, the latest entry in a series of features by young foreign moviemakers. The picture, which was made in Japan, is being presented by Brandon Films. It was shown here in 1964 at the New York Film Festival.
TEL AVIV, Israel, April 12-- Another skirmish broke out on the troubled Syrian-Israeli border today and a farmer of the Gonen communal farm in the Galilee area was reported seriously injured.
BOSTON, April 12--A stockholders' committee seeking control of the Boston Maine Corporation challenged today the propriety of the annual meeting.
BALTIMORE, April 12 (AP) --The Baltimore Bullets of the National Basketball Association rehired Gene Shue as coach today.

Federated Department Stores Inc., the nation's largest department store chain, reported yesterday record sales and earnings for the fiscal year ended Jan. 28, but had a slight decrease in earnings in its fourth quarter.

The 10th season of Clarion Concerts wound up last night at Town Hall with a typical flurry of musical novelties. There were two local premieres: Boismortier's Cantata, "L'Automne" and th eSymphony in E Flat by Simon Le Duc. Newell Jenkins, the conductor, made it an all-French evening with four other seldom-encountered scores:
ALTHOUGH food may not be their prime interest, the art of cooking seems increasingly to become a favorite pastime for bachelors.

A State Supreme Court justice handed down a summary judgment yesterday upholding Mayor Lindsay's position that the city cannot legally transfer $84.3-million in state aid to the Transit Authority to preserve the 20-cent subway and bus fare.
SOUTHERN PINES, N.C., April 12 (AP)--Brig. Gen. Augustus M. Gurney, retired, died on Monday in Womack Army Hospital in Fort Bragg. He was 72 years old.

A board of distinguished scholars called together by the book publishing firm of Charles Scribner's Sons is planning a reference work to be called "Dictionary of the History of Ideas." The publishers expect to put it out in three or four years.

THE ice has grown thin for the New York Rangers as they keep edging toward a plunge into the chilly waters of the open sea that lies almost inevitably ahead. They will have a last chance to brake themselves when they play the Montreal Canadiens at Madison Square Garden tonight in their Stanley Cup playoff series.
United States PlywoodChampion Papers, Inc., announced here yesterday the election of Kenneth L. Morrow as a senior vice president.
Vice President Humphrey said yesterday that the eggthrowing incidents that made headlines during his tour of Europe were blown up out of all proportion.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)--The Johnson Administration underwent sharp criticism today when it failed to come up with a new, comprehensive maritime program at a Senate hearing.

Brooks Atkinson, former drama critic of The New York Times, will receive the 17th annual distinguished service award from the Library Associates of Brooklyn College, an organization of citizens who support the library.
MOSCOW April l2--Sergel G. Lapin, Soviet Amabassador to China since 1965, has been named general director of Tass, the Soviet press agency, the Government announced today.
A 10-ton, 210-foot boom on a construction crane buckled an East 42d Street yesterday morning, slashing into the roof of a bus and knocking out the rear window of a taxicab.
George F. Duborg Jr. was elected yesterday to the board of Arnold Bernhard Co., a mutual fund manager, and as a vice president of Value Line Securities, Inc.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 12--When President Johnson's twinrotor helicopter landed on the sunny lawn of his villa here, one of the first men out was Walt Whitman Rostow.
WASHINGTON, April 12-- The nation's major trucking companies resumed operations today after an early morning settlement of the industry's biggest labor dispute.
THE HAGUE, April 12--The head of the office of Aeroflot, the Soviet airline, in the Netherlands was arrested on an Amsterdam street today on charges of spying for the Soviet Union.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)--John D. Rockefeller 3d was honored last night with a testimonial dinner given by men and women in Government service who have won Rockefeller Public Service Awards. The affair also marked the 15th anniversary of Mr. Rockefeller's awards program.
GENEVA, April 12--The United States proposed today that a new beginning be made toward East-West cooperation within the United Nations Economic Commission for Europe.

WASHINGTON, April 12--At this distance it is difficult to measure all the political and other considerations that went into the $10-million reduction by the New York City Council in the $25-million allocation Mayor John Lindsay had proposed for the model cities program.
More than 700 children were safely evacuated yesterday in three minutes from an Astoria, Queens, public school that was destroyed in a four-alarm fire.

After 11 months of negotiations, the city and the union representing 2,000 municipal administrative employes reached agreement last night on the terms of a contract. The union is Local 1180 of the Communication Workers of America.
R.L. Ireland 3d, a partner in the banking concern of Brown Brothers, Harriman Co. has been named general chairman of the 88th annual campaign of the United Hospital Fund of New York.

FLORENCE, Italy, April 12--"I took the stockings to the cleaner's and had them dyed this way," said Princess Luciana Pignatelli, a Roman boutique designer, waving a pair of long, textured, net stockings that were orange around the knees but became paler going down to the ankles. They looked great.

BIMINI, The Bahamas, April 12--Announcing a policy of strict silence for the present, Adam Clayton Powell declined today to give details of any plans to return to the United States or to try to regain his House seat.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 12--Following is a list of the major participants in the conference of American chiefs of state (Presidents and foreign ministers, respectively):

THE formation of cooperative organizations to combat rising costs in breeding, raising and keeping dogs was suggested yesterday by William J. Trainor of Amherst, N.H., at the Dog Fanciers Club meeting in the Overseas Press Club.
CHAPEL HILL, N.C., April 12 (UPI)--An art student started it with a small colored-chalk drawing on the concrete YMCA court.
SALEM, Ore., April 12--Gov. Tom McCall said here today that 12 Republican Governors had responded "enthusiastically to a proposal to remain uncommitted on a 1968 Republican Presidential nominee.
ALBANY, April 12--The president of the Constitutional Convention appointed executive directors today for five more standing committees.
ATHENS, April 12--Two thousand building workers fought the police for two hours today in the narrow side streets off Omonia Square in downtown Athens.
PEKING, April 12 (Agence France-Presse)--China shook up the political command of the armed forces today.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 12 (AP)--The Cambridge Grant Farm's unbeaten Fleet Swoon, romped to another easy victory at Gulfstream Park today as he won the $10,000 Florida Juvenile Championship.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 12--There are really two conferences going on here: the conference of the Presidents, and President Johnson's conference.

PARIS, April 12--The French Government mobilized civilian and military forces today on the coast of Brittany, along with boats, ships and aircraft, to fight the incoming tide of oil from the tanker Torrey Canyon.
LINDEN, N.J., April 12-- Fred McGillvray of 38 West Gibbons Street, a member of the board of education here for many years, died yesterday at his home. He was 87 years old.
ST. LOUIS, April 12 (UPI)-- Charles W. DeWitt, who was co-owner of the St. Louis Browns in the American League, died last night of a heart attack. He was 66 years old.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 12--President Johnson told the leaders of Latin America today that he would try to support their new common market with more financial aid, but hedged his promises on other forms of economic help.
Gasoline supplies in the week ended last Friday fell to 221,403,000 barrels from 222,372,000 a week earlier and 214,040,000 in the week last year, the American Petroleum Institute said yesterday.

Negotiations between the Communications Workers of America and the Western Electric Company resumed last night, lifting the threat of a strike this morning by 12,300 workers in 35 of the company's distributing houses.
ALLENTOWN, Pa., April 12 (UPI)--Samuel Miller, president of The Call-Chronicle Newspapers, Inc., died today at Allentown Hospital, where he had been a patient for two weeks. He was 62 years old.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 12 (UPI)--E.I. du Pont de Nemours Co. withdrew today a Federal court petition seeking dismissal of a Justice Department demand for information on the company's patent licensing activities.

A prominent Chinese concert violinist and composer, who said he had been beaten by students at the outbreak of the Cultural Revolution in Peking last fall, has escaped from Communist China and is living in Manhattan.
MOSCOW, April 12--A Russian poet raised a plea today that the hard toiling Soviet woman be put back on the pedestal and be treated by men with chivalry and respect.

The Museum of Modern Art made known yesterday plans to expand its activities in LatinAmerican countries. The announcement coincided with the opening of the Pan-American economic conference at Punta del Este, Uruguay, and with Pan-American Week, which started Sunday.
The Rangers, whose chances are reduced to the possible rather than the probable, continue their Stanley Cup semi-final series with the Montreal Canadiens tonight at Madison Square Garden.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 12--Dr. Ralph J. Bunche asserted today that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. should not try to lead both a civil rights campaign and a crusade against American involvement in Vietnam.
BONN, April 12--The West German Government acknowledged today the Socialist Unity (Communist) party for the first time as the ruling force in East Germany.

WASHINGTON, April 12-- No one familiar with the facts believes that President Johnson's decision today to delay a nationwide rail strike for 20 days has done anything more than postpone a tough decision until he returns from Uruguay.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 12 --Spokesmen for two Negro groups, called today for renewed demonstrations against the Louisville Board of Aldermen to protest the defeat last night of a proposed city open-housing ordinance.

SOUTHERN Connecticut's baseball team hopes to start another long winning streak by beating St. Peter's today. The Nutmeg State athletes won 16 in a row over two seasons until Monday afternoon when St. John's,...
"I'm allergic to nostalgia," Groucho Marx said yesterday, sounding for all the world like Capt. Jeffrey T. Spaulding, the African explorer.

Mayor Lindsay's 27-man Summer Task Force to prevent outbreaks of violence held its first meeting yesterday to discuss how city and private agencies could join in setting up programs in potential troublespots.

LYNBROOK, L.I., April 12-- Mr. and Mrs. Philip A. Lincoln have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gail Paula Lincoln, to David J. Levy 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Levy Jr. of Woodmere, L.I. The wedding is planned for August of 1968.
A threatened strike of the Long Island Rail Road by its trainmen and an alternative plan by them to work but not collect fares were headed off last night by President Johnson.

House passage of a bill to modernize the obsolete copyright laws represents major progress in a campaign that has been under way for more than a decade. Though changed in some important particulars from the original committee version, and granting more concessions to the juke-box operators than they deserve, the House-approved bill is still a substantial improvement over existing law.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 12 --The richest pace in harness racing, the classic Messenger Stakes for 3-year-olds, is set for the night of May 13 at Roosevelt Raceway. The declaration deadline for the first leg of the triple crown of pacing series will be the morning of May 4, when the starting payment of $2,500 is due.

ROME, April 12--A Roman court is expected to leave for the United States early next month where it will hear testimony in the trial of 32 persons accused of smuggling half a ton of heroin into the United States.

PARIS, April 12--Two Paris police officials apologized today to the United States Embassy and to the American Cathedral for anti-American incidents the occurred during Vice President Humphrey's visit last Friday.

The situation was back to normal at Aqueduct yesterday. A crowd of 26,655 turned out for the races. Advocator won the feature event, the betting handle reached its customary figure of about $100 per capita, and Jack Dreyfus Jr. was on the scene without a necktie.

NAPLES, Fla., April 12--Two of the country's leading medical examiners testified today that they found traces of a usually undetectable drug in the body of Mrs. Carmela Coppolino. Dr. Carl A. Coppolino, who was her husband, is on trial on a charge of having murdered her.
The Stauffer Chemical Company will offer $6 a share for 57 per cent of the common stock it does not own in the Mountain Copper Company, Ltd., the two concerns announced yesterday.
The New Scofield Reference Bible, a revised edition of one of the country's most popular Bible study volumes, was published yesterday by the Oxford University Press.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)--The number of working days lost nationwide because of labor disputes this year has been running 36 per cent ahead of the figure in 1966, Department of Labor statistics indicate.

CHICAGO, April 12--The American Bishops of the Roman Catholic Church cleared the way today for Catholics to fulfill the obligation of attending Sunday mass on either Saturday or Sunday under certain circumstances.
MADRID, April 12--Spain moved today to tighten the economic blockade of Gibraltar, barring aircraft from most of the airspace around the tiny British colony effective next month.

BOSTON, April 12 (AP)-- Rico Petrocelli drove in four runs with a homer and single and the Boston Red Sox survived late-inning jitters to down the Chicago White Sox, 5-4, in the opening game for both teams today.

The grand jury investigation into charges of a multimilliondollar milk industry conspiracy has been broadened to determine if companies are postdating milk sold to stores and whether stores have been prevented from changing dealers.
JERSEY CITY, April 12-- Detailed plans for a $34.3-million Transportation Center in the Journal Square area here were made public jointly today by Jersey City and the Port of New York Authority.
The New York Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the election of R. Manning Brown Jr. and Charles W.V. Meares as directors. Both men are executive vice presidents of the company.

HOUSTON, April 12 (UPI)-- Bob Aspromonte's two-out single in the sixth inning tonight drove in Rusty Staub from second base with the deciding run as the Houston Astros scored a 4-2 victory over the Atlanta Braves.
St. John's University announced yesterday that it would establish a School of General Studies in September, 1968.
The world heavyweight title fight between Cassius Clay and Floyd Patterson was canceled yesterday.
