An outdoor peace protest at Hunter College's Bronx campus moved indoors briefly yesterday to a mock session of the United Nations, sponsored by the college.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) --The Federal Aviation Agency yesterday proposed higher safety standards for planes used in air taxi service.
The Maritime Subsidy Board has asked six steamship lines to file proposals for the construction of six vessels for which subsidy funds are available in the 1967 and 1968 Federal building program.
In an enlightened ruling a three-man Federal court has written an opinion that reaffirms the right of protest in time of war.
New York University alumni have selected three members of the faculty for $1,000 Great Teacher awards, it was announced yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 12-- A New York drug wholesaler asserted today that restrictive membership practices by the National Wholesale Druggists Association were hampering competition and had forced a number of small dealers out of business.
Mayor Lindsay gave a dinner for the President of Turkey in a jungle setting last night--in a lush greenhouse at the New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP) --Broadcasters and song writers joined today in opposing a proposal to require that stations pay royalties to companies and performers who make records played over the air.

ON the south New Jersey coast line, roughly be tween Cape May Point and Corson's Inlet, hundreds and perhaps thousands of sea ducks are dead and dying from bunker oil pollution. The oil started drifting into the area last Monday.

Sales of the Celanese Corporation reached the highest quarterly level in company history during the first three months of this year, but earnings fell 9.3 per cent from a year earlier, Harold Blancke, chairman, told shareholders yesterday.
The election of B. Glenn MacNary as president of the Continental Baking Company was announced yesterday in Rye, N.Y.

ST. LOUIS, April 12 (AP)-- The San Francisco Warriors rallied from 18 points behind to defeat the St. Louis Hawk, 112107 tonight and win the National Basketball Association's Western Division playoff.
WASHINGTON, April 12-- A lawyer in the Justice Department asked the Supreme Court today to grant the police more power to search for and seize evidence of crimes.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 12--Former deputy sheriff Harvey King Conner was found not guilty today after a two-day trial in United States District Court here on a charge of violating the civil rights of a 27-year-old Negro who died of injuries received in an arrest last Nov. 20.
In a lease with aggregate rent of $800,000, REA Express has taken the entire 40,000square-foot building at 511-19 West 21st Street for a 10-year period.
British Government bonds and gold mining shares advanced sharply yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
The New York Jets will conduct a football seminar for women tonight at 7 o'clock in the Adelphi University gymnasium at Woodruff Hall, Garden City, L.I.
LONDON, April 12--The price of gold jumped sharply in the London market today because of exceptionally heavy demand.
LONDON, April 12--Lord Shackleton, accompanied by seven advisers, flew to Aden today with full authority to work out a new approach to South Arabian independence and the withdrawal of British forces.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., April 12--Mark D'Andrea, who retired 10 years ago as president of D'Andrea Brothers, formerly custom tailors in New York, London, and Paris, died today at Mercy Hospital. He was 80 years old and lived here at 6 Judson Place.

The city will file a suit tomorrow charging the New Haven Railroad with failing to protect rail cars filled with fruit and vegetables against theft at the new Hunts Point Market terminal in the Bronx.
SAN QUENTIN, Calif., April 12 (UPI)--Cyanide gas fumes took the life of a murderer today in California's first execution in four years and the first of 1967 in this country.

MADISON, N.J., April 12-- The student body of Drew University's theological school called today for the resignation of Dr. Robert Fisher Oxnam, the university president. The students said they would boycott and picket all classes "for the rest of the academic year" in support of their demand.
The Waterside Housing Development designed to reclaim a section of Manhattan's rundown waterfront near East 25th Street for living purposes was approved yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
WASHINGTON, April 12-- The Marquesa Merry del Val, wife of the Spanish Ambassador, gave one of her simple little dinner parties tonight.

Leonard Bernstein, music director of the New York Philharmonic, will conduct 14 weeks of the orchestra's subscription concerts next season. William Steinberg, principal guest conductor, will conduct 12 weeks, and each of six guest conductors will lead the orchestra for one week.

WASHINGTON, April 12-- The Joint Chiefs of Staff gave their endorsement today to the treaty on the peaceful uses of space, but only on the condition that it leads to increased United States military activity in space.
YONKERS, April 12--Miss Sandra Reed Steele and Specialist 4 Stephen Henry Schneider, U.S.A., have made plans to be married Oct. 14 in Crestwood.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 12 (AP)--The Communist party and the leftist Workers Revotionary party were outlawed by the Government last night in the campaign to combat guerrilla movements.

The Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism announced yesterday that this year's $250 Paul Tobenkin Memorial Award would be shared by Brian R. Donovan of The Rochester (N.Y.) Democrat and Chronicle and Cal Olson of The Fargo (N.D.) Forum.
WASHINGTON, April 12-- The Senate tentatively agreed today to impose restrictions on the use of Federal funds by political parties under a new Presidential campaign financing law.

Marvin Morgenstern, a violinist who has appeared as a member of the Galimir String Quartet and participant in several modern music programs, gave his first solo program last night at Carnegie Recital Hall.
AVALON, N.J., April 12 (AP)--At least 2,500 birds were dead or dying and another 8,000 were seriously affected today as oil began to reach the beaches along the South Jersey coastline.

NEW DELHI, April 12-- The Indian Government said today that the United States decision to resume the sale of spare parts for weapons to Pakistan would "imperil peace in the Indo-Pakistan subcontinent."

WASHINGTON, April 12-- The four former employes of Senator Thomas J. Dodd who instigated the investigation of the Connecticut Democrat have accused the Senate ethics committee of limiting the scope of the inquiry for reasons of "policy."

Stocks closed on a mixed note with advances outnumbering declines by a slight margin, although leading market averages finished off; volume, 7.75 million shares. Corporate bonds were off in brisk trading; transactions, $11.88-million.
The American Stock Exchange faltered yesterday after a promising start and ended lower on the day.
MADRID, April 12--At least 50 students were arrested today after a battle between demonstrators and the riot police on the campus of Madrid University.
Short-term interest rates continued to decline yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 12--Norman E. Bensinger, proprietor of what he always called the nation's oldest billiard parlor, died yesterday in St. Joseph's Hospital. He was 79 years old.

BONN, April 12--Smoldering antagonism between church and state over school reform in West Germany flared today as a result of a Vatican note accusing the Government of violating the 1933 concordat between the Holy See and Hitler's Third Reich.
PARIS, April 12--The United States is pressing its allies for acceptance by next Wednesday of the controversial clauses of a draft treaty to prohibit the spread of nuclear weapons.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12 (AP)--An American soldier who escaped after almost a week as a Vietcong prisoner was identified today as Pfc. Bruce Graening of Kenmore, Ohio.

"I like to focus my energy on the people who are really making a contribution to this world," said Yousuf Karsh, the portrait photographer, as he stood yesterday in the lobby of the Union Carbide Building, 47th Street and Park Avenue, and supervised the hanging of his own contributions to history.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N.J., April 12--Emerson D. James, assistant director of the urban relationships service of the Boy Scouts of America, died yesterday at Memorial Hospital, Oconomowoc, Wis. He was 56 years old and lived at 65 Central Avenue, Franklin Park, N.J.
"A miracle," one broker commented yesterday.
PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 12--President Johnson asked both sides in the rail dispute today to "use every hour of these next 20 days" to reach a settlement.
WASHINGTON, April 12-- The Johnson Administration's drive toward expanded trade with the European Communist countries won a point in the Senate and lost one in the House today.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 12-- An "epidemic" of illegal abortions, including at least a million a year in the United States, was described today as a major medical problem.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)--Gen. Mark W. Clark, retired, called today for stricter action against draft evaders and card burners in urging Congress to extend and improve the Selective Service Act. He urged severe and prompt punishment.
DETROIT, April 12--New car sales advanced in the first 10 days of April, marking the first time auto sales have topped the 1966 level in any 10-day period this year.

Robert S. Klein, a senior and captain of the Columbia fencing team, was named the winner of the Varsity "C" Watch, donated by former President Dwight D. Eisenhower, at the 46th Varsity "C" Club dinner last night.

More than 700 persons, including wounded veterans from the St. Albans Naval Hospital in St. Albans, Queens are expected to attend the 19th anniversary ball of the Bedside Network in the Grand Ballroom of the New York Hilton tomorrow.
NEW ORLEANS, April 12 (AP)--Dean Andrews, a lawyer who once represented Lee Harvey Oswald on minor legal matters, was reindicted for perjury today by the Orleans Parish (County) grand jury.
SANTIAGO, Chile, April 12 --The Minister of Finance, Sergio Molina, has declared that Chile would have to cut public spending if copper prices continued to drop in the London market.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 12 --Life is different now for Gay Brewer since he won the Masters golf title last Sunday. "When we were home in Dallas on Monday" said the 35-yearold professional today, 'my wife and I stayed up until 3 o'clock in the morning receiving phone calls and telegrams of congratulation."

NASHVILLE, April 12--The Tennessee Legislature took a step today toward repealing the state's 42-year-old prohibition against the teaching of the theory of evolution in taxsupported schools and colleges.

MONMOUTH BEACH, N.J., April 12--Stanley W. Prenosil, a former foreign correspondent of The Associated Press, died today at Monmouth Medical Center in Long Branch. He was 73 years old and lived here at 44 Monmouth Parkway.

An apparent agreement to end the student boycott at the Brooklyn center of Long Island University was reached early today.
DETROIT, April 12--An open housing ordinance was defeated yesterday by a two-to-one margin in Jackson, Mich., a city of 51,000.

CANCALE, France, April 12 --A 50-yard wide oil slick lurks two nautical miles from this quiet little fishing port's... famed oyster beds. The oysters' fate hinges on the wind.
WASHINGTON, April 12-- In their struggle to equal the monument to mediocrity that the Mets have erected, the Yankees overdid it tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 12--A subcommittee of the House Banking Committee has agreed unanimously to continue and to expand its controversial studies of bank ownership, conflicts of interest of bank directors and officers, and anticompetitive relationships between banks and other financial institutions.

As far as familiarity is concerned, Stravinsky and Richard Strauss were the "old masters" on the Boston Symphony program last night at Philharmonic Hall. Haydn, along with Gunther Schuller and Anton Webern, fell into the "rarely heard" bracket.

MILLBURN, N.J., April 12-- Ernest J. Oberlaender, a retired textile importer, died Monday at Northfield Manor Nursing Home, West Orange. He was 67 years old and lived at 14 Bailey Road here.
LINCOLN, Neb., April 12-- Nebraska's unicameral Legislature passed a combination salesincome tax bill today and Gov. Norbert T. Tiemann signed it 23 minutes later.

A gold bar worth about $40,000 has disappeared from an airliner that carried it from New York to Aruba in the Netherlands Antilles, authorities disclosed yesterday.
LONDON, April 12--Voters in the London area, about onesixth of Britain's electorate, will go to the polls tomorrow to pick the 100 members of the Greater London Council.

MOSCOW, April 11--The Soviet Union announced today that Marshal Andrei A. Grechko, a 63 year-old professional soldier, had been named Minister of Defense.

WASHINGTON, April 12--A top official of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation said today that the company had never made any move to renegotiate the price it had agreed to pay for the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 12 (AP)--Pablo Casals, the Spanish-born cellist, received tonight the John F. Kennedy Prize from the Institute of North American Studies of Barcelona, in a ceremony at City Hall.
BERLIN, April 12--The East German Communists have demanded as a price for a German detente that Bonn give up its claim of being the sole legal representative for all Germans.

WASHINGTON, April 12-- A space official testified tonight that he once considered taking part of the Apollo spacecraft contract away from North American Aviation, Inc., because of the company's "considerable problems" in meeting schedules.

WASHINGTON, April 12--A dozen leaders of a Negro farmers' cooperative in Alabama came to Washington today to try to shake loose a Federal grant that is being opposed by the concerted political power of their state.
The stock market closed on the fence yesterday after a morning advance faded in the afternoon.

IT is perfectly legitimate to draw inferences from the deportment of one's opponents and Ely Culbertson once made an important contract because he noticed that P. Hal Sims relaxed suddenly in the middle of the play.
The Daily News made a new offer to the printers last night in an effort to settle the newspaper dispute.

Jimmy Dean will continue as Johnny Carson's replacement on the "Tonight" show until Friday, April 21, the National Broadcasting Company announced yesterday. The following week, Bob Newhart, who was recently signed to a longterm contract by the network, will take over.

SEOUL, South Korea, Thursday, April 13 (AP)--At least three North Korean soldiers and one South Korean were killed early today in what appeared to be the most serious border clash since the 1953 Korean armistice.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 12--The Soviet Union announced today that it was preparing to make a long-awaited voluntary contribution to help cover a United Nations deficit that almost crippled the world organization.
JERSEY CITY, April 12-- Bowman Gray, chairman of the R.J. Reynolds Tobacco Company, charged today that a mandatory requirement to list "cigarette tar and nicotine content" would mislead the public.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 12 --The Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy, contending that peace demonstrations planned for next Saturday will be based on the view that the United States is totally responsible for the Vietnam war, said today that it would not take part in them.
More than 1,100 policemen now in clerical positions are scheduled to be transferred to the patrol force after July 1. In Mayor Lindsay's executive budget, which he will...

GUATEMALA, April 12--The bodies of 12 men were found in various parts of Guatemala yesterday, police authorities announced. The victims' hands were tied behind them and their bodies were riddled by .45-caliber bullets.
CLEVELAND, April 12--The trustees of Case Institute of Technology and Western Reserve University approved today the consolidation of the two institutions into Case Western Reserve University.

Dr. John C. Porges, an obstetrician and gynecologist who retired a year and a half ago from a practice at 77 Park Avenue, died Tuesday at the Mayflower Nursing Home, 601 West End Avenue. His age was 69.
WASHINGTON, April 12-- Adam Clayton Powell's future in the House of Representatives remained almost totally obscure today.
A 90-year-old woman died and her son was critically burned yesterday in a fire in Brooklyn.

AN interregnum, the first in more than a decade, exists in the National Basketball Association today. The Boston Celtics have been dethroned--but the Philadelphia 76ers, who dethroned them, are not yet entitled to be crowned in their place.

Gen. John P. McConnell, the Air Force Chief of Staff, said here yesterday that enemy supplies flowing into South Vietnam increased 25 times above normal during the four-day truce in Febraury for the lunar new year.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 12 (AP)--Larry Kristoff of Chicago successfully defended his crown and another 1966 winner claimed the trophy in a lighter class in the Greco-Roman section of the National Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships tonight.
BRUSSELS, April 12--The European Economic Community is moving cautiously toward making a deal with Spain.
ANDOVER, Mass., April 12-- Charles W. Arnold Jr., former chairman of the Merrimack Valley National Bank in Haverhill, died yesterday at his home, 88 Central Avenue. He was 75 years old.

Dr. Walter A.H. Mosmann, a New Jersey orthodontist, will be installed as president of the New York Academy of Dentistry tonight at the Columbia University Club, 4 West 43d Street. The academy is an international hon-...

BONN, April 12--Konrad Adenauer, former West German Chancellor, is in serious condition, suffering from bronchitis. A spokesman said his condition had become worse today, and complications had set in.

HONG KONG, April 12--Sir David Trench, the Governor of Hong Kong, was criticized in an editorial published today in both Ta Kung Pao and Wen Wei Pao, the British colony's two major Chinese Communist newspapers.
AN oven that can also refrigerate was among six prototype appliances shown in Detroit yesterday by Kelvinator, division of American Motors Corporation.

DANANG, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 13 (Reuters)-- Vietcong guerrillas blew up a five-span steel bridge eight miles north of here today on the main supply route to allied troop bases near the demilitar-...

CAPETOWN, April 12 (Reuters)--Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vo rster said tonight that it would be a big mistake to think that all racial barriers would be removed from South Africa's international sports policy.
WASHINGTON, April 12--The United States, in an attempt to slow the arms race on the Indian subcontinent, removed itself today as a major weapon supplier to Pakistan and India.

A former member of the Council of Economic Advisers said yesterday he foresees a resumption of business expansion in the United States that "is probably going to come a little sooner and be a little stronger than some of us would have predicted even a few weeks ago."

THIS is one of the finest travel books of the year. The territory it covers goes around the earth--and deep into tough forces that still shake contemporary man. Africa, the Africa of today's emergent nations, is Alan Moorehead's main stage. The three wartime books he wrote about the bloody fight against the Nazis and the...
The United Presbyterian Church's Commission on Ecumenical Missions and Relations has withheld its proxies on 3,628 shares of Eastman Kodak Company stock to challenge the...

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 12--The "plan of action" approved by foreign ministers of the Western Hemisphere for examination today by the Presidents details the principles, objectives and methods for achieving social and...

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 12--A United States Air Force board of inquiry determined today that the bombing of a village in which 105 people died and 200 were wounded was the result of human and mechanical error.

Britain's Labor Government has unveiled a holdthe-line budget to see it through the next twelve months. While refraining from proposing new taxes, the Chancellor of the Exchequer is also not relaxing the harsh austerity measures imposed last year to save the pound.
Cellu-Craft, Inc., made its first public offering of common stock yesterday. A group of underwriters led by Blair Co., Inc. managed the sale of 200,000 shares with warrants to purchase 20,000 more.

At 5:30 P.M. yesterday Dr. Paul Dudley White, the Boston heart specialist, stepped before television cameras at Grady Memorial Hospital in Atlanta and spoke for 90 minutes on "The History of Cardiology."

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12 (AP)--Dr. Joseph N. MacDonald, dean of the School of Medicine at the American University in Beirut, died of a heart attack Tuesday night at the University Hospital. He was 54 years old.

DHALA, South Arabia, April 11--Ali Ben Ali and his band of terrorists, skilled in "keeny weeny," struck again last night and escaped, foiling soldiers of the South Arabian Federation and cheating once more the chains of the Emir's dungeon.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 12--A fund-raising drive to build the Merry-Go-Round Mews, a four-story brick home for 72 elderly men and women, will get under way on Friday and Saturday with a carnival in the Greenwich Armory and, on the morning of the second day, a street parade.

A local chapter of the Conservative Young Americans for Freedom repudiated yesterday the support by its national organization for the war in Vietnam and declared that "we cannot, in good conscience, fight and die in Lyndon Johnson's war."
MERIDIAN, Miss., April 12 --Eighteen white men pleaded not guilty today to conspiracy charges arising from three civil rights murders in Neshoba County in 1964.
PHILADELPHIA, April 12-- The 1967 Award of Merit of the Religious Public Relations Council will be presented to The New York Times on Friday at the council's annual meeting in the Warwick Hotel.

WASHINGTON, April 12-- How to insulate a system of taxpayer-supported television from governmental review or political influence was the main theme at today's Senate Commerce Committee hearing on a bill contemplating the creation of a Corporation for Public Television.

WASHINGTON, April 12 (AP)--A Senate Judiciary subcommittee took only eight minutes today for a hearing on the nomination of Prof. Jack B. Weinstein to be a Federal judge for Eastern District of New York.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 12 --Syria has summoned the Trans-Arabian Pipe Line Company, known as Tapline, to discuss an increase in transit royalties on petroleum that crosses Syria from fields in Saudi Arabia.

LOS ANGELES, April 12-- The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. challenged today the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People to take a "forthright stand on the rightness or wrongness" of the Vietnam war.

PEORIA, ILL., April 12--The defense opened its case this afternoon in the trial of Richard Speck, accused of having murdered eight nurses. But none of the first nine defense witnesses offered any evidence to show that the state had accused the wrong man.

Mrs. Katharine Fowler Milbank, a patron of music and a benefactor of young working women here, died of a heart attack yesterday morning in the East Side town house in which she was born 82 years ago, on March 4, 1885.
SOMERS, N.Y., April 12-- The inability of political leaders to agree on a new Supervisor has left Somers without a chief official or a voice in Westchester County affairs.

NEW DELHI, April 12-- Secretary General Thant warned the nations of the world today that if peace is to be achieved, "it is not enough to know a man or a country--it is necessary to understand them in their own terms."
ENUGU, Nigeria, April 12-- Washington has banned travel of American officials to Nigeria's dissident Eastern region, causing a diplomatic furor in the region's capital.

AUTOMOTIVE analysts on Wall Street are continuing their guessing game about just how low earnings of the Chrysler corporation went in the first quarter. The longer they think about it, the more bearish they seem to become.
DETROIT, April 12--The Ford Motor Company announced today organizational changes aimed at centralizing its automobile operations and strengthening the company's car division.
Gathering of data to decide on new subway lines for Queens has been started, Borough President Marlo J. Cariello announced yesterday.

New York City's beleagured municipal hospitals, which have been widely criticized because of shortages of personnel and general disrepair, will receive an additional $65-million in Mayor Lindsay's new budget.
The Police Department has urged the man who is sought in the March 31 shooting of three detectives to "surrender to the police or the district attorney to avoid further violence and bloodshed."

The special projects committee of the Girl Scouts of Greater New York held a dinner dance last evening at the St. RegisSheraton Roof. Some of the women among the 275 guests changed into evening pajamas lent by prominent designers to entertain the company with a game of musical chairs.

Marianne Moore, hailed by Mayor Lindsay as "truly the poet laureate of New York City," last night received the Gold Medal for Distinguished Achievement of the Poetry Society of America at its 57th annual dinner, in the Plaza Hotel.

PARIS, April 13--France's challenge in the computer industry took shape officially today with the signing of a five-year agreement between the Government and a newly created, allFrench computer company.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 13 (AP)--Citing "the will of the people," the California Senate reversed a position taken four years ago and voted 23 to 15 today to repeal the Rumford Open-Housing Act.
Two benefits are planned for the Brooklyn Museum this month. They are Brooklyn Museum Day at the New York Flea Market on Sunday and the Magic Carpet Ball on Saturday, April 22.

TORONTO, April 13 (AP)-- Eric Nesterenko's tie-breaking goal in the third period helped carry the Chicago Black Hawks to a 4-3 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs tonight in the Stanley Cup playoffs. The Chicago triumph tied the bestof-seven semi-final series at two games each.
The bond market shuffled through the day yesterday without hitting any really interesting territory.

James W. Rouse, a mortgage banker and realty developer of Baltimore, has been elected president of Urban America, Inc., a nonprofit organization dedicated to improving the quality of city life. Mr. Rouse, president of the Rouse Company, reveloper of the commuity of Columbia, Md., succeeds Stephen R. Currier, founder and first president of Urban America, who was lost on a plane flight over the Carribbean in January.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)--The heavyweight boxing champion, Cassius Clay, went into the Supreme Court today in an effort to block his scheduled April 28 induction into the Army.
Miss Regina C.M. Burke, former associate superintendent of schools here, died Wednesday at her home at 1900 South Ocean Drive, Fort Lauderdale, Fla. She was 85 years old.
The spot rate on the British pound continued to rise in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 13 (UPI)--Willard Schilff, a harness race driver, was charged today with first-degree perjury arising from the Nassau County grand jury investigation of alleged race-rigging at Roosevelt Raceway in Westbury.

WASHINGTON, April 13-- The Indian Government has formally protested to the United States over Washington's decision to resume selling Pakistan spare parts for her American-made jet fighters and tanks.

ROBERT DALEY'S long, lumpish, but not uninteresting novel may be taken three ways: as an oil-fashioned tale of romantic disillusionment, as a rancorous expose of newspaper reporting and editing, or as a rather unpleasant roman a clef, assuming you've got the clef.
HE was a retired tanker captain who probably never had earned as much as $20,000 a year. But his first trip to a broker's office, one day in San Francisco, showed that he was a man of substance.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13--The Bank of America and the Chase Manhattan Bank have taken steps to prevent the use of their military banking facilities by currency black marketeers.

TORONTO, April 13--Canadian Javelin, Ltd., mailed proxy statements to shareholders today calling a meeting April 27 in St. John's, Nfld., to approve the issuance of controlling stock to the Newfoundland Government to accelerate a $120-million pulp and paper venture.

The head of the printers' union, Bertram A. Powers, said yesterday that a new package proposal by The Daily News, including a 16 per cent money increase over three years, was not acceptable. He said he would seek further improvements at the bargaining table.

SANTIAGO, Chile, April 13 --Six Roman Catholic priests from six Latin-American countries attending the world Planned Parenthood conference asked the Vatican today to speed its doctrinal study of "demographic problems."

Officials of an antiwar group sponsoring a demonstration here tomorrow called a news conference yesterday to decry what was described as a Federal attempt to prevent a party of Sioux Indians from attending the protest.
MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 13 (AP)--Seven of the nine Southern Governors invited to a meeting here next Monday on school integration have declined the invitation.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13--Dr. Ralph J. Bunche said today he accepted "at face value" the disavowal by the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. of any effort to merge the civil rights movement and the campaign against United States involvement in Vietnam.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)--The Federal Aviation Agency has proposed to apply to small jet planes the same noise abatement procedures that are in force for all large airplanes of any type.

TOKYO, Friday, April 14 (AP)--The Cuban Embassy here said today that it had granted asylum to a Koreanborn United States soldier assigned to Vietnam duty and had rejected a demand from the Japanese Foreign Ministry that he be surrended to the Tokyo police.

THE timing was unfortunate to the point of embarrassment. The first--and last--publicity release on the Cassius Clay-Floyd Patterson fight came bouncing blithely into the office from Las Vegas, Nev. With a slight bit of editing the first sentence tells the entire story. The editorial insertion appears in italics and here's the way the revised version would have read:

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 13--President Johnson's meetings with other American chiefs of state reached a climax this evening when the Latin leaders overwhelmed Ecuador's demand for more help from Washington and vowed to open a new era of economic development.
New price schedules for chlorine, caustic soda and soda ash were filed yesterday by a number of chemical producers in conformance with a consent decree they accepted in December.
WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)--The House has passed legislation that would authorize $167,713,000 for the Coast Guard, with $5,460,000 of the total amount earmarked for three projects in New York State.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 13--Following is the official text of the "plan of action" of the American chiefs of state, scheduled for signing tomorrow. The term "Latin America" in the text includes all members of the Organization of American States except the United States. "Presidents" includes the Prime Minister of Trinidad and Tobago. "Continent" comprises islands as well.

CHICAGO, April 13 (UPI) --Members of the Philadelphia Phillies and Chicago Cubs baseball teams were among 100 guests who fled their rooms when smoke from a storeroom fire spread through the Edgewater Beach Hotel early today.
PATERSON, N.J., April 13 (AP)--"Car Four, where are you?" the police radio dispatcher asked.

In ruling that pupils faced with suspension from school have a right to be represented by lawyers at hearings in the school district superintendent's office, Judge Constance Baker Motley has put the spotlight on a serious problem, too long ignored.
BURBANK, Calif., April 13-- Anthony Ventoura, a partowner of the De Beers Consolidated Diamond Mines, of South Africa, died in his home here yesterday. His age was 97.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)--Members of the Senate ethics committee said today that the panel had already investigated charges against Senator Thomas J. Dodd that four former aides of the Connecticut Democrat want the committee to air in public hearings.
Mrs. Elsie Wolff Kiefer, who was active in Jewish affairs, died Wednesday night at Doctors Hospital. She was 85 years old and lived at the Hotel Bradford, 210 West 70th Street.

GENEVA, April 13--West Germany has sent a note to participants in the Geneva Disarmament Conference stating its conviction that the proposed treaty to prohibit the spread of nuclear weapons should not become an instrument for producing "greater inequality among nations."
The stock market rose in a slow and steady fashion yesterday.
"The specs are holding the ball and not giving it up," one broker commented yesterday, referring to the recent sharp rises in world sugar futures prices and the speculators who often deal in them.

ATLANTA, April 13 (AP)-- Vice President Humphrey said tonight that during his European trip Pope Paul VI told him "with tears in his eyes" that America's moral image was being eroded by the way the United States is described in accounts of war and racial violence.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (UPI)--The Internal Revenue Service today proposed taxing the advertising profits of publications like the National Geographic Magazine that are published by otherwise taxexempt organizations.

Dr. Howard A. Rusk, professor and chairman of the Department of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University Medical Center, was awarded a certificate of honorary fellowship in the New York Cardiological Society, yesterday.
Alfred Hitckcock joined 5,004 other polar bears at Shea Stadium yesterday and watched the New York Mets produce "The Case of the Disappearing Baseball."

IT becomes tedious after awhile to keep pointing out that a good deal of the wildlife conservation efforts are paid for by hunters, but this is the way it goes. The established refuges and new lands are financed by the duck hunters' Federal hunting licenses, the duck stamp.

Evidence supporting a new biological principle fundamental to the way living organisms function was presented here yesterday by scientists from university laboratories and research centers in the United States, Canada and Europe.
William C. (Buster) Bailey, jazz clarinetist, died yesterday in his home, 341 Washington Avenue, Brooklyn, following a heart attack. He was 64 years old.

HAINES FALLS, N.Y., April 13--At first glance Nino Benvenuti of Italy, who will challenge Emile Griffith for his world middleweight title next Monday night, does not look like a professional prizefighter.

NAPLES, Fla., April 13--Despite attempts by the defense counsel to deride his testimony, the chief toxicologist of New York City today stated that the first wife of Dr. Carl A. Coppolino could have died of an overdose of succinylcholine, the muscle-relaxing drug often used in surgery.
VALERIE HOFFMANN and Donald Davis, partners in an architectural concern, walk to work every morning--down several flights of stairs.

Maria Lucia Godoy, the Brazilian soprano who made her local debut April 3 with Leopold Stokowski and the American Symphony Orchestra at Carnegie Hall, followed it up last night at Carnegie Recital Hall with her first local recital.

SEOUL, South Korea, Friday, April 14--South Korean Government officials said today provocative North Korean action along the demilitarized zone was obviously aimed at creating tension in South Korea before its Presidential election May 3.
Runoff from remnants of the winter snowfall added half a billion gallons to the city's reservoir system yesterday, raising the level to 443.5 billion gallons.
A Christian-Marxist dialogue will be held behind the Iron Curtain in Prague in two weeks, according to Dr. Roger Garaudy, a leading Marxist theoretician.
TEL AVIV, April 13--Tal Brody, a former University of Illinois basketball star, led a Tel Aviv Maccabee quintet to a 68-67 victory over Ignis of Varese tonight in a European Cup basketball final.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 13 (UPI)--Jeering whites hurled stones, firecrackers and tomatoes into a crowd of open housing demonstrators tonight, injuring three persons.

WASHINGTON, April 13-- Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien asked Congress today for the "tools" to prevent "catastrophe" in the postal system. His plea elicited a combination of warm sympathy and cold criticism.

HANOI, North Vietnam, April 13 (Agence France Presse)-- A little country like Vietnam can defeat "the No. 1 'Hun' of our time, the United States imperialists," the chief of the North Vietnamese General Staff, Lieut. Gen. Van Tien Dung, said today.
Profit taking reduced industrial prices yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 97.8 on Wednesday from 97.9 on Tuesday.
The principal indicators of Federal Reserve policy showed a mixed pattern yesterday, but on balance the trend was still toward easier money.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13--Vietcong guerrillas severely damaged two bridges between Danang and Quangtri early today, cutting land communications to strongpoints manned by United States Marines along the demilitarized zone.
WILMINGTON, Del., April 13--The question of a possible merger of the Avco Corporation and the wealthy but little-known Paul Revere Corporation was hotly debated at Avco's annual meeting here today.
MIAMI, April 13--Cuba's Minister of the Interior, Maj. Ramiro Valdes, today acknowledged that crime had become a national problem.

Brunch, one of the Tartan Stable's excellent candidates for the major 3-year-old stakes ahead, came through with the third straight victory of his career yesterday in a mile race at Aqueduct. The winner of his two previous outings by big margins, Brunch made it a little closer this time, but he left no doubt in the minds of the 26,349 observers that he was the best in the field of nine contestants.

ALBANY, April 13--Two proposed amendments to the existing state Constrution will be facing the voters at the Nov. 7 election even though the current Constitutional Convention may decide to submit an entirely new Constitution to the voters in the same election.

ATLANTA, April 13 (UPI) --Gaylord Perry, aided by home runs by Willie Mays and Willie McCovey, picked up where he left off last year tonight when he set the Atlanta Braves down on four hits while pitching the San Francisco Giants to a 2-0 victory.
KANSAS CITY, Kan., April 13 (AP)--High winds and a few small tornadoes battered portions of Kansas, Texas and Arkansas early today as rain and snow covered much of the Middle West and Southwest.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13--A statistical survey made public here today shows that it costs slightly more to live in Paris than in New York and a good deal less in Vienna.
Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler said yesterday that the discovery of hundreds of new violations in city schools, many of them "hazardous to life and limb," left "no room for complacency."
CHERRY HILL, N.J., April 13 (AP)--Garden State Park officials said today that 456 colts and geldings were kept eligible for this fall's Garden State Stakes, with a payment of $125.
Directors of Stouffer Food Corporation yesterday approved a plan to join Litton Industries, Inc., giant West Coast diversified electronics producer.
Prof. Marshall D. Shulman, as authority on Soviet affairs, has been appointed director of the Russian Institute of Columbia University.

JERUSALEM (Israel), April 13--Israel's biggest manhunt ended late last night when Anwar Menashe, suspected of killing three people, surrendered to policemen in an abandoned orange grove near Tel Aviv.
John H. Glenn Jr., the first American to orbit the earth, has been signed to star in a series of one-hour television documentaries on great explorations.

WASHINGTON, April 13 (AP)--The Securities and Exchange Commission today lifted its ban on over-the-counter trading in the common stock of the United Security Life Insurance Company of Birmingham, Ala., effective Monday. The current suspension order, periodically renewed over the last 14 months, expired today.
What are believed to be the oldest paintings discovered in the New World have been found on rock walls in a Mexican cave by two amateur anthropologists from the United States.
WASHINGTON, April 13-- The tentative settlement in the national trucking negotiations was snagged today by a continuing local dispute in Chicago.
The New York Civil Liberties Union moved yesterday in Federal Court to protect the right of free speech for a 17-year-old high school editor.
A first-quarter decrease in profits is indicated for the Atchison, Topeka Sante Fe Railway, John C. Davis, a vice president, told a group of investment brokers in Chicago yesterday.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 13--In his speech at the American Presidents' meeting today, President Johnson offered the Latin-American nations technological and educational projects ranging from communications satellites to school lunches.
CLEVELAND, April 13 (AP) --Max Freedman, who founded the Cook Coffee Company in 1921 and headed a chain of 94 stores doing a $318-million annual business, died last night at the age of 79.
A real estate consultant's office has been opened by Frederick W. Jackson at 156 Fourth Avenue in Bay Shore, L.I.

Norishige Hasegawa, a top executive in Japan's chemical industry, predicted here yesterday that there would be a substantial increase in joint United States-Japanese ventures in Japan in the next few years.
Mayor Lindsay is expected to announce plans this morning to set up an official New York City marching band. The proposal would eliminate the Department of Sanitation band in the coming fiscal year.

WASHINGTON, April 13-- The first significant controversy over creation of a Corpora tion for Public Television erupted today at a Senate Commerce Committee hearing on a bill to develop a national system of noncommercial television.
MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 13 (Reuters)--Luis Somoza de Bayle, former President of Nicaragua, died today. He was 45 years old.
JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 13 (AP)--A Federal judge blocked today the executions of Florida's 50 death row immates at least through May.

The North Shore (L.I.) Chapter of Brandeis University's National Women's Committee will hold its annual champagne musicale tomorrow evening at the home of Mr. and Mrs. Norman Blankman of Sands Point, L.I. About 100 guests are expected to hear Patricia Brooks of the New York City Opera sing.
A booby-trapped sticker advertising a peace demonstration exploded in the hand of a 15-year-old Queens boy as he tore it from a utility pole yesterday morning.

A year-old Italian organization has decided to continue to use the words "Anti-Defamation League" in its name, despite protests from the established Anti-Defamation League of B'nai B'rith that this will confuse the public.
ATLANTA, April 13--Vice President Humphrey de scribed womanpower tonight as the nation's "most significant under-realized human resource," and recommended several steps to fulfill this potential.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 13--Mrs. Beata Hoffman Rank, former wife of the late Dr. Otto Rank, the noted psychologist, died here Tuesday. Her age was 71.

CHARLOTTESVILLE, Va., April 13 (AP)--The Club Universitario de Buenos Aires defeated the University of Virginia Rugby Club, 11-0, today in a game described as both the roughest and best ever played here.
BOSTON, April 13--Dissident stockholders seeking control of the Boston Maine Corporation gained ground today by blocking a quorum for the annual meeting.
George Whitmore Jr. will be tried a third time on charges of assault and attempted rape in Brooklyn, District Attorney Aaron E. Koota announced yesterday.

McKinsey Co., manage ment consultant, announced yesterday the appointment as a director of Neil E. Harlan, who was Assistant Secretary of the Air Force from 1962 to 1964. The new post represents one of top management rather than a seat on the board.

The Westinghouse Electric Corporation, the nation's second largest electrical manufacturer, had a 14 per cent decline in first-quarter earnings despite record sales, D.C. Burnham, president, reported yesterday.
BREWSTER, N.Y., April 13--The Russians landed here today, and when they left, the children of Green Chimneys were in tears.
RIDGEFIELD, Conn., April 13--Robert Fawcett, a magazine and book illustrator and a founder of the Famous Artists School of Westport, died here today at his home. He was 64 years old.
Three men escaped Wednesday night from the first narcotics center opened here under the new state addiction control law that went into effect April 1.
CHICAGO, April 13--The nation's Roman Catholic bishops authorized today an intensified educational campaign aimed at defeating widespread efforts to liberalize stag laws on abortion.

Saudi Arabia's Deputy Minister of Petroleum, Hisham Nazer, expressed doubt yesterday that Syria's demand for additional transit royalties for petroleum crossing her territory from fields in his country would lead to a shutdown of the pipeline.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., April 13 --Dr. and Mrs. Nathan S. Rakatansky have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss France Rakatansky, to David D. Sicher, son of Dr. and Mrs. William D. Sicher of New York and Lake Placid, N.Y.
Fifty-five members of Actors Equity, protesting the hiring of British performers for Broadway and Lincoln Center Repertory Theater productions, picketed the opening last night of Brecht's "Galileo."

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.
PEKING, April 13--Wall posters announced today that Premier Chou En-lai of Communist China had accused President Liu Shao-chi of "conducting an anti-party policy"
PARIS, April 13--France is making plans for a bigger nuclear striking force.
Several university newspaper editors said yesterday they would turn down The Campus Courier, the glossy college paper supplement that Reader's Digest plans to publish next fall.
Ideas to stimulate the growth of printed fabrics in men's wear were discussed yesterday by retailers, apparel manufacturers and textile producers in a seminar at the Warwick Hotel.

PUNTA DEL ESTE, Uruguay, April 13--Comments by highranking United States officials suggested today that a new criterion, and a stern one, has been adopted in Washington to judge how much help Latin America was to receive.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 13 (AP)--Five of the six defending champions scored victories tonight by pins in the first round of the free-style section of the National Amateur Athletic Union wrestling championships.

WASHINGTON, April 13-- Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended April 8 were both below the volume in the corresponding week of last year.

Federal Judge Anthony T. Augelli in Newark, N.J., yesterday named two trustees of the Central Railroad of New Jersey. The road recently entered reorganization proceedings under the Bankruptcy Act. Act.

The modernized Pier 60 on the Hudson River at 20th Street was officially reopened yesterday with cermonies at which Myor Lindsay joined industry and labor spokesmen in hailing the project as evidence that shipping is not abandoning the Hudson River area.
A city board of inquiry reported yesterday that "the acts and omissions" of a contractor caused the collapse of a building on West 54th Street on Jan. 26 in which five workmen were killed.

Columbia University's College of Physicians and Surgeons will train 300 physicians of the Harlem community in modern medical procedures, Hospitals Commissioner Joseph V. Terenzio told a City Council hearing yesterday.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 13 (AP)--American bombers are being guided to targets in North Vietnam by daily photographs received from United States weather satellites.

While behaving more reasonably is some areas of international relations, the Soviet Union remains bitterly hostile toward the development of practical efforts to improve United Nations machinery for peacekeeping.
A powerful member of the Senate Finance Committee denounced yesterday a key element affecting chemical duties in the United States negotiation strategy in the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting talks.
A spokesman for 50 milk companies said yesterday that the industry was "tired, oppressed, frustrated, harassed and whipsawed by endless investigations."

IT is open to doubt whether even George Balanchine has ever created a work in which the inspiration was so sustained, the invention so imaginative or the concept so magnificent as in the threeact ballet that had its world premiere at the New York State Theater last night. There is, indeed, one thing, and one very obvious thing, missing.

BRUNSSUM, Holland--Pollyannas don't help NATO by saying things are better every time the alliance gets kicked in the teeth. After General de Gaulle ordered allied troops and headquarters evicted, a distinguished American argued this was beneficial because it provoked needed reforms. General Lemnitzer, NATO's Su preme Commander, commented: "One more benefit of this sort and we'll be out of business."

ATLANTA, April 13--The outspoken stand of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. on the war in Vietnam has dampened his prospects for becoming the Negro leader who might be able to get the nation "moving again" on civil rights.
LONDON, April 13--Douglas Houghton, who was a member of Prime Minister Harold Wilson's Government until three months ago, was elected chairman of the Labor party contingent in Parliament today.

Four armed men walked up to a United States Lines pier on the Hudson River before dawn yesterday, corralled and bound the four security guards and carried away two wooden boxes containing $620,000 in American Express travelers' checks.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 13--The Rhodesian Government issued statistics today that indicated the rebel colony had not been hit very hard by voluntary economic sanctions in 1966.
WASHINGTON, April 13-- The Senate voted today to repeal the campaign financing law that Congress enacted last year with President Johnson's backing.

NEPTUNE, N.J., April 13-- Jake Zastko, pro, and Charles Highley of Spring Lake combined for a better-ball 35, 32--67 today to win the season's first New Jersey Professional Golfers Association pro-amateur tournament at the Jumping Brook Country Club.
WASHINGTON, April 13-- Several members of the Supreme Court bluntly criticized today the New York law that permits, with court approval, electronic eavesdropping by policemen.
PARIS, April 13--France mobilized 200 naval and civilian craft today to dump sawdust, sand, plastic foam and other materials on patches of crude oil drifting off the coast of Brittany.
A combined gift of $5-million to Fairleigh Dickinson University from the son and the widow of one of the instititution's founders was announced here last night.
PITTSBURGH, April 13-- Lorenz Iversen, who retired in 1963 as president of the Mesta Machine Company in nearby West Homestead, died yesterday. He was 90 years old.

The Overseas Press Club of America announced last night the winners of its 1967 awards for distinguished achievement in foreign journalism.
Max Bollt, a lawyer with an office at 50 Broadway and a former Democratic Alderman from Manhattan, died yesterday at his home at 440 West End Avenue after a brief illness. He was 72 years old.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 13 (AP) --Cornell University came under new criticism today over the dormitory fire that killed nine persons.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 13--President Cevdet Sunay of Turkey promised the African and Asian nations today that his country would give full support to the fight against South Africa on the question of apartheid and of rule over South-West Africa.
LONDON, April 13--Britain today postponed a new round of talks with Spain over Gibraltar because of Spain's move to close the airspace around the tiny British colony.

During the winter, Michael Burke, the new president of the New York Yankees, authorized an expense of $1,350,000 to refurbish Yankee Stadium. A crowd of 20,000 is expected for the home opener today.

Two and a half pounds of frozen french-fried potatoes for every man, woman and child in this country may not sound like a lot. But the total of 503,646,000 pounds in cold storage on April 1 is a record amount. A month ago the Government reported holdings at 479,316,000 pounds, the previous record.

The students, Marshall Bloom of Denver and David Adelstein of South Africa, were suspended on, March 13 after leading an attempt to hold a protest meeting that had been banned by school officials.

TOKYO, April 14--Japanese interest in the kibbutzin, the Israeli collective farm communities, is growing fast. In two years, about 80 Japanese students have gone to Israel in groups at their own expense to study the kibbutz idea first hand; this year more than 100 will go.

JACKSBORO, Tenn., April 14 --A 24-year-old science teacher accused of teaching evolution in violation of a state law was dismissed today from his $4,700a-year job at the high school in this Cumberland Mountain community.

John B. Naughton has been named assistant general manager of the Ford division of the Ford Motor Company, it was announced yesterday. He had been vice president of marketing and planning of the Ford Motor Company of Canada.

WILMINGTON, N.C., April 14 (UPI)--Hot-putting Larry Mowry, giving the professional golf tour a last try, tied the Azalea open's 36-hole record today with a 132 and held a fivestroke second-round lead. His total is 12 under par.

LAS VEGAS, April 14-- Scores soared with the wind today as Frank Beard increased his lead by a stroke with a 36hole aggregate of 133 in the Tournament of Champions. The Louisville, Ky., professional shot a 68 in the second round at the Stardust Golf Club Course. Jack Nicklaus, Dan Sikes and Doug Sanders were tied for second with 136's.

A.J. MUSTE'S life ended in his 82d year, shortly after an arduous journey to Vietnam in the interest of peace. He was jeered at his press conference in Saigon, had an interview with Ho Chi Minh in Hanoi and carried a message of invitation from Ho to President Johnson. It was a fitting climax to a creative career of a pacifist who was also a revolutionary Christian. It may have cost him his life.

EPIMEDIUMS, otherwise known as barrenwort and bishop's hats, are small spring-blooming perennials of the barberry family. I would include epimediums in a list of 10 perennials I would not be without--chiefly because they are delicately beautiful in foliage as well as bloom.
