NEW DELHI, April 16 (UPI)--Stalin's daughter, Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva has written a book about her father, a leading Indian newspaper reported today. Mrs. Alliluyeva defected six weeks ago in India and is now in Switzerland.
LONDON, April 16--Procter Gamble and Unilever are moving into the final stage of a battle with the Labor Government over detergent prices, fair profits and advertising.
Angami Zapu Phizo, president of the National Council of Nagaland, has arrived in the United States to seek American support for the independence of his state from India.
THERE is no such thing as an infallible restaurant. There are too many variables involved, too many human factors.

MEXICO CITY, April 16-- President Gustavo Diaz Ordaz warned last night that Latin America's projected economic integration must primarily benefit Latin companies rather than those of the United States.

The Boston Symphony Orchestra closed its local season Saturday night at Carnegie Hall with Its fourth concert of music from "The Viennese School." This time the composers were opposite extremes with two works by Mozart and one by Bruckner.

MEXICO CITY, April 16 (Reuters)--Rafael Osuna and Luis Garcia beat Brian Fairlie and Kevin Woolcott of New Zealand, 11-9, 4-6, 6-4, 6-4, in a three-hour doubles match today to give Mexico a 2-1 lead in their Davis Cup American Zone tennis series.

STONEWALL, Tex., April 16 (AP)--President Johnson drove his family to a little country church here today as he relaxed and worked over the weekend. Mr. Johnson and his wife, their daughter Luci and son-inlaw, Patrick J. Nugent, attended the St. Francis Xavier Catholic Church, which is about two miles from the President's ranch house.

PHILADELPHIA, April 16-- A monstrous home run by Richie Allen sent the New York Mets to their third straight defeat at the hands of the Philadelphia Phillies today--and to their, 16th straight in six years at the hands of Larry Jackson.
ONION soup and a meat loaf stuffed with mush rooms can provide the core of a meal that is both hearty and tasty. Or either one could provide the high point of a lighter meal.
A CONSERVATIVELY dressed woman in her mid-50's was consulting the Max Factor man at Gimbels one afternoon recently.
Miss Katherine S.V. Bassett, a registered nurse with the Home Life Insurance Company, died Saturday in her home at 40-50 Denman Street, Elmhurst, Queens.

CLIFTON, N.J., April 16-- Four young children were killed early today in a fire that destroyed a frame tenement house that was undergoing renovations to conform with fire safety regulations. The blaze left 46 tenants homeless.

TOKYO, April 16--"I had planned to vote for Dr. Matsushita, but when the price of bottled milk was raised by 2 yen on the eve of the election, I decided to vote for Dr. Minobe," a Tokyo housewife told a television street interviewer today.

BLOOMINGTON, Minn., April 16 (AP)--Sam McDowell pitched his way out of trouble in the eighth inning today with the tying run on second base as the Cleveland Indians scored a 4-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins.
WASHINGTON, April 16-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the "Communist apparatus" was working hard in support of antiwar demonstrations in the United States and elsewhere.
CROWDING the air inside a little white-walled shop on Christopher Street are dozens of shimmering butterflies-- all made of leaded glass.
Leaders of Cuban exile groups in the United States said yesterday that they would wage a sabotage campaign against the regime of Premier Fidel Castro and "any other nation which supports Castro."
ATLANTA, April 16 (AP)-- Fred J. Turner, former president and board chairman of the Southern Bell Telephone Telegraph Company, died today. He was 74 years old.
Bargains in liquor still obtainable abroad by American tourists despite tightened customs exemptions may soon be sharply curtailed for residents of New York State.
ATLANTA, April 16 (UPI)-- Four escaped Negro convicts waited 30 minutes in a reception line to surrender to Gov. Lester G. Maddox today and to allege mistreatment at their rural prison work camp.
OAKLAND, Calif., April 16 (AP)--Trailing, 3-0, with 13 minutes remaining, the Pittsburgh Phantoms rallied for a 3-3 tie with the California Clippers today.

Young King Constantine's political maneuvering has produced in Greece the very situation he wanted most to avoid: an election in circumstances likely to accelerate a dangerous polarization of political forces that will favor those lukewarm toward the monarchy in general and hostile to him personally.

Temperatures went up in international financial circles when the Chase Manhattan Bank and the Bank of America suggested that the United States re-examine its traditional policy of buying and selling gold to friendly governments at the official price of $35 an ounce. But they went down again after the Treasury denied it was considering such a shift.

NORTH WILKESBORO, N.C., April 16 (AP)--Darel Dieringer, who set a qualifying record for the race, led all the way today in winning the seventh annual Gwyn Staley 400 stock car race at the North Wilkesboro Speedway.
Dead and dying ducks with oil-soaked wings washed up on the New Jersey shore last week as a result of oil slicks off the coast.

A DEFENDER who holds a strong hand is often in danger of being end-played. Sometimes he can take precautions against that danger, and it may even be necessary to do so on the opening lead, when end-plays seem far away.

What contemporary American opera needs is exposure (no double meanings intended). One place it receives it is the West Side Young Women's Christian Asociation, whose Clark Center Workshop, under the direction of Naomi Ornest, tries to stage new works as often as possible.
WELLFLEET, Mass., April 16--A huge oil slick hit Cape Cod today, killing hundreds of ducks and making beaches useless for recreation far 35 miles along the Atlantic Ocean side of the Cape.

Scientists observing the largely unexplored atmosphere of the tropics have discovered that the region is a peculiar "doughnut factory." generating ring-like clouds that may play an important role in determining worldwide weather patterns.
HANOI, North Vietnam, April 16 (Agence France Presse)-- North Vietnam is systematically gathering up mines dropped by United States aircraft in its estuaries and harbors.
ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 16--The bulbous bow, a common fixture in ship experiments to increase speed, has been developed into an efficient hull form by two University of Michigan scientists.

LINCOLN, Neb., April 16, (AP)--Larry Kristoff and Pat Kelly won individual National Amateur Athletic Union freestyle wrestling titles last night to lead Chicago's Mayor Daley Club, the defender, to the team championship.
NEW HAVEN, April 16-- The Ivy League colleges are moving swiftly away from geographical distribution as a major standard in admitting students.
Theodore W. Kneel, the chief mediator in the New York newspaper contract negotiations, said yesterday that the printers' union and The Daily News must reach an agreement quickly.
This week's $1-billion of new fixed-income securities seems sure to dispel the cloud of indecision that has overhung the bond markets ever since the Federal Reserve discount rate was lowered.
THE National Professional Soccer League made its bid yesterday for a chunk of the American sports dollar. Its first dividends exceeded expectations.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 16 --Despite a phenomenal fourthround 64 by Arnold Palmer, Frank Beard won the $100,000 Tournament of Champions today with a birdie at the final hole.
Mayor Lindsay's $5.18-billion executive expense budget, largest in the city's history, solves the immediate crisis. But New York City is still faced with a difficult fiscal future.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 14--Safer windshields on late model cars are reducing the danger of major facial injuries in accidents, according to Dr. Donald F. Huelke, associate professor at the University of Michigan's Medical School here.

CHICAGO, April 16 (AP)-- Darold Knowles walked Jerry Adair with the bases loaded in the 16th inning, forcing across the run that gave the Chicago White Sox a 4-3 victory today in the second game of a doubleheader with the Washington Senators. The White Sox won the first game, 7-3.
GRAND MASTER PAL BENKO of New York, scoring 10 points out of a possible 15, tied for third place with the Soviet master Savon in the recent Sarajevo, Yugoslavia, International Tournament.
CLEVELAND, Monday, April 17 (AP)--Violence broke out last night in Cleveland's Hough area, the scene of rioting last summer. By early today, at least four men were arrested, one person was injured.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 16--The texts of the long-secret recommendations submitted to Pope Paul VI by the Papal Commission on Birth Control have been made public here. They confirm that the majority favored approval of "decent and human means" of contraception.
Bicyclists may soon have Central Park's East and West Drives all to themselves on Saturdays as well as Sundays.
WASHINGTON, April 16-- The conservationist campaign to expand the wilderness system is running into opposition from groups fearful that future sources of water supply will be cut off.

A far-reaching overhaul of the city school system to overcome an alleged "failing" in the teaching of Puerto Rican pupils was recommended yesterday by the city-sponsored Puerto Rican community conference.

ST. PETERSBURG Fla., April 16 (AP)--Fourth-seeded Allen Fox of Los Angeles defeated the defending champion, Nicola Pilic of Yugoslavia, 6-3, 3-6, 6-4, 4-6 6-3, today in the final of the Masters tennis tournament.

The Washington National Symphony ended its New York season yesterday at Philharmonic Hall with a double-barreled farewell. The afternoon subscription concert, conducted by Howard Mitchell, offered a symphonic premiere, solo and double concertos and a fervent orchestral plea for peace.

CINCINNATI, April 16 (AP) --Mel Queen's six-hit pitching, supported by a two-run homer by Vada Pinson and a two-run double by Pete Rose, enabled the Cincinnati Reds to beat the Francisco Giants, 6-0, and sweep a double-header today.
WASHINGTON, April 16 (UPI)--The Federal income tax deadline falls at midnight tomorrow.
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 16--President Johnson decided tonight to seek an injunction to halt a strike by 4,900 workers at a helicopter engine plant in Stratford, Conn.

ST. LOUIS, April 16 (AP)-- Two home runs by Lou Brock, his third and fourth in two days, and a tie-breaking blast by Orlando Cepeda paced the undefeated St. Louis Cardinals to an 11-8 victory over the Houston Astros today.

Last December, when Senator Robert F. Kennedy announced the formation of a corporation to channel private and public funds into Bedford-Stuyvesant, he stressed that the people of that largely Negro ghetto in central Brooklyn would have a chance to do things for themselves.
Kenneth Burke, the literary critic, received a medal and $1,000 from Brandeis University yesterday for "notable creative achievement."
PITTSBURGH, April 16-- Steel shipments in March rose by about one million tons.

JIDDA, Saudi Arabia-- King Faisal of Saudi Arabia and the Yemeni royalists, with whom he is allied, are preparing for a showdown in Yemen with President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic. The desultory fighting and bombing characteristic of the 20-month-old "cease-fire" in Yemen threatens to turn into full-scale guerrilla warfare later this year.
BERLIN, April 16--Leonid I. Brezhnev, General Secretary of the Soviet Communist party, arrived in East Berlin tonight to attend the Seventh Congress of the East German Communist party.
The city's Buildings Commissioner was accused yesterday of frightening parents with his method of announcing violations found in the schools.

HANOI, North Vietnam, April 16 (Agence FrancePresse)--A recording purportedly by a captured American pilot, Lieut. Comdr. Richard Allen Stratton, denies that he has been ill-treated or forced to answer questions under duress.

WILMINGTON, N.C., April 16 (UPI)--Randy Glover of Florence, S.C., sank a 20-foot birdie putt on the second hole of a sudden-death playoff with Joe Campbell today and won the $35,000 Azalea open golf tournament. Glover won $5,000 and Campbell got $3,300.

SANA, Yemen--A few months after the republicans overthrew the royal government on Sept. 26, 1962, the "republic" was still a shadow thrown by Egyptian "advisers." The republican army hardly existed and the Egyptians were somewhat in shock from the severe resistance of the Saudi Arabianbacked royalists following the coup.
Brick Presbyterian, one of the city's oldest and best-known Protestant churches, marked the midpoint yesterday in a month-long celebration of its 200th anniversary.
Morris Harvey College of Charleston, W.Va., defeated Louisiana State University of New Orleans yesterday on the National Broadcasting Company's "College Bowl" program. The score was 310 to 150.

BONN--In the last quarter of 1966 beer consumption in the Ruhr, West Germany's industrial heartland, declined 14 per cent. When Ruhr workers cut their beer consumption, it can mean only one thing:- Hard times have come again.
Eastern Air Lines has announced plans to establish its own travel club to provide packaged vacations at discount rates.
SOCCER was nationally introduced on network tele vision yesterday afternoon as the Baltimore Bays defeated the Atlanta chiefs 1 to 0.
FONTANA, Calif., April 16 (AP)--A helicopter team rescued today a man and his wife who had survived a plane crash on a mountain peak, night-long freezing temperatures and high winds.

MANAGUA, Nicaragua, April 16 (UPI)--Former President Luis A. Somoza was buried with full military honors today in the family crypt, next to his father, founder of the Somoza dynasty, which has ruled Nicaragua for most of the last 30 years.

Leaders of large corporations who use New York as the center of their international operations are joining in a loose partnership with the city's government, bridging the no man's land of indifference that once separated the men of Wall Street from the men of City Hall.

KANSAS CITY, Apri1 16 (AP) --Two relief pitchers, Tony Pierce and Bob Duliba, checked a seventh-inning Detroit rally today to give Kansas City an 11-7 victory over the Tigers in the second game of a doubleheader after the Athletics had lost the first, 6-3.

The odds against being gored to death by a moose during a total eclipse may seem formidable. Yet many insurance buyers pay substantial sums each year for double indemnity riders on policies that often are only slightly less of a long-shot gamble.
The Metropolitan Opera ended its 82d season, its longest ever, Saturday night with Verdi's "La Traviata," the opera that will open its 83d season on Sept. 18.

Lincoln Center events: Wheeler Becket Orchestra young people's concert, Philharmonic Hall, 2 P.M.; National Association for American Composers and Conductors program, Library of the Performing Arts, 7 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 7:30 P.M.

JACKSON, Miss., April 11-- On a shabby business street here, a penniless Negro in trouble with the law can walk into a sparsely furnished office at the sidewalk level, shake hands with an Ivy League lawyer and, if he has a case at all, get help without fee.

"A WARM BODY," which has been promising to visit us for some weeks past and then opened so suddenly at the Cort on Saturday evening that I'm not certain all of the actors quite made it, is a peculiar experience. It's a drop-in play. You feel that you've dropped in unexpectedly on the performers, or they've dropped in on you, but you're not sure which. This creates a social problem: Who should leave first?
MOSCOW, April 16--Soviet steel production for the first quarter makes it clear that total output in this country will surpass 100 million tons in 1967.

A "skindiver" was reported moving around the hull of the aircraft carrier Wasp here early yesterday but turned out to be nothing more than floating debris and bubbles from an outlet below the ship's waterline, according to a Navy spokesman.
The Alfred P. Sloan Foundation announced yesterday that it had made record grants and expenditures of $21.3-million last year.

The twice-postponed announcement of a new Federal maritime policy is now expected to be made no later than May 1 when Alan S. Boyd, the new Secretary of Transportation, is scheduled to appear before the Senate Merchant Marine subcommittee.

ITHACA, N.Y., April 16-- The possibility of a liaison between Broadway's commercial Producers and the National Council on the Arts was raised here this weekend by Roger L. Stevens. chairman of the national agency.
HAVANA, April 16 (AP) --Maj. Ernesto Che Guevara, the Cuban leader who dropped out of sight two years ago, was quoted today as appealing for world rebel groups to create "many Vietnams."

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 17 (UPI)--America's third Surveyor robot soared into space early today to attempt a gentle landing on the moon, photograph its landscape and dig into its surface with man's first lunar shovel.
Johnny Carson said yesterday that there was a possibility he would return to the "Tonight" show this week.

In a letter printed today, Secretary of Agriculture Orville L. Freeman eloquently describes the plight of the nation's dairymen. There is no doubt that many milk producers are lagging behind other farmers as well as urban workers even though milk price supports were raised substantially last year.
GENEVA, April 18--The burning of a large portrait of President Johnson near the United States Embassy in Bern capped today a weekend of antiUnited States demonstrations over the war in Vietnam.

HOUSTON, Tex., April 16 (AP)--Comdr. M. Scott Carpenter of the Navy, the second American to orbit the earth, his abandoned all hope of ever flying in space again after surgery failed to mend a once-broken arm.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 16 --Bonwit Teller will open a 43,000-square-foot branch in the Vernon Hills Shopping Center on Tuesday.

WILLIAMSBURG, Va., April 16--Gov. George Romney's first openly political venture into the South was judged a solid success today by Virginia Republican leaders, who are not conspicuous among his Presidential supporters.
TEL AVIV, April 16--A trade pact and an agreement for economic and scientific cooperation between Rumania and Israel were welcomed here today as marking a new era in relations.

MILLBROOK, N.Y., April 16--Valhalla, Kristine Pfister's smart-stepping 6-year-old bay gelding, squeezed through to the green working hunter championship by winning the last class at the Bennett College spring horse show today. The event was held in conjunction with the opening of Bennett's new $232,000 riding center.

A group of 21 private investors in the Eastman Kodak Company have withheld from the management their proxies on 5,060 shares of stock to challenge the company's repudiation of an agreement to train Negroes for jobs.
The American Civil Liberties Union expressed disapproval yesterday of student demonstrators who interfere with the academic freedom of others.

ROME, April 16--The Vatican remained officially silent today on a report that a Catholic weekly newspaper in the United States had published the majority and minority views of the commission appointed by pope Paul VI to study family problems, including birth control.

WHEELING, W.Va.--Copies of two bulky confidential reports on the Wheeling Steel Corporation were shipped out of here the other days to the banks and insurance companies that had advanced more than $145million to the troubled company.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 16-- More than 5,000 independence advocates marched through the streets of historic Old San Juan today as part of a celebration marking the 101st anniversary of the birth of Jose de Diego, a fiery orator who fought for the island's independence and Hispanic heritage until his death in 1918.

WASHINGTON, April 16-- After Senator Mark O. Hatfield delivered a particularly dovish speech on Vietnam last month, Secretary of State Dean Rusk telephoned to say he was sending three of his top experts up to Capitol Hill to set the Senator straight on a few points.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 17--A military spokesman announced yesterday that for the second straight day American planes had mistakenly bombed an allied target. The new attack, at 5:30 A.M. killed 14 civilians and wounded 25, all residents of a village for Vietcong defectors and their families near Trucgiang, southwest of Saigon.

GIOLINH, South Vietnam, April 16--The "barrier" being built just south of the demilitarized zone to stop infiltration from North Vietnam is a bulldozed strip 200 yards wide and 6 miles long that looks like a fire break.

J. Montgomery Curtis, a newspaperman who has served 20 years with the American Press Institute, will join Knight Newspapers, Inc., on July 1 in the newly created position of vice president-development.

Rear Adm. Edward Joseph O'Donnell, superintendent of the United States Naval Postgraduate School, Monterey, Calif., will take over as president of the State University Maritime College at Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, on Sept. 1, it has been announced.

SAN JOSE, Costa Rica, April 16 (Reuters)--A speech critical of the United States made by President Otto Arosemena Gomez of Ecuador at the hemisphere summit conference last week was broadcast at threehour intervals today over the Ecuadorian radio.

ANN ARBOR, Mich., April 15--One-third of the United States population, that portion with less than a high school education and an annual income of less than $7,500, knows little about world affairs and is insulated from information about them, according to data from a series of surveys since 1957.
NEW DELHI, April 16--"It's a matter of blood," a high Indian official said today in commenting on the United States' decision to sell Pakistan spare parts for weapons.
Big league soccer made its American debut yesterday. If it's to be a financial success "promotion" will have to be the name of the game.
Dr. Jane C. Wright, a cancer researcher and chemotherapist, has appointed associate dean of New York Medical College, Dr. David Denker, president-elect of the college, announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Inter-American Development Bank announced today the sale of $30-million of oneyear and two-year United States dollar bonds to central banks of 14 Latin American countries.
LONDON, April 17--The Labor Government announced today that it would extend for one year, with modifications, its powers to block wage and price increases.
PHILADELPHIA, April 17-- Cecil B. Moore, head of the Philadelphia branch of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People belatedly paid a $300 fine today for contempt of court.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 17-- Harry F. Guggenheim, president and editor in chief of Newsday, announced today that he would give Falaise, his 90-acre estate in Sands Point, to Nassau County for use as a recreataonal and cultural center.
WELLFLEET, Mass., April 17--Federal shore rangers and volunteers collected dead and dying waterfowl on Cape Cod beaches today amid a gummy residue of oil.
PARIS, April 17--The organizers of Bertrand Russell's "War Crimes Tribunal" have found a place in a Paris suburb to meet from April 29 through May 9, they announced today.
LONDON, April 17 (AP) Prime Minister Wilson will visit the United States for talks with President Johnson June 2, after he attends Expo '67 in Montreal, his office announced today.
"Why did you split your stock last year?" Patricia O'Brien asked yesterday of Malcolm Baldrige, the president of the Scovill Manufacturing Company.
Miss Jane Rust Munson and Lieut. John Holderness, U.S.M.C., plan to marry April 29.

India's Secretary of Health and Family Planning, Govind Narain, has arrived in the United States to begin a "dialogue of understanding" that he hopes will involve more Americans in his country's birth control problem.
A reviewer of a new book of sermons of the Rev. Adam Clayton Powell says that he has found "fascinating parallels" between this volume and other published materials.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- Personal income rose more in March than in February while housing starts edged up slightly, the Commerce Department reported today.
LONDON, April 17--There is severe and widespread discrimination in Britain against people with dark skins.

WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)--The president of the Norfolk Western Railway testified today that he was not certain whether the N. W.Chespeake Ohio-Baltimore Ohio Railroad merger would be completed if plans to absorb five smaller lines were not approved.

An investment counseling concern and a law firm have signed leases for a total of 156,000 square feet of floor space in the 44-story tower being built by Samuel Rudin on the site of the old Sheraton-East Hotel at 345 Park Avenue.
Overcome with emotion in his dressing room, Nino Benvenuti said last night he knew he could win "after the sixth round."
Increased buying pushed most issues ahead on the American Stock Exchange yesterday in heavy trading.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- The American Civil Lberties Union challenged today the constitutionality of parts of the Uniform Code of Military Justice, the basis of military law for the United Sates armed forces.

SPRINGFIELD, Ill., April 17 (UPI)--Fourteen trotters and pacers valued at $175,000 periahed today in a predawn fire at the State Fairgrounds. Nine other hazness horses in the barn were removed to safely.
The city moved a step closer yesterday to wrapping up its plan for constructing a new Police Headquarters building and parking garage in the Manhattan civic center.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 17 --Three persons were injured, none seriously, as open housing demonstrations were resumed in Louisville tonight.

"The Trial of Lee Harvey Oswald," a first play by Amram Dueovny and Leon Friedman that deals with the trial that might have taken place had Oswald not been murdered, will open on Broadway Sept. 25th at one of the Shubert theaters.

GENEVA, April 17--William M. Roth, President Johnson's Special Representative for Trade Negotiations, made a flying visit to Brussels today to express Washington's grave concern over the outlook of the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting talks to officials of the European Common Market.
BONN, April 17--A Bremen court today ruled invalid an order by Fritz Thielen, chairman of the National Democratic party, expelling Otto Hess, national executive member, from the party.
The New York Generals meet the California Clippers in Los Angeles tonight in the second National Professional Soccer League match.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- Commerce Department officials defended today a provision in the Administration's proposed revision of the patent law that would recognize the first person to file an application for an invention as the inventor.

IF it is possible to imagine a collegiate baseball game as a grudge match, Seton Hall and St. John's are close to working up such a contest. At least for Seton Hall, the game on April 26 involves a quest for revenge.

SATTIHIP, Thailand, April 10--This once-sleepy fishing town on the Gulf of Siam, with its gleaming white beaches and green offshore islets, is rapidly being transformed into one of the biggest strategic bases in southeast Asia.

THE reissues of these two works by S.Y. Agnon have been occasioned by his winning of the Nobel prize for literature last year.
