FEATHERWEIGHT girls with headlamp eyes and concave chests might be some people's idea of fashion paragons, but there is at least one agency that supplies models who bear little resemblance to Twiggy or Jean Shrimpton.
ACCRA, Ghana, April 17-- A poorly executed coup d'etat by army officers was crushed almost as soon as it began today.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- There were growing signs today that the Johnson Administration might be hard pressed to prevent Congress from approv ing income tax credits for col lege expenses.
CHICAGO, April 17--The loss of bone substance mostly mineral, that accompanies aging constitutes an important problem in public health, a scientist said here today.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)--The Food and Drug Administration is drafting new regulations to deal with advertising of drugs.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 17--Mihajlo Mihajlov, a persistent critic of the monopoly or power that he says is exercised by the Yugoslav League of Communists, was brought out of the Belgrade jail today to begin a new trial.

MONTREAL, April 17 (AP)--Four bandits held up two Brink's guards while they were loading money from a large Montreal department store onto a truck today. The men escaped with $400,000, about a third in cash and the rest in nonnegotiable checks, according to a store spokesman.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- Nearly every day, a stocky man with graying hair scampers nimbly around the paddle ball court in the House gymnasium. On his left foot he wears a special shoe with a rocker sole because of a missing ankle bone.
Stock prices continued to boil upward yesterday, although the advance lost a good deal of its steam in an afternoon retreat.
Negotiators for the pressmen and publishers met for two and a half hours yesterday, but did not announce any details of their talks in the current newspaper dispute.

STOCKHOLM, April 17-- Sweden will not send a new Ambassador to South Vietnam, Torsten Nilsson, Minister of Foreign Affairs, announced today. He said that the Saigon regime did not represent the majority of the people.
The Metropolitan Opera's 79th annual tour began yesterday morning when two special trains carrying 330 company members, baggage and scenery left Grand Central Terminal for Boston.

The American Electric Power Company reported yesterday record earnings of $89,421,000 for the 12 months ended March 31. This also reflected a rise in profits for the quarter and the month ended March 31.

SAVANNAH, Ga., April 17 (UPI)--One Negro was named principal of virtually all-white Chatham Junior High School today and another was named assistant principal of predominantly white Savannah High School, the largest in the state. It was the first faculty integration in the community.
There have been a number of unsolved murders in Brooklyn and Manhattan in recent weeks in which white people were slain by persons identified by witnesses as Negroes.
TRENTON, April 17 (AP)-- Legislation to increase purses at New Jersey's four race tracks cleared the Senate today and was sent immediately to the Assembly.
Charles L. Crawford was named the "Queens College basketball coach yesterday, replacing Dr. Robert H. Salmons, who had held the post since 1947.

NEW ROCHELLE, N.Y., April 17--James Wilson Paul, who did architectural work on the United Nations headquarters, Shea Stadium and the United States Military Academy, died today at New Rochelle Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at 1374 Manor Circle in nearby Pelham Manor.

TEHERAN, Iran, April 18 (AP)--At least 22 people are believed to have been killed when an Iranian Air Force C-130 transport plane exploded in midair last night when it was struck by lightning, air force officials said today.
Interest rates rose sharply throughout the credit markets yesterday as investment bankers began to handle this week's huge supply of new fixedincome securities.

ROME, April 17--Vatican Sources said today that publication in the United States of the final report by the Papal Commission on Birth Control appeared to be a move to force Pope Paul VI into "making some sort of response."
England, April 17 (UPI)--Ring-rusty, free bleeding Henry Cooper, the British heavyweight champion, won an unimpressive 10-round Recision tonight over Boston Jacobs of New York.
IF one asked what New York State has done in the way of interesting experimental projects with large mammals, the reply would be as short as the hair on a trout.
NEW HAVEN, April 17 (AP)--Strikers at a Connecticut plant producing helicopter engines vital to the Vietnam War were ordered back to work today by a Federal judge.

Richard D. Sauer, executive vice president of the Standard Oil Company (Ohio), charged yesterday that the Interior Department had provided "special-treatment handouts" to some oil companies under the guise of helping the economies of Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands.
HACKENSACK, N.J., April 17--A meat dealer charged with conspiring to rig bids on meat purchases for Bergen County institutions pleaded guilty today shortly after going on trial.
The incoming and outgoing presidents of the New York Shipping Association called yesterday for full cooperation of the port's longshore industry to meet management-labor prob
BRIDGEPORT, Conn., April 17 (AP)--Earle J. Van Doren, an assistant to the dean at the Columbia University Graduate School of Journalism, died of cancer today at his home. He was 37 years old.
CHILLED Out of their game with Washington yesterday even before the rain began, the New York Yankees rescheduled the one-game series for today at 2 P.M. at Yankee Stadium. The respite
HATTIESBURG, Miss., April 17 (AP)--Twelve white men pleaded not guilty today to charges of conspiracy to murder a Negro civil rights leader.

PEORIA, Ill., April 17 (AP) --An armed police convoy returned Richard Speck today to Chicago, where he will remain for the duration of the legal proceedings planned to save him from the electric chair.

Edwin Newman, critic at large for the National Broadcasting Company, yesterday took to task the producers of "Illya Darling" for using an out-of-context quotation from his review in advertising the musical.

The United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit stayed yesterday the prison sentence of David J. Miller, who began serving a two-and-ahalf-year sentence last April 6 for refusing to replace a draft card he had burned.
LONDON, April 17--Britain's book critics have come down hard on William Manchester's "The Death of a President," which was published here today by Michael Joseph.

SANTA FE, N.M., April 17 --David F. Cargo, New Mexico's personable young Governor' was talking politics last night over a magnificent spread of Mexican food (they call it "Spanish" food here) when someone mentioned the name of his most likely Democratic opponent next year.
The Port of New York Authority reported yesterday gains during 1966 in the use of all its major facilities: airports bus terminals, bridges and tunnels, rail lines and marine terminals.
Frank L. Zerega, a macaron' manufacturer for 83 years, died Sunday in his home, 2 Montaguc Terrace, Brooklyn. His age was" 99.

HARRISON, N.Y., April 17-- The Pederson Golf Company of Wilton, Conn., will sponsor the Metropolitan Open this year, the Metropolitan Golf Association announced today at its fifth annual educational forum and luncheon at the Westchester Country Club.
Any merger between the Western and American Hockey Leagues has been put off until May, the A.H.L. board of directors decided yesterday.

ARLINGTON, Va., April 17-- The military hats placed at the grave of President Kennedy in Arlington National Cemetery have been removed and will be put on display in the Kennedy Library at Cambridge, Mass.
CHICAGO, April 17 (AP) --Danny Escobedo, appellant in the famed Escobedo decision of the United States Supreme Court, was denied use of that decision today on a burglary charge.

Nino Benvenutl, the coolly handsome Italian intellectual, rose slowly and glassy-eyed from a fourth-round knockdown and went on to win the middleweight championship of the world last night with a bril liantly fought decision over Emile Griffith.
New evidence of a softening in zinc demand came yesterday from the American Smelting and Refining Company, which announced that it would temporarily cut its zinc-smelting capacity by 13 per cent.
The 40-story office building scheduled to replace the old Metropolitan Opera House by autumn, 1968, will have a facade of white stone and two plazas, one facing Broadway and the other Seventh Avenue.

WHITE PLAINS, April 17--In the last two years, 3,375 businesses established themselves in the green suburbs of Westchester, showering wealth and other benefits upon some communities, but forcing higher taxes and unwelcome changes in settled patterns of life upon others.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Supreme Court took the following actions today:

TRENTON, April 17--The Senate Judiciary Committee unanimously approved the nomination of Dr. Carl L. Marburger for State Commissioner of Education today under the threat of a statewide patronage freeze by Gov. Richard J. Hughes.
STUART, Fla., April 17-- Richard Wilson Stevenson, who once played Witzel, the colonial cynic, in "White Cargo," died here today. He was 75 years old and lived at 10 East 16th Street, New York.

MIAMI BEACH, April 17 (AP)--Mike Collins of Hartford, Conn., piled up a nine-game total of 1,838 to tie for 10th place in classic all-events is today' s only significant change in the American Bowlig Congress tournament standings.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 17-- A 25-year-old Valley Stream man was charged with firstdegree manslaughter today in the death of a Queens woman who, he said, had fallen overboard from his motorboat last night.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Supreme Court refused today to delay the enforcement of a lower court ruling requiring the desegregation of all public schools in six Southern states next fall.
Leopold Stokowski, 85 years old today, does not expect anyone to be impressed. He isn't.

ELIZABETH, N.J., April 17 --Timothy J. Cronin, guidance counselor at Thomas A. Edison Vocational and Technical High School here, died yesterday at the Alexian Brothers Hospital. He was 58 years old and lived at 730 Jersey Avenue.

Muddy Waters, the blues singer and guitarist, appeared with his Blues Band at Carnegie Recital Hall last night, filtered through the kind of low fidelity amplification that might be found in some of the sidestreet joints that they have passed through.
A CITY official gave a lesson yesterday on how to be a Jewish mother at Passover.

PINEHURST, April 17, N.C. (AP)--Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit followed a double-bogey 6 on the llth with birdies on three of the next four holes and went on to win the medal today in the North and South Amateur golf tournament. She shot a 72.
Louis Edelman, a 42-yearold art dealer, was indicted by a Federal grand jury on charges of interstate shipment of 260 stolen oil paintings valued at more than $5,000.

NEW ORLEANS, April 17-- President Johnson's chief economic adviser said today that nothing had changed sufficiently in the economy to eliminate the need for the proposed 6 per cent surcharge on corporate and personal income taxes.

TOKYO, April 17 (AP) -- Communist China charged today that President Nikolai V. Podgorny of the Soviet Union and Pope Paul VI, during their recent meeting, plotted secretly "to help United States imperialism in its policy of aggression against Vietnam."

PEKING, April 17--Wall posters appearing in Peking today demanded that President Liu Shao-chi be condemned to death for plotting to overthrow Mao Tse-tung, the party chairman, and seize power in China by a military coup d'etat.
THE growing trend toward using posters as decoration in the home has spawned a gallery devoted entirely to art posters.

WASHINGTON, April 17--The Supreme Court upheld today the legal right of labor unions to block the automation of their members' jobs by enforcing contract provisions against the use of prefabricated materials.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 17-- (AP)--Battered, bruised and trailing 2-0 in the four-of-sevengame series, the San Francisco Warriors return to the friendly confines of the Cow Palace tomorrow night to resume their National Basketball Association final playoff action against the Philadelphia 76ers.

LOS ALTOS, Calif, April 17 --Dr. and Mrs. Guy Carlton Marshall have announced the engagement of Dr. Marshall's sister, Miss Francesca R. Marshall of Scarsdale, N.Y., to Robert F. Giegengack Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Giegengack of Bethany, Conn.

First-quarter earnings of the American Cyanamid Company fell 22 per cent from the yearearlier level although sales improved slightly, stockholders attending the annual meeting in Portland, Me., were told yesterday.
The Gotham Chapter of Brandeis University's National Women's Committee will give a dinner dance, "Night of Treasures," on Friday in the Terrace Room of the Plaza.
A Civil Court judge ruled yesterday that the City was liable for any damage done to vehicles towed away by the police for illegal parking.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)--The Federal Communications Commission announced today that it had begun a study of the rapidly growing community antenna television industry.

The chairman of the Interstate Commerce Commission warned the Western railroads yesterday that they must consider the entire railroad picture if they expected their dozen or more merger proposals and counterproposals to be taken seriously by the commission.
TOKYO, April 17--The United Nations Economic Commission for Asia and the Far East established a subsidiary agency on population control before adjourning today.
MOSCOW, April 17--A rare inside view of decision-making in the Kremlin during Stalin's rule has been presented to Soviet readers by a leading scientist who helped develop the Soviet atomic bomb.

The Radio Corporation of America had the highest firstquarter sales and earnings in its history, despite a general softening in the national economy Elmer W. Engstrom, chairman of the executive committee and Robert W. Sarnoff, president, reported yesterday.

NEW ORLEANS, April 17-- By the year 2000, at least half of the nation's, electric power supply will be generated from nuclear sources, the vice president and managing director of the Edison Electric Institute predicted here today.
New issues are getting hot again on Wall Street. Overthe-counter traders gobble sandwiches and coffee at their desks during lunchtime and occasionally take a bicarbonate of soda for desert.
Mayor Lindsay was sharply criticized by City Councilman Robert A. Low yesterday for having replaced William F.R. Ballard as chairman of the City Planning Commission with a campaign aide.

Dr. Joseph M. Glaser, president of the Dental Society of the State of New York in 194445, died yesterday morning at his home, 114 Nassau Boulevard in Garden City, L.I. He was 68 years old and practiced at 89-19 146th Street in Jamaica, Queens.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Treasury bill rate rose somewhat at today's auction after its recent steep decline, the Treasury disclosed tonight.

LONDON, April 17--Foreign Secretary George Brown said today that he had reached agreement on key issues with the United Nations Aden mission. There were signs that he had succeeded, in 13 hours of talk, in mollifying the threeman mission, which last week stormed out of Aden charging that British officials had been uncoopreative.
SAN JUAN, P.R., April 17 (UPI)--Carlos Ortiz, the lightweight champion, will defend his title against Sugar Ramos, the former featherweight champion, Ortiz's manager, Bill Daly, said tonight.
A leading maritime labor leader expressed serious doubts yesterday over the adequacy of Administration proposals for a new maritime policy.
The week of the tax gatherer is an appropriate time to consider the latest tax proliferation, albeit a volun tary one, the new state lottery.
MONTICELLO, N.Y., April 17 (AP)--The state police said today that they had identified the victim of a gangland-style slaying here as Robert Capparelli, an ex-convict of Astoria, Queens.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Senate ethics committee was considering today whether to recommend that the Senate "censure" or "condemn" Senator Thomas J. Dodd.

GENEVA, April 17--Dr. Nahum Goldmann, president of the World Jewish Congress, said today that visits to Czechoslovakia, Hungary, Yugoslavia and Rumania had assured him that the Jewish communities of those Socialist republics enjoyed "complete equality."

A man who has allegedly been smuggling $10,000 worth of untaxed cigarettes into the state every week for the last six months is being investigated by the Brooklyn District Attorney's office, according to sources in the office of Roy M. Goodman, the city's Director of Finance.

DETROIT, April 17--The American Motors Corporation announced today it would double production of its smaller cars, but the auto maker plans to offset this increase by reducing output of its larger cars.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Supreme Court let stand today a Connecticut court ruling that the "estate planning" activities of Norman F. Dacey, author of the book, "How to Avoid Probate," constituted the unauthorized practice of law.
The New York University Law School faculty voted yesterday to change its basic degree from a baccalaureate to a doctorate.
Once, Rudy Maffei was known as a pretty fair stickball player on "West 125th Street. Today, he is known as a pretty fair network program buyer at the Gardner Advertising Company.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17--The United States has sent 3,000 additional troops into the embattled northern provinces of South Vietnam, an American military spokesman said tonight.

PITTSBURGH. April 17-- Don Cardwell, who might nave defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates on opening day last week but for five Met errors, took the problem into his own hancks tonight. With help from Ron Taylor, Cardwell not only hurled New York to a 9-6 victory, but also smashed a majestic tworun homer high and far over the red-brick left-field wall at Forbes Field.

WHILE nearly everybody else is rejoicing over easing lending rates, William S. Renchard, chairman of the Chemical Bank New York Trust Company, is predicting rates will climb back to the historic levels of 1966 before long.

AMERICAN tourists in Europe frequently find themselves doing an instinctive double-take at the sight of boys at play with an oversize round ball. It may take a few moments to realize what jarred them because there is an uneasy feeling that something" is wrong. Suddenly they are aware of what it is.

THE heroic exploration of Antarctica by Capt. Robert Falcon Scott, who was to perish on the return trip to his expedition's base camp on McMurdo Sound, was the subject last night of a documentary that combined a simulated re-enactment of the struggle against the elements with actual newsreels and still photographs.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP) --The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether the Federal Trade Commission may issue cease-and-desist orders on the affirmative votes of only two of its five members.

Nathan Kclmenson, a former New York lawyer who specialized in real estate and corporation law, died, Sunday of a heart attack in Bal Harbour, Fla., where he had lived since his retirement 10 years ago. He was 82 years old.

In an otherwise dull market, the most bullish aspect of futures trading came yesterday in a report from the Association of Commodity Exchange Firms, Inc. It said commodity futures trading in the first quarter was still setting records. In the period January through March, a record 2,434,490 contracts were traded on the nation's commodity exchanges, 6 per cent more than the 2,296,729 in the 1966 period.

COLORADO SPRINGS, Colo., April 17 (UPI)--Lieut Gen. James H. Doolittle the pilot who led a bomber raid on Tokyo during World War II, was named winner today of the Air Force Academy's Thomas D.White National Defense Award for 1967.

NAPLES, Fla., April 17--The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Carl A. Coppolino was apparently taken by surprise to day when a biochemist testified that traces of the paralyzing drug succinylcholine were found near a needle puncture on the body of Mrs. Carmela Coppolino.
MUNICH, Germany, April 17 --The six members of the European Common Market have split four to two over the means for implementing international monetary reform.

Cologne, making her first appearance at Aqueduct, displayed a fondness for a wet racing surface as she moved to victory in the $27,800 Distaff Handicap yesterday. Under the skillful urging of Braulio Baeza, Cologne scored at a length over Lady Diplomat with Miss Moona third in the seven-furlong test for fillies and mares.
A Woman who had sought a $57,000 income tax refund was faced yesterday with a ruling by Federal Judge Richard H. Levet that she had $33,000 more in taxable income than was reported.

The engagement of Miss Marguerite Athena Polites, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Adam Polites of 150 East 69th Street and Athens, to John Jeffrey Avlon, son of Mr. and Mrs. John Avlon of 993 Fifth Avenue, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

MANILA, April 17--The Philippines, which has shunned diplomatic and trade relations with Communist countries since the island became independent in 1946, appears to be moving cautiously closer to informal exchanges with the Soviet Union. President Ferdinand E. Marcos gave the green light today to a trade mission to go to Moscow.

MIDDLETOWN, Conn., April 17--Paul North Rice, former chief of the reference department of the New York Public Library and president of the American Library Association in 1947-48, died yesterday. He was 79 years old and lived at 159 High Street.
Prices on the London stock market rose on a broad front yesterday with industrial shares generally making a strong showing.

PITTSBURGH, April 17-- The Amen Corner, an organization of community leaders, refused today to cancel its invitation to former Gov. George Wallace of Alabama to address its annual meeting here April 27.

BABYLON, L.I., April 17-- The first Conservative candidate to ran for Suffolk County Executive took to the hustings here this morning, holding a mass of tea bags and, possibly, the balance of power in the November election.
OTTAWA, April 17--Blending royal pomp and Canadian informality, Roland Michener took office today as this country's 20th Governor General, the personal representative of Queen Elizabeth II in Canada.
LINCOLN, Neb., April 17-- Nebraska's 16-year-old loyalty oath was held unconstitutional today.

MEXICO CITY, April 17 (AP)--With Marcelo Lara and Rafael Osuna winning the final singles matches, Mexico gained a 4-1 victory over New Zealand in the northern section of the American Zone Davis Cup tennis playoffs today.

WESTBURY L.I., April 17 --The 192d anniversary of Patti Revere's famous ride will be celebrated at Roosevelt Raceway tomorrow night. The harness racing track is holding a "Paul Revere Night," in which the patriot's midnight ride astride a pacer will be celebrated with a card devoted exclusively to pacing races.
The Philadelphia Inquirer has asserted that its top investigative reporter for many years, Harry J. Karafin, was a "shakedown artist" and a "remarkably adept liar."
The spot rate on the British pound eased in quiet trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here.
The New York Urban league proposed yesterday that Negroes be given priority rentals in housing projects that are built with public funds.
Now that the speechifying about the Latin-American common market is over, the long, complicated and incredibly delicate task of bringing about integration begins.
WASHINGTON, April 17 (AP)--The Supreme Court sidestepped, today a chance to rule broadly on the rights of tenants in Federally assisted housing projects.
The City Health Services Administrator called yesterday for a halt to increased Medicare and Medicaid expenditures unless health services were improved.
WASHINGTON April 17--In the Supreme Court of fhe United States today, the following proceedings were had:
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 97.8 on Friday from 97.9 on Thursday.

PITTSBURGH, April 17-- Warren Giles, the president of the National League, disclosed today that no disciplinary ac, tion would be taken, against Wes Westrum as a result of the New York Met manager's outburst last Friday night in Philadelphia.
TOKYO, Tuesday, April 18 (AP)--A Soviet TU-114 turboprop airliner carrying Japanese and Russian airline markings inaugurated the first commercial service across Siberia from Moscow to Tokyo today.

MOUNT VERNON, N. Y., April 17--Mr. and Mrs. Benpamin Bertram Littman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Emily Barbara Littman, to Dr. Steven Leslie Eisen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sidney Eisen of Rosyln Heights, L.I.A July wedding is planned.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 17--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon indicated today that he would recommend a sharp increase in American efforts to win the Vietnam conflict after his return to the United States next Monday.

Richard C. Werner Sr., a member of the printers' union committee negotiating contracts with the city newspapers, died yesterday in Jamaica Hospital, after suffering a heart attack. He was 50 years old and lived at 144-42 158th Street, Jamaica, Queens.

The Canadian peace Plan has now been added to the list of proposals turned down by North Vietnam. In recent months there have been President Johnson's direct approach to Ho Chi Minh, Pope Paul's pleas, a suggestion from the Wilson Government in London and Secretary General Thant's revised plan.

BERLIN, April 17--In response to an appeal by West Germany for an improvement in relations between East and West Germany, Walter Ulbricht, the East German Com munist chief, proposed today a meeting between Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger and Premier Willi Stoph to "negotiate an understanding between the two German states."

NASSAU, the Bahamas, April 17--The Commissioner of Police of the Bahamas Islands insisted today that he saw nothing wrong about helping an American gambler travel to England after his passport had been lifted.
WASHINGTON, April 17-- Spring is threatening to retire. "I'm utterly exhausted," she said last week, while sprawled voluptuously in a daffodil bed. "This may be my last national tour."

The National Federation of Music Clubs gave a Celebrity Luncheon yesterday in the Trianon Ballroom of the New York Hilton Hotel. The organization's 34th biennial convention closes today at the Hilton after five days of meetings. About 1,000 of the 600,000 members attended.
A dozen pickets marched at the Internal Internal Revenue Service office at 120 Church Street yesterday as thousands of New Yorkers filed their 1966 tax returns before the midnight deadline.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Supreme Court agreed today to consider whether state court judges can impose long prison terms for criminal contempt of court without granting jury trials to the defendants.

Ordinarily, when you see a program reading Ballet Espanol you know they're fibbing in their mantillas, and there won't be a ballet step to be seen. Unfortunately, Mariano Parra's Ballet Espanol at the Village Theater last night read its own publicity and tried a few "echappes a la second" with clicking castanets, and produced a jarring discord that was neither ballet nor Espanol.

Mayor Lindsay is now giving the fight against crime high priority in the city's maze of problems. Putting more. muscle into the Poiice Department in the form of more men and more equipment is expensive; but the need is indisputable. This is true even though crime in New York City increased less than the national average last year.

Dick Van Arsdale has signed his contract for next season, the New York Knickerbockers announced yesterday. Since his twin brother, Tom, signed with the Detroit Pistons last week, Dick's acceptance of a contract for fit salary estimated at $22,000 ends speculation that one or both of the former Indiana stars would join Indianapolis of the newly formed American Basketball Association.

TORONTO, April 17 (AP)-- The Chicago Black Hawks, the defending champions of the National Hockey League, are faced with a win-or-get-out situation when they face the Toronto Maple Leafs tomorrow night.
The men who make their living selling ski apparel and equipment to consumers are in New York this week to do some buying of their own for the season that starts six months or more from now.

Ghana's National Liberation Council has worked hard to clean up the mess it inherited after throwing out the profligate Kwame Nkrumah fourteen months ago. It has moved slowly to restore normal political life to a politically minded citizenry, but the Council's first take had to the restoration of a bankrupt economy.
The Department of Hospitals reported yesterday that an average of 478 fewer patients a day were hospitalized in the 21 municipal hospitals in 1966 than in 1965.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- James E. Webb, head of the space agency, refused today to tell Senators whether he had ever considered canceling the Apollo spacecraft manufacturing contract with North American Aviation, Inc., because of alleged failures to meet development schedules and stay within cost estimates.

PORT CHESTER, N.Y., April 17 (AP)--Benjamin Andrew Dutton, worldwide asphalt coordinator for the Standard Oil Company (New Jersey), died today at United Hospital. He was 63 years old and lived at Byram Shore, Greenwich Conn. Mr. Dutton returned from a business trip to England several weeks ago.
The Soviet Union says It is ready to pay repartions to the United States for backing out of a Los Angeles track meet last-July.

ROGERSVILLE, Tenn., April 17 (AP)--James A. MacLachlan, a professor emeritus of Harvard Law School, was killed today when his car collided head-on with a tractor trailer truck near here, state troopers said. He was 75 years old.

Consolidated first-quarter earnings of the Chicago North Western Railway fell from the year before but the result "wasn't too unsatisfactory" considering factors that had an adverse impact on operations, Ben W. Heineman, chairman and president, said yesterday.

GENEVA, April 17--The head of the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna is confident that it can expand its inspection system in time if it is given the job of checking on compliance with the proposed treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons.

NEW DELHI, April 17--Foreign Secretary Chandra S.Jha said today India was concerned about an aspect of a new United States policy that might make it easier for Pakistan to acquire American arms from third countries.
Lincoln Center today: Malcolm Bilson, pianist, LibraryMuseum, 6:30; Philadelphia Orchestra, philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- The Senate voted today to broaden the Social Security law to permit workers to retire voluntarily at the age of 60 years, provided they also agree to accept a 30 per cent cut in Federal retirement benefits.

LONDON, Tuesday, April 18 --Peter Gibbings, deputy manager of The Observer, a London Sunday newspaper, was named today managing director of The Guardian, the Liberal daily published in Manchester and London.

WASHINGTON, April 17-- Millions of years ago North America stole a large chunk of Europe, including much of what is now New England, according to a theory presented here today by Dr. J. Tuzo Wilson, a noted geophysicist.

First-quarter net income of E.I. Du Pont de Nemours Co, Inc., fell to $78-million, or $1.64 a share, from $102-million, or $2.17 a share, in the first three months last year, the nation's largest chemical producer reported yesterday.

ALBANY, April 17--The Constitutional Convention began a three-week working recess today after the filling of a Democratic vacancy on the delegates' roster and some jockeying over proposals to lower the voting age to 18.
The police believe they know who murdered Verna Ann Coppola.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 17--President Johnson has nominated five delegates and two alternates to represent the United States at the forthcoming special session of the United Nations General Assembly.

A deal that will be a strong candidate for the bestplayed of the year occurred recently in a tournament in Marbella, Spain. It was reported by the famous French writer, Jose le Dentu, and the hero was Claude Deruy, who represented France in the 1961 World Championship.
PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., April 17 (UPI)--Arnold, Palmer, golf's leading moneywinner, is back on top again.

JACKSONVILLE, Fla., April 17 (UPI)--Florida's compulsory school attendance law was ruled unconstitutional tonight by a Duval County judge who said the state had failed to provide equal protection for Negro and white children.

A utility expert contended before the State Public Service Commission yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company had "improperly" charged to its customers "hundreds of thousands of dollars" in contributions to 164 organizations from July, 1965, to June, 1966.
Mr. and Mrs. Arthur J. Goldberg paid homage last night to John Hall Wheelock at a reception in the residence of the United States Mission at the United Nations in the Waldorf Towers.
John, F. White, president of the National Educational Tele vision network, yesterday presented its station affiliates with the networks 1967-68 program schedule.

The Coast Guard closed the Hutchinson River in the Bronx to navigation yesterday after thousands of gallons of highoctane gasoline were spilled into the river from a tanker that had hit a submerged object, which had ruptured two of its tanks.

PORT-AU-PRINCE, Haiti, April 18 (AP)--Two explosions occurred Saturday night during a celebration for President Francois Duvalier. They are believed to have been a result of rivalry in the Haitian dictator's regime and not the work of his enemies.
Negotiators for the printers and The Daily News resumed their bargaining talks late yesterday, but neither side disclosed any information on the status of their discussions.
GREENWICH, Conn., April 18 (AP)--The Tamarack Country Club here was destroyed by fire today with damage estimated at as much as $500,000.

A new battle is impending between Traffic Commissioner Henry A. Barnes and the City Planning Commission on the perennial subject of off-street parking in midtown Manhattan. We hope that Mayor Lindsay will hold fast to his conviction that the city must not encourage the entry of more automobiles into the congested business district.

WASHINGTON, April 18--In his private conversation and increasingly in his public statements, Secretary of State Rusk has recently been complaining that the world is losing sight of what he calls "the great central question of our day."
Uniroyal, Inc., reported slightly lower sales and earnings yesterday for the first quarter of 1967 and informed its stockholders that the outlook for the rest of the year was "uncertain."
BUDAPEST, April 18 (AP) --Three Hungarians were sentenced to death and 16 others to long prison terms today after a court found them guilty of murdering 250 Jews and Communists during World War II.

MINEOLA, L.I., April 18 (UPI)--William Cahn, the Nassau County district attorney who charged two months ago that a leading Southern football coach had bet on his team with a national gambling ring, brushed off charges today that he was "frustrating" an investigation by the National Collegiate Athletic Association.
Lincoln Center today: James Oliver Buswell 4th, violinist, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30 P.M.
The 1967 film festival season opens next week with the start of the 21st annual Cannes Film Festival on the evening of April 27.

There will be disappointment that Pope Paul VI has not accepted the majority opinion of his special commission of bishops on birth control and also that a seemingly hopeful passage in the recent encyclical, "Populorum Progressio," was incorrectly interpreted as presaging a modification of present doctrine.
"THE HAPPY FACULTY," which opened last night at the Blackfriars Theater, wants to be a new kind of campus comedy.
DETROIT, April 18--The Chrysler Corporation reported today a 71 per cent drop in first-quarter earnings, but stockholders at the annual meeting in Detroit took little note of the decline.

Ruling that the trial judge had made a "serious and prejudicial error" in his instructions to the jury, the United States Court of Appeals unanimously reversed yesterday the conviction of a man who admitted narcotics sales to undercover agents.
GAYA, India, April 14--The "loo," the hot, dusty wind of summer, has begun to blow across Bihar's parched acres.
THE thinking behind recent activities at Blooming dale's seems to be: "If at first you do succeed, why not try again?"
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 18--President Johnson took off for Washington this evening to confront a familiar set of problems in somewhat novel form.
Nino Benvenuti signed a contract yesterday to defend his new world middleweight championship in a return match with Emile Griffith on July 13 at Madison Square Garden or Shea Stadium.
Thomas P.F. Hoving, who is not running for anything at the moment, spent most of yesterday shaking thousands of hands and making small talk with his constituents.

The Connecticut General Life Insurance Company has made a commitment to provide $9million in mortage financing for 25 years for a shopping center, named the Mall, under construction in New Rochelle. Tha building site consists of 4.3 acres at Main and Harrison Streets.

AMES, Iowa, April 18 (AP) --The student government president who shook the crew-cut world of Iowa State University with his Castro beard and a New Left political philosphy, has left the campus he had said he would drag "kicking and screaming into the 20th Century."
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Vice President Humphrey is scheduled to meet here tomorrow with a group of big-city mayors to discuss urban planning after the Vietnam war.
The election of H. Clifford Hatch to the board of Parke, Davis Co. was announced yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting in Detroit.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)--Domestic airline passenger traffic was 26 per cent greater last month than in March, 1966, the Air Transport Association said today.
The last of three men who pleaded guilty in the extortion trial of Harold (Kayo) Konigsberg was given a five-year prison sentence here yesterday.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- A detailed audit that cleared an embattled Head Start project of mismanagement charges, except for relatively minor amounts of money, is not fully acceptable to the Office of Economic Opportunity and to Senator John Stennis, Democrat of Mississippi, informed sources said yesterday. Both are studying the report.

WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)--An American Broadcasting Company executive testified today that the company got more than its officials expected through "forceful" negotiating on a merger with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
OAKLAND, Calif., April 18 (AP)--The California Clippers scored in the last 30 seconds of play and beat the New York Generals, 1-0, in a rain-soaked National Professional Soccer League match tonight.
TRENTON, April 18 (AP)-- Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed into law today a bill to exempt a wide range of items ranging from railroad equipment to Bibles from the state's 3 per cent sales tax.

The controversy over the crowd estimates is Saturday's antiwar demonstration here continued yesterday as leaders of the march charged that the city's police and its newspapers were "deliberately lying" in reporting the number of protesters.
PITTSBURGH, April 18-- Vice President Humphrey called today for complete cooperation between two recently created Federal departments to insure the success of urban transportation development.

A scene reminiscent of a sunset evening on the Riviera was reproduced for the Fete Champetre last night at the Waldorf-Astoria. It was titled Bal du Soleil a Monte Carlo, and guests dined and danced in the Grand Ballroom, which had been decorated to resemble a terrace overlooking flowering gardens on the blue Mediterranean.

The women's auxiliary of St. Bartholomew's Episcopal Church will hold its annual house and garden tour on May 4. Proceeds will benefit the charitable activities of the churchwomen. Mrs. Herbert Allan Dingwall is chairman and Mrs. John K. Weeks and Mrs. Dallas B. Sherman are co-chairmen of the tour of seven residences and gardens.
The Royal Ballet from London opened a six-week season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night in an atmosphere of Anglo-American amity.
ATLANTIC CITY, N.J., April 18--Representative Cornelius E. Gallagher, Democrat of New Jersey, said today he would hold Congressional hearings on the dissemination of credit information.

HANOVER, Germany, April 18 (Reuters)--Fritz Thielen, chairman of West Germany's extreme right-wing National Democratic party, seized three filing cabinets from the party headquarters today in his latest move to remain its leader.

WASHINGTON, April 18--The Justice Department charged 18 book publishing companies today with having conspired, with book wholesalers and others, to set arti fically high prices for library editions of children's books. As a result, the department said, costs had been higher for schools, libraries and other public institutions that buy such books.

TOKYO, April 18 (UPI)-- Gen. Van Tien Dung, Chief of Staff of the North Vietnamese Army, said in a war analysis broadcast today that United States "self-complacency" and "passive tactics" in Vietnam would lead to a Communist victory.

BRUSSELS, Belgium, April 18--The security police today arrested Anatoli T. Ogorodnikov, the Brussels correspondent of Tass, the Soviet press agency, on charges of "endangering the security of the state."

Alexander's Department Stores, Inc.--the chain of seven promotional department stores in the metropolitan area, --has decided to go public under an arrangement with Spartans Industries, Inc., the holder of a 38 per cent interest.
When Hirsch Jacobs reached Aqueduct yesterday morning, he went directly to Reflected Glory's stall and rubbed the 3-year-old colt's sore left shin.
The operators of the Empire State Building charged yesterday that the Port of New York Authority was trying to steal its uppermost tenant.

LUCIEN BIANCHI of Belgium, one of the top ranked international drivers, will be in the starting field for the 150-mile Indianapolistype car race at Trenton on Sunday. He will be one of a group seeking to beat the qualifying record of 115.718 miles an hour, set last year ...

Efrem Brauer has been appointed head of the new commercial division of Goldman Builders, Inc., of Union, N.J., builder of homes, apartments, recreation centers and industrial buildings. Mr. Brauer was formerly a locations analyst and real estate representative of Food Fair Stores.

DUBLIN, April 18--The Irish Government announced tonight that it would merge Trinity College, British-created and Protestant, with University College, mainly Roman Catholic, into a University of Dublin. Both are universities with international reputations.

MUNICH, Germany, April 18 --The Common Market's finance ministers glossed over some of their differences to reach a patchy agreement today on the stand they will take in the debate over expansion of the world's financial resources.
LONDON, April 18--Jacqueline du Pre, the cellist, and Daniel Barenboim, the Israeli pianist and conductor, announced today they would marry in September.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 18 (AP)--Mrs. Marlene Stewart Streit, the medalist, struggled to a 1-up victory over Mrs. David Chaffee of Rumford R.I., in the first round of the North and South amateur golf tournament today.
SALISBURY, Rhodesia, April 18--Leo Baron, a lawyer who was restricted by the Rhodesian Government after the November 1965, declaration of independence, is to leave Rhodesia and settle abroad.

The Sinclair Oil Corporation, the first major oil company to issue March quarter results, turned is net earnings of $25.7million, or 5 per cent more than the $24.4-million earned in the initial three months last year, E.L. Steiniger, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.
The American Brass Quintet was the solo group in two new works at the National Orchestral Association concert at Carnegie Hall last night.

A silver Sabbath lamp, made in Italy in the 18th century, was auctioned yesterday for $3,500, the high price in a sale of Hebrew ritual objects and manuscripts at the Parke-Bernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue.

Major executive changes have been announced by the Louis Schlesinger Company, industrial real estate concern of Newark. Joel Schlesinger, who has been in the real estate business for 50 years, has become chairman of the board, a new position. He has been succeeded as president and chief officer by his nephew, Frank A. Schlesinger, who has been with the company since 1946.

NAPLES, Fla., April 18-- Dr. Carl A. Coppolino acquired six bottles of a paralyzing drug a month before the sudden death of his wife, Carmela, saying he wanted it for experiments on animals, a witness at the Coppolino murder trial testified today.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- Senate Republicans agreed today to adopt Senator Charles H. Percy's sweeping plan to encourage home ownership in the slums as the main weapon in the party's attack on city problems.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- New orders for durable goods held steady in March after an almost uninterrupted decline since September, the Commerce Department reported today.

LONDON, April 18 (AP)-- There was a joke about it, said Maria Callas, but it was a serious deal. She told how her friend, Aristotle S. Onassis, and another Greek shipowner quipped --over dinner at Maxim's in Paris--that she would become like "Olga the Tanker" as a result of a pending deal.

The Franklin National Bank, which last year attracted almost $200-million in deposits with an aggressive promotion of "savings bonds" paying high rates of interest, announced yesterday that it had reduced the rate of interest paid on such time deposits to 4.8 per cent from 5 per cent.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- The Federal Bureau of Investigation believes that for the last three weeks a high ranking Soviet intelligence official has been visiting the United States under an assumed name on his passport.
ALBANY, April 18--Leaders of the Constitutional Convention have agreed on how to divide up the jobs at the convention. They insist that political jobseekers will be disappointed.

GLADWYNE, Pa., April 18-- Mrs. Mary Gibson Henry, a noted botanist, died on Sunday in Wilmington, N.C., where she was collecting rare native plants. She was 82 years old and lived here. Her late husband, Dr. J. Norman Henry, was a physician and explorer.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- An official of the American Telephone and Telegraph Company said today that telephone service might deteriorate if the utility did not receive a "fair" rate of return on its investment.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 18 --A Washington economist testified today that California's minimum freight rates were "detrimental to the national economy" because, in a fiercely competitive situation, they were too high for out-of-state shippers.
The city plans to take over and run the four detention homes of Youth House, where, it has been charged, youngsters have been subjected to mistreatment.
Seven more addicts have escaped from agents of the new state Narcotic Addiction Control Commission, it was announced yesterday.

CHICAGO, April 18--David Rockefeller, president of the Chase Manhattan Bank, recommended today doubling to about $15-billion a year the total aid funds being provided by the United States and other nations to developing countries.
HOUSTON, April 18 (AP)-- The four foreign entrants seeded in the River Oaks invitation tennis tournament gained straight-set victories today in the rain-splattered first round of men's singles play.

IN THE PRESENCE OF KINGS," open to the public today, brings the Metropolitan Museum back into operation again and does it with a great big, glorious, golden, bejeweled bang. Of course the place has hardly been shut down over the last several months, what with tens of thousands of people streaming in and out as usual ...

The National Aeronautics and Space Administration has always cultivated an image of openness and candor with the American people. It habitually sends its rockets skyward before an army of reporters and television cameras, in contrast to the Soviet Union's habit of hiding its failures and publicizing only its successes.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, April 19 (AP)-- United States Air Force jets bombed the big Thainguyen stel plant yesterday in what was believed to be the biggest attack so far against the industrial complex, 38 miles north of Hanoi.
Vice Adm. John S. McCain Jr. turned over the command of the Eastern Sea Frontier to Vice Adm. Andrew McBurney Jackson Jr. at a ceremony here on the carrier Wasp yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 18 --It is doubtful that Paul Revere was in more trouble the night he rode a Narragansett pacer to warn of the advance of British troops than Billy Haughton was tonight at the reins of Van Rebeck.
The stranger who aided a 19-month-old boy who suffered convulsions aboard a jet airliner last month was disclosed yesterday to be Mayor Lindsay.
PASADENA, Calif., April 18 (UPI)--Surveyor 3, sped on its mission to the moon today, ready to transmit live television pictures of a robot hand digging in the lunar surface.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- Everett McKinley Dirksen, the Senate Republican leader, said today that political office holders should not regard the proceeds of testimonial dinners as gifts unless this intent was stated beforehand on the tickets or letters of solicitation.
Potatoes for 4 cents a pound. Large eggs at 45 cents a dozen. Pure lard for 20 cents a pound. These were among the prices yesterday in a tiny store in East Harlem.

WASHINGTON, April 18--A decision, described as "unofficial," by Catholic University not to renew the teaching contract of an assistant professor with liberal theological views caused student and faculty demonstrations and protests today on the school's campus.

ATHENS, April 18--The socalled Aspida plot, which has dominated the Greek political scene for more than two years, took an unexpected turn today with the arrest of Demetrios Georgiadis, the Greek Army's former chief in Cyprus, on charges of high treason.

Robert V. Roosa, former Under Secretary of the Treasury for Monetary Affairs, took the nation's two largest banks to task yesterday for having suggested recently that the United States consider reviewing its policy of buying and selling gold in unlimited quantities with foreign governments.

Mrs. Mathilde Weill Cohen, until two years ago a registered psychologist associated with the counseling center at New York University, and a specialist in testing gifted children, died Monday in Lenox Hill Hospital. She was 71 years old and lived at 46 East 91st Street.

Britain's Labor Government plans to extend its experiment in holding down wages and prices when the present freeze expires in July. The hope is that the trade unions and industrial leaders will exercise voluntary restraint; but Prime Minister Wilson does not want to be without his own defenses against inflationary price or wage increases. So the Government will maintain the right to suspend any increases that it considers harmful to Britain's competitive position.

OAKDALE, L.I., April 18-- Mr. and Mrs. George Henry Remmer have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Louise Remmer, to John David Vincent-Smith, son of Mr. and Mrs. Julian VincentSmith of Brighton, England.

ALBANY, April 18--A state audit disclosed today that the New York Racing Association was just scraping by financially now, but if it stretched out its debt payments and put its food and parking concessions up for competitive bidding, it might harvest enough money to provide larger purses for thoroughbred racing in the state.
Automobiles will be barred from Central Park this Saturday from 6 A.M. to 8 P.M. so that bicyclists can have the park roads to themselves.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- The Southeast Asia Treaty Organization opened its annual ministerial meeting today, with differences over the conduct of the war in Vietnam underlined by unusually outspoken addresses by the Australian and Thai delegates.
Bond prices dropped sharply and interest rates rose yesterday under the impact of a heavy volume of new fixed-income securities issues, brighter economic news and a big rise in stock prices.
The city has asked to crossexamine at a public hearing staff members of the Public Service Commission who regularly check the books and records of the Consolidated Edison Company.
The stock market made its fourth consecutive advance yesterday as prices rose steadily in busy trading.

STOCKHOLM, April 18 (AP)--Erwin Klein of Los Angeles and Dick Miles of New York, who had been the only American survivors in the men's singles of the world table tennis championships, bowed in the fifth round today.
URBANA, Ill, April 18 (AP) --Three University of Illinois coaches who were dismissed for their parts in a $21,000 recruiting slush fund were honored by the university tonight at a farewell dinner.

First-quarter earnings of the Long Island Lighting Company, which services Nassau and Suffolk counties, rose to 61 cents a share from 54 cents in the 1966 period, the company's annual meeting of stockholders in Hicksville, L.I., was told yesterday.

The Union Carbide Corporation is planning the largest corporation program in its history with a record investment of $400-million, Birny Mason Jr., chairman, told shareholders at their annual meeting here yesterday.

EASTCHESTER, N.Y., April 18--At the opening of a new suburban store here today by Bonwit Teller, women bought $400 earrings and $85 hats, architects studied the Italian marble floors and antique crystal chandeliers, and tax collectors calculated the new town income.
James Creighton Drury, sales manager of the National Licorice Company died Monday of a heart attack here. He was 51 years old and lived at 289 Concord Drive, River Edge, N.J.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 18 --A kind of international competition has grown up here around requests for the extradition of Franz Paul Stangl, a wartime commandant of the Nazi death camps at Treblinka and Sobibor.
Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday that the city retained full veto power over any project proposed by the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority within city limits.
NATIONAL Video, the color television tube maker, which tacked on a nice gain yesterday in American Stock Exchange trading, may be in for rough sailing today.
PARIS--Mickey Belverger is a successful model who personifies a new fashion attitude among French girls. She wouldn't dream of owning lots of expensive clothes.

Barbara Meister, a New York pianist who made her recital debut here in 1964, returned for another appearance last night in Carnegie Recital Hall. Her playing emphasized the impression she had made before, that she is an intelligent, unassuming and appealing artist.

ANOTHER torturing recollection of the horrors of the Nazi concentration camps, this one stamped with the authenticity of production in East Germany, is rendered a bit less torturing than usual by a fresh and hopeful theme in the Defa Studio's "Nackt unter Wolfen" ("Naked Among the Wolves,") which came to the 34th Street East yesterday.

BELGRADE, Yugoslavia, April 18--Mihajlo Mihajlov, the Yugoslav author and publicist on trial on a charge of spreading hostile propaganda, said in a hot, crowded Belgrade courtroom today that some of his criticisms of the Yugoslav system had been mistaken or tactless.

Harold Chaney, a harpsichordist with music degrees from the University of Southern California who has toured the Far East and played here with chamber groups, last night played his debut recital at Town Hall. A serious, scholarly musician, Mr. Chaney included two works never heard here before.
The American Stock Exchange extended Monday's gain yesterday on expanded trading volume.

BERLIN, April 18--Leonid I. Brezhnev pleaded again today for unity of the world's Communist parties, directly to aid the Communist struggle in Vietnam and indirectly to make common cause in Europe against the West German Government.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Lawyers for urban voters in New York and Alabama urged the Supreme Court today to extend its one-man, one-vote doctrine to all local governmental units elected by the people.
MUSKEGON, Mich. (UPI)-- R.J. Thomas, president of the United Auto Workers union during the strife-torn nineteenthirties, died Tuesday at his home. He was 66 years old.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 18 --At least 50 persons were arrested tonight during a march of open housing supporters through a white neighborhood in the south end of Louisville.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)--The United States Tax Court ruled today that a wife is responsible for Federal income taxes on money her husband embezzled from her if they file a joint return.

Walter Ulbricht seems to have exceeded even his own previous records for cant and hypocrisy in his four-hour speech to the congress of East Germany's "Socialist Unity" party. Herr Ulbricht now says Germany can be united only after the West German working class has seized control, overthrowing "militarism, neo-Nazism and the power of the monopolies."
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)--Georgetown University, the nation's oldest Roman Catholic University, says it will add two Protestant clergymen and two rabbis to its theology faculty.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz began efforts today to settle a Chicago labor dispute that is threatening to wreck the national trucking contract settlement.
The Western Union Telegraph Company announced yesterday a public offering of two issues of preferred stock totaling $50,086,600 to help finance the company's 1967 construction program.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday eased most restrictions on the use of water, effective immediately.

ACCRA, Ghana, April 18-- The Ghanaian Army appeared shaken today in the wake of the abortive coup yesterday, but took encouragement from widespread manifestations of support from the country's civilians.
The Green Bay Packers, the champions, will play the New York Giants in Yankee Stadium next fall for the first time in five years. The date is Oct. 22.
The Liberal party's Bronx organization broke with tradition last night and endorsed Isidore Dollinger, a Democrat, for reelection as Bronx District Attorney.
A New York County grand jury is investigating the meat industry to determine whether union officials and public officials have been conspiring to defraud the public.
BALTIMORE, April 18 (UPI) --Sinai Hospital here is making available, under certain conditions, birth-control pills to unmarried teen-age girls.

FISHERMEN have a deep interest in how fish locate objects mainly because the object is their bait or lure. The more they know of the process, the greater the chance of helping the fish find the goodies.
A Mexican farmer and a local jeweler were arrested yesterday by Federal agents in connection with the alleged smuggling of $125,000 worth of gold jewelry into this country from Mexico.
BOSTON, April 18--The Boston Maine Corporation finally completed its annual meeting today by breaking a deadlock over a quorum and electing the management slate of directors.
Despite a fairly complete statistical picture of business activity for the first quarter, there is still no consensus among business forecasters about where the economy has been or where it is going.

The New York City Ballet's first performance this season of "Harlequinade," at the State Theater last night, tickled the sensibilities as the first sip of champagne tickles the palate. With the help of Rouben TerArutunian's toy theater setting, we were transported to a time when stylish suitors played mandolins beneath a lady's window and a beautiful fairy with one wave of her wand could right all wrongs.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (UPI)--Senator Russell B. Long, Democrat of Louisiana, offered today a new version of the Presidential campaign fund act that the Senate voted to repeal last week.
The Holly Sugar Corporation announced yesterday in Colorado Springs, Colo., the election of John L. Loeb Jr., as a director.

One of Johannesburg's leading producer-directors, Mrs. Taubie Kushlick, yesterday criticized the "dollar hypocrisy" of some American playwrights who have prohibited the presentation of their plays in South Africa while permitting them to be shown there as movies.
WASHINGTON, April 18 (AP)--The Senate defeated, 79 to 6, today an attempt to tie a $4-billion increase in basic Social Security benefits to a bill restoring business tax incentives.

CARDIFF, Wales, April 18 (Reuters)--Britain's National Coal board was accused today of having caused the death of 144 persons, mostly children, in the Aberfan mud-slide disaster last October by a "combination of indifference, incompetence, ignorance and inertia--attitudes of mind which pervaded the board from top to toe."

Henry (Red) Allen, who for many years was one of the country's leading Dixieland jazz trumpet players, died Monday night at Sydenham Hospital. He was 60 years old and lived at 1351 Prospect Avenue, the Bronx.
MOSCOW, April 18 (AP)-- The Soviet supersonic airliner will not be ready for next month's air show in Paris but it may still fly before the British-French Concorde.

PARIS, April 18--Gen. Lauris Norstad, former commander of North Atlantic forces, met for 45 minutes with President de Gaulle today and talked with several other officials in what he described as a private visit.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- George Meany said today that Walter P. Reuther's attacks on the A.F.L.-C.I.O. were a result of the auto union leader's personal frustrations rather than any policy differences.

WASHINGTON, April 18-- James J. Saxon, the former Controller of the Currency, predicted today that the Justice Department's antitrust division would one day have the power to rule on the establishment of bank branches and other aspects of bank operations over which it has no current jurisdiction.

ROME, April 18--References to birth control in Pope Paul's recent encyclical cannot be interpreted as showing a change in the church's traditional teaching, the Vatican city newspaper, L'Osservatore Romano, said today.

Paperboard production rose 8.40 per cent, with 456,300 tons, in the week ended April 15 from 420,900 tons in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 18--Mr. and Mrs. Bayard Ewers Sawyer of New Canaan and Jaffrey Center, N.H., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss. Stacey Cobbett Sawyer, to Richard Lawrence Munk, son of Mr. and Mrs. Frederick L. Munk Jr. of Katonah. N.Y.
One of two women justices in the State Supreme Court here was asked yesterday to establish the precedent that a husband can collect alimony.
Ed McCabe is the copy chief at Carl Ally and after last night he should be the happy copy chief at Carl Ally.

Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday that Governor Rockefeller "would be eminently qualified" for President, but he emphasized that the Governor had "chosen not to run nationally" on the 1968 Republican ticket.

JOEY BISHOP has started his new career as a con versational spinoff from the Johnny Carson "Tonight" program. In his debut on Monday he was indebted no end to the formidably attractive Debbie Reynolds, actress, singer, mother and prospective tackle for the Green Bay Packers.

WASHINGTON, April 18--Senator Robert F. Kennedy confronted the leaders of the nation's building trades unions in a Senate committee room today and told them that their efforts to open union ranks to Negroes had failed.
The most significant development in civil rights in the past two years has been the growing recognition that race relations are not the unique problem of the South.

LANSING, Mich., April 18 (UPI)--The directors of the Race Betterment Foundation, an organization founded 61 years ago by the late Dr. John H. Kellogg, were accused today of squandering nearly $687,000 in funds intended for charity.
ALBANY, April 18--Governor Rockefeller signed the lottery bill today, thus allowing the State Tax Department to prepare for the first drawing, which will be held in July.
BOSTON, April 18--Once upon a time, 192 years ago, Paul Revere rode through the Boston suburbs warning of impending disaster (This was long before the Red Sox or Bruins).
THE Philadelphia Orchestra gave the 10th and final concert of its 1966-67 Philharmonic Hall series last night, and Eugene Ormandy made the event an absorbing musical adventure.
WASHINGTON, April 18-- The nation's lawmakers got a glimpse into the future of law enforcement today and the new crime-fighting technology they saw was worthy of Dick Tracy or James Bond.

CHICAGO, April 18--Scientists suggested today that while becoming obese a person may activate an internal biochemical system that makes him even fatter and keeps him that way.

JOHANNESBURG, South Africa, April 18--More than 100,000 people will vote tomorrow and Thursday for Swaziland's first self-rule government, one that will lead the territory out of Britain's control and into independence within two years.

The 107-man graduating class of the State University of New York Maritime College, Fort Schuyler, the Bronx, was praised yesterday for having given up its Easter and Christmas vacations to answer a national need.

Maine potato growers, who have suffered from declining prices in recent months, managed to keep the spot quotations firm yesterday at the $1.25-$1.35 a hundred pounds level.

The Tri-Continental Corporation, the nation's largest closedend investment company, reported yesterday that its net assets on March 31 totaled $527,247,736, or $34.41 a share. This is up from $509,425,996 or $33.31 a share on March 31, 1966, and $470,754,386, or $30.69 on Dec. 31.

LES LEVINE will be creating disposable rooms faster than they can be disposed of in coming weeks.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 18 (AP)--Walter Blum rode five winners at Gulfstream Park today and moved into a tie with Jorge Velasquez for the lead. Each has 47 victories.
CASTEAU, Belgium--France's position inside the North Atlantic alliance as distinct from that alliance's integrated "organization," NATO, is uncertain and subject to varied interpretations.

NASSAU, the Bahamas--Bahamian political leaders were given contracts as consultants with the expectation that they would use their influence in behalf of a casino on Grand Bahama Island, the man who signed the contracts testified today.
CLEVELAND, April 18 (UPI)--Joe Adcock, manager of the Cleveland Indians, lost his battle against the Kansas City Athletics and their new white shoes today.

MOSCOW, April 18 (UPI)-- A West German student pleaded guilty today to charges that he had smuggled antiSoviet literature into the country with instructions to give it to anti-Communists here.

BALTIMORE, April 18-- Port operations were back to normal here today following the settlement over the weekend of a tugboat strike that lasted six months and two days.
New York City's ability to borrow money remained relatively good yesterday with the sale of $105-million worth of bonds at 3.975 per cent interest.
Msgr. Patrick J. Frawley, director of the department of health and hospitals for Catholic Charities of the Archdiocese of New York, died yesterday in St. Vincent's Hospital. His age was 50.

The Westinghouse Broadcasting Company says it will refuse to carry National Broadcasting Company movies if the network increases the number of commercial interruptions.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 19-- One of the major decisions of Konrad Adenauer's chancellorship--to pay reparations to the state of Israel for Nazi crimes against the Jewish people--was taken almost impulsively after an emotional 40-minute meeting with Dr. Nahum Goldmann, President of the World Zionist Organization, in a London hotel room.
The West German Government paid Israel $860-million in reparations under agreements worked out by Dr. Adenauer.

The latest news from China calls to mind the old speeches of Andrei Vishinsky at the Moscow purge trials in the mid-1930's. The famous prosecutor accused Trotsky, Bukharin, Kamenev and Zinoviev of plotting with foreigners to overthrow Stalin. Peking's will posters now tell of Liu Shao-chi, Teng Hsiao-ping and Peng Chen plotting with foreigners to overthrow Mao. And today's wall posters, like Vishinsky's speeches three decades ago, demand the death penalty for the accused.
