Time, Inc., reported record earnings and revenues in the first quarter of 1967, but the company is now feeling the slowdown in the general economy, officials told the annual meeting yesterday.

STOCKHOLM, April 20 (AP) --The last United States survivors in the world table tennis championships were eliminated today when Brooke Williams of Santa Barbara, Calif., and Dan Pecora of Chicago bowed in the third round of the mixed doubles.

MONTREAL, April 20 (AP) --Henri Richard scored three goals tonight and led the Montreal Canadiens to a 6-2 victory over the Toronto Maple Leafs in the first game of the National Hockey League's final playoff series for the Stanley Cup.

A group of Roman Catholic, Protestant and Jewish clergymen said yesterday that a Soviet Government official had agreed "in principle" to permit young Soviet Jews aspiring to be rabbis to attend seminaries in Western Europe.

BERLIN, April 20--Erich Henecker, an East German party secretary, called today for world-wide Marxist loyalty in the Soviet party as "the pioneer of human progress and the avant-garde of the international movement."
HALIFAX, N.S., April 20 (Canadian Press)--Premier Robert Stanfield set Nova Scotia politicians scurrying today with the announcement that a provincial election would be held May 30.
A STATUS-SEEKER determined to pay a quarter of a million dollars for a new boat can count on an obliging "no problem" response from Chris-Craft salesmen.
PASADENA, Calif., April 20 --An analysis of radioed data from Surveyor 3 indicated today that the spacecraft bounced twice after its initial touchdown on the moon's surface yesterday.
PARIS, April 20--At least three groups have expressed an interest to the French and British Governments in handling the private side--financing and constrution--of a tunnel under the English Channel.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)--The Daughters of the American Revolution passed unanimously today a special resolution expressing "alarm and unalterable oppositiion" to United States gold reserve policies and calling for a review of these policies by Congress.

WEST ORANGE, N.J., April 20--The Garden State Women's, Golf Association opened its season today over the 6,251-yard, par-74 Rock Spring club course. The association is open to players with handicaps of 12 and under. One-day tournaments usually are played from scratch once the players are assigned to groups, based on their handicaps.

The Federal authorities hope that the shipping industry itself will propose an acceptable solution to a pending dispute on liability limitation in cases involving ship disasters at sea, a spokesman for the Federal Maritime Commission said yesterday.

THE WIDE OPEN DOOR," last night's 90 minute special, was supposed to be a droll and light-hearted account of an imaginative mob worming its way into Scotland Yard as a prelude to holding up a London bank branch. But the drama sank hopelessly into a sea of confusion, the consequence of altogether too complicated a plot and of reliance on the creaky device of giving the leading performers two parts.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 20--Arthur J. Goldberg said today that his greatest disappointment as chief United States delegate had been "the failure of the United Nations to come to grips with the problem of Vietnam."

THERE was no shortage of enterprise in the program given by the Juilliard Dance Ensemble at the Juilliard Concert Hall, 130 Claremont Avenue, last night. Indeed, with two world premieres, one by Anna Sokolow, the other by Josh Limon, and two revivals, by Martha Graham and by Antony Tudor, this was a program any company in the world would be proud to own.
The Chemical Bank New York Trust Company announced yesterday the appointment of Donald C. Platten as administrative head of its international division.

More than 95 per cent at the United Artists Corporation's stock has been tendered to the Transamerica Corporation and the stock is expected to be delisted from the New York Stock Exchange soon, officials of both companies disclosed yesterday at a news conference in the Yale Club.
Mrs. Rose Shapiro, the initiator of the Board of Education's new policy on sex education, said yesterday that she hoped city schools would eventually start instruction in the first grade.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 20 --A policy of gradualism was prescribed last night by President Carlos Lleras Restrepo to meet Latin America's economic and social problems.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 20 (AP)--A dispute between Stokely Van-Camp, Inc., and the teamsters' union over a master contract for the canning company has closed 14 plants and brought cancellation of 1967 contracts with growers.

RICHMOND, April 20--Mr. and Mrs. William Edward Black have announced the engagement of Mr. Black's daughter, Miss Ellen Faucette Black of New York, to Robert Cornelius Seabring, son of Capt. Cornelius Samuel Seabring, U.S.N., retired, and Mrs. Seabring of Summit, N.J.A. September weeding is planned.
The spot rate on the British pound advanced slightly in moderate trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.
Roy Wilkins yesterday described as "dangerous" Dr. Martin Luther King's recent warning that at least 10 cities across the nation could "explode in racial violence this summer."

Corn futures found a reason to go up yesterday--the surprise purchase by Red China of about 4 million bushels of corn from Argentina. Another factor was the reported sale of a substantial amount of corn here to Japan, probably about 400,000 bushels for nearby shipment.
A strong plea for an American-flag passenger liner fleet within the framework of a new Federal Maritime policy was made yesterday by four maritime labor leaders.

WHITE PLAINS, April 20-- Taxes and fees have absorbed $35,730,803, or 58 per cent of the $60.6-million estate of Mrs. Mary Duke Biddle, the tobacco heiress, according to papers filed in Westchester County Surrogates Court here today.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)--The Federal Reserve Board asked Congress today for limited authority over state banks whose deposits are insured by the Federal Government.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 20 --Dr. Charles E. Smith, dean of the University of California School of Public Health at Berkeley and former president of the California State Board of Public Health, died Tuesday at the Presbyterian Hospital in San Francisco at the age of 62.
BONN, April 20--The funeral of former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer is expected to serve as an occasion for brief but concentrated political talks between West Germany and its western allies.

A seven-story office building at 144 East 44th Street, between Third and Lexington Avenues, has been leased by Bill Publications in an unusual transaction. The company, a publisher of business magazines, will take possession over a six-year period.
ROME, April 20 (Reuters) Chaos broke out in the Italian Chamber of Deputies tonight when a neo-Fascist Deputy shouted "Long live Fascism!"

A new musical, "Mr. Congressman," with a book by Don Appell, the creator of "Milk and Honey," will be presented on Broadway next season. The show will have music and lyrics by Al Hoffman and Dick Manning. It will go into rehearsal in January and open here next April after an out-of-town run. Jack Beekman and Jules Itts will produce, and Elias Goldin will serve as general manager.

PASO ROBLES, Calif., April 20(UPI)--Harold P. Garrity, 61 years old, a former Westchester County Democratic chairman, was in serious condition at Paso Robles Memorial Hospital today following a plane crash in which his son also was injured.

PARIS--Konrad Adenauer was one of history's anomalies. His career as a national and an Internatlonal figure began only when he was an old man in his seventies. Rigid, a poor speaker, he had no more charisma than an oak tree. In fact, there was something remarkably wooden about his appearance. Yet, underneath, he was a subtle leader, filled with complex suspicions, and a sensitive human being.
The bond market, which came out of its week-long slump on Wednesday, continued to perk up yesterday.

PARIS, April 20--Bertrand Russell's American assistant, Ralph Schoenmann, was escorted by an airport police agent today from one Paris airport to the other while he was on his way from London to Prague.

HARRISON, N.Y., Friday, April 21--Striking members of the Westchester Welfare Workears Association voted early this morning to submit their dispute with the county to a fact-finding procedure and to return to work Monday.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- The natural gas industry strongly defended its pipeline safety record today and sharply criticized Congressional efforts to bring gas companies-- for the first time--under broad Federal safety regulations.

A NEW wall covering that looks like paper but per forms like Plastic was introduced yesterday by E.I. du Pont de Nemours at F. Schumacher Co., 939 Third Avenue (at 56th Street). The sheeting material, called Tyvek, is of polyethylene fibers and was seven years in the

EAST WILLISTON, L.I., April 20--Mrs. Vincent de Paul of the Nassau Country Club scored a 41, 41-82 today over the Wheatley Hills Golf Club course to lead a field of 64 by four strokes in the opening tournament of the Women's Cross-County Golf Association. Par for the 5,939-yard course is 36, 36--72.

MONTREAL, April 20-- A delegation from the Soviet Union headed by Col. Gen. Georgi S. Schetchikov, a deputy, minister for Civil Aviation has arrived in Montreal to discuss membership in the International Civil Aviation Organization, which has its headquarters here.
The Aluminum Company of America had good news for stockholders yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 19-- On more than 100 occasions during the last six years spots on the moon have been observed to glow and even sparkle, yet there is still no agreed explanation for such events.

A declaration of independence by a group of Puritan churches in 1648--"Platform of Church Discipline"--was bought for $80,000 by the Harvard College Library in an auction of the Thomas W. Streeter Americana collection, conduction yesterday and Wednesday.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- The Senate worked itself into an angry stalemate today over legislation that would restore the 7 per cent tax bonus for business investment and also modify the new law permitting taxpayers to contribute $1 to finance Presidential campaigns.
Columbia broke a five-game losing streak by routing C.C.N,Y., 14-6, yesterday at Baker Field, capitalizing on poor fielding by the Beavers, who committed nine errors.
CLEVELAND, April 20 (AP) --Steve Hargan shut out the Kansas City Athletics on five hits tonight in pitching the Cleveland Indians to a 2-0 victory.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP)--The Defense Department's new public affairs chief agreed today with members of the House Government Information Subcommittee that too much Pentagon information was classified.

EAST ORANGE, N.J., April 20--Grace M. Freeman, an Essex County Assemblywoman from 1947 to 1951 who sponsored civil-rights legislation in the late nineteen-forties, died yesterday at the Orange Memorial Hospital. She lived at 361 North Arlington Avenue.

Union contracts covering 20,000 elevator operators, doormen, porters and other service employer in 4,000 apartment and commercial buildings here expired last night, and the union said there could be a strike at any time.
TRENTON, April 20--The Senate unanimously confirmed Dr. Carl L. Marburger today as New Jersey's new State Commissioner of Education.
The spirit of cooperation within the Asian and Pacific region under Asian initiative has continued to show vigorous growth in many directions.
Joseph Korson, former manager of the City College cafeteria, pleaded guilty in Criminal Court yesterday to two counts of commercial bribery. Judge Amos S. Basel set sentencing for June 2.
A late burst of strength helped the stock market to post its fifth consecutive advance yesterday.
Secretary General Thant returned to New York last night from a journey to five Asian countries expressing a fear that the war in Vietnam may yet spread to countries not so far involved.
For about 10 weeks, young women have been reported driving a fleet of eight automobiles to North Carolina and back to New York City, about 15 trips a week, on roads other than turnpikes.
MACON, Ga., April 20--A group of Baptist ministers failed today in an attempt to remove the chaplain of a small church-owned university because he used an obscenity in a sermon.

NAPLES, Fla., April 20-- The defense in the murder trial of Dr. Carl A. Coppolino called as its first witness today a biochemist who disputed the state's contention that Mrs. Carmela Coppolino was slain in 1965 by an injection of a paralyzing, drug.

PARIS, April 20--Premier Georges Pompidou was shouted down for several minutes in the National Assembly today as he refused to yield the floor while defending his Government against Opposition criticism.

LE PETIT SOLDAT," Jean-Luc Godard's dra ma of French and Algerian terrorists and street warfare in Geneva during the crisis of 1958, begen its commercial run yesterday at the New Yorker Theater. The film, made in 1960, was banned from showing in France until the end of the Algerian War in 1962. The movie was screened here once at the very beginning of the newspaper strike two years ago in the New York Film Festival.
MOSCOW, April 20 (AP) --Unconfirmed reports circulating here say that a major new Soviet space launching is imminent.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., April 20--Dr. Jerome J. Morgan, who retired in 1949 as professor of chemical engineering at Columbia University, died yesterday at Orange Memorial Hospital. He would have been 87 years old on Saturday. He resided here at 67 Salter Place.
WASHINGTON, April 20-- Neariy all classes were suspended today in a spreading strike of students and teachers at the Catholic University of America.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- Intercity truck tonnage affected by work stoppages in the week below the volume in the corresponding week of 1966. Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings in United States railroads in the same period registered an increase.
Jean Martinon will not return as conductor of the Chicago Symphony when his contract expires next spring, he announced today.

Assemblyman Daniel M. Kelly held a consistently big lead through five ballots yesterday in balloting by the New York County Democratic executive committee for a designee for the vacant countywide Civil Court judgeship in Manhattan.
PARIS, April 20--Combat, a left-of-center independent morning paper, announced today that it was suspending publication prior to reappearing "in a few days" in a new format.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20-- Students wearing gas masks marred Hay Day exercises today at the University of Pennsylvania.
ALBANY, April 20--The state will take over New York City's parole system starting Sept. 1, under a bill that has been signed into law by Governor Rockefeller.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 20 --Cassius Clay, the world heavyweight boxing champion, said today that he would not step forward to take the tradilional Army oath of induction on April 28 in Houston.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- Several years ago, before he became director of the Arms Control and Disarmament Agency, William Chapman Foster was nearing the finish in a sailing race when his crew--his wife, Beulah-- fell overboard. Convinced that he had a chance of win-
WASHINGTON, April 20-- Representative Hugh L. Carey, Democrat of Brooklyn, acted today to have the New York State delegation lead a movement to seat Adam Clayton Powell with penalties.
Radio station WLIB in Harlem was honored yesterday with one of broadcasting's highest awards for having helped to prevent racial unrest last summer.

The City College's Intercollegiate Athletic Division issued plans yesterday for the basing of varsity and freshman teams, at sites around the city for an indefinite period beginning with the scheduled demolition of Lewisohn Stadium in September, 1968.
The Federal Reserve's steady push toward an easier credit policy was again evident in banking statistics released yesterday by the Reserve System.
THE New York double elimination knockout cham pionship for the Von Zedtwitz trophy has reached the semifinal stage almost six months after the start of the contest.

DALLAS, April 20 (AP)-- Gay Brewer, the Master's champion now engaged with Arnold Palmer in a fight for the lead in money winnings on the Professional Golfers' Association tour, shot a 6-under-par 64 today to take the lead after the first round of the $100,000 Dallas open golf tournament.

LONDON, Friday, April 21-- An army radio station in Athens said today that the military had taken control of Greece under a royal proclamation signed by King Constantine, Premier Panayotis Kanellopoulos and his Cabinet.
The first organized effort by the American apparel and textile industry to tap the consumer markets of the Soviet Union and other Eastern bloc countries was announced here yesterday.

In a letter printed on this page today the chairmen of the Port of New York Authority write that they "simply cannot understand" The Times's most recent criticism of the proposed World Trade Center in view of our previous support for the project.

A $4-million, 22-story lowrent public housing project under construction at Amsterdam Avenue and 93rd Street was chosen yesterday to bear the name of the Eugenio Maria de Hostos Towers. It will be the first housing project here named for a Puerto Rican.
BUCK HILL FALLS, Pa., April 20--An Episcopal priest told a World Council of Churches assembly today that the modern era demanded a new "theology of conversion."
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 98 on Wednesday from 97.8 on Tuesday.

WHEN Benjamin Britten's "War Requiem" appeared in 1962, it was generally greeted as the English composer's masterpiece to date as well as a work of unusual emotional depth. It was introduced to this country at the Berkshire Festival by the Boston Symphony Orchestra.
DETROIT, April 20 (AP)-- Auto production reached a 1967 high this week in the wake of strong sales reports.
Industrial issues advanced slightly after a weak start yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, April 20-- The Treasury announced today the imposition of a "countervailing duty" of $22.40 a ton on imports from Italy of steel units for electrical transmission towers.

Kinney Rent A Car, a division of Kinney National Service, Inc., yesterday announced a new low-cost auto rental and leasing program, built around the Rambler American. It said rates would be about 20 per cent below the previous lowest Kinney rates and the lowest of any major auto rental company.
George W. Ball, former Under Secretary of State, called yesterday for support of the Administration's drive toward expanded trade with the European Communist countries.
Governor Rockefeller is banking on the new state lottery for so much revenue for education that he is going to extraordinary--and ill-advised-lengths to promote the drawings.

Moon Palace, 2879 Broadway (at 112th Street), 666-7517. At its best, the food at the Moon Palace ranks with the best to be had in any Chinese restaurant in Manhattan. A dish of shredded chicken with abalone and another of pork shreds with soft bean curd were enjoyed recently with uncommon relish, and they will long be remembered. Both the boiled

WASHINGTON, April 20-- Two lengthy and quiet negotiations involving chiefly the United States and Western Europe may determine within the next two weeks whether the highly successful postwar world trading and financial system continues or breaks apart.

A demonstration against Marine Corps recruiting at Columbia University erupted into an hour-long session of namecalling and sporadic fist-fights yesterday as students clashed with one another on the school's Morningside Heights campus.
JERUSALEM (Israel) April 20--Nearly 17,000 sun-bronzed marchers from Israel and abroad strode into Jerusalem today to end the 13th annual four-day holiday march.

ERNIE BANKS had to wait six years to give Maury Wills a jab from the same needle. But it was worth the wait, particularly to a joyous, laughing guy like Ernie. So much good humor bubbles constantly within him that he pounced on the opportunity when it came.

RIO DE JANEIRO, April 20 (Reuters)--Alfred A. Knopf, the publisher, and Mrs. Helen E. Hedrick, widow of an Oregon educator, were married here today at a simple ceremony in the private chapel of Mauricio Nabuco, a Brazilian diplomat. A small group of friends attended.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 20--United States planes struck targets in Haiphong today for the first time.

LEWIS MUMFORD'S 22d book is a major recapitulation and extension of the themes of his earlier work, especially of his pioneering "Technics and Civilization" (1934) and "The Condition of Man" (1944). Significantly, the new work, which might be called a radical reinterpretation or philosophy of human ecology, opens with a passage from...
ELIZABETH, N.J., April 20 --Israel Greenberg of 775 Floral Avenue, a lawyer here for 35 years, died yesterday in Memorial General Hospital, Union, after a brief illness. His age was 58.
THE invitation reads "Black Tie." It is an authoritative direction for men. But only a woman can see the invisible line forgotten by the printers. It reads "Fashion Crisis--What Shall I Wear?"

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20 (AP)--Ken Henderson drove in two runs today with San Francisco's fifth single of the second inning, capping a five-run uprising that gave the Giants a 7-5 triumph over St. Louis.

Orders for machine tools, which rose sharply in February after a slump of several months, rose only slightly in March, an analysis of figures released in Washington by the National Machine Tool Builders Association disclosed yesterday. However, volume was still well below the 1966 level.
The start of the 52d year of the Kips Bay Boys' Club was marked last eveing by the 15th annual Kips Bay dinner dance at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.
PRAGUE, Czechoslovakia, April 20 (AP)--Brazil defeated Italy, 60-30 today for its second victory in the tournament determining seventh to 11th places in the women's world basketball championship.

ATLANTA, April 20--Ralph Emerson McGill, publisher of The Atlanta Constitution, and Dr. Mary Lynn Morgan, a children's dentist, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Mac R. Morgan of Jacksonville, Fla., were married here this afternoon. The Rev. Frank Ross performed the ceremony in All Saints Episcopal Church. Three hundred guests attended the reception that followed in the parish hall.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- Senator Robert F. Kennedy's public declarations that he will not seek the Democratic Presidential nomination next year have been fortified by private pledges of a united political front with the Johnson Administration.

Single discoveries or devices are said to be able to change the course of the world, like gunpowder or the atom bomb, for instance. The single device used in the Contemporary Music Society's concert at the Guggenheim Museum last night is not so far-reaching, but it certainly did change the course of a single evening of music.

BRUSSELS, April 20--The North Atlantic Treaty Organization is considering establishment of a satellite communications system to make possible simultaneous consultation of its heads of government during a crisis.
WASHINGTON, April 20-- The Defense Department acknowledged tonight that both Haiphong power plants attacked today were within the metropolitan limits of the port city.

An investigation has been started by the Lindsay administration to determine whether New York City's schools and public libraries have been pay- ing artificially high prices for children's books for years.

LONDON, April 20--Unemployment in Britain, as recorded on April 10, showed the seventh monthly rise in 10 months. The Labor Ministry reported today that the national unemployment rate edged up to 2.1 per cent from 2 per cent in March.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) -- A National Research Council committee is urging studies to determine whether there are any long-term health hazards in such foods as potatoes, lima beans and fish.
Johnny Carson and the National Broadcasting Company settled their differences yesterday, and the star of the network's "Tonight" show will be back Monday.

The "hostile propaganda" that the Yugoslav writer Mihajlo Mihajlov is alleged to have spread could never have been so damaging to his country's reputation as his conviction and sentence to four and a half years in prison. This inexcusably severe verdict, suggesting that Belgrade fears Mihajlov's ideas, can only enhance his political stature at home and abroad.

A LEADING rating service bumped New York City's bonds down a notch in July of 1966 and Roy M. Goodman said it cost the city an additional $2-million a year in interest costs. He is very unhappy about it.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- The Treasury, through speeches by its two top-ranking officials, declared today that the other leading financial nations must "do much more by way of cooperation" if the United States was to be able to continue its policies "unchanged."

Mr. and Mrs. Arthur R. Freeman of 965 Fifth Avenue and Atlantic Beach, L.I., have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Karen Jane Freeman, to John Andrew Lowe, son of Mr. and Mrs. Irwin Lowe, also of New York and Atlantic Beach.
CAPETOWN, South Africa, April 20--The Governments of the United States and South Africa are to enter into a "dialogue" on the dispute over South-West Africa.

LONDON, April 20--Lord Robens, chairman of the National Coal Board, conceded today that the Aberfan mine disaster in which 144 people, including 115 children, were killed would probably not have happened if known safety techniques had been properly employed.

Despite record sales, firstquarter earnings of the National Dairy Products Corporation dipped 7.7 per cent from the record profit of the initial three months a year ago, Gordon Edwards, president, reported to about 1,000 shareholders at the annual meeting in the Statler Hilton Hotel here yesterday.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 20, --The precise Philadelphia 76ers coolly cut down the San Francisco Warriors tonight, 122-108, to take a commanding three games-to-one lead in their playoff series for the National Basketball Association championship.

Dick Tiger of Nigeria who won the world light-heavyweight championship after losing the middleweight crown twice, signed yesterday to defend his title against Jose Torres. The 15-round bout is scheduled for May 16 at Madison Square Garden.
NEW HAVEN, April 20-- Yale used strong relief pitching today by Hank Spires and Brad Jonasson to turn back New York University, 8-5.
As some 60 enraged Bronx residents shouted their opposition, the Board of Estimate approved plans for the highly controversial $7-million Hazel Towers housing project in that borough.

ADEN, April 20--South Arabia's Prime Minister said tonight that a United Nations peace-seeking mission would "not be allowed to set foot one inch on the soil" of the protectrates of the South Arabian Federation unless it agreed to deal directly with his Government.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI)--The Justice Department has started investigating possible antitrust violations in the electrical power industry, it was announced today.
LONDON, April 20 (UPI)-- Prime Minister Wilson promised today an announcement soon on a new British bid to enter the European Common Market.

A trial opened in State Supreme Court here yesterday in which a 39-year-old woman is seeking to have her marriage annulled on the ground that her husband concealed a Nazi background and "fanatically anti-Semitic" views.
Mrs. Katharine Witchie Riggs of the dance team of Witchie and Riggs, died Wednesday in a nursing home in Babylon, L.I. She was 80 years old and had lived at the Royalton Hotel here.
WASHINGTON, April 20 (UPI)--United States military spending soared to $6.7billion in March--its highest level since the start of the war in Vietnam, the Treasury said today.

WASHINGTON, April 20--The United States and its six allies in the Vietnam war held their first high-level strategy conference in six months today amid private talk of the need for more troops for the war effort.

Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary yesterday suspended firearms practice for members of the force during the spring and summer months and was immediately criticized by the Patrolmen's Benevolent Association.
MUNICH, Germany, April 20 (Reuters)--An attack of acute appendicitis today forced Munich's dumpling. marksman to postpone a mission to New York to fire his homemade missiles at lowflying jets.
The printers' union put additional pressure on The Daily News yesterday by varying the time and length of shop meetings that stop all work in the composing room.
The city's water supply yesterday stood at 451.2 billion gallons, or 94.7 per cent of capacity, according to the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

BUENOS AIRES, April 20 (AP)--Cliff Richey of Dallas and Clark Graebner of Beachwood, Ohio, members of the United States Davis Cup team, gained the men's semi-finals today in the River Plate lawn tennis championships.

INDIANAPOLIS, Aprll 20-- Ninety entries, six more than the previous high of 1953, have been filed for the 500-mile Mcmorial Day race. The starting field of 33 will be determined by time trials scheduled for May 13, 14, 20 and 21.
Three of the city's leading judges strongly opposed yesterday Mayor Lindsay's proposal to transfer most violations of the housing code from the Criminal Court to the Civil Court.
PHILADELPHIA, April 20-- Dr. Frederic Palmer Jr., retired professor of physics and dean emeritus of Haverford College, died yesterday at the Bryn Mawr Hospital. He was 88 years old.

MOSCOW, April 20--Whatever may be said about the cultural provincialism of Moscow, and the huge city does indeed remain a provincial center, there is no denying the impressive amount of music to be found day after day in the concert halls and opera houses. The Russians take their culture very seriously, and take music with

John U. Monro, who will resign as dean of Harvard College in July to become director of freshman studies at Miles College, a small Negro school in Birmingham, Ala., said yesterday that leadership in Negro education would have to come from privately financed colleges and schools.

WASHINGTON, April 20--A great change is coming over the discussion of public affairs in America. The old optimistic illusion that we can do anything is giving way to doubt, even to a new pessimism that maybe the problems of the nations, the cities and the races are beyond our control.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- The White House announced today that President Johnson would nominate R. Peter Straus of New York to be assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development in charge of its bureau of African Affairs.
The election of Weston E. Hamilton as a director of the General Baking Company was announced yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting in Flamingo, Fla.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 20 --At least 70 open housing demonstrators were arrested tonight when they attempted to march through an all-white neighborhood for the sixth successive night.

Senator Jacob K. Javits called yesterday for an end to formal backing of the United States dollar by gold and for a new policy under which the Treasury would "reserve to itself the right to determine whether and when to stop selling or buying gold at $35 an ounce."

AUSTIN, Tex., Apr. 20--The fourth successive monthly cut in Texas oil production, and the largest of the series, was ordered today by the Texas Railroad Commission after a gloomy hearing at which all but one purchasing company asked for cuts.
WASHINGTON, April 20-- President Johnson was chided today by a committee of top editors for "consistently trying to make the news sound or seem better than it is."

PINEHURST, N.C., April 20 (AP)--A 40-foot birdie putt provided the winning spark today for Phyllis (Tish) Preuss and Connie Day played at a sparkling two-under-par pace to gain the final of the North and South women's amateur golf tournament.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- The United States is prepared to relax its strict trade embargo of Communist China so that American drugs may be sold or donated to thousands of Chinese suffering from cholera, meningitis and infectious hepatitis, Government officials said tonight.

District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's reported use of electronic cavesdropping to obtain information against milk companies suspected of price-fixing, bid-rigging and other violations, of the law was criticized yesterday by the Metropolitan Dairy Institute.

MADISON, N.J., April 20-- Striking seminary students at Drew University voted today to return to classes next Tuesday but to continue to demand "by other means" the removal of the institution's president, Dr. Robert Fisher Oxnam.
CHICAGO, April 20 (AP) --The United States probably will not land a man on the moon this decade, an official of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration said tonight.
AMMAN, Jordan, April 20-- The newly elected Parliament chose a Palestinian moderate, Qassem Rimawi, as its Speaker today by a vote of 42 to 17 blank ballots with one absentee.

Along the coasts of Massachusetts and New Jersey thousands of sea birds are dead and dying. They are probably victims of unknown oil tankers which somewhere at sea dumped quantities of heavy black crude oil. As winds and currents carried this oil toward shore, it engulfed the birds, coating their feathers and making it impossible for them to fly. Many van ished in the sea and others were washed ashore, barely alive.
Only an inveterate optimist could hope for much progress from the special session of the United Nations General Assembly that convenes today.

DETROIT, April 20--Walter P. Reuther, president of the United Automobile Workers, attempted today to patch over differences between skilled and production workers at the union's pre-bargaining convention here.
AKRON, Ohio, Friday, April 21--The United Rubber Workers union struck three of the Big Four tire manufacturers early today.

Saw Adm. U.S. G. Sharp; met with Ambassadors MacArthur to Austria and Rolvaag to Iceland: saw Prime Minister Keith Holyoake of New Zealand; met with Secretary of State Rusk, Secretary of Defense McNamara, Presidential Assistant Rostow and Press Secretary Christian.

A memorial service will bee held on Monday at the Church of the Heavenly Rest (Episcopal), 2 East 90th Street, for W. Howard Bell, a former investment banker here and in Philadelphia who died April 7 in his winter home in Jamaica, West Indies, at the age of 74.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- Senator Charles H. Percy, a freshman Republican, introduced his housing bill for the poor today, and it was received with more fanfare than is usually accorded to proposed legilslation from the White House.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 20-- Kuwait and Iraq have moved troops to their frontier and recalled their ambassadors after Iraqi border guards crossed the frontier, tore down a tent camp of workers drilling water wells and briefly occupied the area, according to reports from both countries.
The city will begin to charge fees for medical services in municipal outpatient clinics and emergency rooms on July 1 in an effort to induce more than a million persons to enroll in Medicaid.

WHITE SULPHUR SPRINGS, W. Va., April 20--Some of the nation's most important advertising agency men arrived here this morning, quickly changed from well-tailored business suits to well-tailored sports clothes, and got right down to business --the business of the American Association of Advertising Agencies' 50th anniversary meeting. And may all of their business be so friendly.

OSSINING. N. Y., April 20-- Mr. and Mrs. John Cheever have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Liley Cheever, to Robert William Cowley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Malcolm Cowley of Sherman, Conn. The wedding is planned for May 6.
Tom Seaver, a college student who cost the New York Mets $50,000, began to pay off on the investment yesterday by pitching his owners to a 6-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs.
Grace Line announced changes yesterday in its top executives, brought about by the retirement on May 1 of Adm. Wilfred J. McNeil, who has headed the steamship line since October, 1959.

WASHINGTON TOWNSHIP, N.J., April 20--Mr. and Mrs. John V. Adams have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Jo Adams, to William B. Whitman, son of Mr. and Mrs. W.H. Whitman of Glenview, Ill.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., April 20--Tennessee's prohibition against teaching the theory of evolution in tax--supported schools and colleges survived today the most serious challenge in its 42-year existence.

Alice Esty's career is fraught with good deeds: the commissioning and performing of new songs. Last night the soprano brought another program of French and American rarities to Carnegie Recital Hall. Miss Esty was well prepared but her meager vocal powers only suggested what lay beneath the words.

Youth had its evening yesterday at Carnegie Hall, as 90 high-school instrumentalists and a 120-voice chorus joined talents for the second annual "American Youth Performs" concert. The series, founded seven years ago by Charles Abdoo, has been sponsored for two years by American Airlines. It is devoted to the encouragement of teen-age musicians, and, so far this school year it has presented these gifted performers in some 90 concerts, in 35 cities coast to coast.
Gov. George Romney said yesterday that "more is needed" in Federal civil rights legislation. It was the second major message of his undeclared cam- paign for the Republican nomination for President.
Prices edged ahead yesterday on the American Stock Exchange on slightly reduced volume.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 20--United States officials have disclosed that the number of civilian casualties in South Vietnam is rising as the tempo of the war increases.

The election of Frank J. Nunlist as chairman and chief executive officer of the Worthington Corporation and Adm. Albert G. Mumma, retired, as president and chief operating officer, was announced yesterday at the annual stockholder meeting in Newark.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., April 20--The engagement of Miss Caroline Sue Hodges, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Albert R. Hodges, to Charles B. Persell 3d, son of the Right Rev. Charles B. Persell Jr., Suffragan Bishop of the Episcopal Diocese of Albany, and Mrs. Persell, has been announced by the future bride's parents. The Persells live in Loudonville.

The Young New Yorker League for Cerebral Palsy will hold its first dinner dance tomorrow in the Pierre's Cotillion Room. Mayor and Mrs. Lindsay have been invited to the party, of which Mrs. Daniel Hirtenstein and Mrs. D.J. Shagrin are co-chairmen. Proceeds will go to United Cerebral Palsy of New York City.

WASHINGTON, April 20 (AP) --Following is the roll-call vote by which the Senate adopted today an amendment to the investment tax credit bill to restore and rewrite a provision for the use of tax money to finance Presidential campaigns:

Burton Fields, former assistant state attorney general, was sentenced yesterday to 18 months to two years in state prison. He had been convicted March 11 of conspiracy to extort and attempted extortion of $1,200 from a Brooklyn funeral home manager.

WASHINGTON, April 20-- The chairman of the House Ways and Means Committee rejected today the view reiterated this week by the Johnson Administration's chief economist that frequent tax changes were necessary to keep the economy prosperous and growing.
WASHINGTON, April 20-- A civil rights activist charged today that the "white press" reported statements by Negroes only if they were antiNegro or threatened violence.
NASSAU, the Bahamas, April 20--Thousands of dollars in payments were unexplained today at a hearing by the special commission of inquiry into gambling in the Bahamas.
THE other day this corner heard a rumble of a rec ord fish, or rather a would-be record fish. If it stands, it is likely to hold up for a long time.

GREENWICH, Conn., April 20--George Francis Wright of Greenwich, former president and chairman of the G.F. Wright Steel and Wire Company of Worcester, Mass., died today at Greenwich Hospital. He was 74 years old.

A final check on 1967 captal expenditures by American industry made last month by McGraw-Hill, Inc., indicates that a total of $64-billion will be spent, Douglas Greenwald, chief economist of the trademagazine publisher, reported yesterday.
Planned Communities, Inc., has named Sol M. Fromer, a realty investor, as its executive vice president.

PARIS, April 20--United States officials said today that they had received "a green light" from the Atlantic allies to resume negotiations with Moscow for a treaty to prevent the spread of nuclear weapons. They declared that the talks would be reopened soon.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- Vice President Humphrey said today that relations between the United States and Europe were entering a period in which the European nations must be prevailed upon to work with the United States in helping the poorer countries of the world.
The spot rate on the British pound eased on the usual weekend technical considerations in moderate trading yesterday on foreign exchange markets here,

WASHINGTON, April 21 --The American Broadcasting Company telephoned, teletyped and wrote to many of its 137 affiliated broadcasting stations suggesting that the stations attempt to enlist the support of members of Congress for the pending merger of the network with the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
At Lincoln Center today: Ethel Colt, presenting "Take It From the Top, Library-Museum, 2:30 P.M.; New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

Private collectors are lending works of art, some of which have never been exhibited publicly, for the annual benefit show for Cancer Care. The show opens Wednesday evening at the Wildenstein Galleries, 19 East 64th Street. Decorators have been invited to design backgrounds for the paintings.

A Federal district judge authorized yesterday the filing of a $50-million damage suit against William Zeckendorf Sr., former chairman of Webb Knapp, Inc., by the bankrupt real estate company's court-appointed trustee, Mortimer M. Caplin.
BUENOS AIRES, April 21 (AP)--Ramanathan Krishnan of India moved into the semifinals today of an international tennis tournament, beating Charles Pasarell of Puerto Rico, 6-3, 10-8.
CALVERTON, L.I., April 21--A test model of the F-111B jet fighter crashed here today on take-off, killing its two-man crew.

NEW styles in furniture, unlike styles in clothes, usually take a few years instead of a few weeks to take hold. And furniture customers, instead of letting designers create fashions for them, are likely to create fashions themselves--a fact that never fails to astonish and delight manufacturers.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- President Johnson ordered today a "greatly accelerated" Government research program into methods of air pollution control and again raised the amounts of money he wanted Congress to spend on the problem this year and next.
Theodore W. Kheel said last night that the time for decision had arrived in the prolonged newspaper dispute.

NAPLES; Fla., April 21--The chief medical witness for the defense in the murder trial of Dr. Carl A. Coppolino condemned as "unreliable" and "without scientific significance" today the pioneer research that detected elements of a paralyzing drug in the body of Mrs. Carmela Coppolino.

In this fiftieth year after Lenin's Bolshevik Revolution, the daughter of the man who ruled the Soviet Union for more than half that time has arrived in the United States proclaiming, "I have come here in order to seek the self-expression that has been denied me for so long in Russia."

LAKEHURST, N.J., April 21--Clarence A. Cole of Robin Street, former president of the General Fire and Casualty Company of New York, died or a heart ailment today at Paul Kimball's Hospital in Lakewood. His age was 68, and he had lived in Ridgewood.

The sharp drop in some automotive products and in appliances reduced first-quarter earnings of the Borg-Warner Corporation by 30 per cent from last year, although sales advanced, Lester G. Porter, president, told shareholders at the annual meeting in Chicago yesterday.

LAKE FOREST, Ill., April 21 --Mr. and Mrs. Frank J. Kelley 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mary Lewis Kelley, to Bert George Kerstetter, son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell B. Kerstetter of Beaver Falls, Pa. The wedding will take place here Aug. 19.

HANOI, North Vietnam, April 21 (Agence FrancePresse)--North Vietnam tonight rejected the United States proposal for withdrawing troops ten miles from both sides of the demilitarized zone as a preliminary to peace talks.

THE Museum of Modern Art has burrowed into its collections to put up a handful of examples of Latin-American art in honor of PanAmerican week. There is a new gallery in town, called Adria Art, 635 Madison Avenue near 59th Street, that handles only Yugoslav art.

NASSAU, the Bahamas, April 21--The members of the commission inquiring into gambling in the Bahamas got a brief glimpse of the tangled relationships of the gambling world today from a man who remembered that his friends had mostly said, "Hello, How are you? Good-by."

LOS ANGELES, April 21 (AP)--The Los Angeles Dodgers were rained out of a game tonight with the St. Louis Cardinals, marking their first home postponement since they moved from Brooklyn for the start of the 1958 season.
"America's poets," said Andrei Voznesensky on his arrival from Moscow yesterday, "have destroyed the myth that the United States is anti-intellectual."

The Philadelphia Orchestra, which gave its final Philharmonic Hall concert of the season on Tuesday, will begin a 10-concert series at Philharmonic Half on Oct. 17. It will mark the orchestra's 60th season in New York.
Some passengers who left the Untied States for Athens on Thursday are having an unexpected Roman holiday because of the Government crisis in Greece.

In an unusual application of a section that was recently add ed to the Shipping Act of 1916, a Federal Maritime Commission examiner has determined that a large number of steamship lines have charged unreasonably low rates.
The National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy yesterday sent a letter to President Johnson deploring the air attack on Haiphong on Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- The State Department said today that Svetlana Alliluyeva, the daughter of Stalin, had "decided to visit the United States" and would be "free to remain here as long as she wishes."
A strike was authorized yesterday by a union covering elevator operators, doormen and other service employes in 4,000 apartment and commercial buildings here.
The election of Otto A. Becker as regional vice president and the appointment of Richard F. Lambert as vice president for freight were announced by American Airlines yesterday.
Villanova, Georgetown and Fordham collide in the big races in today's 13th annual QueensIona Relays at Randalls Island.
MADRID, April 21--Key constitutional liberties were suspended today in Vizcaya, the restive northern industrial province in the Basque region.

The Administration's disclosure that a mere 1 per cent of the 7.3 million Americans on the relief rolls are capable of gainful employment makes it evident that both the myths about welfare clients and the programs that have been drawn up to deal with them must be radically revised.

First New York performances of sonatas by Alberic Magnard and A. Adnan Saygun were played at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon by Harold Kohon, violinist, and Isabelle Byman, pianist. The program also included Francis Poulene's Sonata.

GENEVA, April 21--The chief Kennedy round negotiators for the United States and the European Common Market clashed today over what the American Ambassador, William M. Roth, called the community's "nonexistent" agricultural offers.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Thursday the level it reached on Wednesday which was 98.

ALBANY, Calif., April 21 (AP)--Reason to Hail and Field Master rate as slight favorites for the 52d running of the California Derby at Golden Gate Fields tomorrow, with 14 expected in the battle of 3-year-olds.

MADISON, N.J., April 21 (AP)--Almost 100 seminary students staged a chanting, thumping sit-in at the Drew University Administration Building today and called for the resignation of Robert F. Oxnam as president of the Methodist theology school.

Reports that the six nations of the European Economic Community had joined together to slow or possibly thwart international negotiations on monetary reform represented a "regrettable misunderstanding," one of the leading participants in the world talks said yesterday.

COPENHAGEN, Denmark, April 21 (AP)--More than 600 banner-waving demonstrators protesting the military takeover in Greece marched through Copenhagen today and scuffled with the police and fur-hatted guardsmen drawn up outside the Royal Palace.
AUCKLAND, New Zealand, April 21--British pressure on. New Zealand to buy the British B.A.C-111 short-haul jet airliner instead of the American Boeing 737 is being greatly increased.

The city's upstate reservoirs gained 700 million gallons of water during the 24-hour period ended at 8 A.M. yesterday. This brought the reserves to 451.9 billion gallons, or 94.8 pet cent of capacity.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 21 (AP)--Superlative chipping and putting made the difference today as Phyllis (Tish) Preuss scored a 1-up victory over Connic Day and won her second North and South Amateur golf tournament in four years.

At Yankee Stadium, young men will parade today carrying, flags of 19 countries. They will be led by a coach who has instructed teams in North Borneo and watched by more than 300 fans from the United Nations plus perhaps, 10,000 more who will pay up to $5 for a seat.
WASHINGTON, April 21Constantine V. Kollias, chief prosecutor of the Greek Supreme Court, was installed as Premier in Athens today after the swift military take-over of power last night.

Joseph Presser, an American artist whose works are in the permanent collections of the Metropolitan Museum of Art and the Whitney Museum of Art, has drowned in the Scine in Paris, according to information received here yesterday. He was 57 years old.
MOBILE, Ala., April 21 (AP) --Operations at the port of Mobile were reported to be continuing on a near-normal basis today in the face of a strike that has idled all harbor tugs.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- Adam Clayton Powell will not claim his seat in Congress when his certificate of re-election is delivered to the House next week, but instead will wait for a Congressional invitation to be sworn in.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- An early settlement of a dispute over the dismissal of a liberal theology professor appeared possible tonight as striking students and teachers maintained a shutdown of all classes at the Catholic University of America.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- President Johnson will be accompanied by four prominent Americans when he flies to West Germany for the funeral Tuesday of former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- The Administration issued a strong denunciation tonight of a plan devised by Senator Charles H. Percy to encourage home ownership among the poor.
DETROIT, April 21--The United Automobile Workers union approved today a list of demands to present to the automobile manufacturers in new contract talks this summer.

BOSTON, April 21--Bill Rohr and Elston Howard, hero and villain in last Friday's little drama at Yankee Stadium, repeated their act in less spectacular but equally efficient fashion for 25,603 spectators at Fenway Park tonight as the Boston Red Sox defeated the New York Yankees. 6-1.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 20-- A well armed, well financed, and professionally, led Communist guerrilla, force that has killed 18 soldiers in Bolivia has posed a threat to this country's weak armed forces.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 21--Adm. Roy L. Johnson, commander of the United States Pacific Fleet, said tonight that at least eight more destroyers were needed for the war in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, April 21-- The South Vietnamese Foreign Minister called today for an increase in American bombing of North Vietnam. He said that the bombing should not be halted until the Hanoi Government promised formally to stop infiltrating troops into South Vietnam.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 21--A special session of the General Assembly began discussion today of a proposal for the United Nations to replace South Africa as the administering power of the territory of South-West Africa.

Unless there is a shift in sentiment, the House of Representatives appears likely to exclude Adam Clayton Powell from the seat to which the voters of New York's Eighteenth Congressional District have just re-elected him. THE exhibition of paintings by John Storrs (18851956), on view at the Downtown Gallery, 465 Park Avenue at 57th Street, is an unusual event. From mid-April to mid-May, the dogwood covers the hills, woods and fields with a blaze of white. Later, peach and apple orchards blanket the sloping land with pink and white, and rhododendrons bloom in heavy masses on rocky hillsides.

WHEN daylilies are mentioned, some gar- deners still think of the old tawny orange "mailbox flower." But this mediocre daylily (Hemerocalis fulva) is best left to spread along roadsides and into meadows.
The new French National Assembly had its first great debate last week.

MONTREAL, April 21 United States citizens who hope to enjoy Havana cigars or Cuban rum drinks at the Cuban pavilion at Expo 67 will be breaking a United States law if they purchase any goods of Cuban orgin.

Fox of Penllyn. The ceremony was performed in St. Paul's Episcopal Church, in Chestnut Hill, by the Rev. Tom Turney Edwards.

IN the deluge of legalistic and intricate papers on the future of communications, there occasionally emerge a few words of almost poetic simplicity that, in their lean imagery, touch both the mind and heart. In almost every case, the material used to do this job of keeping the moisture out and the heat in will be an exterior grade calking compound.

The Humane Society of New York will benefit May 2 from the 10th annual Spring Frolic, a buffet dinner dance at the Pierre. Mrs. J. Baird Magnus, Mrs. Robert Leighton Crawford, Mrs. Lawrence Phelps Tower and Mrs. Middleton Rose head the committee of patrons.

ARUBA LODGE, Kenya, April 22 Mrs. Glenn W. Ferguson, the wife of the United States Ambassador to Kenya, spent a night with her three children last week viewing African wildlife the hard way: in a car mired in mud in Kenya's huge Tsavo National Park.

VAIL, Colo. The snows may have begun to disappear from this ski-minded, mile-and-a-half-high Rocky Mountain community but all signs point to one of the busiest summers in the area's short history. Construction of about 500 new rental rooms is scheduled to be completed by December.

Roe Sr. of Flushing, Queens, for 20 years one of the most powerful Democratic leaders in New York and one of the dominant figures in the state party, died of a heart atack this morning at the Sheldon Hotel. He was 70 years old and lived at 35-72 167th Street in the Murray Hill section of Flushing.

TOLSTOY insisted that artistic communication was infectious, emotional: "Critics explain!" he protested. "What do they explain? The artist, if a real artist, has by his work transmitted to others the feeling he experienced. What is there, then, to explain?" This was part of Tolstoy's lifelong, unremitting war against Reason Reason that murders feeling by, dissection, screens man from his inborn knowledge of God, distracts him from his terror and so from his self's salvation.

SEVENTH Avenue's leading ladies, although hardly suffragettes, are strong advocates of women's right to be appropriately, attractively and even expensively dressed. Their campaign headquarters are spacious showrooms on Seventh Avenue with their names on the door. The fashion message varies from showroom to showroom but is rarely extremist; it bears down heavily on accepted concepts of elegance and good taste.

WYNNEWOOD, Pa., April 23 Miss Susan Jane Seiver, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore J. Seiver of Drexel Hill, was married here today to Pvt. Richard Alan Mandell. U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Herbert M. Mandel of Hewlett Harbor, L.I.

SYDNEY, Australia Despite an expected cutback of foreign investment in Australia from $1,008,000,000 in 1965-66 to about $560-million this financial year, economists do not expect any major retardation of Australian development.
And as we bid a fond farewell to grand living at the Greenbrier, we hear echoing from its elegant Georgian halls these parting words of Thomas B. Adams, president of Campbell-Ewald:
GENEVA, April 23--The Geneva cab driver asks whether there is some kind of party going on at the American mission. He is curious because that is where all his fares have gone today.
The Federal Aviation Agency has announced the reassignment of three top executives.

BATESVILLE, Miss., April 23 A majority of Negroes was elected yesterday by more than 2,600 poor Negro farmers, day laborers and white businessmen in a five-county election to direct a new migrant worker training program.
DETROIT, April 23 The stage finally has been set for the long-awaited showdown between Walter P. Reuther and George Meany over the future course of the labor movement.
About 350 former Peace Corps volunteers were interviewed over the weekend for teaching jobs in New York State.
TIMONIUM, Md., April 23 Ch. Silver Ridge Crackerjack, a 4-year-old pointer, was selected best in show from an entry of 1,272 dogs today at the Baltimore County Kennel Club show.
Miss Kathleen Joy Bernstein and Harvey Alan Heffner were married last evening at the Waldorf-Astoria by the Rev. Dr. Julius Mark, senior rabbi of Temule Emanu-El.
The track and field public expects near miracles week after week from such super-heroes as Jim Ryun and Randy Matson. Sometimes, such as last weekend, they can oblige.

Shulamit Ran, a pretty 19-year-old Israeli who has been a soloist with Leonard Bernstein and the New York Philharmonic in a televised Young People's Concert, made her local recital debut Saturday night at Carnegie Recital Hall.

A century from now Americans will be eating synthetic foods, living in domed cities and commuting to work along computerized traffic lanes if the crystal balls of leading engineering educators are flawless.

The Eastman Kodak Company attained record sales and earnings in the first quarter, but the rate of increase was less than in recent years, according to the weekend report of William S. Vaughan, chairman, and Louis K. Eilers, president. The executives said comparison was being made with exceptionally high results last year.

ST. LOUIS, April 23 (AP) A penalty-shot goal by Eric Hahn of Germany in the final minute gave the St. Louis Stars a 2-1 victory over the California Clippers today in a National Professional Soccer League game before a crowd announced as 34,129.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (UPI) Catholic University's chancellor, the Most Rev. Patrick A. O'Boyle, Archbishop of Washington, will meet tomorrow with the school's faculty and the young priest whose ouster has led to a classroom boycott by teachers and students.

WASHINGTON, April 23 Republican leaders increasingly believe that they have a good opportunity to capture the White House next year, but their optimism his shadowed by a fear that the party may frit ter away its early advantage.
WASHINGTON, April 23 Would you like to picket the White House, or the Capitol, or anything, but find you cannot spare the time! Let Proxy Pickets do the walking for you.
SINGAPORE, April 23--"I picked Singapore for R and R," an American soldier said, "because I heard it was quiet and not too many Americans come here."

MIDDLEBURY, Conn., April 23 F. Stillman Hyde, who retired three years ago as sales manager of the forging division of the Scovill Manufacturing Company, manufacturers of brass mill and fabricated products, died of cancer today at Waterbury Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived here.

DALLAS, April 23 (AP) Bert Yancey pulled a great shot out of the bag on the 18th hole today to finish with a fourunder-par 66 and take the lead at 203 in the $100,000 Greater Dallas open golf tournament.

The University of Colorado yesterday defeated Morris Harvey College of Charleston, W. Va., 250 to 120. on the National Broadcasting Company's "Collere Bowl" program. Morris Harvey defeated Louisiana State University the previous Sunday.
The most significant pressures on interest rates this week will come from Washington, not Wall Street.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 23 (UPI) Open-housing advocates rallied tonight but decided, for the first time in six nights, not to try to march in defiance of a court order banning afterdark demonstrations.

TORONTO, April 23 John H. Moore is Canada's corporate hero now for his success in sabotaging the attempt by the Jos. Schlitz Brewing Company of Milwaukee to take over Canada's thirdlargest brewer, John Labatt, Ltd., of London, Ont.

TO the genuine fan there is no bigger thrill than a glimpse of perfection in the execution of any play in any sport. One such play was unfolded a week ago in the Stanley Cup semi-final hockey series between the Toronto Maple Leafs and the Chicago Black Hawks. Television even sharpened the appreciation of its flawlessness by offering an instant replay and slow-motion action, thereby emphasizing the beautiful flow of the play's artistry.

WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) Personal income rose to record levels in all 50 states last year, with Washington State leading the expansion largely because of growth in the aerospace industry, it was reported today by the Commerce Department. It said that increases in personal income among the states ranged from 2 per cent for Idaho to 13.1 per cent for Washington State. Personal income nationally rose 8 per cent over 1965 to $575.89billion.
Eastern Orthodox Christians around the world marked Palm Sunday yesterday in preparation for their Easter next Sunday.
A civil rights leader warned yesterday that "there seems to be a real plan underfoot" to cause racial violence in New York City this summer.

HANOVER, N.H., April 23 A two-day Dartmouth College conference on the economic problems of southeastern Canada and northern New England ended today with plans under way for a program of regional cooperation.

PRINCETON, N.J., April 23 Radcliffe won two of the three races today for a total of five of eight in the weekend series and captured the sailing championship in the Tiger Bowl Regatta for the seven sister schools.
The port's towboat industry last week established a New York Harbor Panel to maintain liaison with the Coast Guard on matters of mutual interest.
SCARSDALE, N.Y., April 23 Gone Flyin, the last of a long line of mounts developed by the late Ben O'Meara, captured the open jumper championship tonight at the Boulder Brook Horse Show.

Two high-ranking Soviet intelligence officers left New York aboard an Air France jetliner last night after a cloakand-dagger delay that seemed like something straight out of a novel by Ian Fleming or may be Len Deighton.

The Eleo Pomare Dance Company offered the premiere of Mr. Pomare's "Las Desenamoradas" Saturday evening at the Kaufmann Concert Hall of the Young Men's and Women's Hebrew Association, Lexington Avenue and 92d Street.

LONDON, April 23--An official at the Athens telephone exchange, presumably a censor, would not allow correspondents of The New York Times to telephone their dispatches to the London bureau of their paper tonight.

MONTROSE, N.Y., April 23 A church more than half a century older than the United States celebrated its 250th birthday here today with costumes, a birthday cake and a banquet in the style of the Dutch settlers with everybody contributing something to the menu.

SEOUL, South Korea, April 23 Posun Yun, former President of South Korea, asserted today that he would regain that office from President Chung Hee Park "if fair voting was held" in the presidential election scheduled for May 3.
There was hardly a thing to warm the heart of a true Met fan during the season's first double-header at Shea Stadium yesterday.
CHICAGO, April 23 (AP) Norm Gigon's first major league hit a three-run homer in the fifth inning helped the Chicago Cubs score a 7-3 victory over Pittsburgh today.
MONTREAL There is a genuine exhilaration about dining in this French-oriented city, a place where people think, talk and care about what they eat.
LOS ANGELES, April 23 (AP) Ron Fairly drove in five runs with a double and a homer today to pace the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 9-3 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Monday, April 24 United States Marines have landed in an area of northern South Vietnam in which enemy pressure has been building up steadily. In the air war, United States Air Force Phantom jets flew through heavy antiaircraft fire yesterday to bomb a major steel mill near Hanoi for the 11th time. The pilots reported having shot down one MIG-21. They said they had probably destroyed another MIG.
BUTLER, Pa., April 23 Norbert S. Garblsch, a retired industrialist and banker, died yesterday in his home here. His age was 69.
PARIS, April 23 President de Gaulle has refused to let the so-called Vietnam War Crimes Tribunal be held in France because he feels it would be a travesty of justice.

Paul Blakemore, who retired in 1962 as advertising manager of the John Blair Company, advertising representatives, died on Thursday night, apparently of a heart attack, while walking from a neighborhood restaurant to his home at 799 Park Avenue. He was 68 years old.
Ludwig Misch, a musicologist, conductor, teacher and an authority on Beethoven, died of cancer on Saturday in his home at 60 West 78th Street. He was 79 years old.
BABYLON, L. I, April 23 (AP) The police said a 47year-old-man committed suicide early today by smashing his station wagon into a bridge abutment after setting his house afire.

City Budget Director Frederick O'R. Hayes said yesterday that the city's $5.2-billion expense budget for for 1967-68 was in delicate balance and that, unless solutions are found, "a major fiscal gap next year is obviously clearly in the offing."

In these days of thriving Communist polycentrism, it has not been easy for Moscow to convene even such a mini-summit as the meeting of European Communist leaders opening today in Czechoslovakia's Karlovy Vary. The months of Kremlin persuasion and arm twisting required to make this conference possible would hardly have been justified if all that were involved was a discussion on European security.
Dr. David Ulmar, a specialist in chest diseases, died Saturday in Roosevelt Hospital, His office was at 207 East 63d Street.

FAIR HAVEN, Vt., April 23 (AP) Mrs. Amy Bassett of Hulett's Landing, N.Y., who served in World War I as assistant director of military relief for the American Red Cross, died yesterday at a nursing home here at the age of 86. She was the widow of Prentice Bassctt, a retired naval captain.
ATHENS, April 23 The regime that seized control of Greece in a coup d'etat Friday said today that it did so to prevent a revolution fomented by former Premier George Papandreou.

The American Broadcasting Company last night signed Jack Paar for a special guest appearance on tonight's "Joey Bishop Show." The last-minute move was an attempt to steal some of the thunder from this evening's return of Johnny Carson to the "Tonight" show on the National Broadcasting Company network.

MOSCOW, Monday, April 24 The Soviet Union's new manned spacecraft, Soyuz 1, continued circling the earth today with its lone crewman amid reports that another large spaceship would be launched to attempt a rendezvous in orbit.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., April 23 Conservationists and birdwatchers on eastern Long Island report that the number of ospreys, a majestic bird that returns every spring to nest, is the smallest in years.
MARTINSVILLE, Va., April 23 (AP) Richard Petty captured the 12th annual Virginia 500 stock car race today scoring the first major NASCAR victory for Plymouth this year. Petty won $4,540.
The resignation of John W. Gardner as president of the Carnegie Corporation of New York, with his appointment as consultant on leave of absence, was announced yesterday.
ATHENS, April 23 A state of siege has been in force since Friday morning, following the suspension of 11 articles of the Constitution in the Greek Army's take-over of the Government.

PHILADELPHIA, April 23--In a fourth quarter that combined spirited resilience and frantic failure, the San Francisco Warriors produced a 117-109 victory today and delayed, if not discouraged, the Philadelphia 76ers from winning the National Basketball Association championship playoffs.

BOSTON, April 23 Miss Patricia Goodrich Brown, daughter of Justice Matthew Brown and Mrs. Brown of Brookline, was married here today to David Kenneth Specter, son of Dr. and Mrs. Louis Specter of Brooklyn, New York, and Woodmere, L.I.
BELFAST, Me., April 21 A panel from the Department of the Interior served notice yesterday on the Penobscot Bay area to reduce the pollution of shellfish beds by 1970 or face Federal penalties.

The chairman of the Metropolitan Commuter Transportation Authority said yesterday that the New York-New Jersey area had reached "a point of imminent crisis" because there were not enough airports for jet planes.
Mrs. Alice Damrosch Kiaer, a former skiing champion and an early promoter of competitive skiing in this country, died yesterday in her home at 170 East 71st Street. She was 74 years old.

Rent Commissioner Frederic S. Berman said yesterday that a six-month survey by his department showed that 6 per cent of the tenants living in rent-controlled apartments in New York City were being overcharged.

Great Britain is about to begin a test with worldwide implications of the capacity of a national labor federation to act as an anti-inflation policeman over the wage settlements of its affiliated unions.

The New York Times Company had a consolidated net income last year of $9,355,469, or $4.28 a common share, the 1966 annual report disclosed yesterday. This compared with net earnings of $5,131,301, or $2.25 a share, in 1965. The report noted that the 1965 figures excluded two special credits totaling $1,883,174, or 92 cents a share.

The recommendations of President Johnson's special mediation board in the railroad strike threat represent a generous even overgenerous basis for resolving the dispute over higher wages for skilled shop workers. If the six craft unions and their employers persist in their initial coldness to the proposals, the White House and Congress will be obliged to mandate a solution through a new exercise of legislative compulsion the third in the railroads since 1963.
Where cocktail glasses once tinkled and elegantly dressed patrons dined at leisure, stock clerks will bustle amid the closely shelved supplies of a chain variety store.

HOUSTON, April 23 (UPI) John Newcombe defeated his fellow Australian, Tony Roohe, in straight sets to win the championship of the 33d River Oaks invitation tennis tournament today.
DETROIT, April 23 (AP) Zoilo Versalles's ninth-inning triple drove in two runs and gave the Minnesota Twins a 4-2 victory over the Detroit Tigers today.
WASHINGTON, April 23 William Parker, a newspaperman for more than 50 years, died today, apparently of a heart attack, at Doctors Hospital. He was about 75 years old and lived in Rumson, N.J.

THIS has been fairy-tale week In American ballet. Britain's Royal Ballet offered "Cinderella" and "The Sleeping Beauty," and then the Dancers' Workshop of San Francisco topped it all off at the Hunter College Playhouse on Saturday night with an event called "Parades anti Changes." It reminded me of yet another fairy story "The Emperor's New Clothes."

BOSTON, April 23 (AP) Outdated blood that can no longer be used for transfusion is being turned into a gamma globulin preparation that fights tetanus without the potentially dangerous side effects of antitotanus serum derived from horses.

RYE, N.Y., April 23 Mrs. Joseph W. Appleton has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Mary Wheeler Appleton, to Robert Hewitt Hallowell, son of Mr. said Mrs. Thomas J. Hallowell Jr. of Northport, L.I., and Nantucket, Mass.
BONN, April 23 Leaders of the non-Communist world, headed by President Johnson, began assembling here tonight to pay tribute to Konrad Adenauer.

The nation's daily newspapers were described yesterday as in a state of "unprecedented economic vigor," but with "an alarming increase" in strikes in the last year and... "no sign of any abatement" in labor tensions.

PARIS, April 23 Mrs. Claude Blancpain, a heroine of the French Resistance who had entertained Svetlana Alliluyeva during her stay in Switzerland, was killed in an automobile accident Friday, the day Stalin's daughter arrived in New York.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 23 (AP) A village chief running for re-election was assassinated in Bienhoa Province by the Vietcong today during the fourth round of South Vietnam's village council elections.

GETTING a horse ready for the Kentucky Derby might be compared to preparing a crepe suzette. Each operation demands quality ingredients, careful blending, delicate timing and a great deal of luck. Success means a blazing delight, instead of an also-ran pancake.

PAWLING, N.Y., April 23 William R. Clay, a writer and a former school service and international advertising representative of The New York Times, died today, apparently of a heart attck, in his home here. He was 52 years old.
The nation's leading chain store organizations increased their sales in March for the 70th consecutive month, according to a survey completed over the weekend by The New York Times.
PASADENA, Calif., April 23 (AP)--Surveyor 3 halted operations today after four days of picture taking on the moon.

Dr. James Allen Colston told students at his inauguration yesterday as president of Bronx Community College that threequarters of them would live to work at jobs that didn't yet exist.
The Albert Einstein College of Medicine announced yesterday the four winners of the Einstein Commemorative Awards for 1967 in art, science, philanthropy and humanities.

CLEVELAND, Apri1 23 (UPI) Marcelino Lopez scored on a ninth-inning throwing error by Max Alvis to give the California Angels a 2-1 victory over the Cleveland Indians today. Bobby Knoop's tie breaking single led the Angels to a 9-6 triumph in the 12-inning first game of the double-header.
HAMPTON BAYS, L.I., April 23 Two brothers drowned this morning when their rowboat was swamped in the choppy waters of Tiana Bay, south of here.

DETROIT, April 23 The General Motors Corporation reported yesterday that its automobile sales in the middle third of April climbed slightly from a year before, and called the April upturn "most encouraging."

The argument of the Johnson Administration in favor of Federal safety standards for natural-gas pipelines is based on the enormous potential for disaster inherent in the present system. Pipelines extend over 800,000 miles in the United States, they are continuing to grow, and they have been built through many heavily populated areas. Power Commission can investigate pipeline accidents but cannot compel the private companies to carry out its recommendations.
ALEXANDRIA, La., April 23 (AP) An official of Continental Southern Trailways said tonight that an agreement had been reached between the bus line and a striking union.

JERUSALEM (Israel), April 23 Senator Edward W. Brooke came to the Hebrew University campus as a visitor today and was made to feel at home, but in a way unintended by his hosts.

Four members of an East Harlem family were killed yesterday when fire swept their third-floor tenement. The family's only survivor, a 3-year-old girl, was thrown to safety across an airshaft in a rescue that was described as an "exceptional feat."

Arex Savadjian, a soloist with the Bucharest Opera for more than 20 years, and a newcomer to the United States, gave her first song program here last night at Carnegle Recital Hall.

Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr., fresh from a political victory in making Florida a two-party state, has set about quietly to seek the Republican nomination for Vice President next year, an associate said last week.

Hallmark Cards, Inc., which has annual sales estimated at $120-million, plans to go into book publishing. Donald J. Hall, president of the greeting-cards company, said in Kansas City, Mo., yesterday that the first 24 books, Hallmark Editions, would appear Aug. 1.

"This summer we will pray for snow on weekends, or at least for heavy rain," Mrs. George Voskovec said. She was sitting behind closed windows in her six-room apartment overlooking Washington Square and a long line of horn-honking traffic.
Adm. John Harllee, chairman of the Federal Maritime Commission, has announced that Chief Justice Earl Warren will swear in James Foster Fanseen as a member of the commission in Washington tomorrow.
ROME, Monday, April 24 (UPI) Enrico Cardinal Dante, prefect of pontifical ceremonics under three popes, died of cancer today. He was 82 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 23 (AP) The vote of teamsters' union members on a proposed national contract was running against acceptance in early returns last night.
RIDGEFIELD, N. J., April 23--A Public Service foreman was killed and two of his crew were critically injured here today in an explosion that demolished the Ridgefield Restaurant Diner.

LAWRENCEVILLE, N.J., April 23 Sidney Morgan Shea, a retired history teacher of the Lawrencville School, who resided hare and in Hyannis Port, Mass., died today in the University of Pennsylvania Hospital in Philadelphia. His age was 68.

TRENTON, April 23 Mario Andretti was the whole show today in the 150-mile championship car race before a crowd of 20,000 here.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., April 23 The 1967 DamienDutton Award was presented today to Dr. Howard A. Rusk. director of the Institute of Rehabilitation Medicine at New York University Medical Center for his pioneering work in rehabilitation. The presentation was made by the Damien-Dutton Society at its annual luncheon at the Rutgers Univercity Commons.

CLEVELAND, April 23 This city has decided to put down its Negro street gangs the young vandals, arsonists and looters whose repeated acts of rage have left few persons here opposing harsh countermeasures.

Five hundred to 1,000 cars will be sunk off Atlantic Beach, L.I., to create an artificial fishing reef as a Federal-state demonstration project, Senator Jacob K. Javits announced last night.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 23 The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. called today for an "escalation of our opposition to the war in Vietnam" as he helped inaugurate a nationwide peace effort called Vietnam Summer.

ARA PARSEGHIAN'S call for a moratorium on the new college football punting rule may not fall on deaf ears, but the rule won't be changed between now and next January. It will go into effect with the first intercollegiate football game of 1967. The Notre Dame coach objects to the rule, contending it will cause injuries. He said some injuries have occurred during the Irish spring football practice that is now under way.
Margaret Hansen left for Nigeria yesterday. She took with her half a dozen pairs of overalls, some sheets, an old iron pan and a herd of cattle.
