When Hedley Woodhouse, the jockey, drove his car into Aqueduct race track yesterday morning, it was hailing and the temperature was 35 degrees. Earlier there had been snow flurries and later there was hard rain through the first race.
The new cardiac-care unit at the Lenox Hill Hospital will benefit from the hospital's 10th annual spring dinner dance May 4 in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom.

DALLAS, April 24 (AP)-- E. Roland Harriman, the chairman of the American Red Cross, told the organization's national convention today that fund raising efforts were at their highest point since World War II.
The New York Legal Aid Society, the nation's oldest, opened its third neighborhood office yesterday, this one in the Hunts Point section of the Bronx.

ELLENVILLE, N.Y., April 24--A drifter who was tried, convicted and sentenced to a year in jail within three and a half hours of being arrested last Thursday will be given an opportunity to change his plea to not guilty.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 23 --The Government is seeking to engage the Soviet Union as an ally against Cuban-backed guerrillas who are active in Colombia.
DETROIT, April 24--New car sales nudged above last year's levels in the middle third of April, with three of the four automakers reporting gains.

TEL AVIV, Israel, April 24 (Reuters)--Two Israeli journalists started a campaign today to abolish a law under which they were sentenced to a year's imprisonment at a secret trial for publishing false information liable to harm state security.
Silence, creatively used, can be golden, as Merle Marsicano and Dance Company demonstrated last night at the Village Theater in "Images in the Open."

NORTH TARRYTOWN, N.Y., April 24--Mrs. Helen Bard Nixon, a former radio and choir soloist, died today at Phelps Memorial Hospital. She was 74 years bid and lived at Dobbs Ferry. She was the wife of Allen Nixon, a retired insurance broker.
ATHENS, April 24--The new Greek regime announced today that King Constantine would preside over a Cabinet meeting "in the course of the week."

The Texas Eastern Transmission Corporation achieved record earnings in the March quarter, B.D. Goodrich, president, told stockholders at yesterday's annual meeting in Wilmington, Del. He added that it was "only reasonable to expect that 1967 will be another year of record earnings."
Du Pont rose sharply yesterday, and that was about enough to put the stock market into new-high ground for the year.
The election of Justin S. Dunn as president was announced yesterday in Tarrytown, N.Y., by E. W. Axe Co., an investment company and mutual fund sponsor.
BONN, April 24--President Johnson expressed his sympathy today to the family of Colonel Komarov and to the people of the Soviet Union.
ALBANY, April 24--Miss Patricia Francis Ryan and George Biro of New York plan to marry there June 3.
NASHVILLE, April 24 (UPI)--Continental Trailways buses began rolling again today after being idle for 10 days while the Amalgamated Transit Workers Union fought for a new contract.
Prices declined sharply yesterday on the London Stock Exchange, registering the steepest daily drop in some eight months.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 24--Jewish servicemen in Vietnam sat down to Seder feasts tonight to mark the start of Passover.
Woodrow Chan, who pleaded guilty of attempted forgery in a plot to collect $18,000 illegally unemployment benefits, was sentenced yesterday to one to three years in Sing Sing.
The Columbus Line announced yesterday that it was withdrawing from the River Plate Brazil Conferences aft er 10 years of membership.
LOS ANGELES, April 24 (AP)--Lou Johnson's run-scoring single capped a two-run rally in the 13th inning and gave the Los Angeles Dodgers a 6-5 victory over the St. Louis Cards tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 24--The Inter-American Development Bank has raised the possibility that nations granted loans be required to spend the proceeds in countries that make "satisfactory" contributions to the bank's capital resources.
PINEHURST, N.C. April 24 (AP)--Ward Wettlaufer, the defending champion, was eliminated from the first round of the North and South amateur golf tournament today by Jay Baumgardner on the 20th hole.
BRUSSELS, April 24--The $12-million Brussels Hilton opened today, 10 days ahead of schedule, with a puddle in the thickly carpeted lobby because of hasty work by plumbers.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- The Johnson Administration, which has repeatedly explained its reasons for not attacking North Vietnam's MIG airfields, offered no explanation for the shift in policy that led to today's attacks on two MIG bases.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)--The Defense Department identified today 58 servicemen who had died in combat in Vietnam.
GENEVA, April 24--Svetlana Alliluyeva spent nearly three of her six weeks in Switzerland in a Roman Catholic convent, the Swiss Government disclosed today.

Julius Gassner, maitre d'hotel at the New York Athletic Club for 25 years until he retired in 1954, died Sunday at Deepdale Hospital in Little Neck, Queens. He was 76 years old and resided at 219-03 89th Avenue, Queens Village.

PHILADELPHIA, April 24 (AP)--Cecil Moore, a rights leader, lost his fight today in the Pennsylvania Supreme Court to stop the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People from breaking up its local chapter into five branches.

Earnings of the Allied Chemical Corporation in the first quarter dropped about 10 per cent to $18,400,000, or 67 cents a share, from $20,113,955, or 74 cents a share a year before, Chester M. Brown, chairman and chief executive officer, reported yesterday.
HALLANDALE, Fla., April 24 (AP)--Caesar Stable's Funny Valentine scored a front-running victory in the closing feature at Gulfstream Park as Florida's winter racing season ended today.

The nation's news media are being treated in a "very arbitrary" and "callous and offensive" manner by the Federal Communications Commission, Wes Gallagher, general manager of The Associated Press, charged yesterday.

LOME, Togo, April 24 (UPI)--A guard tried today to assassinate Lieut. Col. Etienne Eyadema, the President of Togo. He fired a rifle at a range of 12 feet, but the President escaped with a wound on his left thumb.

EDWARD CHARLES (WHITEY) FORD will make his third start of the 1967 baseball season for the New York Yankees today, when they open a two-game series against the Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadium. Elston Gene Howard, possessor of a brand new "Spoiler Trophy," will catch.
TOKYO, April 25 (AP)-- Chairman Mao Tse-tung, in a rare public appearance, has met with leaders of provincial and city revolutionary committees, the official Hsinhua press agency reported today.

Assemblyman Daniel M. Kelly received the Liberal party endorsement yesterday for the (countywide vacancy on the Civil Court in Manhattan. The Liberal party action was seen enhancing Mr. Kelly's chances of winning the Democratic designation for the post.

The death of the Russian cosmonaut Vladimir Komarov brings a shared sorrow to Americans, who saw three of our own astronauts die just three months ago. The dangers that astronauts faced were sensed by everybody, but the presence of death puts a special emphasis on the risks being daily run.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 24--A Saigon businessman was arrested today on charges of accepting "kickbacks" from American manufacturers he represented here and of illegally depositing the payments in a Swiss bank account.
Despite a rise in sales, net income of the Republic Steel Corporation declined in the first quarter this year to $16,659,233, or $1.05 a share, from $18,302,810, or $1.16 a share, in the 1966 period.

GENEVA, April 24--The United States has tightened up its draft of the proposed treaty banning the spread of nuclear weapons to prevent nonuclear nations from gaining exemption to the pact by exploding a nuclear device between now and whenever the treaty is approved by the Geneva Disarmament Conference.

In his speech at an Associated Press luncheon here yesterday Gen. William C. Westmoreland probably dispelled any lingering notions in the minds of Republican professionals or the socalled "Eastern Establishment" that he could be the Moses who might lead them out of the political wilderness next year.

NEW York bridge enthusiasts are losing a valuable monopoly this year. This city has been the host to the world championship on every one of the six occasions that such an event has been held in North America, but the 1967 Bermuda Bowl contest will be held in Miami Beach, between May 26 and June 4.

BONN, April 24--West Germany will pay farewell to its first Chancellor tomorrow in what is expected to be the biggest and most elaborate German funeral since that of Paul von Hindenburg, the last President of the Weimar Republic, who died in 1934.

The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. joined leaders of various cultural and religious organizations yesterday in announcing the formation of a group demanding that the United States end the bombing of North Vietnam "now and without conditions."
WASHINGTON, April 24-- The Treasury bill rate dipped sharply at today's action to the lowest point since early in November, 1964, the Treasury disclosed tonight.
In the early 1900's, Wall Street welcomed the high-school dropout. In fact, quite a few prominent brokers started as teen-age runners, office boys or clerks.
VILLANOVA, Pa., April 24 (UPI)--Alex Bell resigned today after seven years as head football coach at Villanova University to become a scout for a National Football League organization.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- The Supreme Court let stand today the jail sentence of two men who were convicted on the strength of evidence seized illegally from former New York financier Lowell M. Birrell.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- The United States Commissioner of Education, Harold Howe 2d, said today that Southerners would shortchange their states if they voted for a Republican school aid proposal.
WHEN Mrs. Diederik van Hamel wants to get away from it all, she walks into the next room.

ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., April 24--An Indian tribal representative told a Senate subcommittee today that the antipoverty program had "brought a sense of dignity, responsibility, enthusiasm and desire to people who were almost completely without hope in the depths of poverty."
TRENTON, April 24 (AP)-- legislation giving Gov. Richard J. Hughes emergency powers during an air pollution alert was passed unanimously by the Senate today.
TOKYO--A Soviet hydraulic engineer walked into the the United States Embassy last night and requested political asylum. United States officials said today that his case was "under consideration."
The establishment of a Health Careers Center by the City University was proposed yesterday by Dr. Albert H. Bowker, chancellor of the university.
LONDON, April 24 (AP)-- J. Paul Getty, the millionaire who supplies the oil that keeps millions of British cars moving, advised motorists today how to get more miles for their money.
GRIFFIN, Ga., April 24-- Four white youths invaded a Negro church service last night, robbed it and took as hostages two 18-year-old worshippers whom they later raped.
LONDON, April 24--The profitable saga of James Bond is to be resumed where the late Ian Fleming left it off.

DUBLIN, April 24 (AP)-- The simmering row between Ireland's farmers and the Government flared again today when police arrested 20 farmers for nonpayment of fines. The fines were imposed in January after 30,000 farmers had blocked roads outside Dublin with trucks, cars and tractors to press their claim for increased government grants and subsidies.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 24 --Leaders of the open housing demonstrations here turned their attention today to the city's affluent East Side.

The Union Carbide Corporation's first-quarter net income declined to $45,089,000, or 75 cents a share, from $61,712,000, or $1.02 a share, earned in the initial three months last year, Birny Mason Jr., chairman, reported yesterday, Sales dipped to $521,373,000 from $530,521,000.
First-quarter net income of Atlantic Richfield Company of $32,526,000, equal to $2.16 a share, was reported yesterday by the Philadelphia oil and natural gas producer.
Austin N. Heller, the Air Pollution Control Commissioner, said yesterday that he intended to close incinerations in apartment house that fail to meet new standards that become effective on May 20.

EAST NORWICH, L.I., April 24--Tom Nieporte, a golf professional who is house hunting, was given a welcome home reception today as 155 members of the Metropolitan Professional Golfers Association greeted him at the Pine Hollow Country Club.
CULVER CITY, Calif., April 24 (AP)--Tom Conway, the suave hero-detective of the "Falcon" movie series, died in a hospital on Saturday of a liver ailment. He was 63 years old.

BRILLIANTLY powerful and provocative documen tary on the question of whether Germany can emerge from the darkness of its past was offered last night by the National Educational Television Journal on Channel 13.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 24 (AP)--Using a single rocket, the Air Force plans tomorrow to orbit five unmanned satellites, including two to act as space sentries helping to enforce the nuclear test ban treaty.

BLOOMFIELD, Conn., April 24--Mrs. Samuel Ferguson Jr. has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Marian Rand Ferguson, to Robert Henry Abzug. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Seymour W. Abzug of Great Neck. L.I.

MADRID, April 24--An authoritative interpretation of the meaning of Spain's order forbidding all flying over Spanish territory and adjacent territorial waters in the Gibraltar area indicated today that Madrid was not planning to close all of the Bay of Algeciras to British air traffic.
Margin-account customers stepped up their activity in March, a month when trading volume climbed to record levels on the New York Stock Exchange and stock prices generally rose.

The New York Generals, who gained their first National Professional Soccer League triumph Saturday at Yankee Stadium after two losses on the road, will have an added incentive for victory in future games.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., sought to establish today that it runs a very poor third among the three television networks and therefore needs the help that it believes a merger with International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation would provide.

The Rev. Paul H. Scaer, pastor of Trinity Lutheran Church, 18th Avenue and East Eighth Street, Brooklyn, died on Saturday at the new University Hospital of the Downstate Medical Center in Brooklyn. He was 68 years old and lived at 1121 Ditmas Avenue, Brooklyn.
Edward Francis Jordan of 105 East 38th Street, a customs attorney, died yesterday in the New York Hospital at the age of 77.

THE first time, quite a number of years ago, that I saw a fisherman cutting and pushing pussy willow limbs into a stream bank, I thought he was building some kind of fence. It didn't seem sensible, for a weak cat could have pushed them over.

NEW ORLEANS, April 24 (UPI)--The Saturday Evening Post said today that the office of District Attorney Jim Garrison had "prompted" a key wit ness, Perry R. Russo, under hypnosis, and drugs to describe a meeting in 1963 at which the assassination of President Kennedy was allegedly plotted.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)--The Commerce Department announced today it would build a multi-million dollar oceanographic laboratory on Virginia Key in the Miami area.

RED BANK, N.J., April 24-- Mr. and Mrs. Louis King Timolat have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence King Timolat, to Richard Turner Short of Virginia Beach. He is the son of Mrs. George H. Parker of Franklin, Va., and the late Richard Turner Short of Petersburg, Va. A May wedding is planned.

DALLAS, April 24 (UPI)-- Bert Yancey scrambled to a one-over par 71 today and nursed his one-stroke lead to a $20,000 victory in the $100,000 Greater Dallas open golf tournament with a 72-hole total of 274.

The Tulane Drama Review, the theatrical quarterly pub lished for the last 10 years by Tulane University of Louisiana, will move to New York this summer if certain financial arrangements are completed.

WHITE PLAINS, April 24-- Francisco Lafontaine wrote to his brother, Miguel, in Puerto Rico recently and told him not to bother coming up to Westchester for a seasonal gardening job this year--it was too hard finding a place to live.

American planes yesterday bombed two military airfields in North Vietnam for the first time in the war, indicating a new stage in the widening air war. Later they attacked a rail yard 2 miles from the center of Hanoi and a transformer site seven miles out. The raids were seen as part of an increasing effort to help force Hanoi to negotiate.
WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)--Three runs were scored on an error by Ken Harrelson with two out in the eighth inning to give the Boston Red Sox a 7-4 victory over the Washington Senators tonight.

The Mayor's office, the police and the District Attorneys of New York's five boroughs made plans at City Hall yesterday to stop the smuggling of untaxed cigarettes. Illegal sales of the cigarettes are reported to cost the city and state about $60million a year in lost revenues.

KARLOVY VARY, Czechoslovakia, April 24 (Reuters)-- Leonid I. Brezhnev, Soviet party leader, told a European Communist conference here today that the United States Sixth Fleet must leave its permanent stations in the Mediterranean Sea.

DJIBOUTI, French Somaliland, April 24--This East African territory, which is known in French as "the French Coast of the Somalis," will soon change its name for political reasons, the Governor announced today.
Clark R. Wilcox, a real estate broker, died Friday in Doctors Hospital. He was 86 years old and lived at 155 East 55th Street.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- Man's talent for constantly creating new menaces to himself is illustrated again by the oil slicks that have polluted Cornwall, Cape Cod and Nantucket. This summer, for the first time since World War II, people who want to go swimming will have to contend with the possibility of being smothered in errant sludge.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- Although March expenditures were higher than expected, defense spending in the current fiscal year will turn out within $1-billion of the estimate made last January, a Congressional committee was told today.

TRENTON, April 24--Gov. Richard J. Hughes signed into law tonight a controversial measure that raises unemployment compensation benefits and extends them to workers who have been on strike for at least six weeks.
PARIS, April 24 (Reuters) --The Archbishop of Canterbury, Dr. Michael Ramsey, called today for more joint worship between Roman Catholics and Anglicans as a step toward Christian unity.

The vigorous diversification program of Hazel Bishop, Inc., has prompted directors to propose a change of name to Bishop Industries, Inc., Morton Edell, president, told a news conference here yesterday in the Hotel Americana.

Thomas J. Watson Jr., chairman of the International Business Machines Corporation, told the annual meeting yesterday at the Coliseum that most of the problems with the company's System 360 computer line had been brought within manageable proportions.

The credit markets are approaching one of those infrequent tests whose outcome should tell a great deal about the likely cost of borrowing for weeks to come. Late tomorrow afternoon, the Treasury is slated to announce the terms on which it will refund some $9.7-billion of its notes that come due on May 15.

JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 24--The Chinese charge d'affaires, Yao Ten-shah, and the consul general, Hsu Yen, were accused today of hurting Indonesian-Chinese relations and were given five days to leave the country.

BEL AIR, Md., April 24--Ch. Coughton Sungable of Perryacre, a faun brindle Pekingese owed by Mrs. Ralph West and Mrs. Elaine Rigden of Livonia, Mich., was selected best in show today in a field of 890 dogs at the Harford County Kennel Club's 16th show. The victory was the 4 year old's 44th best in show and his 126th group.

The printers lengthened their shop meetings yesterday to a total of five hours on each shift at The Daily News as the union sought to increase the economic pressure on the newspaper in the current contract dispute.
Earl D. Babst, retired board chairman of the American Sugar Refining Company, died Sunday at a nursing home in Greenwich, Conn. He was 96 years old and had lived at 580 Park Avenue.
PASADENA, Calif., April 24 (UPI)--The Surveyor 3 space craft, working in the cook shade of an eclipse, photographed the earth and Venus today.

ST. LOUIS, April 24--Mr. and Mrs. James C. Burkham of St. Louis and Biddeford Pool, Me., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Douglass Burkham, to William A. Borders Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Borders.

Governor Rockefeller signed a bill into law yesterday providing for New York's membership in a proposed Mid-Atlantic States Air Pollution Control Compact with four other states and the Federal Government.
BONN, April 24--President Johnson discreetly mixed international politics with his mission of condolence and official mourning in the West German capital today.

HOUSTON, April 24 (AP)-- Tony Perez's three-run homer in the fourth-inning gave the Cincinnati Reds a 3-1 victory over the Houston Astros tonight, extending the Reds' winning streak to five games and running the Astros' losing string to eight.

PORT WASHINGTON, L.I., April 24--Harold Ferguson, who retired in February as business manager and controller of Newsday after guiding the newspaper's finances through its period of greatest growth, died tonight in his home at 10 Hawthorne Avenue. He was 60 years old.

TEANECK, N.J., April 24-- Four teen-age girls, including two sisters, were killed last night when the automobile in which they were riding hurtled out of control off Teaneck Road and crashed into a concreteblock office building.

PALERMO, Sicily, April 20-- The Sicilian Mafia, breeding ground for American "Cosa Nostra" gangsterism, has been largely driven out of organized big-time criminal violence by Draconian government action in the last four years.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, April 25--Bidding farewell to South Vietnam today, Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge declared that continued allied military successes were giving the country "a chance to evolve towards stability and constitutional government."
The American Stock Exchange seesawed yesterday and ended on the downside.
WASHINGTON, April 24--International monetary negotiations resumed today in the nextto-last phase before the annual meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Rio De Janeiro in September.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 24 (AP)--John Cottrell of Australia eliminated Canada's No. 1 Davis Cup player, Keith Carpenter, in the first round of the British hard courts tennis championships today. The scores were 6-2, 5-7, 6-4, 1-6, 6-2.

Howard Komives, backcourt man who led the Knickerbockers in assists last season with 401, has signed his contract for the 1967-68 season with the New York club in the National Basketball Association. It will be the fourth season in professional basketball for Komives, who was the Knicks' second draft choice in 1964.

HAMPTON, Va., April 24 (AP)--Stokely Carmichael, a "black power" leader, urged students at Hampton Institute today to defy the draft and was angrily challenged by a Negro student enrolled in the college's R.O.T.C. program.

The best hope for a peaceful and moderate resolution of the crisis in Greece now rests with King Constantine. The young monarch may indeed be the only hope for averting large-scale bloodletting, despite his blunders that helped build the crisis.
Dr. Wong Lin Ken gave details yesterday of his government's new campaign to attract foreign industries to Singapore.

Johnny Carson, missing from the television screen since a strike of the American Federation of Televlsion and Radio Artists began early this month, returned to the National Broadcasting Company's "Tonight" show last night in a performance taped here earlier.

Three national agencies of the United Church of Christ yesterday petitioned the Federal Communications Commission to withhold licenses from radio and television stations that discriminate unfairly in employment practices.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 24 --The Philadelphia 76ers made a magnificent fourth-period comeback tonight to defeat the San Francisco Warriors, 125-122, and win the National Basketball Association championship.
Mrs. Adam Clayton Powell has written that her husband "told me once he was not really a Negro."
A change of mind by Alex Herrero, a co-owner, has put Dawn Glory back in the Kentucky Derby, to be run May 6.

Dr. William Andrew Irwin, an Old Testament scholar and emeritus professor of Old Testament Language and Literature at the University of Chicago and Southern Methodist University, died Saturday in the University Nursing Home in Wheaton, Md., at the age of 82.

MONTREAL--Although Montreal has numerous specialty restaurants--international, sea food houses and the like--the principal establishments are generally French or French Canadian. The French menus are almost invariably more elaborate and more interesting than one is special to in New York, and the French Canadian menus have an interest all their own.
PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., April 29 (AP)--Frank Overton, co-star on last year's television series, "12 O'Clock High," died in his home today, apparently of a heart attack. He was 49 years-old.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- On some solemn platforms he would be introduced as the Rev. Dr. Charles Edward Curran, assistant professor of sacred theology at the Catholic University of America. But on campus, even the students call him "Charlie."

THOSE to whom the poetry written since the last war is a tangle of strange growths, a confusion of styles, voices and subject matter will find in M. L. Rosenthal's "The New Poets" a useful and thoughtful guide to part of the terrain that makes up the world of contemporary poetry. "Thoughtful" is used purposely because his book is not exactly.

LONDON, April 24--The board of the National Theater decided today that Rolf Hochhuth's play. "The Soldiers," is unsuitable for production because some characters, including Sir Winston churchill, are "grossly maligned."

KUALA LUMPUR, Malaysia, April 200--The key to Malaysia's future as a successful multiracial society lies in the Government's campaign to bring the backwoods Malay into modern society as a wage earner with a stake in the country.

"NAPLES, Fla., April 24-- Mary Gibson Coppolino, called by the state as an adverse witness in the murder trial of her husband, testified today that Dr. Carl A. Coppolino had never inquired about her wealth before they were married, 40 days after the death of the first Mrs. Coppolino.
New York University has estabiished a Real Estate Institute whose faculty will consist mainly of leading Manhattan real estate specialists.

Fifteen persons ducked for cover behind desks and counters in an Eighth Avenue bank yesterday while an armed guard and an armed man rolled on the floor in a wild struggle in which four shots were fired.

Richard M. Nixon, back from a month's tour of Asia, said yesterday he doubted that the United States bombing of MIG jet airfields in North Vietnam would increase the danger of Communist China's entering the war.
MONTREAL, April 24--The Soviet Union's pavilion at Expo 67, with its emphasis on space achievements, was opened for a preview as scheduled today despite the death of a Soviet cosmonaut.
The Council Against Poverty, the policy making body on expediture of city and Federal antipoverty funds, announced approval yesterday of six summer education programs that will cost $7,170,000.

The neo-Nazis of West Germany almost fell on their hate-warped faces in two state elections Sunday. Twenty-two years after the collapse of Hitler's Third Reich, however, the world is likely to note that the so-called National Democratic party has won seats in two wore state parliaments.
General Mills, Inc., voted yesterday a 2-for-1 split of the common shares, to be followed by an increase in the dividend.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 24 --The Bolivian armed forces announced today, that they had killed four guerrillas and wounded several others in a clash last night in the southeastern part of the nation.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- Waters appears to have played an important role in shaping the lunar surface, according to a leading authority on the moon.

LIVINGSTON, N.J., April 24--Arthur Wagner, retired production manager of the Nopco Chemical Company of Harrison, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Medical Center here. He was 62 years old and lived at 37 Chestnut Street.
The award of nine $10,000 scholarships to children of its members way announced yesterday by the National Maritime Union.

Mina Horne, an American dramatic soprano who achieved success as an opera singer in Europe during the nineteentwenties, died yesterday at St. Clare's Hospital of a heart ailment. She was 75 years old and lived at 205 West 57th Street.
Tom Dillon, for 29 years a Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn man and for three years its president, is now the agency's chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (UPI)--The Supreme Court Knocked down today two lastditch legal efforts by Cassius Clay, the world's heavyweight boxing champion, to escape his draft induction date with the Army on Friday.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 24 --George Sholty was looking over his shoulder at seven straining opponents while driving Special Dream to victory in the featured Class A-3 pace at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.
Plans for Potlatch Forests, Inc., to acquire the Fibreboard Corporation through an exchange of shares were announced yesterday.

Dr. Lenore Fay Meadows, an assistant professor of chemistry at Queens College, died yesterday in Maimonides Hospital, Brooklyn, after a long illness. She was 41-years-old and lived at 2718 Ocean Avenue, Brooklyn.
A utility expert said yesterday that the Consolidated Edison Company did not need as big a profit margin as it had been allowed in recent years by the state Public Service Commission.
NOTTINGHAM, England, April 24 (UPI)--Johnny Pritchett, the undefeated British middleweight champion, was held to a 10-round draw tonight by Milo Calhoun of New York.

Dick Hodgins Jr. a cartoonist for the Associated Press Newsfeatures, has won the National Cartoonists Society Reuben Award. He was hailed as last year's outstanding advertising and illustration cartoonist.
WASHINGTON, April 24-- Striking teachers and students at the Catholic University of America won the reinstatement and promotion today of a liberal young theology professor.

Louis Wolfson, the New York financier, challenged yesterday the constitutionality of an indictment charging him and others with violating the Securities Act in the sale of unregistered stock.

Moscow, April 24--Col. Vladimir Mikhailovich Komarov will join the many Communist heroes who have been buried over the last half century in the massive wall of the Kremlin.
DETROIT, April 24 (AP)-- Ford Motor Company's LincolnMercury division had a new potential recall problem on its hands today--but it involved golf balls instead of cars.

Stocks closed with a few more advances than declines with du Pont accounting for the bulk of the advance in more-active trading; volume, 10.25 million shares. Corporate bonds declined in slower trading; transactions, $13.77-million.
"The Chelsea Girls," Andy Warhol's 3 -hour, twin-screen study of the life of lower bohemia, has been added to the United States films to be shown at the Cannes Film Festival, which starts Thursday.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)--The United States has revoked the passports of five crew members of the yacht Phoenix for defying United States regulations and sailing to Haiphong this month with a cargo of medicine.
BOMBAY, India, April 24 --V. K. Krishna Menon was defeated today for the second time in two months for his old seat in Parliament.

WASHINGTON, April 24-- Senator Russell B. Long, Demoocrat of Louisiana, acknowledged today that Mike Mansfield was "the boss" and said he would go along with the majority leader in the controversy over financing Presidential elections with tax money.
Ownership of color television sets nearly doubled last year, according to the media research division of the A. C. Nielsen Company.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 24-- Vice President Humphrey dodged jeering antiwar pickets today after he delivered a long, sometimes emotional, speech to the Texas legislature on "The Administration's "commitment" in Southeast Asia.
Wall Street reacted bearishly yesterday to the stocks on the American Stock Exchange that were involved last year in alleged manipulative activities by certain brokers.

BREWSTER, N.Y., April 24 --A pile of rocks was found on the southbound tracks of the New York Central Railroad's Putnam Division at 2:30 A.M. today, two miles from where 50 youths had been arrested Friday night for throwing stones at a train and injuring the engineer.

The chairman of the labor relations committee of the American Newspaper Publishers Association accused the newspaper unions yesterday of intransigence, of making "extraordinary and exorbitant" wage requests and of using illegal work stoppages to enforce their demands.

MOSCOW, April 24--Col. Vladimir M. Komarov, pilot of the Soviet Union's first manned space flight in more than two years, was killed today when his craft's main re-entry parachute snarled and the ship plummeted 4.3 miles to earth.

All sections of the bond market gave ground again yesterday. There was relatively little selling pressure, but dealers marked prices down as much as 12-32 for long-term Government issues and 5/8-point for corporates.

WASHINGTON, April 24 (AP)--James E. Webb, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, called today for full cooperation between the United States and the Soviet Union to prevent space accidents.
ATLANTA, April 24--The doors had been officially closed for more than an hour, but Gov. Lester G. Maddox was still in his office signing a stack of letters when the telephone rang one night recently.
CAMBRIDGE, England, April 25--When Prince Charles enters Trinity College next fall as one of 220 freshmen there will be no special welcome for the heir to the British throne.

THE opportunities for brilliant opening leads are rare and when they do arise are rarely taken. The lead in the diagramed deal helped William Eisenberg, one of New York's younger generation of experts, to win a recent individual tournament at the Mayfair Club and may prove to be the best effort of 1967 in this department.

DEDHAM, Mass., April 25-- Mr. and Mrs. R. Rowland Stebbins have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Gertrude Ellis Stebbins, to Donald Lord Bartlett 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Bartlett Jr. of Washington, Conn.

In choosing Robert W. Haack as its new president the New York Stock Exchange has selected a man knowledgeable in the workings of the securities markets and experienced as a negotiator with Washington. These are important qualifications for guiding the nation's biggest stock exchange as it completes its transformation from a strictly professional market that was pretty much of a private club to a true public market.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)--Official Washington paid its respects today to the memory of Dr. Konrad Adenauer, hailed as the man who "restored the soul of his country and his people."

HOUSTON, April 25 (UPI)-- Al Jackson yielded only one hit --a single by Bob Aspromonte leading off the eighth inning-- and Tim McCarver walloped a two-run homer in the second inning tonight to lead the St. Louis Cardinals to a 4-0 triumph over the Houston Astros.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)--The Boston Red Sox, with early-inning home runs by Reggie Smith, Mike Andrews and Tony Conigliaro, made it two in a row over the Washington Senators tonight with a 9-3 victory behind the five-hit pitching of Hank Fischer.

The chairman of the New York City Commission on Human Rights and the national director of CORE urged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay call an immediate conference of community leaders to "combat the danger of hysteria" over the fear of racial violence this summer.
Columbia Records said yesterday that a contract dispute with Bob Dylan, the singer, had been settled amicably.

Sylvia Fine, who has been working principally in motion pictures and television, and Leonard Spigelgass, the playwright, are writing an original musical comedy called "We're a Whole New Thing" to be done on Broadway by Kermit Bloomgarden in the spring of 1968.
A compromise between conflicting American and French views on international monetary reform is the only possible way out of the current bitter deadlock.

BRITAIN'S Royal Ballet is this year giving its long est season ever, having just entered the second week of its six-week occupancy of the Metropolitan Opera House. As a kind of corollary to this, it is also the most diversified season it has offered New York.
BONN, April 25--Although President Johnson spent a somber day at the funeral of Konrad Adenauer there were smiling moments.

The establishment of a code and seal of fair practice for property and liability insurance companies was proposed yesterday at the annual meeting of the American Insurance Association. Individual companies would subscribe to the code voluntarily.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The president of the InterAmerican Development Bank issued a warning today against converting the bank into a "soft credit" lending organization.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- United States space officials believe that the ill-fated spacecraft Soyuz 1, in which Soviet Col. Vladimir M. Komarov died on Monday, got into trouble near the end of its first day in orbit and that it tumbled out of control as he tried to land it safely in the remote flatlands of Central Asia.

DENVER, April 25 (UPI)-- One opponent of Colorado's new abortion law said it would "signal a flood of calls from all over the United States begging physicians in Colorado to solve pregnancy problems."

General Westmoreland describes the Vietnam conflict as "a war of attrition." The alternative would be "a war of annihilation," which the general said had been "ruled out as a matter of policy." In the same way, President Johnson and Secretaries Rusk and McNamara talk of a "limited war" in Vietnam.

SUMMIT, N.J., April 25-- Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Greaney have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Patricia Ann Greaney, to Dennis H. Taylor, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard D. Taylor of Short Hills.
This dispatch was filed to The Associated Press by Wilfred Burchett, an Australian writer who has close connections with North Vietnam and the Vietcong.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- Following are excerpts from an introduction to a speech in the Senate today on the "lesson of Vietnam" by Senator George McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, and from the speech and the exchange on the floor during and after the speech:
A Brooklyn landlord tapped on the rear window of a firstfloor apartment yesterday morning to demand that a tenant quiet her four young children.

ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., April 25--Mr. and Mrs. David Plesser have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Susan Ilene Plesser, to Joel Brenner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Sam Brenner of Roslyn. An August wedding is planned.
PASADENA, Calif., April 25 (AP)--Scientists decided to put Surveyor 3 back to work digging ditches in the lunar soil today--despite the approach of noon on the moon.
Tentative boundaries for 58 community planning districts for the city were made public yesterday by the City Planning Commission.
James K. Seymour, president of Associated Transport, Inc., since 1963, has been elected to the additional post of chief executive officer, it was announced here yesterday at the annual meeting.

PARIS--Konrad Adenauer was eminently practical and it is therefore suitable that Der Alte's funeral should serve as an excuse for diplomatic discussions. The fact that President Johnson wisely chose to bring with him for this sad occasion Secretary Rusk and former High Commissioner McCloy makes it possible to have truly serious talks with Chancellor Kiesinger.

Mrs. Maximilian Mader is chairman of the annual awards dinner that the Easter Seal Home Service will give Monday in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom Mrs. Arthur Gallucci is chairman of the committee of sponsors.
Hirsch Jacobs, who disposed of much of his stock last year to curtail his activities for health reasons, was back on the Aqueduct scene yesterday for the first time this year as a winning trainer.

THE Islip Speedway on Long Island and Wall Stadium on Route 34 in Belmar, N.J., announce practice sessions free to the spectators on Saturday afternoon. Both tracks are tuning up foropenings on May 6.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)--Faculty members at the Catholic University of America will press additional demands for academic freedom after the university's backdown that ended a five-day campus boycott, sources said today.

THE state funeral of Konrad Adenauer was tele vised live around the world yesterday morning as the Pacific and Atlantic communications satellites carried the last rites for West Germany's first Chancellor to the United States and Japan. The services were seen throughout Europe via Eurovision, the Continental network.

TORONTO, April 25 (A5)-- Bob Pulford's goal at 8:26 of the second sudden-death overtime period gave the Toronto, Maple Leafs a 3-2 victory over the Montreal Canadiens tonight and a 2-1 lead in their Stanley Cup final playoff series.
The Italian Charities of America will hold its 31st annual dinner dance on Saturday in the Imperial Grand Ballroom of the Americana Hotel.
NEWARK, April 25 (AP)-- The Government won the right today to a trial on its claim to 130,000 shares of stock to satisfy a $449,265 lien against the wife of Anthony (Tino) DeAngelis.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 --A couple of transplanted San Franciscans--Wilt Chamberlain and Coach Alex Hannum-- hit the professional pinnacle last night as the Philadelphia 76ers defeated the San Francisco Warriors, 125-122, for the National Basketball Association title.

MADISON, N.J., April 25 (AP)--Methodist seminary student's at Drew University ended their boycott of classes today but will try a new tactic tomorrow in their effort to oust President Robert F. Oxnam.

Irwin P. Strauss, treasurer and former president of the National Waste Company, which makes cotton waste for railroad use, died Monday in New York Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 215 East 68th Street.
The election of Richard M. Wartes as executive vice president was announced yesterday in Sterling Forest, N.Y., by the City Investing Company, which has extensive real estate holdings.
Ida Presti, a member of the guitar duo known as Presti and Lagoya, died in Rochester Monday night during an emergency lung operation. She was 42 years old.
LONDON, April 25 (AP)-- Joe Carr, the 45-year-old Irish amateur golf star, was named playing captain of Britain's Walker Cup team today.

A 35-year-old Bronx man was shot fatally at 125th Street and Park Avenue in Harlem about 3:15 A.M. yesterday. Last night the police seized a 22-yearold unemployed driver's helper. Two other suspects were being sought.
ALBUQUERQUE, N.M., April 25--A neighborhood renovation project that makes the antipoverty dollar do double duty impressed a one-man Senate subcommittee today.

PARIS, April 25--Frederic Rossif, the French director whose documentary on the Spanish Civil war, "Tonio in Madrid," was nominated for an Academy Award last year, has returned from the Soviet Union, where he spent 17 subzero weeks at work on "The October Revolution."
CHICAGO, April 25--Dick Radatz, once the outstanding relief pitcher in baseball, was sold by the Cleveland Indians today to the Chicago Cubs.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- Two Congressional committees were competing today to unfold a bizarre story of a self-styled inventor who parlayed 38 cents and some worthless chemicals into $370,000 in foreign aid orders for South Vietnam.
NEW HAVEN, April 25--A Federal judge ordered today an 80-day cooling-off period in a labor dispute that threatens the production of helicopter engines vital to the Vietnam war effort.
The spot rate on the British pound rose slightly in moderate trading yesterday on foreignexchange markets here.
The Government proved to be a big bear in the corn futures market yesterday and prices went down as holders of long positions sold out.
THERE is a way of speeding up room service in a Moscow hotel. That is, if you happen to be a New York hairdresser like Marc de Coster.

First-quarter earnings of the American Smelting and Refining Company rose to a record $13,615,000, or $1.25 a share, from $12,068,000, or $1.10 a share, a year earlier, the annual meeting in Jersey City was told yesterday. Sales rose to $162,480,000 from $168,022,000.
A group of 16 lay teachers at five Roman Catholic elementary schools in Central Harlem have threatened to strike on Monday if their demands for improved wages and working conditions are not met.

The charitable way of reporting Estela Bringuer's United States debut would be to say that the Argentine composerconductor led the American Symphony Orchestra last night at Philharmonic Hall in three of her works: the world premiere of a Piano Concerto in D and the first United States performances of her ballet suite, "Carnival in Humahuaca," and of her Symphony No. 1, "Earth."

ONCE upon a time the only guys who kicked footballs in top level competi tion were genuine football players who also blocked, tackled and performed all the normal gridiron chores. Usually they were 60-minute operatives with the toughness and skills to function on offense and defense. But nowadays the kicker doesn't have to be a real football player at all. He can be a specialist.
NEWCASTLE, England, April 25 (UPI)--Maurice Cullen retained his British lightweight title tonight by outpointing Vic Andretti in a 15-round bout at Newcastle's St. James Hall.
BABYLON, L.I., April 25-- With a touch of sarcasm and a call to history, the neighbors of Robert Moses turned out tonight to protest the downzoning of his rambling, shingled home here.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Administration announced today a series of actions aimed at bolstering farm income and allaying unrest among farmers ...

About 2,400 students at DeWitt Clinton High School in the Bronx learned yesterday that they would have to take their English, economics and American history midterm exams again because several students had stolen the tests before they were given.

ATHENS, April 25--The military junta that seized power in a coup d'etat Friday is firmly in control of Greece and its rule is accepted, however, unwillingly, by King Constantine and the people, in the view of informed diplomats and Greek observers.
DENVER, April 25--Gov. John A. Love signed today a bill designed to liberalize the state's existing statutes on abortion.

WHITE PLAINS, April 25-- The corporation that operates the Westchester County Airport has agreed to pay the county $1.2-million if its concession is extended and the money is used to build a new passenger terminal, County Executive Edwin G. Michaelian said today.

ATLANTA, April 25--Stockholders of Texaco, Inc., were told at the annual meeting here today that earnings in the first quarter were the best for any three-month period in the company's history and 8.7 per cent over the level a year earlier.

CHICAGO, April 25 (UPI) Michael Wood, who first exposed financial aid from the Central Intelligence Agency to the National Student Association, was reported today to have linked the C.I.A. to another major United States student organization, the World University Service.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The United States announced today that its program of military and economic aid to Greece was "under review."
I DO hope cartoonist Jules Feiffer isn't going to lose that sunny look that masks his social growl. He's young, and has miles to go before he weeps.
NEW PALTZ, N.Y., April 25 (AP)--Twenty-nine students of New Paltz State College were arrested on disorderly conduct charges today for interfering with military recruiting on the campus.
GEORGETOWN, Guyana, April 25--A bill giving the Government powers to expel foreigners indulging in activities threatening state security was adopted by Parliament last night.
ATLANTA, April 25--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. reiterated his support of the peace movement today but announced that he would not be its candidate for President in 1968.

The Consolidated Edison Company of New York, Inc., reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for three months and 12 months ended March 31. The company also approved plans for a third nuclear power generating unit at the Indiana Point station at Buchanan, N.Y.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., April 25--Mr. and Mrs. Thomas R. Smidt have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Diana Cole Smidt, to Pfc. Richard Warfield Sylvester Jr. U.S.A., son of Mr. and Mrs. Sylvester of Riverside, Conn.
Eastern Air Lines achieved record earnings in the first quarter, "giving the carrier an excellent start for the year," Floyd D. Hall, president, reported yesterday.
BRUSSELS, April 25--The European Common Market has a substantial stake in a successful Kennedy round, according to figures in the latest quarterly economic report of the Market's commission.

The directors of Foremost Dairies, Inc., and McKesson Robbins, Inc., announced a plan yesterday to merge under the name of Foremost-McKesson, Inc. Foremost owns 51 per cent of the common stock of McKesson, a drug, liquor and chemical concern.
The Lindsay administration is preparing legislation providing for the universal metering of city water.

The New York Giants, whose pickings in the draft of college football players five weeks ago were slim enough, lost one of their choices yesterday to the Montreal Alouettes of the Canadian Football League.
The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) and its worldwide affiliates earned exactly the same amount in the first quarter this year as in the initial three months of 1966.

DALLAS, April 25--The president of the General Electric Company said today that G.E. will spend $600-million this year for more "mechanization" in an effort to improve sagging earnings of the company, fourth-largest industrial corporation in the nation.
Mayor Lindsay yesterday accused City Council President Frank D. O'Connor of "raising public doubt and suspicion" by questioning the validity of the Police Department's crime statistics.

NANTUCKET, Mass., April 25 (AP)--"Like a ball of fire," a big Air Force radar picket plane, with a wing commander at the controls and 15 other men aboard, plunged into the sea off Nantucket Island tonight.
Columbia defeated Harvard 4-3, yesterday in an Eastern Intercollegiate Baseball League game at Baker Field. The Lions sent seven men to the plate in the eighth and collected three runs on four hits.
LONDON, April 25--Britain's income-tax sieuths are hard on the heels of Samuel Pepys.

STOCKHOLM, April 25-- Bertrand Russell's "war-crimes tribunal," directed against the United States, is scheduled to begin preliminary work tomorrow in the face of opposition by the Swedish Government.

Thomas C. Fogarty, chairman of the Continental Can Company, greeted shareholders yesterday morning with the news that directors had just raised the quarterly dividend to 50 cents a share. The board meeting was held before the annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel here.
ATLANTA, April 25 (AP)-- Walter Turner Candler, son of Asa G. Candler who founded the Coca-Cola Company, died Sunday at the age of 81.

BALTIMORE, April 25 (UPI) --Frank Robinson drove in one run with a sacrifice fly in the third inning and scored the other after hitting a triple in the sixth tonight as the Baltimore Orioles knocked the California Angels out of first place with a 2-1 triumph.

WILMINGTON, Del., April 25--Severe winter weather and higher operating costs cut firstquarter earnings of the Bethlehem Steel Corporation by 12.5 per cent from the year-earlier level despite a sales rise of 4 per cent, the annual meeting was told here today.
Bond prices continued to retreat yesterday in the face of large credit market offerings and a Treasury announcement on refunding plans expected after the close of trading today.
MARSEILLES, France, April 25 (Reuters)--A strike by merchant marine officers for higher pay tied up cargo ships, liners, car ferries and other vessels in French ports today.

WASHINGTON, April 25--A New York investment banker said today that the price of the stock of American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., might drop to "somewhere in the high 50's" if the network's proposed merger with International Telephone Telegraph Corporation were forbidden.

MOSCOW, April 25--Tens of thousands of Muscovites waited hours in line today to file past the flower-decked bier of Col. Vladimir M. Komarov, the Soviet astronaut who was killed yesterday on his descent from a 24-hour space flight.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25--Navy fliers staged morning and afternoon attacks against a cement plant a mile from the center of Haiphong, North Vietnam's major port, and an ammunition dump and petroleum storage tanks a few miles beyond Hanoi today.
The stock market sagged a little in early trading yesterday but revived to score its 11th consecutive advance.

GENEVA, April 25--The United States has offered to delay inspection of Euratom countries by the International Atomic Energy Agency in Vienna until three years after the effective date of the proposed treaty barring the spread of nuclear weapons to additional countries.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- For the first time in party history, Democratic leaders are officially setting up an open line to the young voters of the country in an effort to capture their loyalty or at least their attention.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 25 (AP)--Glynn Perkins, a lefthander golfer, up set a former champion, Dale Morey, on the 20th hole and Dr. Ed Updegraff trimmed John Guenther, 5 and 3, to share the spotlight today in the second round of the North and South men's amateur.

NEW HAVEN, Conn., April 25--This is the time of year when high school seniors are told what college they can attend, and when college seniors make their plans for graduate school and marriage, which is the most important graduate school of all. But this year it is different.

THERE'S a gap of about a yard between the hemline of the shortest coat and the hemline of the longest coat designed by Don Simonelli for Modelia. Yesterday's preview was the first complete collection of coats and suits for next winter to be shown on Seventh Avenue. Out of 65 styles, many of which stopped just below the buttocks, four descended to anywhere from just below the knee to just above the ankles.
The Board of Education agreed yesterday to the formation of a committee of parents, community leaders and faculty members for Public School 36125 on the western edge of Harlem.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 (AP)--Federal agents reported today finding eight more tons of ammunition consigned to William Thoresen 3d, who had a sizable arsenal hidden in his San Francisco home.

LAS VEGAS, Nev., April 25 (UPI)--Herbert Lodge, the president of a group applying for a Nevada gambling license, won the approval of the Gaming Control Board yesterday after undergoing cross-examination about possible underworld ties.
HONOLULU, April 25 (AP) --Former United States District Judge Delbert E. Metzger, who once left the bench to defend 13 Communists in an appeal, died last night at a rest home. He was 92 years old.
LONDON, April 25 (AP)-- Elizabeth Taylor and Richard Burton swept top honors in the 20th annual British Film Academy awards tonight.

GRAHAM GREENE scribbles acrid love stories here. These are tales of gamey people--shot, so to speak, out of season.

NEW ORLEANS, April 25 (AP)--The New Orleans States Item said today in a copyrighted story there was mounting evidence of Central Intelligence Agency links in District Attorney Jim Garrison's investigation of President Kennedy's assassination.
Federal Judge Marvin E. Frankel denied yesterday an injunction sought by Thomson McKinnon, a stock brokerage concern, against a Securities and Exchange Commission probe of the company.

KARLOVY VARY, Czechoslovakia, April 25--The communist leaders of Hungary and Poland, Janos Kadar and Wladyslaw Gomulka, lashed out today against West Germany's penetration of Eastern Europe by means of diplomatic relations. But the Hungarian clearly left room for some kind of deal with the West Germans.

James H. Meredith, the civil rights leader, said early today he had backed out as a Republican candidate against Adam Clayton Powell because of an accusation by Jackie Robinson, the former baseball star.

DENVER, April 25--A Federal district judge, refusing to interfere in the processes of military justice, dismissed the case today of an Air Force captain who has declared himself a conscientious objector.

PEKING, Wednesday, April 26 (Reuters)--Chanting Chinese smashed windows of the car owned by the Indonesian charge d'affaires and burned straw effigies of Indonesian leaders as demonstrations outside the Indonesian Embassy mounted in intensity today.

INDIANAPOLIS, April 25 (UPI)--Peter Revson of New York, and Lothar Motschenbacher of Beverly Hills, Calif., two rookies seeking their first starting assignments in the 500mile Memorial Day auto race, were suspended today for 60 days by the United States Auto Club.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- Mrs. Milton W. King, a civic leader here for more than 50 years, died yesterday in Georgetown University Hospital. She was 73 years old and lived at 4000 Cathedral Avenue Northwest.
WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)--The Soviet Union has rebuffed a United States proposal to send two American astronauts to the funeral of Col. Vladimir M. Komarov, it was learned today.
Net income declined for the Youngstown Sheet and Tube Company in the first quarter although sales and shipments increased, the annual meeting in Youngstown, Ohio, was told yesterday.
Fears of a possible "air war" between the United States and Britain over the rights of charter airlines lessened somewhat yesterday.

WESTBURY, L.I., April 25 --Chalkplayers, the breed of punter that finds adventure in wagering on short-priced horses, batted .500 in tonight's co-features at Roosevelt Raceway. Those who took 11-10 on Peerswick in the $10,000 Class AA one-mile pace wound up smiling, but those who risked $10 to win $7 on Jericho Hanover in the $7,500 invitation for 3-year-old sidewheelers found no joy.
The second Rheingold Central Park Music Festival will again be presented at the Wollman Memorial Skating Rink this summer.
BOSTON, April 25--The Young Women's Christian Association moved today to redefine its purpose in an era of religious change.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 25--Gov. Ronald Reagan ruled himself out today as a possible Republican Vice-Presidential nominee in 1968.
ALBANY, April 25--New York City can enact a new housing maintenance code and gain about $75-million in Federal housing funds under a bill that has been signed by Governor Rockefeller.

Robert L. Natal of 56-12 Oceania Street, Bayside Queens, manager of the cargo claims division of Associated Transport, Inc., a trucking company, and former president of the National Cystic Fibrosis Research Foundation, died yesterday in North Shore Hospital, Manhasset, L.I., after a long illness. He was 53 years old.
WASHINGTON, April 25 --The Treasury auctioned ninemonth and one-year bills today at interest rates significantly lower than in other recent issues of these bills.
HONG KONG, April 25--The Peking radio reported today that two American jet aircraft had been shot down over Chinese territory.
An effort to rebuild the splintered Democratic party in New York City will be started today when the state chairman, John J. Burns, comes to town to arrange a meeting wth the five county leaders.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- An increase of 50,000 troops in Vietnam above the currently planned levels would increase defense spending by $4-billion to $6-billion in the forthcoming fiscal year, Senator John Stennis said today.

WASHINGTON, April 25 (UPI)--Maj. Gen. Benjamin D. Foulois, the nation's oldest military pilot and the first American to fly in combat, died today at Andrews Air Force Base Hospital. He was 87 years old.
United Nations, N.Y., April 25--the Soviet Union demanded today that the General Assembly declare South-West Africa independent without any interim administration by the United Nations.
LONDON, April 25--Informed quarters indicated today that Britain's long-awaited move for admission to the European Common Market was imminent. It may come next week.

The Rogers Peet Company, in a long-term leasing transaction involving more than $1-million in aggregate rent, has taken 15,000 square feet of store space in the fashion center being developed by the Associated Dry Goods Corporation on a 34-acre tract in Paramus, N.J.

FLEMINGTON, N.J., April 25--Angry Negro shareholders stalked in and out of the annual meeting of the Eastman Kodak Company today, demanding the company honor an agreement for a job training program, while about 700 supporters demonstrated outside.

Profits of the American Express Company rose in the first quarter over the level in the period last year, and earnings for all of 1967 should be higher than those a year before, Howard L. Clark, president, reported yesterday.
The lengthened chapel meetings of printers continued at The Daily News yesterday despite a warning by the publisher that the union's tactics might force the newspaper to suspend publication.

John F. Kennedy wrote in a letter in May, 1959, that he found it "thought-provoking" that all Presidents elected since 1840 in years ending in zero had not lived out their time in the White House. He was a Senator at the time.

PALERMO, Sicily, April 21 --In the face of many handicaps, including weak regional government, Sicily has made substantial progress toward turning a depressed agricultural economy into a more balanced mixture of industry and farming.
DETROIT, April 25 (AP)-- Former State Senator Charles C. Diggs Sr., the first Negro elected to public office in Michigan in the Democratic ticket, died today in a fourstory fall.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25--Ellsworth Bunker arrived here today to take up his post as American Ambassador less than five hours after the departure of his predecessor, Henry Cabot Lodge.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- Officials said today that the United States was planning to widen its bombing raids against North Vietnam's industries soon to include installations that have hitherto been immune from attack.

Two companies mentioned in connection with alleged manipulative activities by brokers and customers in their stock trading on the American Stock Exchange issued statements yesterday denying any involvement.
Paul Miller, president of the Gannett Newspapers, was reelected president of The Associated Press yesterday by the board of directors in a meeting at its headquarters, 50 Rockefeller Plaza.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Lindsay administration, in an attempt to outmaneuver opponents of the proposed Cross Brooklyn Expressway, has quietly won a promise of Federal funds for the planning of the controversial highway.

James F. Fairman, who retired in 1963 as senior vice president for engineering of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died yesterday at Birmingham, Mich., where he was living in retirement. He was 71 years old.

The Seagrave Corporation said yesterday it had developed a process to produce leather in a continuous sheet. The sheet leather, which has not yet been named, will be produced at a plant the company is acquiring in Newport, Me.

XEROX Corporation, which took some hard knocks when it invaded the high-volume copying market with its fast 2400 model last year, seems to be doing better now.

The election of A. Benedict Doran and Samuel M. Kinney Jr. as directors of the Union Camp Corporation was announced yesterday at the annual stockholders, meeting in Jersey City. Both men are vice presidents of the paper bag producer.

Prices turned mixed yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 25--The United Nations has weathered a minor new crisis over nonpayment of contributions.

WHITE PLAINS, April 25-- Two painters distinguished by their work in the first half of the century, Frederick J. Waugh and Frank Vincent DuMond, will be honored by the Hudson Valley Art Association at its annual exhibition opening Sunday in the County Center here.
