Determined to win back fan interest by creating a new, slick image of one sort or another, the New York Yankees unveiled their latest mod creations--the mini-hit and the mini-rally--in an 11-2 triumph over the Chicago White Sox at Yankee Stadium yesterday.

MIAMI BEACH, April 25 (AP)--Bob Crawford of Detroit took the lead in the classic allevents today and Lou Schissler of Denver rolled the first 300 game ever recorded in the team event in the 64 years of the American Bowling Congress tournament.

At Lincoln Center today: Philip Miller, presenting a lecture-demonstration on the performances of Mary Garden and Maggie Teyte, Library-Museum, 6:30 P.M.; George London, bassbaritone, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30.

JACKSON, Miss., April 25 (AP)--Kenneth Dean, director of the Mississippi Council on Human Relations, filed a report with a Senate subcommittee today that says a widespread and critical poverty situation exists in the state.

WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Senate approved today, 63 to 22, a plan to get action on the stalled investment tax credit bill and to repeal the Presidential Campaign Fund Act of 1966. The repealer is an amendment to the tax bill.
HOUSTON, April 25 (AP)-- Lawyers for Cassius Clay told a Federal judge today the heavyrweight champion never would submit to induction into the armed services.

The architectural firm of Brand Moore has been established by Leon Brand and S. Hart Moore, members of the American Institute of Architects. Both men were formerly with the architectural firm of Frederick G. Frost Associates.

HALLELUJAH, BABY! Musical, with book by Arthur Laurents; music by Jule Styne; lyrics by Betty Comden and Adolph Green; staged by Burt Shevelove, starring Leslie Uggams, Robbert Hooks and Allen Case. At the Martin Beck Theater, 302 West 45th Street, at 7.

WEST ISLIP, L.I., April 25 --Mr. and Mrs. Glen E. Givens have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Merilyn Givens, to Lieut. James Gaylord Gasque, U.S.A., son of Dr. and Mrs. Mac Roy Gasque of New York and Brevard, N.C.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Senate approved unanimously today a treaty establishing general principles for the peaceful exploration and use of outer space.

Fifty-four works from the collection of Governor Rockefeller--paintings, sculpture, drawings and prints by 37 artists, will go on exhibition at the New School Art Cnter, 66 West 12th Street, May 4 through May 31.
LOS ANGELES, April 25 (UPI)--A retired Air Force sergeant, who amassed a $3million fortune, apparently had only one hobby during his lifetime--making money.
The board of trustees of the Consolidated Edison Company approved yesterday plans for a third nuclear generating unit to be built at the company's Indian Point station in Buchanan, N.Y.
MIAMI, April 25 (AP)--The Miami Dolphins of the American Football League traded John McKeever, a defensive back, to the San Diego Chargers today for an offensive guard, John Farris.
Marten Sameth sang a program of lieder at Carnegie Recital Hall last night that was mostly devoted to a complete Schubert cycle, "Die Schone Mullerin."
Several New York City travel agencies said yesterday that plans of tourists to visit Greece this summer had not been appreciably altered by the recent army coup.

NAPLES, Fla., April 25-- Boston's Medical Examiner testified today that he could never have concluded, as had the Chief Medical Examiner of New York, that the wife of Dr. Carl A. Coppolino was murdered by an injection of a paralyzing drug.

LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 25 (UPI)--An estimated total of 225 persons, nearly all of them white and many from religious orders, staged a "pray-in" in front of City Hall today to support demands of Negro leaders for open housing legislation.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 25-- Government antiguerrilla forces have captured a close associate of Premier Fidel Castro in a battle in the southeastern part of Bolivia.

WASHINGTON, April 25 --The International Brotherhood of Teamsters said today that a majority of workers was voting in favor of a new national trucking contract, but that the results were "still inconclusive."

Robert L. Geddes, dean of the School of Architecture at Princeton University, and Adolph R. Serimenti, a former president of the New Jersey Society of Architects, have been named Fellows of the American Institute of Architects. Both men have received many awards for their work as architects.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 25--Henry Cabot Lodge, the departing United States Ambassador to Saigon, has said that the new Government to be elected this fall in South Vietnam must include military men.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 25 (AP)--An explosion that appeared to come from a bomb damaged tonight the home of Mrs. Frank Johnson Sr., the widowed mother of Federal District Judge Frank M. Johnson Jr. No one was reported injured.

A contract for a Pure Waters Program construction aid grant of $38,596,507 to cover the Newtown Creek water pollution control project in Greenpoint, Brooklyn, was signed yesterday bfy Governor Rockefeller. The sewage treatment plant, to be completed early in 1969, will be the largest in the East and treat an average of 310 million gallons a day.
IT used to be that only nature was knowledgable enough to create a new fish. Now it seems that every time one turns around the biologists come up with a new fish.
CHICAGO, April 25--Tom Seaver pitched the New York Mets to a 2-1 victory over the Chicago Cubs in 10 innings today and went to the head of the class as the brightest Met rookie of 1967.
SIX YEARS AGO, two-packa-day puffer Robert Wil liam Haack decided to give up smoking. "He did it on the first try, cold turkey," a friend recalls in admiration.
A plan for a consolidated six-berth passenger ship complex on the Hudson River in "luxury liner row" was disclosed yesterday by Mayor Lindsay and the Port of New York Authority.
The United States Steel Corporation had a difficult first quarter and sees little likelihood of any major change in the coming months.

CENTERPORT, L.I., April 25--Anton F. Pecha Sr., deputy chief engineer of the Bureau of Gas and Electricity, City Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity, died of a heart attack yesterday in Huntington Hospital. He was 64 years old and lived at 135 Buchanan Street.
Gov. Ronald Reagan and Senator Robert F. Kennedy will take part in a one-hour "Town Meeting of the World" on the Columbia Broadcasting System Monday, May 15, at 10 P.M.

MBABANE, Swaziland, April 25--Sobhuza II became His Majesty, the constitutional King of Swaziland, today as the red, blue and yellow Swazi flag with its fighting shield symbol was raised in place of the British Union Jack in an official ceremony.

Ward A. Cavanaugh and Hamilton Robinson Jr. were elected yesterday as vice presidents of Schroder Rockefeller Co., New York investment bankers. Mr. Cavanaugh was formerly treasurer, while Mr. Robinson was previously with the law firm of Sullivan Cromwell.

Paperboard production rose eight-tenths of 1 per cent to 454,000 tons in the week ended April 22 from 450,600 tons in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paperboard Association reported yesterday.

One of every six Negroes receiving higher education today is attending a college or university supported by the United Negro College Fund. These thirty-three relatively small liberal arts institutions provide a significant share of the widening educational opportunities for Negroes. But there is need for further vast expansion.
LITTLE FALLS, Minn., April 25 (AP)--Charlie Margulis, a trumpet player for leading bands, died yesterday while visiting relatives here. He was 64 years old.
Three offerings of common stock were made yesterday and another was announced.

I THINK I look younger today than I did when I first came to work for Stern Brothers as a cash girl, almost 51 years ago," said Miss Mary Denning, now a telephone order clerk with the store. "We had to wear black or navy dresses down to our ankles."
WASHINGTON, April 25 (AP)--A 29-member advisory committee to evaluate research and standards for highway safety was sworn in office today by Secretary of Transportation Alan S. Boyd.
A change in portwide waterfront hiring practice, instituted yesterday morning for the first time, has produced an angry protest from the leader of Brooklyn's longshoremen.

Mrs. Martin Drucker of New York, and Stanley Adams of Great Neck, L.I., have announced the engagement of their danghter, Miss Barbara Paula Adams, to Seymour George Hammel Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Hammel of New York. A May 28 wedding is planned.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 25 (AP)--Juan Marichal scattered seven hits for his first victory of the season as the San Srancisco Giants routed the Cincinnati Reds tonight, 6-1, thereby snapping the Reds' winning string at five games.
Unanimous Senate approval of the space treaty has come as a pleasant surprise after the widespread concern earlier this year that the pact might fall short of the needed two-thirds vote.

North American Aviation, Inc., the nation's third largest aerospace company, reported yesterday reduced earnings for the three-month and six-month periods ended March 31, reflecting a decline in sales.

The Protestant Council of the City of New York approved yesterday the immediate establishment of a Joint Office of Churches on Housing and Urban Renewal. Its primary function will be to encourage and assist churches in becoming sponsors of public housing and urban renewal projects.

Stocks closed up following a late rally; many electronic and special-situation issues rose in active trading; volume, 10.42 million shares. Bonds declined in more-active trading; transactions, $15.18 million.
LONDON, April 25--A tanker described as the biggest ship ever build in Britain was launched today at the Wallsend yard of the Swan Hunter group, near Newcastle, on the northeast coast of England.

Running counter to a trend shared by a majority of chemical companies, the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation reported yesterday that profits for the first quarter this year rose 36 per cent to a record high for any first quarter.

DETROIT, April 25--James P. Hoffa won the Democratic primary today in Michigan's 19th legislative district on the west side of Detroit. The election for the vacant House seat will be held May 23 in the normally Democratic district.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- The Senate Banking Committee unanimously approved today the nomination of William W. Sherrill as a member of the Federal Reserve Board.

A 33-year-old suspect in Monday's holdup and gunfire exchange at the Bank of North America, Eighth Avenue at 35th Street, was in the Tombs at 125 White Street yesterday under bail and a warrant for violation of parole.
Robert W. Haack was named yesterday as the next president of the New York Stock Exchange at a salary of $125,000 a year to succeed Keith Funston, who has headed the Big Board since 1951.

ALBANY, April 25--A person operating an automobile or motorcycle will have to keep at least one hand on the steering wheel or the handlebars while driving, under a bill that has been signed into law by Governor Rockefeller.

MILAN, Italy, April 25 (Reuters)--Roger Vadim, the French movie director, will face trial charged with obscenity and five stars will be tried on immorality charges because of the motion picture "Il Piacere e l'Amore" ("The Merry-GoRound of Love"), the authorities said here today.

MONZA, Italy, April 25 (UPI)--Lorenzo Bandini of Italy and Chris Amon of New Zealand, posting their second victory in three races, led a Ferrari one, two victory today in the Monza 1,000-kilometer endurance race for sports prototype cars.
A two-week festival of Czechoslovak features and short subjects will be presnted from June 16 to 28 under the joint auspices of the film departments of Lincoln Center and the Museum of Modern Art.

Heavyweight crews from Yale, Pennsylvania, Columbia, Fordham and Rhode Island and lightweight eights from Cornell, Columbia and Massachusetts Institute of Technology will race Saturday on Hunter's Island Lagoon in one of the season's biggest days of rowing here.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 98.1 on Monday from 97.9 Friday.
SAYVILLE, L.I., April 25-- A rookie policeman discovered his parish church on fire here today, routed children from the adjoining school and carried the infirm pastor to safety.
Newspaper publishers were told yesterday that the United States had developed a "psychedelic society," confronting them with a challenge on how to stir interest in public causes.

LOS ANGELES, April 25 (AP)--Rico Carty clouted a three-run homer and Mack Jones drove in two runs with a single and double for the Atlanta Braves tonight in a 7-1 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
LONDON, April 25--Lovers of classical languages, who have lost so many battles in recent years, made a last stand today at Oxford--and won.
WASHINGTON, April 25-- Consumer prices edged upward in March but wholesale prices declined in both March and April, the Labor Department reported today.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday that a "sustained springlong, summerlong" campaign to clean up the city's sidewalks and gutters will start May 2.

PARIS, April 25--"Messieurs de Rothschild Freres"-- a French branch of the Rothschild financial empire--announced today that they will soon become the Banque Rothschild, and do business with the common man.
RED BANK, N. J., April 26 --Miss Susan Howard and Barron Zachary Biederman will be married next month.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- Representative William F. Ryan made public today what he said were exerpts from an unpublished report by the space agency listing inadequacies in performance by the main contractor for the Apollo spacecraft.
LONDON, April 2--In the face of left-wing pressure, Foreign Secretary George Brown declined today to condemn the United States for the reported air attack on a British freighter in Haiphong.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Council of War:

The Soviet Union's Politburo and Central Committee, some of whose members Svetlana Alliluyeva said yesterday must share the blame for crimes of the Stalinist era, are the dominant groups of the country's Communist

DORION-VAUDREUIL, Quebec--If you want to find genuine French Canadian food, a Quebecois said recently, the best place to find it is in a French-Canadian home. And one of the best home kitchens in all the region around is that of Mrs. Lue Castonguay, a neatly Coifed young grandmother in this town of 6,000 inhabitants about 30 miles from Montreal.
Stocks drifted off yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.
In an otherwise dull market yesterday, futures trading was wild for at least two commodities--potatoes and sugar.
Negotiators for The Daily News and the printers' union met again yesterday with Theodore W. Kheel, mediator, but neither side gave any report of progress in the deadlocked newspaper dispute.

WHEN the Chicago White Sox opened their instructional school in Florida last autumn, they watched the prog ress of one man with almost fearful anxiety. They knew that their pennant chances this season depended heavily on him. However, he was no boy wonder who was about to rocket to instant stardom in some sort of fictional miracle.

Rokeby Stable's Just Kidding, the compact filly purchased primarily for breeding purposes at a private sale last summer, accounted for the most important victory of her career yesterday by winning the $28,100 Prioress Stakes at Aqueduct.

LEXINGTON, Ky., April 26 --A better than fair preview of the Kentucky Derby will be contested tomorrow with the 44th running of the Blue Grass Stakes. Ten colts are listed to compete in the 1 1/3-mile test for 13-year-olds and the modest $25,000-added value of the race is far exceeded by the class of the field.
Most businessmen who fled the Republican ranks to vote for President Johnson have returned to the fold.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- Senate investigators heard testimony today that foreign aid officials "were indifferent" when they were told last year that the Agency for International Development was about to pay out $250,000 for shipment to South Vietnam of a worthless battery additive.

Old-line district leaders in the Manhattan Democratic organization won a battle with Reformers last night when the organization designated Andrew R. Tyler, board chairman of Haryou-Act, for a seat on the Civil Court bench.
Contracts have been signed for the Jewish State Theater of Poland, headed by Ida Kaminska, to open a limited run at the Billy Rose Theater on Oct. 19.
United Nations Secretary General Thant praised Pope Paul VI yesterday for his "preoccupation with the theme of peace on earth."
The nation's electric power production in the week ended April 22 rose 7.7 per cent from the level in the corresponding 1966 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.
Expo 67, opening tomorrow in Montreal, is expected to draw millions of Americans in its six-month run and many of them will be crossing the border in their own underinsured cars.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, April 25 --The Lebanese Government published a criminal indictment tonight against Yussef Beidas, former managing director of Intra Bank, and 11 other executives of the bank, which closed its doors last October.

LESLIE UGGAMS has a secretive smile that sug gests she knows something we don't know, and I imagine Broadway is going to keep her around long enough to find out what that gleeful, dark-eyed, warmly modest and slyly kept little confidence may be.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The presidents of the three major television networks supported today the creation of a nationwide educational television service.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)--Lieut. Col. Michael Collins and Lieut. Col. David R. Scott, both in the Air Force, will represent the United States at the Paris Air Show next month, Acting Secretary of Commerce Alexander B. Trowbridge said today.
BOSTON, April 26--Ambassador Henry Cabot Lodge returned to his home state today with a warning that "disunity in America prolongs the war" in Vietnam.
PROVIDENCE, R. I, April 26 --Dartmouth's baseball team spotted Brown two runs in the first inning, then went on to a 5-2 victory in an Eastern Intercollegiate game here today.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26--Yugoslavia joined 49 African and Asian states today in a formal resolution calling for the use of force to establish United Nations control of South-West Africa.
LA PAZ, Bolivia, April 26-- The armed forces announced today that they had killed two more guerrillas in a clash last night in the Muyupampa area.
New York University defeated Iona, 4-1, in a Metropolitan Conference baseball game yesterday.
The stock market's long winning streak was snapped yesterday.
The report of Procter Gamble Co. disclosed yesterday record sales and earnings for the three-month and nine-month Periods ended March 31.
A group of dissident stockholders took charge of the Penn-Dixie Cement Corporation yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Both exports and imports declined slightly in March, the Department of Commerce reported today.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP)-- William Thoresen 3d, 30year-old son of a Chicago steel corporation president, surrendered today while Federal agents were rounding up weapons and ammunition consigned to him, including a 37-mm, antitank gun.
A shift in the top management of Fieldcrest Mills, Inc., Spray, N. C., was announced yesterday by the company's directors.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- Senator Abraham A. Ribicoff, Democrat of Connecticut, challenged President Johnson today to display the same kind of "leadership" in solving urban problems as he has in conducting the war in Vietnam.

In a major policy address, John E. Horne, chairman of the Federal Home Loan Bank Board, yesterday warned the nation's savings and loan industry to build up its holdings of shortterm Government securities, or face the possibility that Federal regulation might compel it to do so.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- An academic specialist on Asia has challenged the United States Government's general explanation of Communist strategy in Vietnam by asserting that Communist China and North Vietnam have conflicting goals in Southeast Asia and have been forced into reluctant cooperation by American actions.
Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday voluntary acceptance by the Consolidated Edison Company and the Brooklyn Union Gas Company of the city's proposal for a safety program covering gas distribution.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Hearings on the proposed merger of American Broadcast ing Companies, Inc., into the international Telephone Telegraph Corporation ended today.

MONTREAL--There are red and white traffic signs throughout this bilingual city that read Stop-Arret. There are no such visible signs in fashion. They aren't necessary. Most women who have passed the first blush of youth and progressed to the bloom of maturity recognize the intersection of time that says Stop.
Barnard College announced yesterday the appointment of its first male librarian in its 78-year history.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The Treasury announced today that it was offering to holders of $22.1-billion of Government securities maturing in May, June and August a chance to exchange them for two new note issues.

DETROIT, April 26--The General Motors Corporation reported today first-quarter net income of $389.6-million, or $1.35 a common share, down 34.5 per cent from $594.1-million, or $2.07 a common share a year ago.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The Government intensified efforts today to settle a Chicago trucking dispute that is holding up final settlement on a national trucking contract.
The credit markets, which have been declining nervously for several days in anticipation of the refunding offer announced by the Treasury yesterday afternoon, were generally down again yesterday.

DALLAS, Tex., April 26 (AP) --The president of the American Red Cross said today that thus far the organization had been unable to do anything substantial for United States prisoners of war in North Viet nam.
The Celanese Corporation announced yesterday the election of its three executive vice presidents to the board of directors.
EASTMAN KODAK, the blue-chip favorite of banks, churches and many other investors, moved into lower territory yesterday.

NAPLES, Fla., April 26-- Dr. Charles J. Umberger, testifying at the murder trial of Dr. Carl A. Coppolino, conceded today that the experimental methods by which he found "possible" traces of a paralyzing drug in the body of Carmela. Coppolino were "not complete enough" for publication in a scientific journal.

The New York Knickerbockers have called a news conference for noon today at which the National Basketball Association club expected to announce the signing of Bill Bradley, a former Princeton all-America who was the Knicks' No. 1. draft choice two years ago and who has been a Rhodes Scholar at Oxford since then.

FRANKFORT, Ky., April 26 (AP)--The State Court of Appeals refused today to keep Jefferson Circuit Judge Marvin Sternberg from jailing seven civil rights leaders for contempt of court in Louisville's open housing controversy.

ALBANY, April 26--A network of community hostels where the mentally retarded can live, hold outside jobs and carry on almost normal lives with a minimum of support and supervision will be set up in the state under a bill signed by Governor Rockefeller.

Grandiose plans to hold annual international summer and winter games in the United States along the lines of the Olympics and to raise a $10million permanent sports development fund were announced yesterday by the Amateur Athletic Union.
SYRACUSE, April 26-- George C. Wallace opened a four-day political tour through potential racial trouble spots in the North today by proclaiming himself a "spoiler."
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The Eastern Milk Producers Cooperative Association rejected today a Government move to raise the price of milk paid to farmers by a half cent a quart.

The Directors Guild of America will present a retrospective showing of eight films made by Fred Zinnemann, winner of the Academy Award for his direction of "A Man for All Seasons," starting Tuesday, at the Cinema Rendezvous, 58th Street, east of Seventh Avenue.
An artist's sketch of a suspect wanted for the shotgun slaying of a uniformed marine in Greenwich Village last April 3 was distributed by the Police Department yesterday.
The city's grime and soot will be removed from the Municipal Building for the first time since it was built in 1906.

The grievances of lay teachers, who have threatened to strike Monday in five Roman Catholic elementary schools in Harlem, will be considered tomorrow by Cardinal Spellman and the New York Archdiocese Board of Consultors, an advisory body.

MONTGOMERY, Ala., April 26--Army bomb experts joined with law-enforcement authorities today in the investigation of an explosion last night outside the home of the mother of a Federal judge whose rulings have provoked considerable controversy.

BONN, April 26--Before returning to Washington from the funeral of former Chancellor Konrad Adenauer, President Johnson assured Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger today of "constant, complete and full consultation" between their Governments in the future. He was responding to German complaints about too little consultation.

James N. Peterson, musical director and conductor for the national company of "Man of La Mancha," died Tuesday night at the United States Public Health Service Hospital in Clifton, S. I. He was 55 years old and lived in Freeport, L. I.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- A rioting mob stoned and attacked the United States aid mission in Yemen today and several American aid officials were taken into custody by the Yemeni authorities, the State Department announced.
AKRON, Ohio, April 26 (AP) --Contract negotiations resumed today in the six-day-old strike by 50,000 members of the United Rubber Workers.
ATHENS, April 26--A little after 1 A.M. last Friday the phone rang in the royal palace at Tatoi.
Mrs. Adam Clayton Powell said during an interview here yesterday that any reconciliation with her husband "would depend on many changes being made."

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The Soviet Union has rejected an American request for help in seeking to examine the conditions of United States prisoners of war held by North Vietnam, the State Department disclosed today.

George London was received very warmly last night by the audience when he walked out on the Philharmonic Hall stage for his second solo recital in town this year, after a long absence because of illness.

James Pease, a leading bassbaritone who had appeared with the New York City Opera for a decade, died yesterday, apparently of a heart attack, at the Lincoln Square Motor Inn, where he had been living since January. He was 51 years old and had made his home for the last several years in Munich and London.
PARIS, April 26--La Croix, a moderate Roman Catholic daily, suggested today that the dragging on of the war might work against President Johnson as the 1968 elections neared.

TRENTON, April 26--The Interstate Commerce Commission approved today in Washington the state's Aldene plan, under which 10,000 commuters of the Central Railroad of New Jersey will be able to go to Manhattan without having to cross the Hudson River by ferry.

OTIS AIR FORCE BASE, Mass., April 26 (AP)--An air and surface hunt of the Atlantic off Nantucket Island today sought some trace of 13 Air Force men missing since last night when their four-engined plane plunged into the sea less than two miles off the island.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The Senate called a temporary halt today to a struggle over campaign financing that has taken on aspects of a parliamentary stalemate.
The Bankers Trust Company announced here yesterday the election of C. Wadsworth Farnum and W. Neal Fulkerson Jr. as senior vice presidents.

TORONTO, April 26 (AP)-- Stan Mikita, the Chicago Black Hawk center, and Harry Howell of the Rangers and Bobby Orr of the Boston Bruins, defensemen, received today National Hockey League awards for superiod play during the 1966-67 regular season.

WEST HARTFORD, Conn., April 26--The engagement of Miss Pamela Curzon Heath, to James S. Bailey-Gates, son of Mrs. Charles S. Bailey-Gates of West Hartford and the late Dr. Bailey-Gates, has been announced by the future bride's father, Benjamin W. Heath. An August wedding is planned.

MOSCOW, April 26--A leading Soviet scientist said today that the Soyuz 1 spacecraft was sent aloft on a number of unmanned flights before being launched on the 24-hour flight that ended in its crash two days ago and the death of its pilot, Col. Vladimir M. Komarov.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Tuesday the level it reached on Monday, which was 98.1.
Seton Hall's baseball team gained sweet revenge yesterday by beating St. Johns, 2-0, behind the six-hit pitching of Ray De Riggi, a sophomore lefthander.

AUSTIN, Tex., April 26--Student protests spread widely across the University of Texas campus today over disciplinary action by the university administration against organizers of a protest against the Vietnam conflict.

DALLAS, April 25--Computer sales of the General Electric Company jumped 600 per cent between 1963 and 1966 and the company's backlog of nuclear-power-related orders increased by $1-billion in the last year, but neither operation is showing a profit, the annual meeting was told today.
LONDON, April 26--The Guardian, a Liberal newspaper, Daily Telegraph, Conservative, took differing views today of the latest raids in North Vietnam.
BETHLEHEM, Pa., April 26 (UPI)--Paul-Henri Spaak, former Belgian Premier, called to day for all-out opposition to the "selfish nationalism" of President de Gaulle.
A proposed "final" voyage by the nuclear ship Savannah to Far East nations has run into a legal obstacle in Japan.

A grant of $150,000 to determine whether pretrial crime reporting prevents fair trials will be made to the American Newspaper Publishers Association Foundation, it was announced yesterday at the association's 81st annual convention here.

Producers, directors and members of the company of the National Repertory Theater as well as patrons of the company's New York engagement will be guests at a champagne supper Sunday at the French Consulate.

World Airways, Inc., the world's largest charter airline, applied yesterday to the Civil Aeronautics Board for permission to become a scheduled carrier providing nonstop transcontinental one-way service in the United States for $75.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The National Academy of Sciences announced today the election of 45 new members and 10 foreign associates. The membership of the academy, generally considered to be the nation's scientific elite, now totals 783.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)--The Justice Department, concerned about gangland vengeance against its witnesses and prosecuting attorneys, has arranged with the Defense Department to help protect them.

It wasn't the most expensive benefit party of the season or the most chock full of fun, but the gala preview of the "Art and the Decorator" exhibition last night at the Wildenstein gallery had a lot going for it. None of the 600 purchasers of the, $25 tickets ran the risk of talkine to a total stranger.

UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., April 26--Raul Prebisch, Secretary General of the United Nations Trade and Development Conference,. said today that there were "very positive" indications of a new United States policy on trade preferences for developing countries.

In a trade that proved the peaceful co-existence of the National and American Leagues, the Philadelphia Eagles obtained Mike Ditka, one of pro football's premier players, from the Chicago Bears yesterday in exchange for Jack Concannon, a scrambling quarterback, and a 1968 draft choice.

Humbert Lucarelli's concert at Carnegie Recital Hall last night was full of music but it seemed too short. The oboist made his debut here in 1964, and has appeared in various local ensembles since then. He put together an ideal kind of program, and it was a distinct pleasure to have been there.
The editor and part owner of the leftist weekly National Guardian has resigned after a dispute over editorial policy and has turned his stock over to the staff.

Abandoning the mini-hit offense they unveiled Tuesday, the New York. Yankees went back to orthodox hitting yesterday and were promptly stifled by Gary Peters, who held them to four safeties while pitching the Chicago White Sox to a 5-1 victory at Yankee Stadium.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 26 (AP)--Rain limited the men's North and South amateur golf tournament to one round today. Two Walker Cup players--Jim Grant and Jack Lewis--and Marion Heck, last year's runner-up, were eliminated.
The spot rate on the British pound eased in quiet trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.

HOUSTON, April 26 (AP)-- The St. Louis Cardinals scored four runs on two hits in the fourth inning tonight and beat Houston, 7-2. The victory lengthened the Astros' losing streak' to 10 games.

KARLOVY VARY, Czechoslovakia, April 26--The Communist parties of Eastern and Western Europe launched today a campaign, to prevent renewal of the North Atlantic Treaty when it expires in 1969 and to push the United States out of Europe.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 26 (Reuters)--Anti-Chinese violence has spread to Indonesia's biggest island, Sumatra, the official press agency Antara reported today.

Two hundred Negro and white merchants will try to rally the Harlem community to support the police this summer.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The Soviet Union's Soyuz spacecraft was apparently tested in either two or four unmanned flights before Colonel Komarov made a manned flight last weekend, space officials here said today.
Within the usually hushed Gothic quadrangle in the Union Theological Seminary, nearly 150 students waved placards yesterday, plunked guitars and roared: "We will not be moved."

First-quarter sales and earnings of the Colgate-Palmolive Company both rose more than 10 per cent from a year earlier to record levels, George H. Lesch, chairman and president, reported yesterday to some 400 shareholders at the annual meeting in the Statler Hilton Hotel here.

THIS theatergoer belongs to the spoilsport minority that has never been able to find much to admire in Rodgers and Hammerstein's "The Sound of Music" but the sound of its music. Last night's revival at City Center did not erase the prejudice.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Governor Rockefeller criticized the Johnson Administration today for its proposed cutback on funds for water pollution control.
One thousand seminarians have signed a letter to Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara urging that the draft law be changed to permit conscientious objection to a particular war.
NEWNAN, Ga., April 26 (AP)--Dr. Janie W. McGaughey has become the first woman moderator of a presbytery in the general assembly of the Presbyterian Church in the United States.

DENVER, April 26--Colorado doctors began receiving inquiries from pregnant women in all parts of the United States late yesterday, within minutes after Gov. John A. Love approved the liberalization of this state's abortion law.

WASHINGTON, April 26 --The nation's highest military court ruled today that the limitations on police interrogation and confessions announced last year by the Supreme Court must also be applied in military law.
PARIS, April 26--The Government of President de Gaulle decided today to ask the National Assembly for special executive powers for six months.
Two bank robbery suspects found themselves trapped yesterday in the Lincoln Tunnel with a patrolman ahead of them and a busload of Policemen behind.

CLEVELAND, April 26 (UPI)--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. said today that the best candidates for President in 1968 "from a civil rights standpoint" would be Senators Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, and Charles H. Percy, Republican of Illinois.
An attempt at a new approach to community education for adults was announced yesterday for a six-block area on the lower East Side by Mobilization for Youth, an antidelinquency, antipoverty agency.
IN the Pire Defense--a hypermodern opening in which the defender momentarily cedes control of the center-- one slight lapse may be too many.

BOSTON, April 26--Mr. and Mrs. Louis Kronenberger of Boston and St. Andrews, N. B., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Kronenberger, to George Angus Wanklyn, son of Lieut. Col. Frederic A. Wanklyn, a retired Army officer, and Mrs. Wanklyn of Nassau, the Bahamas.

PRINCETON, N. J., April 26 --Bill van Breda Kolff, who turned Princeton University into a national power in his five seasons as head basketball coach at the school, will leave Princeton to coach the Los Angeles Lakers of the National Basketball Association next season.

BONN, April 26--On the day Konrad Adenauer died, last Wednesday, Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger complained to the West German Cabinet: "it is always the same--one is unclear about the concept of American policy."
In a $34.65-million transaction, Ginn Co., a textbook publisher, and the Cahners Publishing Company announced yesterday in Boston an agreement in Principle to merge.
William Cross Ferguson, former president of the old World Book Company, died Monday in Carmel, Calif., where he lived recently. He was 71 years old and was a former resident of Bronxville, N. Y.

Thomas P. F. Hoving, the new director, of the Metropolitan Museum of Art, said last night that he wanted to change the museum's attitude toward the public and make it a place where people would come, for "refreshment of the mind and soul and body" instead of for merely formal education.

Bert Stand, a chubby, cheerful, quick-witted politician who served for 13 years as secretary of Tammany Hall, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home, 473 Franklin Delano Roosevelt Drive. He was 65 years old.

Governor Rockefeller has every reason to veto the bill now before him that would permit New York City's policemen to "moonlight" up to twenty hours a week. The Lindsay administration's objection that the measure is a legislative violation of the city's right to home rule is well taken. This is certainly a matter for the city, not the Legislature, to decide.

THE three television networks interrupted their games and soap operas yesterday afternoon to introduce a woman who in due course should become a star attraction of the American medium: Svetlana Alliluyeva.
SCHENECTADY, April 26-- Governor Rockefeller tonight sharply criticized the direct primary bill passed by the Legislature that would make it easier for an insurgent to run for statewide office.

ABOARD U.S.S. COLLETT, off North Vietnam, April 26 --Off to the west, the coast of North Vietnam was clearly visible with its shimmering beaches and shadowy mountains. It was about six miles away-- roughly the distance from the Verrazano-Narrows Bridge to the battery.
TEANECK, N. J., April 26-- Don Balsamo's pitching and batting gave Long Island University a 6-1 Metropolitan Conference victory over Fairleigh Dickinson here today.
A partial eclipse of the sun will be seen--weather permitting--in the New York metropolitan area from 9:21 A.M. to 10:19 A.M. on Tuesday, May 9.

MONTREAL--It is a commonplace in the world of food to make a distinction between hotel restaurants and those restaurants that are in themselves a separate entity. They are generally measured with separate yardsticks, the assumption being that hotel restaurants, with rare exceptions, cater to more of a mass and therefore a less discriminating public.

Senator Charles H. Percy. Republican of Illinois, told 1,300 business and banking executives last night that he regarded Governor Rockefeller as the best qualified man in his party for the presidency.
The Waterfront Commission of New York Harbor expressed a "hands off" attitude yesterday in the dispute between longshore management and labor over a second "badge in" for longshoremen.

John C. Lobb, formerly executive vice president of the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation, has been named president, chief executive officer and a director of the Crucible Steel Company, the steel concern said yesterday.
LONDON, April 26--An agreement reached with labor unions this week to save The Sun, an ailing national newspaper, calls for a reduction of 11 per cent in The Sun's staff.
"We'll show the citizens of New York how a clean, city looks," said Sanitation Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr. yesterday.
BRIDGEWATER, N. J., April 26 (AP)--Mrs. Emily Macy Brewster Frelinghuysen, widow of Sen. Joseph S. Frelinghuysen, died today in the Somerset Valley Nursing Home. She was 87 years old.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 26 (AP)--Tony Perez' groundout and Don Pavletich's single produced two fifth inning runs, lifting the Cincinnati Reds to a 4-2 victory over the San Francisco Giants today.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 (UPI)--Stockholders of the Filtrol Corporation voted by a 3-1 margin in favor of retaining the company's present management headed by president Myron A. Bantrell, it was disclosed today.
Girls Clubs of America, Inc., a federation of clubs in the United States and Canada, yesterday acquired a five-story building at 133 East 62d Street that will be its home.
ATHENS, April 26--"Popularity-is not a solid founda tion for monarchy," a Greek politician once remarked.

Every passenger who has ever frozen or sweltered on one of New York's ancient piers will welcome the completion of plans for a modern, comfortable consolidated ship terminal on the Hudson River. Now it is up to Mayor Lindsay, through whose initiative the Port Authority drew up the plans, to find a way to translate this much-needed improvement into actuality.

The Mayors of New York and Los Angeles, whose Harlem and Watts areas have been the scenes of riots, told newspaper publishers yesterday that they were concerned about how the mass media would handle news of racial unrest in the "long, hot summer" ahead.
COLUMBIA, S. C., April 26 --Gen. William C. Westmoreland praised United States Negro fighting men in Vietnam in a brief speech before the South Carolina General Assembly here today.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- Individuals seem to vary greatly in their daily requirements for such food factors as vitamin C, Dr. Roger J. Williams told the National Academy of Sciences today.

LOS ANGELES, April 26 (AP)--Lou Johnson doubled with two out in the eighth inning and scored the tie-breaking run on Ron Fairly's single, lifting the Los Angeles Dodgers past the Atlanta Braves, 2-1, tonight.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary issued a bill of rights yesterday for policemen who are under investigation for assertedly violating departmental regulations.

THE marginalia of great writers are never without interest--especially when they aren't really marginalia but, like "The Wishing Tree," a charming and complete story in its own right; albeit for children. William Faulkner (1897-1962) wrote "The Wishing Tree" sometime between the publication of his first adult novel,...

The Brooklyn Union Gas Company reported yesterday gains in operating revenues and net income for the March quarter. John E. Heyke Jr., president, traced the improvements to a slightly colder heating season.

ROME, April 26--The world faces a "dramatic crisis," with millions of people lacking the necessities for "human dignity" in the midst of plenty, the new Vatican Commission on Peace and Justice said today.

TEANECK, N. J., April 26 --William J. Bolte, vice president, general counsel and secretary of the Worthington Corporation, died today of a heart attack at his home here at 57 Van Buren Avenue. He was 60 years old. His office was at 401 Worthington Avenue, Harrison.
ONE of the advantages of the Bridge-O-Rama method used for displaying the play in major matches is that the players do not have to suffer from the physical presence of the kibitzers.
GARDEN CITY, L, I, April 26--Dr. Arthur W. Brown has resigned as president of Adelphi University to return to teaching, the university's board of trustees announced today.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)--About 200 Howard University students stormed a classroom building today, knocking campus policemen aside and ripping out a door, to break up a disciplinary committee meeting.
ISLAMABAD, Pakistan, April 28 (Reuters)--President Mohammad Ayub Khan presided over the first meeting of his Cabinet today in Islamabad, Pakistan's new capital.

MIAMI, April 26 (AP)-- The Florida peninsula is patching in the grip of the state's worst spring drought in a quarter century. Smoke from fires in the Everglades is hanging over the eastern coast and water rationing has begun in the keys.

The American Electric Power Company plans to spend an average of $275-million a year for the five years 1966 through 1970, Donald C. Cook, president, told some 250 stockholders at the annual meeting yesterday morning in the Biltmare Hotel.

Svetlana Alliluyeva had several minutes yesterday to wonder at the efficiency of American technology. After she left her news conference at the plaza Hotel she became stuck in one of the hotel's elevators.
A Harlem committee yesterday issued a counterproposal for the controversial Intermediate School 201, in opposition to a plan offered last week by the Board of Education.

WASHINGTON, April 26 (AP)--The House Committee on Un-American Activities unanimously approved today a bill providing a fine of up to $20,000 and imprisonment of up to 20 years for anyone who aids the Vietcong or the North Vietnamese.

The Rev. and Mrs. James P. Alter of the Christian Study Center of Rajpur, India, and, Hamden, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Martha Alter, to Lincoln C. Chen, son of Dr.Samuel S. T. Chen of New Britain, Conn., and the late Mrs. Winifred Wan Chen.

CAIRO, April 28--Former King Saud of Saudi Arabia told his former subjects in a radio broadcast from Cairo tonight that he was still their rightful ruler and would return to "save the people and the country."

William Lewis of 40 West 135th Street, the president of the City Employes Union Local 237 of the International Brotherhood of Teamsters, died Tuesday in Harlem Hospital after a brief illness. He was 68 years old.
The Northwestern Mutual Life Insurance Company announced yesterday in Milwaukee the election of Francis E. Ferguson as president.
"If we can change the attitudes of these kids, then we're in business. Otherwise, we might as well forget it."

WASHINGTON, April 26-- Representative Edna F. Kelly, one of the principal opponents of the proposed Cross Brooklyn Expressway, said today that she had been assured by a Federal highway official that the Government had not approved the road as part of the Federal Interstate system.

The Babcock Wilcox Company is observing its centennial year with the highest first-quarter earnings, shipments, new orders and backlog in its history, stockholders were informed yesterday at their annual meeting in the Biltmore Hotel here.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, April 27--The Vietcong set off explosive charges in seven locomotives at a Saigon railroad depot early today, apparently in retaliation for United States bombing of a railroad yard near Hanoi.

"SOLDIER IN LOVE;" last night's play on the "Hallmark Hall of Fame," was a disappointing and tedious telling of the relationship between Queen Anne and the Duke and Duchess of Marlborough. The friendship that began in love and ended in hatred was unfolded by Jerome Ross, the dramatist, in a succession of clipped installments that had more in common with a costume serial than a compelling historical drama.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The managing director of the International Monetary Fund reported today "great progress" in negotiations toward the creation of new world monetary reserves, but negotiators indicated that agreement on a plan this year remained in serious doubt.

TRENTON, April 26--Gov. Richard J. Hughes declared his support today for a law that would require every legislator and all members of the State Government to make a public disclosure of any business dealings with state agencies.
That loud whooshing sound you'll be hearing today, will be the Collective sigh of relief from all the N. W. Ayer Son troops when they hear:
ATHENS, April 26--King Constantine, acceding to pressure from the new military Government, attended a Cabinet meeting today, but later urged an early return to parliamentary government.
The Congress of Racial Equality has been technically off the registration lists of organizations permitted to raise funds in New York State for almost a year.
MARTINS FERRY, Ohio, April 26 (AP)--The superintendent of Martins Ferry schools discharged 87 teachers today for alleged violation of a law prohibiting strikes by public employes.

CHICAGO, April 26--Arrangements were made today to stole the gray Cadillac in Dibbles Garage and close out the long-term room at the 50th On The Lake Motel here. Muhammad Ali, who is also known as Cassius Clay, was going down to meet The Man, and he didn't know when he'd be back.
MANILA, April 26--President Ferdinand E. Marcos ordered today the evacuation of 300 families from Volcano Island, it Lake Taal, 40 miles south of Manila.

WASHINGTON, April 26 -- President Johnson, who returned here today to find increasing Congressional criticism of his Vietnam policy, said tonight that "I want more than any human being in the world to see the killing stopped."
CHICAGO, April 26--The New York Mets, in a move to fortify their bull pen, bought Jack Lamabe from the Chicago White Sox today.
WESTBURY, L. I, April 26-- Best of All, last season's champion 2-year-old pacer, worked out before a knowledgeable and appreciative audience of horsemen at Roosevelt Raceway this morning.
NEW DELHI, April 26-- Prime Minister Indira Gandhi's Congress party finally took power today in the troubled state of Rajasthan, ending more than two months of political stalemate there.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, April 26--United States Air Force pilots tried today to cut Hanoi's only rail approach from Communist China as they struck at the city for the second day in a row.

ORANGE, N.J., April 26-- Showings of the film "I, a Woman" went on as scheduled at the Palace Theater here today despite the arrest of the theater manager on charges of conspiring to violate a state statute on obscenity in presenting the picture.
WASHINGTON, April 26 (UPI)--The Voice of America has suspended its news broadcasts to Greece rather than submit to Greek censorship regarding the Greek coup d'etat, a spokesman said today.
A Brooklyn man injured while taking a shotgun away from an armed robber in a Brooklyn tavern was given a $500 good Samaritan award yesterday by Brotherhood-inAction.
ON the amateur race track, all hounds are equal whether they are champions of record or dogs that wouldn't merit a second look from a show judge.

A change in the stated political policy of the United States appears to have accompanied the change of American Ambassadors in Saigon. In the farewell interview given to The Times by Henry Cabot Lodge he frankly comes out for an important South Vietnamese military role in whatever government results from the coming elections.

More than 750 handymen, porters, doormen and custodians at 50 cooperative housing developments in Queens walked off their jobs yesterday. They left many of the 75,000 tenant families without heat, hot water and garbage collection and maintenance services.

MOSCOW, April 26--A flower-covered urn containing the ashes of Col. Vladimir M. Komarov, the astronaut killed two days ago while testing a new type of spaceship, was buried in the Kremlin wall today in a military funeral attended by top Soviet leaders and scientists.
The election of Crocker Nevin to the board of the Air Reduction Company was announced yesterday at the annual stockholders' meeting in the Commodore Hotel here.

GREAT NECK, L. I. April 26--Mrs. Rosalie Gould Clark, the widow of Howard F. Clark, a partner in Burton Brothers, a former cotton-goods business long at Fifth Avenue and 36th Street, New York, died Saturday at her home here. She was 94 years old.

The Medal for Excellence of the Columbia Law School Alumni Association Will be presented tonight to Chief Judge Stanley H. Fuld of the New York State Court of Appeals at the association's annual meeting at the New York Hilton Hotel.

THE IMAGINARY INVALID, by Moliere, adapted by Miles Malleson, directed by Jack Sydow; presented by the National Repertory Theater tonight and Sunday, at 8:30, at the ANTA Theater, 245 West 52d Street. The play opens May 1.

WASHINGTON, April 26-- The House Armed Services Committee moved today to keep alive the Administration's plans for a fleet of fast deployment logistic ships, which the Senate had rejected because of concern that the United States was overextending its international military force.
A three-in-one motion-picture theater is being planned as a part of the new Gimbels store that will replace the old RKO Theater at Lexington Avenue and 86th Street.

PURCHASE, N.Y., April 26 --Estate owners fighting to save their open fields and picturesque country roads here from intrusions by commerce demanded today a referendum supporting a plan to incorporate Purchase as a self-governing village.
Industrial Issues led a strong rally yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.

Balfour, Maclaine International, Ltd., a trade and finance concern, has leased the eighth floor in the 30-story office building nearing completion at 55 Broad Street, at the northeast corner of Beaver Street.

LONDON, April 26--A Picasso painting brought the highest price ever paid for a work by a living artist. A Cezanne set a record for a water-color at an auction here today. Both were bought by American companies for undisclosed clients.
LONDON, April 26--The Labor Government announced today a compromise settlement in its battle with two giant soap and detergent manufacturers over prices, fair profits and advertising.
MOSCOW, April 28--The bombing attack on Haiphong last week was a "new and extremely dangerous step" in escalation of the war, Pravda, the Soviet party newspaper, has said.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The United States has reluctantly agreed to additional arms purchases from Britain to prevent a substantial reduction in the British forces in West Germany.

THE Friends of French Opera made their point at St. George's Church last night: 45 years is too long to wait between performances of Massenet's "Le Jongleur de Nitre Dame" ("The Juggler of Our Lady").
BABYLON, L. I, April 26 --Robert Moses' request todownzone his home here was rejected today by the trustees of this South Shore village.

An official of a major fiber and chemical corporation testified yesterday that air pollution regulations Proposed by New York State were "unreasonable, unnecessary in many cases, vague and detrimental to the cause of clean air."
Operations of the Standard Oil Company of California in the initial quarter this year resulted in record net income of $103,507,000, it was reported yesterday by O. N. Miller, chairman.

NORWALK, Conn., April 26 --The Rev. Dr. Eugene Carson Blake, general secretary of the World Council of Churches, declared today that United States policies in Vietnam were leading this country "to tragic disaster."
HONG KONG, April 26-- Communist China's Foreign Minister, Chen Yi, declared today that neither the Vietnamese people nor the Chinese people were to be "trifled with."

MONTREAL, April 26 (AP) --President Johnson will visit Expo 67 on May 24, the Quebec provincial government said today. He is among more than 50 heads of state expected at the Montreal World's Fair, which opens Friday.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- House Republicans moved to day to assure private school pupils full benefits of all mon ey under a "state block grant' approach to Federal school aid.

HONG KONG, April 26--The inauguration last week of a new governing committee for Peking was carried out with the fanfare the Communist regime reserves for important events and is being hailed by propaganda media in many parts of the country as a big victory for the Maoist forces in the Cultural Revolution.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The country's first commercial plant for extracting oil from the rich Western oil shale lands will be ready for production in 1970, Congress was told today.

HONG KONG, April 26--The inauguration last week of a new governing committee for Peking was carried out with the fanfare the Communist regime reserves for important events and is being hailed by propaganda media in many parts of the country as a big victory for the Maoist forces in the Cultural Revolution.
WASHINGTON, April 26-- The country's first commercial plant for extracting oil from the rich Western oil shale lands will be ready for production in 1970, Congress was told today.

Svetlana Alliluyeva said yesterday that the responsibility for killings and other crimes during the regime of Stalin, her father, should be shared by Soviet Communist officials still in leadership roles.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The Congress has been given the bill for restoring four historical paintings slashed Dec. 6 by a deranged visitor to the Capitol $64,000.

SOUTHOLD, L.I., April 27 Walter J. Cowan, who retired in 1954 as an officer and director of Brown, Crosby Co., insurance brokers at 110 William Street in New York, died Monday at the Eastern Long Island Hospital in Greenport. He was 78 years old, and his home, named Laughing Water, was here.

A NEW work that is certain to be played by at least 10 symphony orchestras within the next two years was given a brilliant premiere at Philharmonic Hall last night by the New York Philharmonic under the direction of Leonard Bernstein.

ABOARD U.S.S. COLLETT, off North Vietnam, April 27 In the modern Navy, with its missiles, computers, jets and nuclear reactors, it comes as a shock to find someone who fits the swashbuckling tradition of 30 years ago.

WASHINGTON, April 27----Another holiday cease-fire in the Vietnam war was virtually assured today when the Vietcong announced in a radio broadcast that its forces would observe a 48-hour truce for the anniversary of Buddha's birthday, May 23.
WASHINGTON, April 27 A bill setting up guidelines for states to fix their Congressional districts passed the House tonight.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Senate ethics committee recommended today that Senator Thomas J. Dodd be censured for conduct "contrary to accepted morals" that tended to bring the Senate "into dishonor and disrepute."

Canada and the United States both have hits in Expo 67, which opened in Montreal yesterday. The fair bids to be one of the great international shows of the century, and the United States Pavilion is a standout a joyous distillation of the best American art, science and culture, no less profound for its easy wit and beauty.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Senator John L. McClellan said today there were indications that the use of some funds in the commodity import program in Vietnam was improper and "of highly questionable legality."
HANOI, North Vietnam, April 26 (Agence France-Presse)--The American pilot lay still on a woven bed in the hut as a North Vietnamese officer, a girl and a peasant told in whispers how he had died.

THE squirrels have struck a blow for mankind and against automation in nature. It happened way up in Ontario, near Combermere in the District Tweed, and surely the incident must rank in news value with the first man who bit a dog.
TRENTON, April 27 Plans for New Jersey's first comprehensive attack on air pollution cleared the Legislature today.
The bond market rallied in mid-session yesterday to offset many early losses in Government and corporate bonds. Prices ended slightly lower for the most part, but a few issues posted gains.
The newspaper industry offered $10,000 yesterday toward an independent study to determine the true size of television audiences.

The Eastman Kodak Company, which is engaged in a bitter struggle with a militant Negro group over the company's repudiation of a job-training program, announced yesterday that it had hired a Harlem public-relations company specializing in "ethnic marketing."

Perhaps the strangest aspect of the inquiry into last January's Apollo tragedy has been the persistent refusal of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration to put into the public record the so-called Phillips Report which called official attention in December 1965 to disturbing deficiencies in North American Aviation's performance as prime contractor in the program to put men on the moon.
WASHINGTON, April 27 A State Department spokesman said tonight that reported charges that American aid employes in Yemen were involved in sabotage were "totally unfounded."

Homes and gardens in the Chelsea area of New York will be opened for a tour next Thursday afternoon to benefit the neighborhood's Hudson Guild-Fulton Senior Citizens Center at 119 Ninth Avenue, near 18th Street. Some of the residences are 19th-century restorations.

Miss Penelope Ann Makin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. John William Makin of Kuwait, was married yesterday to Thomas William Hamilton Phelps, son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Phelps of Greenwich, Conn. The Rev. George J. Holler performed the Episcopal service in the American Mission Church of Christ in Kuwait.
LEXINGTON, Ky., April 27 Diplomat Way ran straight today, straight to an upset victory in the Blue Grass Stakes for 3-Year-olds.
LISBON, April 27 Premier Antonio de Oliveira Salazar today marked the 39th anniversary of his rise to power. He will be 78 years old tomorrow.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Loyd Hackler, a former newspaperman, is leaving the Veterans Administration information service to join the White House press staff.

WASHINGTON, April 27 If the Senate supports the recommendation today of its ethics committee, Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, will become the sixth Senator whose conduct has been censured or condemned by his colleagues.

Manolis Glezos captured the attention of the world and became a national hero when he climbed the Aeropolis and tore down a Nazi flag after the Germans had entered Athens in 1941. He was sentenced to die three times in the next eight years once by the Nazis, and twice after the war by the Greek Government.
Police Commissioner Howard R. Leary said yesterday that his department had started a major drive to recruit more auxiliary policemen in a move "to get more men out on patrol."
LOS ANGELES, April 27 One of the largest and most ambitious surveys of contemporary American sculpture ever undertaken opened here this evening at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art.
A new administrative procedure requiring landlords to paint rent-controlled apartments every two or three years without subjecting tenants to unnecessary delay will become effective on May 8.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 27 Jamil M. Baroody, the Saudi Arabian delegate, told his African and Asian colleagues today that the General Assembly might adopt their resolution on South-West Africa but that the United Nations would not enforce it.
FRANKFURT, April 27 (AP) The Federal Bank announced today that reserve requirements on commercial bank deposits would be reduced an additional 5 per cent in a further effort to ease credit.
William J. Miller Jr., a vice president of the United States Trust Company of New York at 45 Wall Street, died Wednesday in Myrtle Beach, S.C. His age was 62 and he lived in Murray Hill, N.J.
Special to The New York Times
CANNES, France, April 27 The 20th film festival at Cannes had its premiere this evening.
The Federal Reserve is continuing to press its policy of credit expansion, but at a slower rate than was the case only a few weeks ago, banking statistics released yesterday indicated.
George Meany said yesterday that he was in good health and that it might be a long time before he would step aside for Walter P. Reuther or anyone else.

PITTSBURGH, April 27 George C. Wallace refused today to criticize the John Birch Society and expressed appreciation to three of its members for organizing local support for his candidacy for President.
WASHINGTON, April 27 President Johnson denounced today as "reckless" and "partisan" a major Republican effort to revamp the Administration's program of aid to elementary and secondary schools.

SINGAPORE, April 27 Denis Healey, Britain's Defense Minister, said here today that Britain would reduce her forces in the Far East from the present 50,000 men to 30,000. The withdrawals are to be made over the next year from Singapore and Malaysia.

PARIS The Vietnamese war seems to be escalating politically as much as it is escalating militarily. China's leadership has drawn together to curb excesses of the cultural revolution. At the same time Moscow and Peking, while poles apart on other matters, have patched up an agreement to help Hanoi.

WASHINGTON, April 27--Senator Thruston B. Morton, Republican of Kentucky, said today that the Administration was helping to spread "an epidemic of verbal overkill" by bringing Gen. William C. Westmoreland to speak before a joint session of Congress tomorrow.
CANBERRA, Australia, April 27 (Reuters) Australian politicians angrily rejected a charge by a disillusioned young member of Parliament today that many of them were "half-drunk half the time."

GENEVA, April 27 Serious consideration is being given to calling a meeting here of ministers from key industrial countries in an effort to break the logjam in the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations.
More powerful street lights and, eventually, less-congested traffic will provide a brighter and smoother future for the Avenue of the Americas.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The most important thing for a President in the middle of a war, President Johnson remarked to some visitors recently, is to have the understanding of the heroes.

In the not-always-good old days, the cinder track at Franklin Field in Philadelphia took such a beating during the Penn Relays that the final races of the two-day carnival were run on a near-disaster area.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The United States Court of Appeals decided today to study further a petition by Adam Clayton Powell for an order declaring his exclusion from the House unconstitutional.

BONN, April 27 President Johnson has told Chancellor Kurt Georg Keisinger that the Western Alliance is more important to the United States than the proposed treaty to prohibit the spread of nuclear weapons, a knowledgeable Bonn source said today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, April 28 More than 100 United States marines were wounded yesterday by enemy artillery and mortar barrages in the two northernmost provinces of South Vietnam.
MOSCOW, April 27 (Reuters) Nikolai F. Ignatov, Deputy Minister of Machine Building for the Light and Food Industries, died yesterday at the age of 53, Izvestia, the Government newspaper, reported.

LONDON, April 27 The Communist party of Britain advocated today complete freedom of religion, artistic expression and scientific research and, in government, a diversity of parties operating democratically.
WESTBURY, L.I., April 27 Sooner or later, a race will have to be found for Romeo Hanover, last season's 3-yearold pacing champion. He has yet to start in 1967.
The city's water supply yesterday stood at 456.3 billion gallons, or 95.8 per cent of capacity, according to the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.
OTTAWA, April 27 (AP) The St. Lawrence Seaway had a net deficit of $3,223,149 last year, the lowest since it opened in 1959, the Seaway Authority's annual report to Parliament disclosed yesterday.
THE mysteries of Pirandello are sufficient unto them selves. Actors and directors really shouldn't try to add to them.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Following are the texts of the major sections of the report by the Senate ethics committee in the case of Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut. Sections dealing with development of the case and procedural matters have been omitted.

The International Fiesta for the benefit of the medical education program of the New York Polyclinic Medical School and Hospital will be held at the Waldorf-Astoria on May 6. A thousand persons are expected to attend.

MONTREAL, April 27 Children can ride zebras, teen-agers can frug at the Cafe Dansant, mother can buy Russian folk art and dad well, he can drink at a Czechoslovak roadhouse, a Bavarian gasthaus or a British pub or cheer Candy Kane as she strips on the bar of the Golden Garter Saloon.

A strike of building service employes, which has forced residents in 50 Queens cooperative developments to carry their own garbage and go without heat or hot running water, may spread to Brooklyn and Staten Island today.
The Repertory Theater of Lincoln Center yesterday approved a two-year extension of the contract with Jules Irving, its director, to May 1, 1970.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The Senate reacted with judicial restraint to the ethics committee's recommendations today that it censure Senator Thomas J. Dodd.
DARIEN, Conn., April 27 Miss Judith Elaine Lybrand and Gerald Marshall Calhoun plan to marry here Aug. 26 in St. John's Roman Catholic Church.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 27 (AP) Mel Queen, an outfielderturned-pitcher, won his third game of the season today as Cincinnati defeated San Francisco, 3-2.
ALBANY, April 27 About 425,000 merchants will be spared some of their paper work in collecting the state sales tax, under a bill signed into law today by Governor Rockefeller.

PAKSE, Laos, April 26 United States specialists think that the so-called Sihanouk Trail, a 60-mile truck road from Cambodia eastward across southern Laos to the Ho Chi Minh Trail, has become a major supply route for enemy forces in South Vietnam.
BEFORE the visiting Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam could dig into its serious program at Carnegie Hall last night an announcement had to be made. No, no one was ill or being replaced.
Edward M. Gilbert, who shortly before his financial empire collapsed in 1962 was worth $23-million on paper, was sentenced yesterday in Federal Court to two years in prison and fined $21,000.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Soviet Union knew by the fifth orbit that Col. Vladimir M. Komarov's Soyuz 1 space flight would have to be ended after a day, official sources said here today in discussing the fatal crash of the ship on Monday.
ROCKPORT, Mass., April 27 W. Findlay Downs, an engineering executive who had a major part in many studies of the New York transit system, died in his home here Tuesday. His age was 79.

WASHINGTON, April 27 A proposal that educational and private broadcasters form a close working relationship once a national educational television system is created was made today by the head of a large commercial radio and television company.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Following is the text of a statement read today by Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, immediately following the release of a report by the Senate ethics committee recommending that he be censured:

The Roman Catholic Archdiocese of New York has encouraged the hundreds of thousands of students at its elementary and high schools and their parents to write personal letters of thanks to Senator Jacob K. Javits for favoring the use of state money to aid parochial as well as public schools.
CHICAGO, April 27 Ferguson Jerkins, a 6-foot-5-inch hockey player from Canada, pitched the Chicago Cubs to a 3-0 victory over the New York Mets today.
LONDON, April 27 The swing against the Labor Government continued today with a massive Conservative victory in a parliamentary by-election.
MONTREAL, April 27 Expo 67 is already rated a hit by early visitors, and finding firstchoice accommodations in Montreal is a problem.
Clinton D. Arnot, director of plant engineering of the General Dynamics Corporation, died Wednesday at Memorial Hospital. He was 53 years old and lived at 1175 York Avenue.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) A funeral service was held at nearby Andrews Air Force Base today for Maj. Gen. Benjamin D. Foulois, the country's oldest military pilot, who died Tuesday at the age of 87.
CLEVELAND, April 27 (AP) Willie Smith's pinch-double broke a 4-4 tie in the eighth inning tonight and gave the Cleveland Indians a 5-4 decision over the Minnesota Twins.
Expansion was the chief theme at stockholder meetings yesterday of the MartinMarietta Corporation in New York, Ling-Temco-Vought, Inc. in Dallas and Wilson Co. in Chicago.
Two metals in which futures trading has been dormant for some time came to life yesterday.
PASADENA, Calif., April 27 (UPI) Tracking stations in Canberra, Australia, and in California commanded Surveyor 3's television camera to take pictures of the lunar terrain today.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., April 27 (AP) The National Aeronautics and Space Administration said today development problems would delay the first unmanned test flights of the Saturn 5 moon rocket and a lunar landing vehicle until the last half of 1967.

Mayor Lindsay declared yesterday that his administration would not infringe upon the integrity or autonomy of the city school system. But he also indicated that he intended to make sure that in education, as in housing, transportation and other areas, "we are getting our money's Worth."
PHILADELPHIA Pennsylvania last year had one of the most successful rowing seasons of Jee Burk's long tenure as head coach.

Martin Starr, former entertainment commentator on radio stations here, died of a stroke Wednesday in the lobby of his apartment house, at 76-35 113th Street, in Forest Hills, Queens. He was 64 years old.
LONDON, April 27 The Race Relations Board called on Parliament today to outlaw discrimination in jobs, housing and insurance.
THE aggressive efforts of out-of-state insurance companies to branch out into a wide variety of financial services has brought the closely regulated New Yorkbased companies to the crossroads.
KANSAS CITY, Mo., April 27 (AP) The stockholders of Trans World Airlines, Inc., approved conditionally today the proposed merger of the airline with the Hilton International Company.

GROSSE POINTE, Mich., April 27 Dr. Francis Bartholomew Bicknell has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Martha Bicknell, to George A. Kellner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul J. Kellner of New York. The wedding is to take place here July 22.

THIS is the day when Cassius Clay is confronted by the most important and fateful decision of his young life. Will it be induction or imprisonment? The heavyweight champion of the world has indicated that he will take jail rather than be drafted into the Army. Military service, he claims, is contrary to his religious beliefs.

ALBANY, April 27 The State Board of Canvassers today certified the election of Adam Clayton Powell to the Congressional seat he had been denied last month and dispatched the results to the clerk of the House of Representatives.
Net income of the Southern Pacific Company in the March quarter dipped to $24,355,630, or 90 cents a share, from $25,160,757, or 93 cents a share the year before, the road reported yesterday.
A proposal that the Mayor of New York serve a six-year term, and not be eligible to succeed himself, was submitted to the City Council yesterday by Controller Mario A. Procaccino.

The Temporary State Commission on the Constitutional Convention outlined yesterday the arguments for and against relaxing the state's stringent ban on financial aid to sectarian educational institutions.

ALBANY, April 27 Governor Rockefeller, in a dilemma, is getting mixed advice from the state's political leaders on whether to sign or veto the controversial direct primary bill dropped on his desk by the Legislature.

NEW ORLEANS, April 27 (UPI)-The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit upheld today the civil rights conspiracy convictions of two Alabama Ku Klux Klan members who were sentenced to 10 years in prison in connection with the 1965 slaying of Mrs. Viola Liuzzo.

LONDON, April 27 The Greater London Council yesterday granted a license against the wishes of the British Board of Film Censors to permit the showing of the film version of James Joyce's novel "Ulysses" in movie theaters here.
ST. LOUIS, April 27 Top executives of the New York Central Railroad said here today that they had seen definite signs of a pick-up in new automobile production.

WASHINGTON, April 27 The Interstate Commerce Commission has unanimously approved the merger of the Chicago Western Railway into the Chicago North Western Railway, William H. Tucker, I.C.C. chairman, announced here today.
The American Stock Exchange moved forward yesterday in active trading.

A bipartisan committee has reached the expected adverse judgment on the conduct of Senator Thomas J. Dodd of Connecticut. Although Mr. Dodd has described the censure verdict as "harsh," the committee members could not in conscience have done less.
GARDEN CITY, L.I., April 27--The Nassau County police said the search was continuing for a rapist who attacked a 16-year-old girl last night in the Cure of Ars Roman Catholic Church in Merrick.

A Port of New York Authority bondholders' committee charged in Federal Court yesterday that the authority was jeopardizing the tax-exempt status of its bonds by pressing ahead with the World Trade Center.

Col. Richard Rush Murray, director of communications of the Army Signal Corps in the Aleutian Islands in World War II, died on Wednesday at Doctors Hospital in Washington. He was 60 years old and was a resident of Arlington, Va.

WESTFIELD, N.J., April 27 John H. Hanrahan Jr., an admiralty lawyer since 1943, died yesterday in Overlook Hospital, Summit. He was 49 years old and was a partner in Foley Martin, 80 Pine Street, New York.

TAIPEI, Taiwan, April 27 (AP) The Ministry of Economic Affairs approved today investments in Taiwan by the Union Carbide Corporation and R.C.A. International, Ltd. The investments total more than $10.5-million.

HOUSTON, April 27 (AP) Joe Morgan's three-run triple highlighted a five-run seventh inning that carried Houston to a 6-4 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight and broke the Astros' l0-game losing string.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 27 (UPI) A Federal judge temporarily lifted today jail sentences imposed by a local court on seven leaders of Louisville's open housing campaign.

LESLIE HORNBY, alias Twiggy, must be a source of comfort to those who hoped that an attractive face and impressive limbs would divert attention from the vast wasteland that may lie between. But whatever the opinions on the fashion vogue for making women look like pretty boys, there's no gainsaying that the successor to Jean Shrimpton is an international merchandising triumph.

WASHINGTON April 27 Dr. Edward Teller said today that scientists had made more progress in research on the peaceful uses of nuclear explosives than he had expected would be possible under the restrictions of the nuclear test ban treaty.

RINGWOOD, N.J. April 27 Two big smelting furnaces and water wheels used in production of iron for armaments in the Revolutionary and Civil Wars have been found beneath an acre of accumulated silt, century-old trees and tangled thickets here.

IT IS one of ballet's special charms that yesterday's bright-eyed children are today's ballerinas. It almost comes as a shock to realize that those eternally young and eternally promising soloists of Britain's Royal Ballet, Antoinette Sibley and Merle Park, are now no longer promising, no longer if they will forgive the phrase quite so young, and are in fact, two of the company's senior ballerinas.
The Columbia Broadcasting System, Inc., and Holt, Rinehart and Winston, Inc., have worked out final terms for their merger and have signed an agreement.
