LYNCHBURG, Va., April 27 (AP) Lynchburg's two daily newspapers termed "scurrilous today a locally mailed letter sent to thousands of area homes last Friday.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP)--Carl E. Bagge, a Republican member of the Federal Power Commission since May of 1965, will be nominated for a full five-year term, President Johnson announced today.
ATHENS, April 27 The colonel who masterminded Greece's coup d'etat likened his country today to a patient who had to be tied down to the operating table while surgery was performed.
MONTREAL, April 27 Expo 67 will inaugurate its extensive theatrical season Saturday night when Sir Laurence Olivier of Britain and Jean-Louis Barrault of France star in a World Festival Gala.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, April 27 (AP) An expedition of Canadians and Americans, which had hoped to be the first to reach the North Pole over the ice in half a century, will turn back Sunday about 530 miles from its goal.
HANOI, North Vietnam, April 27 (Agence France-Presse) North Vietnam declared today that 32 persons were killed and 109 wounded Tuesday in the United States' air attacks north of Hanoi.

MONTREAL, April 27 Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson lit a ceremonial flame in opening Canada's Expo 67 this afternoon and declared the $750-million exhibition to be a "monument to man." "We are witnesses today to the fulfillment of one of the most daring acts of faith in Canadian enterprise and ability ever undertaken," the Prime Minister said. "That faith was not misplaced." Mr. Pearson, who ...
American industry was beset in this year's first three months by the poorest earnings reports for a first quarter since 1961.
Working against an Aug. 1 deadline, the Buildings Committee of the City Council decided yesterday to take two actions instead of one in writing the city's new Housing Maintenance Code.
DUBLIN, April 27 The 40year-old censorship law that has banned the works of Irish writers in their own country may soon be repealed for a more liberal code.

BALBOA, C.Z., April 27 The establishment of an authority composed of five United States and four Panamanian members to operate the Panama Canal has been proposed under a treaty being drafted by Panama and the United States.

A tentative agreement between the three television networks and the motion picture cameramen's union Local 644 of the International Alliance of Theatrical Stage Employes was reached Wednesday night, Jay Rescher, the union's business manager, announced yesterday.

Julius Garfinckel Co., Inc., which operates the women's specialty store chain of that name in Washington, D.C., and the Brooks Brothers and A. DePinna Company retail chains here, will acquire Miller Rhoads, Inc., the largest department store group in Virginia.

WHITE PLAINS, April 27 John A. Bradley, president of the Ferncliff Cemetery Association of Hartsdale, died here Tuesday at St. Agnes Hospital. He was 62 years old and lived at 3 Horizon Road, Fort Lee, N.J., where he moved recently from Elmsford.

SITTING in the dining room of her house on Spring Street, Louise Nevelson adjusts her red and green silk hat, lights a thin brown cigar in a white plastic holder and stares for a moment out of the window at the dingy street.

Rear Adm. Daniel V. Gallery, United States Navy, retired, who commanded a hunter-killer task force in the Atlantic in World War II, is to be the guest of honor and principal speaker at the annual muster of the Pennsylvania Schoolship Association in Philadelphia May 6.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 98.3 on Wednesday from 98.1 on Tuesday.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this Page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. The criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

NHATRANG, South Vietnam, April 26 Concerned about the tarnished reputation of this seaside resort, South Vietnamese officials are trying to frighten the "lonely ghosts" and their prot g es among the less honorable "talking flowers" away from local "grottoes."
At least 50 foreign publications are seeking the right to publish Svetlana Alliluyeva's autobiography, or parts of it, simultaneously with its appearance in the United States.

The Savings Banks Association of New York State elected yesterday as its 1967-68 president G. Schuyler Tarbell Jr., president of the Queens County Savings Bank. The action was taken at the association's annual meeting at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel.
Negotiators for The Daily News and the printers' union met again yesterday, but they did not disclose whether progress had been made in resolving the key economic issues in dispute.

MIAMI, April 27 The hat was two sizes too small, a gift from a friend; the pants were old and baggy, but dark enough to disguise the dirt stains. A few patches of black hair covered an otherwise bald head. The same hands that once shook a 34-ounce baseball bat now fought to control a cigarette.

CAIRO, April 27 The republican Government of Yemen has decided to put a halt to the United States aid program there, the United Arab Republic's national press agency reported tonight from Sana, the Yemeni capital.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI) The nation's major trucking companies ratified the new three-year contract with the teamsters today in an apparent attempt to close the door on any union move to increase the terms of the settlement.

COLUMBIA, S.C., April 27 (UPI) The State Senate and trustees of the University of South Carolina rebuked today a young chemistry professor who called Gen. William C. Westmoreland "a doctor of war" during an honorary degree ceremony yesterday.
Rain and sleet did not deter a crowd of 18,474 from appearing at Aqueduct yesterday in a nor'easter likely to make even a sea-hardened tar remain under cover.
Jack Valenti, president of the Motion Picture Association of America, is expected to head the United States delegation to the fifth Moscow international film festival, July 5 to 20.

A shipping program for consideration by Federal policy planners who are now developing future American merchant marine policy, was advanced yesterday by a spokesman for the unsubsidized American shipping industry.

OTTAWA, April 27 (Canadian Press) Currency in circulation and chartered bank deposits, including, federal government deposits, totalled $22,364,000,000 on April 19, the Bank of Canada reported Thursday.

Housing construction, which suffered most during the recent downswing in building activity, is now pacing a vigorous recovery, according to the Dodge Index, a monthly analysis by the F.W. Dodge Company.

The Texas Gulf Sulphur Company reported a 50 per cent sales gain and a 51 per cent earnings increase for the first quarter of this year, as stockholders gathered in Houston yesterday for the annual meeting.

PORT OF SPAIN, Trinidad, April 27 The United States begins tomorrow what assuredly will be a long and perilous campaign to recapture from Australia the Davis Cup, symbol of international amateur tennis supremacy, when it faces the British West Indies in the first round of the American Zone competition.
TOKYO, Friday, April 28 (Reuters) A United States Navy plane carrying a crew of 12 ditched into the ocean today off Kyushu, in southern Japan.
OAKLAND, Calif., April 27 Dr. Robert J. Wert, professor of higher education at Stanford University, has been chosen as the ninth president of Mills College.
NEW ORLEANS, April 27 The Standard Fruit and Steamship Company plans to move all of its dock operations to Gulfport, Miss., at an annual loss of $2.5-million in wages for the local economy.

In the Chapel of St. James' Episcopal Church here yesterday afternoon, Miss Betty M. Sargent, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George K. Sargent Jr. of 161 East 79th Street and Bridgehampton, L.I., became the bride of Pvt. Serge J. Hill Jr. of the Army, son of Mr. and Mrs. Hill of Short Hills, N.J.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., April 27 (UPI) Jorge Velasquez rode five winners today at Garden State Park.

Mrs. Marian Drane Graham, wife of Dr. Frank P. Graham, the North Carolina educator and former United States Senator, died yesterday in Doctors Hospital. She was 66 years old and resided at 310 East 44th Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., April 27--France notified the United Nations today that she was prepared to make a voluntary contribution to help reduce the United Nations deficit, which has been officially estimated at $33-million to $53-million.

"I DON'T want to look like a great white hunter," Col. John H. Glenn Jr. said firmly yesterday to a salesman at Abercrombie Fitch. The first American to orbit the earth was there to be fitted for further explorations...
HOUSTON, April 27 Cassuis Clay, on the eve of his scheduled Army induction, has apparently lost his fight to escape criminal proceedings.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The House's long-awaited ethics committee was set up today with Representative Melvin Price, Democrat of Illinois, as chairman.

The Singer Company, a diversified manufacturer of home appliances and industrial equipment, showed a 6.9 per cent increase in its earnings, totaling $11,525,000, or $1.09 a share, in the quarter ended March 31, Donald P. Kircher, president, announced at the company's annual meeting here yesterday.

In 1950, when New York had the last strike in its towering apartment buildings, the chairman of the State Mediation Board sent Gov. Thomas E. Dewey a note warning that rent controls were making it difficult for landlords to pay their service employes a living wage.
Harry Bannister, well-known radio and television executive, died yesterday at the ColumbiaPresbyterian Medical Center. He would have been 73 years old Monday. He lived at 165 West End Avenue.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., April 27 Harvard University announced today that American and Mexican archeologists had uncovered evidence suggesting that man had lived in the New World for more than 40,000 years.

WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) Representative William F. Ryan announced tonight that, if the space agency did not make available a report he says bears directly on the Apollo fire, he would release it in full to the press.
WASHINGTON, April 27 Eleven of the 18 leading economic indicators now available for the month of March were rising, the Department of Commerce reported today.

One of the joys of the "Music from Marlboro" concerts over the last two seasons has been the devoted, warmly communicative quality of the performance. So it was again yesterday at Town Hall, as six alumni of the Vermont summer festivals gathered to present an evening of chamber music and song.
PARIS, April 27 France's Opposition parties will attempt to topple the Government of Premier Georges Pompidou over a request for special executive powers in the economic field for six months.
CINCINNATI, April 27 (UPI) A 19-year-old Earlham College student was sentenced to three years in prison today for failure to report for military induction.

MONTREAL, April 27 The word is Go. Expo 67 is a fun fair, the fairgoers fair, and the professionals fair. It has substance and style. Many of the details will be collected by architects, planners and designers the way wine fanciers savor their vintages. Expo is overwhelming in its sheer size 700
ELIZABETH N.J., April 27--Abraham I. Lemberg of 197 Browning Avenue, an insurance broker here since 1928, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home. His age was 74.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (AP) The Senate passed today a $448-million bill to extend for two years the Appalachia aid program. The vote was 68 to 13.

ANNAPOLIS, Md. Director of the academic computer center at the United States Naval Academy, as well as the head crew coach, Paul Quinn, has an uncanny faculty of coming up with the right answers in the regatta of the Intercollegiate Rowing Association.
RICHMOND, April 27 Mrs. Jane Scales Leslie, who was married to the late Warren Leslie Jr., whose father founded the Jamaica Water Supply Company, died here today at the age of 64.

WASHINGTON, April 27 "One of the greatest frights of my life," Capt. Benjamin R. Fern, United States Navy, retired, said the other day, "was in 1959 when I took a destroyer, after receiving command, out of the Brooklyn Navy Yard and through busy New York harbor to sea.

Bill Bradley, Rhodes Scholar at Oxford and former all-America basketball star at Princeton, has accepted a four-year contract worth nearly half a million dollars to play with the New York Knickerbockers of the National Basketball Association.
The Veterans of Foreign Wars will hold their 21st annual Loyalty Day parade on Fifth Avenue tomorrow afternoon, the organization announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, April 27 The White House denied today a report from Montreal saying that President Johnson planned to visit Expo 67 on May 24.

The directors of Electric Bond and Share Company announced yesterday the election of Charles K. Rieger as president and chief operating officer. He will succeed George G. Walker, who was named chairman and chief executive officer.

LONDON, April 27 The Shell Company threatened today to build its own pipeline in Britain if it cannot get what it deems a fair price for North Sea gas from the Gas Council, the nationalized distribution system.
The last ice house in Manhattan was condemned yesterday, "the victim of an illusive progress, practical and unsentimental."

WASHINGTON, April 27 The latest theory in this upsidedown war in Vietnam is that a hawk is a dove and a dove is a hawk. This is the new gospel according to our embattled masters: the doves are deceiving the enemy into prolonging the killing, whereas the compassionate hawks are trying to bring the killing to a quick and merciful end.
BERLIN, April 27 (Reuters)--Jurgen Henschel, a 22-year-old West German, was sentenced to 12 years' hard labor here today for kidnapping a 4-year-old Canadian girl last August.
OGDEN M. (DINNY) PHIPPS, a young pillar of the turf who also likes boat racing, is in another "horsepower" quandary.

PINEHURST, N.C., April 27 (AP) Leonard Thompson of Laurinburg, N.C., upset a former national champion and Walker Cup player, Bob Murphy, today to join Billy Campbell, Bill Hyndman and Bill Harvey in the semi-finals of the North and South amateur golf tournament. Each won two matches.
The Shell Oil Company reported yesterday that its net profits in the first quarter rose 7 per cent to the highest level of any opening quarter in its history.

CAPE MAY, N.J., Friday, April 28 The Coast Guard cutter Sassafras churned through 20-foot waves and reached the stricken fishing trawler Mockingbird, 98 miles east of here, early today. The trawler, wallowing in high seas, was in danger of capsizing.

Akira Kurosawa has been signed by 20th Century-Fox to direct the Japanese portions of the projected film spectacle "Tora! Tora! Tora!" It is about the events leading up to and including the 1941 attack on Pearl Harbor.

NAPLES, Fla., April 27 The jury in the Carl Coppolino murder case, unable to reach a verdict after several hours' deliberation, was locked up tonight in a beachfront motel and told to resume deliberations at 9 A.M. tomorrow.
HUNTINGTON, L.I., April 27 Mrs. Olive Lister Smith, a former president of the New York State Federation of Women's Clubs, died here last night at the Hilaire Nursing Home. She was 91 years old.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 27 (UPI) Juan (Chi Chi) Rodriguez and Joe Campbell carded 68's early today and watched the rest of the $100,000 Texas open golf tournament field fail to knock them out of the first-round lead at the 7,100-yard, par 36, 35 71 Pecan Valley Country Club course.

SAN FRANCISCO, April 27--Edward M. Keating, the founder and major shareholder in Ramparts magazine, has been ousted as president and publisher in a bitter struggle for control of the controversial publication.
Archbishop Iakovos, spiritual leader of the Greek Orthodox Church in the Western Hemisphere, washed the feet yesterday of 12 "disciples."

ROME, April 27 (UPI) Sophia Loren and Carlo Ponti won a 10-year legal battle today when an appeals court, in effect, quashed bigamy proceedings against the couple by agreeing with a Mexican court ruling that their first marriage, which took place by proxy in Mexico in 1957, was invalid.

SYDNEY, Australia, April 27 Dame Pattie and Gretel, the yachts contending for the right to represent Australia as challenger for the America's Cup, will race three more times next week before they are shipped to Newport, R.I.
At Lincoln Center today: Licia Albanese, soprano, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30 P.M.
Three offerings of common stock reached the market yesterday and another was registered with the Securities and Exchange Commission.
Seven painters and sculptors were named yesterday to receive grants of $2,500 each from the National Institute of Arts and Letters, which conducts a broad program of assisting the arts.
A Senate subcommittee will hold hearings today on a "fair use" provision in the proposed copyright revision law.
Seven painters and sculptors were named yesterday to receive grants of $2,500 each from the National Institute of Arts and Letters, which conducts a broad program of assisting the arts.
A Senate subcommittee will hold hearings today on a "fair use" provision in the proposed copyright revision law.

KINGSPORT, Tenn., April 27 A four-year strike against the Kingsport Press, one of the nation's largest book manufacturers, approached its formal end today when a representational election tally showed that three unions had been rejected by the company's employes.
A 39-year old woman who had sought to have her marriage annulled because her husband had concealed an alleged Nazi past won her case yesterday, but on a different ground.
TOKYO, April 27 (AP) Peking wall posters quoted by Japanese correspondents said today that an army revolt against Mao Tse-tung had broken out in Tsinghai Province.
The trading pace slowed a bit but industrial issues edged up on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.
THE HAGUE, April 27 Crown Princess Beatrix of the Netherlands gave birth to a boy tonight, the first Prince of Orange in line of succession since 1884.
Pacific Air Lines in San Francisco has just hired Freberg, Ltd., to handle all of the company's ad efforts except the buying of space and time.
BILBAO, Spain, April 27 Fear and tension hang as heavy today over the grimy industrial towns of this Basque province as does the smoke that clings to the factories, the homes and the people.

If the new military rulers of Greece have any concern for world opinion they will call off their apparent plan to try Andreas Papandreou for treason. A fair trial is impossible in the present climate.

The City University, formed in 1961 as an outgrowth of the century-old municipal college system, received full academic accreditation yesterday from the Middle States Association of Colleges and Secondary Schools.
DETROIT, April 27 Automobile makers are increasing their second quarter production schedules slightly following the sales upturn in the first 20 days of April.
A Federal appeals court in New Orleans has ruled that the Government must pay "just compensation" for an invention connected with the production of the atomic bomb.

SAN JUAN, P.R., April 27 (UPI)--Officials at the Rio Piedras Medical Center have been asked to get in touch with the dentist of Mrs. Stephen Currier, the missing heiress, in an attempt to identify a woman's body found near here today.

An executive sought for three weeks by a grand jury investigating cigarette smuggling was identified yesterday as an officer of a supermarket and a trucking concern who allegedly "planted" contraband cigarettes in well-known outlets.
The New York Young Republican Club, which counts Mayor Lindsay as a president emeritus, called last night for the unseating of Representative Paul A. Fino as the party's county chairman in the Bronx.

HARRIMAN, N.Y., April 27 The 31st American Assembly, devoted to a re-examination of United States relations with Eastern Europe, opened here today at Arden House. The American Assembly is an affiliate of Columbia University.

TORONTO, April 27 (AP)--Jean Beliveau and Ralph Backstrom each scored two goals tonight as the Montreal Canadiens beat the Toronto Maple Leafs, 6-2, and evened the Stanley Cup hockey playoff final at two games apiece.
NEW DELHI, April 27 Traditional Hindu mistrust of Moslems is being openly exploited in the close race for India's presidency.
Mrs. John Welchel Finger of 960 Park Avenue was elected president of the Women's National Republican Club yesterday. The club's headquarters is at 3 West 51st Street, here.
IT is often good technique to ruff unnecessarily with an apparently useless trump. The defender hopes that he will "uppercut" the declarer and promote a trump trick for his partner.
The election of Herbert L. Seegal as a director of the New Jersey Bell Telephone Company, was announced yesterday.
Gordon MacRae wound up early Thursday on the floor of the Waldorf-Astoria's Empire Room, where he is performing. That seems clear. What isn't clear is how he got there.

LONDON, Friday, April 28 The Moscow radio canceled regular programs on 19 overseas channels early today and broadcast repeated warnings that "the reactionary forces of Greece" were about to execute a long-time Communist leader, Manolis Glezos.

WASHINGTON, April 27 Revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States railroads in the week ended April 22 registered an increase over the corresponding week of 1966. Intercity truck tonnage in the same period showed a decrease.

CAIRO, Apirl 27--Former King Saud's call for the ouster of his successor, King Faisal of Saudi Arabia, and the stoning of United States Government offices in Yemen yesterday are interpreted here as further symptoms of the new belligerence President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic ...
The stock market got back on the upward track yesterday. A strong afternoon rally carried leading market indicators to highs for the Year.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., April 28 Mr. and Mrs. Stuart D. Watson of New Canaan and West Hartford have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beth Ellen Watson, to Khalil Elias Noujaim. He is the son of Mrs. Elias Noujaim of Port Said, Egypt, and the late Dr. Noujaim.

AMONG the week's openings in the galleries, four shows can be recommended as of special interest, each in its individual way. They can also be made to serve as a contraction of the recent history of sculpture if you are burdened with an obsessively educational turn of mind and are willing to force a point or two.

MIAMI, April 28 (UPI) The police searched with dogs and helicopters today for the last of three men who robbed a Wells Fargo armored car of $186,000 and then drove into gunfire from 25 waiting policemen and agents of the Federal Bureau of Investigation.
The printers and The Daily News reached agreement last night on terms of a new contract providing for wage increases of a little more than 20 per cent over a three-year period.

Mrs. Frederick W. Appell has been elected to a twoyear term as president of the Young Women's Christian Association of the City of New York. Mrs. Appell, who will begin her duties Monday, succeeds Mrs. Felix A. Mulgrew.
HARRIMAN, N.Y., April 28 A reversal of United States trade policy toward the East European Communist states was urged today at the 31st American Assembly meeting here in Arden House.

CHICAGO, April 28 (AP) Gary E. Rader, 23 years old, an Army reservist assigned to a special forces unit in suburban Oak Park, was held for the Southern District Court of New York today to face trial on charges of burning his draft card and the illegal use of an Army uniform.
WASHINGTON, April 28--House Republican leaders accused President Johnson today of "wild and irresponsible" behavior in his attempt to prevent revision of his school aid program.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP)--A broadcasting foundation executive suggested today that the Government spend $200-million on programs to get the proposed public and educational television system started.
MOSCOW, April 28 (AP) The Soviet Union charged today that United States planes had buzzed its ships.
WASHINGTON, April 28 A small office machine has been introduced as a judge of character, both personal and corporate.

Teachers in the city's public schools have been distributing to pupils, during school hours, literature prepared by parentteachers associations and the United Parents Association opposing the use of state funds for parochial schools.
MADRID, April 28 (AP)--In wild anti-American demonstrations, about 1,500 Madrid University students burned four United States flags and caricatures of President Johnson on the campus today.

NEW ORLEANS, April 28 (AP) The Orleans Parish (County) grand jury today heard Harold Weisberg, whose book, "Whitewash," was critical of the Warren Commission report on the assassination of President Kennedy.
Four major lumber associations reported a decrease of 11.2 per cent in production Ior the week ended April 23, compared with the corresponding 1966 week.
The Commonwealth Edison Company of Chicago reported yesterday total revenues of $183,119,275 for the first quarter. This compared with $173,922,600 in the like 1966 period.

The National Committee for a Sane Nuclear Policy announced yesterday that its officers would not be allowed to endorse the activities of other peace organizations without the approval of the board of directors.
The wholesale commodity price index fell to 98.2 on Thursday from 98.3 Wednesday.
The New York Shakespeare Festival is getting ready to roll out its summer mobile theater, a show on wheels followed by large numbers of adults and, often, noisy children.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (UPI) Farm prices fell 1 per cent this month, the department of Agriculture said today. It was the eighth consecutive month of declines.

Frustrated so far in its efforts to obtain a substantial Federal allocation of money to help prevent summer racial disturbances, the Lindsay Administration has turned to business and community leaders for assistance.

WHEELING, W. Va., April 28 The Wheeling Steel Corporation "may face temporary cutbacks in operations" in the next few months, because "drastic action" is needed to solve a shortage of cash and an excess of inventory, Allison R. Maxwell Jr., chairman, told the annual meeting here today.
An American-Canadian University Committee for Andreas Papandreou is being established in New York to seek sanctuary for him, according to two New York University professors.
The insurgent efforts to oust Representative Paul A. Fino as Bronx Republican leader won at least partial endorsement from Mayor Lindsay yesterday.
MOSCOW, April 28 (Reuters) A Dutch airline official seized by Soviet security agents on a street here has been accused of espionage, informed sources said today.
BANGKOK, Thailand Friends and business associates of John W. Thompson are piecing together evidence to suggest that he is not lost in the Malaysian jungle but has been abducted.
HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., April 28 Miss Jeanne Gallois Poett and Lieut. (jg.) Edward Mellon Leonard, U.S.N., are planning to marry in July.

The pricing situation in major appliances clouded yesterday. On the one hand, a spokesman for the Bureau of Labor Statistics predicted here yesterday that durable goods and appliances would remain fairly soft throughout the year. Within the industry itself there were strong rumors that a major appliance manufacturer was about to raise prices for most major appliances.

Dawdling corn and wheat futures rose yesterday. "There was no specific news to account for the brisk upturn," a broker commented. The upswing was welcomed by holders of long positions who had watched prices decline recently.

Reginald N. Webster's Amberoid returns to Aqueduct for the 24th running of the $75,000 added Grey Lag Handicap today and the Count Amber colt is sure to receive considerable backing if only because of precedent.

THERE seems to be a wood-bead revival in the making. In the nineteen-thirties, wood-beaded handbags either multicolored or natural were favorite summer accessories. Last year they popped up again in Paris, London and New York.
Five Democratic City Councilmen yesterday endorsed Mayor Lindsay's new Consumer Council.

The DWG Corporation, cigar maker, and Wilson Brothers, underwear and apparel concern, reached an agreement yesterday on the number of DWG directors to be proposed for the Wilson board. The proposal will be made at Wilson's annual meeting in June.
BOGOTA, Colombia, April 28 A Bronx schoolteacher and former marine who became a hero here for resisting a holdup attempt and killing one of two armed holdup men died here today.

MONTREAL, April 23 A shimmering, gold-spangled eagle 60 feet wide and a muscular metal hammer and sickle 35 feet high keynote the pavilions built by the United States and the Soviet Union in the Expo 67 popularity contest.
BOSTON, April 28 (AP) A New York policeman was held on a charge of murder today after a Roxbury divorcee and her ex-husband were shot to death.
BOSTON, April 28 (AP) The Massachusetts Supreme Court says an unborn baby is "a person" in the eyes of the law and thus has a right to recover damages for wrongful injury.
PASADENA, Calif., April 28 (AP) Surveyor 3, continuing to sample lunar soil, picked up its first moon rock today but then lost it.

A 46-year-old woman was stabbed last night when she resisted a purse-snatcher on Park Avenue South at 20th Street. Two brothers who witnessed the stabbing chased and captured the attacker a block away, according to the police.
MANHASSET, L.I., April 28--Svetlana Alliluyeva went on her first shopping expedition in the United States today.
A Brooklyn man who had just left a bank in the East New York section was held up yesterday by a 10-year-old boy armed with a butcher knife, the police reported.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The movement for a Federal constitutional convention appears to be stalemated, at least temporarily.

WASHINGTON, April 28 President Johnson announced today a series of major shifts in army commands in the United States, Vietnam and South Korea and the nomination of six major generals for promotion to lieutenant general.
TRENTON, April 28 (AP)--A bill increasing horse race purses was signed into law by Gov. Richard J. Hughes today. Sponsors contended it was needed to offset fears of boycotts at New Jersey tracks.
ALTHOUGH most people take the closings on their clothes pretty much for granted, finding the right button for a new style is a serious matter to a fashion designer or manufacturer.
SACRAMENTO, Calif., April 28 (AP) The California Senate Judiciary Committee approved by voice vote today a bill liberalizing the state's 95-year-old abortion law.
Six men convicted of conspiracy in a stock fraud in which the public lost $800,000 received prison sentences yesterday in Federal Court.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) Vice President Hubert H. Humphrey pledged continuing United States support for Latin America's economic and social development today. He said the Johnson Administration would ask Congress soon for an additional contribution of $900-million for the InterAmerican Development Bank.
NEW DELHI, April 28 An attractive and apparently nude young woman has set off a spirited debate here on the role of advertising in a still largely traditional society.

WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The Federal Communications Commission set June 1 today as the date for arguments before the entire seven-member commission on the merger of the American Broadcasting Companies, Inc., and the International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation.
WASHINGTON, April 28 A Federal district judge was asked today to bar the Army from trying Capt. Howard B. Levy on charges of encouraging opposition to the war in Vietnam and disobeying orders.
CHICAGO, April 28 A crucial merchant marine question, that of limitation of shipowner liability, was argued here today by admiralty lawyers and other experts in maritime law.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 (UPI) City officials' first attempt to meet with a crowd of open-housing advocates broke down in confusion tonight.
BOSTON, April 28 (AP) A wild Northeast storm, riding on winds of nearly 100 miles an hour, lashed the Atlantic seaboard today sinking two fishing boats and battering coastal areas.
CINCINNATI, April 28-The I Cincinnati Reds, the hottest team in baseball, scored three runs off Bob Shaw in the first inning tonight and rolled on to defeat the New York Mets, 7-1.

OF all the benefit bazaars that make an annual pitch to local artgoers, the liveliest and best-assembled is the mammoth exhibition staged by the Scholarship, Education and Defense Fund for Racial Equality (an arm of CORE).

THE BURMESE HARP" is odd in more ways than one. It won a prize at the Venice Festival in 1956, then reappeared last year for a showing at the New York Film Festival. Yesterday, it began its first run in a United States theater, presented by Thomas Brandon at the Fifth Avenue Cinema.
JAKARTA, Indonesia, April 28 The Government moved this week to stop anti-Chinese rioting in Jakarta before such incidents spread seriously to outlying areas of the huge island republic.
WASHINGTON, April 27 (UPI ) A pilot for Trans World Airlines said yesterday there were co-pilots who could not always land a plane safely in an emergency.

A member of the President's ' Council of Economic Advisers told a meeting here yesterday that some tax adjustment should be considered "a normal part of each year's fiscal pro gram, even in the ideal situation of full employment with a steadily growing private economy."
SAN ANTONIO, Tex., April 28 (UPI) Bob Goalby and Bob Charles gained the halfwaypoint lead by a stroke today in the $100,000 Texas open golf tournament at 138.

MIAMI BEACH, April 28 (AP)-Mark Kuglitsch and Ron Wheeler of Milwaukee collaborated on a 1,357 series today to take first place in the regular doubles division of the American Bowling Congress tournament.
FALMER, England, April 28 Creation of an international clearing house to increase the flow of industrial know-how to less-developed countries was proposed here today at the University of Sussex.
Thomas M. Goodfellow, president and general manager of the Long Island Rail Road for the last 11 years, was elected president of the Association of American Railroads yesterday.
WESTBURY, L. I., April 28 Orbiter N., beaten a head by Chris Time in 2:01 1-5 one week ago, reversed that decision tonight in 2:02 3-5 in a junior free-for-all one-mile, pace at Roosevelt Raceway.
WASHINGTON, April 28 House Speaker John W. McCormack virtually ruled out today an early vote on the seating of Adam Clayton
DETROIT, April 28 The American Motors Corporation has won an extension on its $95-million bank debt due May 31.

NAPLES, Fla., April 28 Dr. Carl Anthony Coppolino, the 34year old anesthesiologist who was acquitted four months ago of the murder of a neighbor in New Jersey, was found guilty by a Florida jury of second-degree murder today in the poisoning of his wife, Carmela.
Mr. President, Mr. Speaker, members of Congress. I am deeply honored to address the Congress of the United States.

THE HAGUE, April 28 (Reuters) Prince Claus of the Netherlands, in a broadcast today to the rejoicing Dutch people described his son the first male in line for the throne since 1884 as "a splendid baby."
MONTCLAIR., N.J., April 28 Page S. Haselton, a lawyer who specialized in patents, died here today at Mountainside Hospital. He was 70 years old and resided at 171 Fernwood Avenue, Upper Montclair.

A 13-piece jazz group that has been rehearsing for more than a year made its first public appearance here last night at Judson Hall. It is called the New York Improvisation Ensemble, a name that might suggest that it is an experimental group, possibly avant-garde. It turned out.

PITTSBURGH, April 28 (UPI) The United Steelworkers of America and the Aluminum Workers International Union, which represent a majority of workers in the country's aluminum industry, signed a mutual assistance agreement yesterday to enable them "to live together."

The Continental Football League, attempting to capitalize on the national popularity of professional football, yesterday replaced Brooklyn with Akron in the make-up of its franchises. A former pro quarterback of some note, Tobin Rote, was named as general manager and he may be the coach, too, if Doak Walker, another former pro star, turns down the appointment.
HOUSTON, April 28--Cassius Clay refused today, as expected, to take the one step forward that would have constituted induction into the armed forces. There was no... immediate Government action.
WASHINGTON, April 28 President Johnson asked Congress today to delay a nationwide railroad strike for 47 days and promised to recommend legislation within a few days to settle the dispute.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad, April 28 The United States led the British West Indies, 2-0, after the first day of Davis Cup zone tennis competition by virtue of a pair of singles triumphs by Charles Pasarell of Santurce, P. R., and Cliff Richey of San Angelo, Tex.

MONTREAL, April 28 Two of the busiest areas of Expo 67 today were the post offices of Canada and of the United Nations in the Pavilion on the United Nations. Both were scenes of first-day sales, of commemorative postage stamps for the Canadian Centennial and the exposition celebration.
Three companies filed registration statements with the Securities and Exchange Commission yesterday for offerings of common stock.

LOS ANGELES, April 28 Mrs. Virginia French Bourne was married this evening to Peter Inman Tormey of San Francisco. The Rev. Charles R. Peebles performed the ceremony in the Episcopal Church of Our Saviour.
Licia Albanese showed last night, as she substituted for Eileen Farrell in a benefit recital at Philharmonic Hall, that
NEW HAVEN, April 28 "Skull and Bones! Do you accept?"

WASHINGTON, April 28 Gen. William C. Westmoreland roused Congress to enthusiastic cheers today with a pledge that the American forces he commands would "prevail in Vietnam over the Communist aggressor."

Two ambassadors to the United Nations, one a former member of the audience and the other a former member of the cast, attended the signing of an agreement yesterday that will bring Les Ballets Africains back for another American tour in July.

MONTREAL, April 28--When people here speak of the new Montreal, they do not always mean the "billion-dollar skyline," the rubber-tired subway, the richly varied French cuisine or the beautiful bilingual girls.
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) The Senate Democratic Whip accused the Senate ethics committee today of making a scapegoat of Senator Thomas J. Dodd by recommending that he be censured.

There were three wheels for handling the rudders instead of the customary one. Presumably one was for the steering rudder, the other two for the tab, and there was some light speculation on what would happen when the man steering and the man on the tab got their signals crossed.

ALBANY, April 28 To "help bolster public confidence in the disposition of court appointments," Governor Rockefeller has approved a bill requiring full disclosure of the names and fees of the special guardians and other appointees of the surrogates' courts.

WASHINGTON, April 28Government officials asserted today that efforts by groups opposed to the war in Vietnam to encourage resistance to military service were having no effect on Selective Service inducdons.
MONTREAL, April 28 Expo 67 is a $750-mil lion project to overcome Canadian modesty an instrument, as Lester B. Pearson has said, "for blowing our own horn, something we Canadians have never done."

The First National Iron Bank of Morristown, N.J., and the First National Bank of Butler, N.J., announced that a merger of the two became effective at the close of business yesterday. The merged bank, which will operate under the First National Iron name, will have assets in excess of $125-million.
The spot rate on the British pound eased on the usual weekend considerations in quiet trading yesterday on foreign-exchange markets here.

GLEN ROCK, N.J., April 28 Mr. and Mrs. Howard D Crosse have made known the engagement of their daughter Miss Dorothy Linda Crosse, to Rogelio Garcla Jr., son of Mr and Mrs. Garcia of New York The couple plan to marry here in August at All Saints Episcopal Church.

In Temple Rodeph Sholom here yesterday morning Miss Susan Louise Kane, daughter of Harry C. Kane of 685 West End Avenue and the late Mrs. Kane, became the bride of Bernard S. Breitman. He is the son of Mrs. Morris Breitman, also of New York, and the late Mr. Breitman. Rabbi Gunther Hirschberg performed the ceremony.

Supporters of the Big Brothers, a nonsectarian and interracial agency that befriends boys in need of fathers, will gather at the Graham Galleries at 1014 Madison Avenue Monday and Tuesday evenings for previews of "Art: Authentic and Fake."
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, April 29-American pilots returned to Hanoi yesterday and downed their 43d and 44th MIG's of the war in six encounters with the Soviet-built interceptors.

In somewhat blurred but discernible form the case of Cassius Clay, the heavyweight boxing champion, poses to the nation the issue of selective conscientious objection to military service an issue that is being raised increasingly by young men opposed to the war in Vietnam.

BERKELEY, Calif., April 28 Chief Justice Earl Warren said today that even one year of retrenchment could throw the University of California "so far out of adjustment that it might take a generation to recoup."
WASHINGTON, April 28--There was almost universal agreement among members of Congress today after Gen. William C. Westmoreland's address that the war in Vietnam was likely to be intensified.
PHILADELPHIA, April 28 The 73d annual Penn Relays began today on a new track that proved fast. The biggest race of the day went to Villanova, which was fast on the old track and faster on the new.
The city at last made a long awaited proposal for a zoning change to encourage cluster development in the Borough of Richmond. It is a forward step, but a belated one.

Bishop James A. Pike has admitted that he erred when he wrote in the April issue of Playboy magazine that the Society of Jesus (Jesuits) owned 51 per cent of the stock of the Bank of America and a controlling interest in the Creole Petroleum Company.

WASHINGTON, April 28--An effort to place the American Bar Association in opposition to three human rights treaties of the United Nations failed today at a meeting of the association's International Law Section.
BALTIMORE, April 28 (UPI) -Curt Blefary clouted a basesloaded homer in the first inning tonight and the Baltimore Orioles went on to score a 5-3 victory over the Detroit Tigers.

General Westmoreland, in his switch from battlefield commander to mobilizer of homefront support for Administration policies in Vietnam, has given Congress a puzzling explanation of the merits of escalation. With all the fervor of a man proud of his

First-quarter earnings of the Clark Equipment Company fell 13 per cent despite a 7 per cent sales increase. Directors, however, voted to increase the quarterly dividend to 30 cents from 25 cents a share on the 11,200,452 shares outstanding.
For about 10,000 commuters yesterday was the last time to savor a remarkable morning bracer; the serene view of Manhattan s towers from a Hudson River ferryboat.
BANGKOK, Thailand, April 28 (Reuters) A United States Air Force F-4C fighter-bomber caught fire early today at an air base at Ubol, 500 miles northeast of here.

EL PASO, Tex., April 28 Mr. and Mrs. Jonathan R. Cunningham have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Joan Elizabeth Cunningham, to James Ian Keith Knapp, son of the Rev. and Mrs. Charles T. Knapp of Old Greenwich, Corn. The wedding is planned for June 10 in St. Aidan's Episcopal Church in Boulder, Col.

A FORMER operating-room nurse has turned a flair for fashion into a successful career as a personal shopper. Mrs. Lawrence Thompson selects clothes for various of her neighbors among the 4,000 families currently living in Lefrak City, the middle-income housing development in Queens.

The temptation to "go it alone" in international monetary reform is mounting. It is reflected not only in the illconsidered blasts emanating from our two largest banks, but also in the advice recently

Bruckner's Symphony No. 7 was the big work in the program played at Carnegie Hall last night by the Concertgebouw Orchestra of Amsterdam. Bernard Haitink, the conductor, prefaced this behemoth with Beethoven's "Egmont" Overture and Hans Henkemans's Partita for Orchestra.

STANDARDS for opening bids are to some extent a matter of style. Although a minority of Eastern experts headed by the RothStone group maintain elevated standards, the general tendency is to open the bidding rather more freely than it was done a decade ago.
ALBANY, April 28 Starting July 1, all New York drivers will have to have an eye test every time they renew their driver's license, under a bill signed into law by Governor Rockefeller.
Stock prices jumped upward in heavy trading early yesterday but leveled off later in the session.
DETROIT, April 28 Gov. George Romney said today that escalation of the war in Vietnam had failed to bring favorable results as promised by political and military leaders.

The bankruptcy of the Administration's labor policy is indicated afresh by its request to Congress for a second mandatory delay in the threatened railroad strike. The first twenty-day postponement on top of the sixty days that are standard under the emergency provisions of the Railway Labor Act is running out with no remotest sign of a settlement formula acceptable to both sides.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange closed with moderate gains yesterday.

Gerald J. Carey, who retired in January as general manager of the New York City Housing Authority, died yesterday in the Methodist Hospital of Brooklyn. He was 62 years old and lived at 15 Oliver Street in Brooklyn.

Mayor Lindsay said yesterday that city workers would be permitted this year to continue their traditional summer practice of leaving work an hour early, but served notice that he opposed it and would work to abolish it eventually.
HOUSTON, April 28 (AP) Eddie Mathews tripled to lead off the 13th inning and scored on Aaron Pointer's sacrifice fly to give the Houston Astros a 5-4 victory tonight over the Chicaeo Cubs.
MONTREAL, April 28 More than 100,000 sightseers, including Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson, flocked to Expo 67, Montrcal's World's Fair, within a few hours of its public opening today.
GENEVA, April 28 Gloom deepened in the Kennedy round trade talks tonight as the top American negotiators prepared to fly back to Washington for high-level political consultations.

CHICAGO, April 28 (UPI) Mayor Richard J. Daley failed today in an attempt to mediate a lockout involving 2,000 truck lines and 50,000 drivers that has threatened to become a general strike of Chicago teamsters.

Robert Frost, who reveled in his last years in the knowledge that he had achieved the distinction, rare for a poet, of being financially successful, left literary properties that are continuing to grow in value. His estate is even doing better than his executor and the tax authorities thought it would.

CHICAGO, April 28 More than 250 historians sent a telegram to Senator George S. McGovern, Democrat of South Dakota, today applauding his recent Senate speech "upholding the right of Americans to dissent from governmental policies with which they do not agree."
Jules Feiffer's first fulllength play, "Little Murders," will close tonight at the Booth Theater after its seventh performance.
NORMAN, Okla., April 28 (UPI) Jim Mackenzie, head football coach at the University of Oklahoma died today of a heart attack. He was 37 years old.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The Patent Reform Act of 1967 on which hearings have begun before a House Judiciary subcommittee, has been criticized on the ground that many provisions favor the big corporation and discriminate against the "little fellow."

A threatened strike of 16 lay teachers at five Roman Catholic elementary schools in Harlem was called off yesterday when the schools agreed to raise the pay of teachers without bachelors degrees by $1,600 a year.

The impact of the use of containers on world shipping will be explored under United Nations auspices with the opening Monday in London of the first interregional seminar on cargo utilization methods. The conference will run through May 12.
MARIENBAD, Czechoslovakia, April 28--In this one-time playground of Europe's privileged rich, Christian theologians and Marxist theorists met today under the sanction of a Communist Government.
There were new faces in high places yesterday at 10 large companies whose products range from fork lift trucks to raincoats to vacuum cleaners.
More Americans than ever before will go on daylight time at 2 A.M. tomorrow.

BONN, April 28 Richard Wagner's Valkyries may ride free and as loud as they want in Bavaria because they represent "pure music." but, as of today, beat band music rates there as "entertainment" and is therefore taxable.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The Soviet Union has objected to a proposed United States formula, for a treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons, particularly to the safeguards provision, State Department officials reported today.
LONDON, April 28-Britain's partners in the European Free Trade Association gave their blessing tonight to a new British move to enter the European Common Market.
Kennedy International Airport has become the target of an increasing number of complaints from some of the airlines.
SAN FRANCISCO, April 28 A threatened lawsuit in the struggle for control of Ramparts magazine was off today at least for the weekend.

CAPE KENNEDY, Fla. April 28 The Air Force successfully launched today a Titan 3-C booster that orbited five satellites, including two Vela spacecraft designed to detect sneak nuclear tests as far as 10 million miles from the earth

DES MOINES, Iowa, April 28 Jim Ryun anchored the University of Kansas to victory in the four-mile relay today as the 58th annual Drake Relays opened, sprinting the final quarter in 54 seconds to make up a 50-yard deficit.
ROME, April 28--Pope Paul VI sorrowfully acknowledged today that his own position of primacy and authority was probably "the most grave obstacle" to Christian unity.
Dr. Thomas O. Mabbott, an authority on Edgar Allan Poe, said yesterday that he had discovered a Walt Whitman poem hitherto unknown to scholars.
SEOUL, South Korea, Saturday, April 29 (UPI) American soldiers patrolling along the demilitarized zone between North and South Korea killed a North Korean agent and captured two others early today.
LONDON, April 28 (AP) Maria Callas, the opera singer, and Aristotle Onassis, won their high court suit against Panaghis Vergottis, a ship owner, today.
Open-heart surgery has been successfully performed at Bellevue Hospital on a 5-week-old boy, the youngest patient ever to undergo this type of surgery at the 2,500-bed municipal institution.

Only a few hours after he had refused to be inducted yesterday into the armed forces of the United States, Cassius Clay was stripped of his world heavyweight boxing championship by the major governing authorities of the sport in this country and Europe.
Columbia University has canceled the annual Naval Reserve Officer's Training Corps review for the second consecutive year as the result of threats to picket the ceremony.

Intrepid, the 12-Meter yacht built on City Island with even more of the hush-hush secrecy than is usual for aspirants for leading roles in the America's Cup sailing, began her life afloat yesterday at the Minneford Yacht Yard.
Waves of what bond traders described as "genuine retail selling" broke over the Government bond market yesterday, causing sharp drops in the prices of most issues.

ONE way of indicating the balance and merits of K. S. Karol's survey of con temporary China is that those who are friendly to Mao Tse-tung's regime and those who are hostile will find enough in the book to irritate them. And to agree with too. For example, Mr. Karol spent more than four months in China in 1965, traveling over enormous stretches, as
LOS ANGELES, April 28 (UPI)--Tom Haller doubled home two runs in the eighth inning tonight to enable the San Francisco Giants to score a 5-4 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., April 28 Churchill Downs will open tomorrow, with the biggest firstday crowd in its 93 years expected. All reserve seats have been sold for the day.
LONDON, April 28 United States, British and West German negotiators reached final agreement today on plans to offset the cost of British and American forces in Germany.
A Bronx minister who headed a neighborhood antipoverty project pleaded guilty yesterday to charges of taking approximately $2,000 in kickbacks from staff members.
THE mysteries of Oriental carpet design are ex plained in a Brooklyn Museum exhibition of 41 rugs lent by the Kevorkian Foundation.
A CHANGE from the potato, pasta and rice pattern is often all a lagging menu plan needs to give it new life and appeal.

A Federal judge refused to enjoin work yesterday on an 8.8-mile, six-lane expressway between Armonk and Katonah in Westchester County and dismissed a challenge by advocates of a westerly alternate route.

WASHINGTON, April 28 The State Department, in its first official comment on the military coup in Greece, sought today to exert psychological pressure on the new military Government in Athens to permit a return to parliamentary government.

CLEVELAND, April 28 George C. Wallace peered with some difficulty over the top of a lectern bristling with microphones. Just outside the curtained window behind him, protestors and anti-protestors were offering rival chants on the sidewalk.

PHILADELPHIA, April 28 Martin Liquori ran a mile in 4 minutes 4.4 seconds today in leading Essex Catholic of Newark to a national schoolboy distance medley record in the Penn Relays at Franklin Field.

Five officials of milk companies under investigation by District Attorney Frank S. Hogan submitted a legal memorandum in Federal court yesterday accusing him of "intimidation and coercion to waive their' constitutional privilege under the Fifth Amendment."
WASHINGTON, April 28 (AP) Mayor Samuel W. Yorty of Los Angeles said today that Gov. Ronald Reagan "is running for President too soon."

MONTCHANIN, Del., April 28 Mr, and Mrs. Robert Mott Brown have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Tayloe Beale Brown, to John C. Pierson Jr., son of Dr. and Mrs. Pierson of Wilmington. A summer wedding is planned.

Lunched with General Westmoreland, Cabinet members and a group of Governors; asked Congress to order a 47-day additional delay in the threatened railroad strike; sent Congress a series of budget changes for the current fiscal year and the fiscal year 1968 beginning July 1.
ATLANTA, April 28 (UPI) The Atlanta Braves, trailing by eight runs after four innings, rallied to defeat the Philadelphia Phillies, 9-8, tonight in the last of the ninth on a fielder's choice.
BONN, Germany, April 28, (Reuters)-France and West Germany agreed today to develop and build a joint experimental communications satellite, the first European venture of its type.
PARIS, April 28 Edgard Pisani, Minister of Equipment and Housing, resigned from the French Cabinet today in protest against the Government's decision to seek special executive powers.
After going through their worst power failure in 23 years, the Yankees stirred themselves last night to a 5-4 victory over the California Angels at the Stadium.

The cast for the Metropolitan Opera's concert performance of Verdi's "Otello" Aug. 25, at Newport, R.I., will include Renata Tebaldi as Desdemona, Jon Vickers at Otello and Tito Gobbi as Iago. Kurt Adler will conduct.

Two major Jewish Orthodox organizations, the Union of Orthodox Jewish Congregations of America and the Rabbinical Council of America, have withdrawn from an interfaith conference because of their concern that it will be devoted to religious dogma and theology.

THE Dow-Jones industrial average now stands at its highest level of this year, thanks to gains in 11 of the last 12 sessions. Yesterday, the Dow industrials closed at 897.05, up 2.23 points, on New York Stock Exchange volume of 11.2-million shares, the heaviest in six weeks.
ATHENS, April 28 The military junta put George Papandreou, until recently Greece's foremost politician, and his son on display today in a move to prove that it treated its political prisoners well.

HILLSBOROUGH, Calif., April 28 Mr. and Mrs. Richard R. Hanna have announced the engagement of Mrs. Hanna's daughter, Miss Kimberly Ann Sherman, to Robert Charles McCloud. His parents are Mr. and Mrs. Herman C. McCloud of Pittsburgh.
Governor Rockefeller signed into law here yesterday legislation that will permit the state to establish small neighborhood parks in the city.

Louis W. Menk, president of the Northern Pacific Railway, has been elected chief executive officer to succeed Robert S. Macfarlane, who continues as chairman of the board and chairman of the executive and finance committees.
The American Stock Exchange managed to rise slightly yesterday as profit taking in the last half hour of trading pared an early advance.
Maj. Gen. Harrison A. Gerhardt, commander of 1st Region, Army Air Defense Command at Fort Totten, retired yesterday after a military career that spanned more than 34 years.
TEL AVIV, April 28 Israel officials said today that marauders from Syria blew up a local water pipeline in the Jordan River watershed early this morning.

Mr. and Mrs. Alan Morrill have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carma Jean Morrill, to Eldon Van Cleef Greenberg, son of Mr. and Mrs. Allan J. Greenberg of Los Angeles. A June wedding is planned.

Contract negotiations became more tangled yesterday between the owners of 3,900 apartment buildings and a union of service employes who have struck in Queens and are threatening strikes in other boroughs.
Antiques shows keep changing in content and character, but the semiannual event in the Westchester County Center in, White Plains remains evocative of a country fair.

WASHINGTON, April 28The United States, its relations with Yemen strained almost to the breaking point, announced today that it would withdraw its aid mission, from Yemen and quickly evacuate the dependents of all American officials there.
Prince, a 2-year-old Bengal tiger, had a fight Wednesday night in Madison Square Garden with his 35-year-old groom over a bone. The tiger lost the bone and two of his teeth.
Cluett, Peabody Co., an apparel manufacturer, announced here yesterday the election of Norbert G. Schmidt as a director.

MUNISING, Mich.-- After a five-year controversy, Congress has finally approved the Pictured Rocks national lakeshore project for Miclugan's Upper Peninsula. The bill authorizes the appropriation of $6.9-million for the acquisition of land and $56.4million for the development of the lakeshore region.

CLARKS SUMMIT, Pa., April 29--Mr. and Mrs. Arthur F. Horwitz have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Evelyn Horwitz, to James Peter Millett, son of Mrs. Daniel J. Millett and the late Mr. Millett.

The City Gardens Club of New York will hold its 21st annual benefit tours of gardens and penthouse terraces on Tuesday and on May 9. The funds raised will go to scholarships at Audubon summer camps for New York City public school teachers and for natural science programs in the school system. The club's headquarters are at 829 Madison Avenue.

CORAL GABLES, Fla., April 29--Mr. and Mrs. Guy Burdette Bailey have announced the engagement of Mrs. Bailey's daughter, Miss Mary Areca Babcock, to James Marvin Whatmore, son of Mr. and Mrs. Marvin Clement Whatmore of New York and North Salem, N.Y. The wedding is planned for June.

Miss Mary Ann Connellan, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Thomas J. Connellan of Yonkers, was married yesterday to Donald J. Dougherty, son of Mrs. Daniel Dougherty of Jersey City, and the late Mr. Dougherty.

Gerry Arrigo allowed a firstinning single by Jerry Grote, then pitched hitless ball the rest of the way as the Cincinnati Reds defeated the Mets, 7-0, yesterday at Cincinnati. Mickey Mantle hit his first home run of the year as the Yankees downed the California Angels, 5-2, at Yankee Stadium.

BOURNEMOUTH, England, April 29 (AP)--Jan-Erik Lundquish of Sweden, turned back Bob Hewitt, of South Africa, 6-1, 6-8, 6-3; 6-2, to win the British hard court tennis title today for the second time in three years.

Ewing M. Kauffman's Moontrip, the oldest entry in the field, who had been unable to win in all seven previous outings this season, scored a major surprise at Aqueduct yesterday by winning the $83,700 Grey Lag Handicap.

PHILADELPHIA, April 29-- New York City teams set meet records in the two featured high school events in the Penn Relays today. Boys High of Brooklyn won the two-mile relay in minutes 44 seconds and Andrew Jackson of St. Albans, Queens, won the one-mile relay in 3:17 after setting a record of 3:16.8 in a qualifying race earlier in the day.
