MAYMYO, Burma, May 1 A war that crackles and flickers through the hills and crupts suddenly in quiet villages in the plains challenges the authority of Burma's Government.

Some of the country's leading publishers indicated yesterday that they saw no hope for the establishment of a new evening newspaper in New York City as long as the present economic pressures continue.
MIDLAND, Tex., May 5 (UPI) Mickey Wright and Marilyn Smith, playing in the same threesome, shot par 72's today to share the first-round lead in the $12,500 Tall City open.

Net income of Liggett Myers Tobacco Company in the first quarter fell slightly to $4,478,000, or $1.10 a share, from $4,755,000, of $1.17 a share, the preceding year, Milton E. Harrington, president, announced yesterday. He said that sales climbed to $138,857,000 from $116,522,000.

MONTREAL--There is at least one section of the rather pretentious French pavilion at Expo 67 that doesn't take itself too seriously. A display of modern furniture, largely prototypes, it is a concise summary of the direction in which young designers in this field are headed.
NEW HAVEN, May 5 A controversial plan for a testimonial dinner to honor Senator Thomas J. Dodd was dropped today at his insistence.

ADEN, May 4 South Arabia's future is more ominous now than it was a month ago when a United Nations mission arrived in this blowzy port in search of ways to ease the area's transition to independence.
WASHINGTON, May 5--Federal water experts, citing below normal streamflow and groundwater supplies in some of the Northeast, were loathe today to cross the area's drought off the books.

LISBON, May 5 With a festive blend of pomp and informality, Princess Dona Maria del Pilar de Borbon, daughter of a claimant to the Spanish throne, was married today to an untitled Spanish nobleman, Don Luis Gomez-Acebo.

HILL 881 NORTH, South Vietnam, May 5 Weary and grimy United States marines today secured this last major height commanding the isolated airstrip and valley of Khesanh. Nearly half the Americans' combat troops here were killed or wounded in the 12-day campaign.

Mike Pearl, a feature writer on crime for the World Journal Tribune, walked into a bank in Greenwich Village yesterday morning. It was his day off and his birthday. He had been married for a month and was going to open an account.

Behind the death of The World Journal Tribune yesterday lay two potent economic forces that have reduced the number of afternoon newspapers in New York from five at the close of World War II to one today.
Bankruptcy proceedings for the Tahse Corporation, which was organized by Martin Tahse to produce touring shows, have been postponed to May 26 in Federal District Court here.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 5 (AP) A controversy developed today over a scuffle at Barranquilla between Colombian reporters and photographers and the security escort assigned to Lynda Bird Johnson, elder daughter of President Johnson.

The World Journal Tribune rose out of the ashes of three newspapers The New York Herald Tribune, owned by John Hay Whitney; the Hearstowned Journal-American, and Scripps-Howard's World-Telegram and Sun.
The general manager of the Swiss National Bank said yesterday that Switzerland would not support proposals by the United States for a broad overhaul of the world's monetary mechanism.

The summer will be made more pleasant for many elderly men and women who live in the crowded city, frequently lonely and often with limited means, by Vacations for the Aging, now preparing for its ninth helpful year.

TEN years ago nothing would have seemed odder than the thought of a large exhibition of the works of Joseph Cornell in a major New York museum. Mr. Cornell had a devoted following at that time, but it was special following.
A television program about the new "fun morality," that lost its sponsor on Wednesday, picked up two new ones yesterday.

Albert Goldman, who had been Postmaster of New York and before that Commissioner of the city's Department of Plant and Structures, died of a stroke yesterday in the Fairfield Nursing Home, at 3220 Henry Hudson Parkway East, after an illness of two months.
SHORTLY after 9:30 yesterday morning, Matt Meyer called the 10 department heads of The World Journal Tribune into his fourth-floor office and quietly made the saddest announcement of his life.

"BECAUSE of technical advances today, anything that is not factual is not fashion," Emilio Pucci declared at the opening of his second collection of underwear for Formfit Rogers yesterday. "What I've tried to do is give back femininity, elegance and beauty to the things that go next to the skin."
GENOA, Italy, May 5 (Reuters)--The captain of the wrecked Liberian tanker Torrey Canyon said today that he could have saved his ship if he had had 30 seconds more to maneuver.

WASHINGTON, May 5 The defense department again acknowledged today that fragmentation bombs had been dropped on North Vietnam but denied that they were directed against civilians. This statement came in response to reports of criticism of the American air attacks on North Vietnam at the so-called international war crimes tribunal in Stockholm.

MOSCOW, May 5 Independent study, that old standby of the American high school, promises to become a major ingredient of the next Soviet school reform. It is a topic of speculation and debate among Soviet educators.
PARIS, May 5 France's official reserves of gold and dollars rose by almost $18million in April, the Government reported today.

QUANTICO, Va., May 5 At Kenwood High School in the Baltimore suburbs, Charlie Messenger was the star and Dave Patrick ran in his shadow. At Villanova, Patrick has become a national champion, while Messenger has been ill, injured and often disappointing.

NEW DELHI, May 5 Western sources have reported that forged documents and papers have been used recently in an effort to discredit the United States in India and Pakistan. There is no firm evidence as to who is responsible for the...

WASHINGTON, May 5 The Federal Reserve Board staff is making an "inquiry," which it carefully distinguishes from and "investigation," into the possi- bility that four Chicago banks have come under common control under conditions that violate the Bank Holding Com- pany Act.
Air and rail traffic from New York to Montreal has tripled as a result of Expo 67, Canada's centennial exhibition.

IT'S a wonder Wall Street didn't hire a brass band to play "Hail to the Chief." On Thursday, President Johnson sent a plan to Congress that would delay a national rail strike and then dictate a settlement if the two sides failed to agree in due course.
WASHINGTON, May 5 Twenty-five card carrying pickets, all young men and women, set up an elliptical line in front of the White House today, whereupon five others began picketing the first line.

MADISON, Wis., May 5 (UPI) Gov. Warren P. Knowles said today that "it probably will take about a week" to clear up technical procedures before he receives a bill repealing Wisconsin's ban on the sale and manufacture of colored oleomargarine.
A union of building service workers and the owners of major apartment buildings in the city reached agreement yesterday on a new contract, averting a strike at 4,000 buildings.

The highest known temperature at which a material becomes superconducting losing all resistance to electric current was reported yesterday by scientists at Bell Telephone Laboratories, Murray Hill, N.J.
Consumption of newsprint in both New York City and the entire United States has advanced in the last 10 years.

BONN, May 5 (Reuters) Britain and West Germany today signed an agreement under which Bonn will spend about $140-million in Britain during the current fiscal year to help offset the foreign exchange cost of British Army and Air Force units in Germany.
A group of Roman Catholic laymen in the Diocese of Rockville Center have announced plans for an unofficial Long Island Association of Laymen to give themselves a greater voice in diocesan activities.

BUFFALO, May 5--Dr. Leslie A. Fiedler, the prize-winning author and noted literary critic, who was arrested last Friday on a narcotics charge, returned to his classroom at the State University of Buffalo today.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 5 (UPI) Notre Dame's 1967 foot ball team will give a nationwide preview of its prospects tomorrow when the varsity squad meets former players in the annual old-timers game that winds up spring practice.
A fleet of naval ships the frigate Norfolk and seven destroyers sailed into New York harbor yesterday.
MOSCOW, May 5 The United States Government and American businessmen have started a campaign to break a log jam in trade with the Soviet Union.
WASHINGTON, May 5 Two key Congressmen said today that there was considerable sentiment in Congress for altering President Johnson's bill to settle the railroad labor dispute.
The Hughes Aircraft Company is expected to purchase 200,000 common shares of the Teleprompter Corporation, Irving B. Kahan, chairman and president, reported here yesterday.
VIENTIANE, Laos, April 23 War or no war, this cap ital's inhabitants, Laotian and foreign, relieve the oppression of the dog days with a round of traditional high jinks.

MIAMI BEACH, May 6 (AP) Pinky's Bowl of Milwaukee claimed the regular team championship of the American Bowling Congress tournament today. 55 days after the quintet rolled a record three-game series of 3,327.

PHILADELPHIA has always been inordinately proud of its Ameri can firsts first hospital, first public library, first men's city club. One first it is not proud of is America's first kidnapping for ransom. This was the famous and infamous case of little Charley Ross. On July 1, 1874, the 4-year-old boy was taken from suburban Chestnut Hill by two men in a buggy and never seen again.

FRANCES PERKENS lived a long and useful life, a life of particular significance not merely because she was the first woman to serve in a President's Cabinet, but because she was closely connected with some of the most basic social and economic developments of the 20th century. As a social worker and Government administrator.
A corps of young workers who set up headquarters of an antipoverty program in a vacant liquor store in Harlem is about to expand operations to new neighborhoods in Queens, Brooklyn and the Bronx.
DALLAS, May 6 (UPI) Surprise points from Steve Hontoya, who won the threemile, and Tommy Marshall, second in the pole vault, gave Rice the Southwest Conference track and field championship today.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 6 (AP) Mid-American Conference football coaches expressed "grave concern" today over the new punt formation rule, saying it was responsible for a rash of serious injuries during spring practice.

William E. Keane, a retired New York City civil engineer and the captain of the 1903 baseball team at Fordham University, died of a heart attack at his home on Friday. He was 88 years old and lived at Narraganset Avenue, the Bronx.
COBLESKILL, N.Y., May 6 (AP) Ken Dietz, a senior at Rye Neck High School, set a state schoolboy record today in the first high school invitation track meet here.
KANSAS CITY, May 6--Reports, which have arisen for several years, that Charles O. Finley plans to move his Kansas City Athletics to Oakland, are gaining a great deal of momentum here this year.

DOYLESTOWN, Pa., May 6 Straight from the classes on his third time out as a show dog, Ehrstag's Gage, a 2-yearold Pembroke Welsh corgi, won the best-in-show award at the 26th annual Bucks County Kennel Club fixture. There were 1,786 dogs in the competition.

THIS volume is a pleasure to the eye and inexpensive for the satis faction offered. Only a Scrooge or a very angry young man would not be charmed by the 232 illustrations (86 in color) which depict gently and blandly a cheerful view of a vanished America.

TALK, which was supposed to be one of the first casualties of television, not only has survived but also seems to be increasing. Chit-chat, both trivial and substantial, is proving to be one of the most economical of broadcasting staples. It is now flourishing in late evening and afternoon TV and is developing into a mainstay of radio. The trend may have more significance than meets the eye or ear.

LUSAKA, Xambia, May 6 Two Zambian golfers, Jimmie McCabe, 52 years old, and Tony Mack, 36, beat a six-foot crocodile to death with their clubs yesterday on the golf course at the small mining town of Bancroft on the Congo border.

VICTORIA, B.C. Vancouver Island, the larg est island off the Pacific Coast of North America, is capitalizing on an odd virtue its rugged wildness, which until now has has been almost inaccessible to tourists.

HEWLETT HARBOR, L.I., May 6 Wearing three sweaters under his foul-weather gear, and worried about a puddle in his golf bag, Dick Siderowf successfully fought The Seawane Club course today and won the William D. Richardson Memorial Tournament for the second year in a row.

EAST MEADOW, L.I., May 6 Ch. Falco of Thunder Rock, owned by Antonio Maurizio of Brooklyn, was best of breed for the fourth year in a row at the German Shepherd Dog Club of Long Island's 17th annual specialty show held today on the rain-soaked field of Salisbury Park.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 6 Western diplomats say that the Soviet Union is a major factor in stalling efforts here to solve the critical problem of managing and paying for peace-keeping operations.

Miss Justine James Moran, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Justin James Moran of Grymes Hill, S.I., was married yesterday morning to H. Stephen Fletcher, son of Mr. and Mrs. F. Harry Fletcher of Ridgefield, N.J. The Very Rev. John Coffey performed the ceremony in the Roman Catholic Church of Our Lady of Good Counsel.
GREENPORT, L.I., May 6 Five-year-old Aaron Gills walked from his home this week, wearing his Zorro shirt. He was obviously more inter ested in being a cowboy than a bridge builder.
"Twisting in Red Square!" a middle-aged Russian woman exclaimed. "What next?"

CENTERPORT, L.I., May 6 James B. Moore Jr. of the Manhasset Bay Yacht Club led from the third race on today but had to survive a protest in the seventh and final event to win the Yacht Racing Association of Long Island Sound Frostbite dinghy championship.

WASHINGTON, May 6 Conflict is expected to break out in Congress next week among the users of the nation's mails. The battlefield will be provided by the Subcommittee on Rates of the House Post Office and Civil Service Committee.
WASHINGTON, May 6 The National Rifle Association has defended the private ownership of guns as "a potential community stabilizer" in the event of urban riots.

Ship operators of all nations have been informed by insurance underwriters that under certain conditions it may cost them twice as much to insure their vessels for war risk hull and machinery coverage while in South Vietnamese waters.

One hundred Wast Harlem families are being selected for an expanded aid program by Community Service Society of New York, which aims to remove them ultimately from the City's Welfare Department rolls.
CAIRO, May 6 (AP) Dr. Hans Eisele, former physican at Buchenwald, who fled to Egypt almost a decade ago after having served a prison term for war crimes, was reported to have died here Wednesday.
LUCAYA, Grand Bahama, May 6 The longest and most severe test of men, women, motors and boats ever conceived begins with the dawn tomorrow morning.

BOXES, tubs and pots are good accessories to brighten terrace or patio, dooryard, deck, steps or the swimming pool. The type of plants used will depend, to some degree, on the location where they will be growing. Shade-loving plants will not be at their best in full sun and those that must have full sun will be spindly and lack flowers in dense shade.
The Citizens' Committee for Children has complained that Mayor Lindsay's 1967-68 budget lists lump sums without details on how they will be spent.

Governor Rockefeller's veto of a bill that would have made it easier for foster parents to adopt a child they had cared for over two years has been severely criticized by the Adoptive Parents Committee.
On April 11, 1965, President Johnson returned to the Texas schoolhouse he attended as a boy and ceremonially signed into law the Elementary and Secondary Education Act (ESEA).

ROME, May 6 (UPI) Gina Lollobrigida and Claudia Cardinale, actresses who have been targets of bitter criticism by the Vatican press over their private lives, chatted today with Pope Paul VI during an audience for members of the entertainment and communications professions.

The M.E.B.A. Apprenticeship Program, operated jointly by District 1 of the National Marine Engineers Beneficial Association and its Pacific Coast district, has announced publiccation of the booklet "Be a Marine Engineer."

Miss Jane DeWitt Sessions, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Ralph D. Sessions Jr. of Andover, Mass., was married yesterday to James Patrick Kiernan, son of Mrs. Elmer M. Shankland of Brooklyn and the late James Kiernan. The Rev. Victor Ratigan performed the ceremony in St. Joseph's Roman Catholic Church, on the Avenue of the Americas and Washington Place
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 6 Army posted its fourth straight outdoor track and field victory by easily defeating Manhattan, 111 to 42, today.
HANOI, North Vietnam, May 6 Three United States pilots, shot down over the Hanoi area, were put on display here today.

GEARY, Okla. The Chisholm Trail, which Wayne Gard, the historian, has called "the Texas cowhand's road to high adventure," is 100 years old this year, and folks along the way plan to whoop it up a bit during the summer.
The New York Studio School of Drawing, Painting and Sculpture will celebrate its move to its new home at 8 West Eighth Street with a benefit party there May 22.
The keel of a 201,600-deadweight-ton tanker that will be the largest diesel-driven vessel in the world was laid last month in Japan.
MOSCOW, May 6 (UPI) The Soviet press agency Tass reported today that three captured American pilots had been led through angry, shout Plane Losses at 553 Hanoi.

Ignoring national political considerations and Communist doctrine, Danril Granin, a Soviet novelist, argues in a Soviet publication that only the international mobilization of resources and brains will be able to cope with the physical and technical changes engulfing mankind.

ASBURY PARK, N.J. With the warming days of May, the resorts along the 120 miles of New Jersey's Atlantic coastline have come alive. From Keansburg, in the wash of New York Harbor, south to Cape May, which lies below the Mason-Dixon line, officials of seashore communities are looking toward Memorial Day and the opening of the resort season. As usual, the feeling once again is one of optimism.

PROVIDENCE, R.I., May 6 (Ap) A state conference of the American Association of University Professors unanimously passed a resolution today urging John C.A. Watkins, publisher of The Providence Journal and Evening Bulletin, to reinstate a weekly column, "One Man's Opinion."
A one-time tiny business enterprise that produced an irresistible, mosquito-like plane called the Mite is now building the "world's first pressurized single-engine executive plane."

TWO or three years ago the South, and with it the entire nation, was caught up in a variety of struggles called "the civil rights movement." Today the movement seems stalled, almost a thing of the past, much to the relief of some and the frustrated bewilderment of others.

ATLANTA For a while some Negroes and sympathetic whites held out hope that the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. might say what he had to say about the war in Vietnam, and then turn his undivided attention back to civil rights.

HEWLETT, L.I., May 6 The engagement of Miss Ellen Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Goodman, to Paul Eric Wattenmaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Wattenmaker of Freeport, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

CLEVELAND, May 6 (AP) Joe Horlen and Bob Locker combined to pitch a three-hitter tonight, giving the Chicago White Sox a 2-0 victory over the Cleveland Indians. The victory was Chicago's fourth straight and kept the White Sox tied with the Detroit Tigers, who beat the Orioles, for first place in the American League.

ELMIRA, N.Y. Just 100 years ago, a world famous humorists began an association with this Southern Tier city that was to last his lifetime and beyond. Samuel L. Clemens, better known as Mark Twain, married an Elmira girl, wrote a number of his best books here, and now lies buried in Elmira's Woodlawn Cemetery.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) In a new effort to increase the population of whooping cranes, their eggs are to be removed from nests in northern Canada and flown to Maryland for hatching is captivity.

IT is astonishing that anyone could tread so carefully through the quicksands of Mexican theology as has C.A. Burland of the British Museum. The complexity of his task is incredible: he has attempted to organize and to clarify what little is actually known about the several thousand-year-old religions of ancient Mexico.

UNIVERSITY PARK, Pa., May 6 (AP) Don Abbey kicked a 24-yard field goal with 30 seconds remaining to give the Blue team a 23-21 victory over the White team in Penn State's annual intramural football game today.

The Canterbury Choral Society of the Episcopal Church of the Heavenly Rest celebrated the 15th anniversary of its founding by giving a performance of Handel's "Samson" at Philharmonic Hall Friday night. The chorus usually performs in the church.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 6 Mrs. Constance Schild Baruch, wife of Joseph M. Baruch, president of the Presidential Realty Company of White Plains, died of cancer yesterday at the White Plains Hospital. She was 53 years old and lived at 146 Mercer Avenue.

JERRY BAKER, a 32-yearold professional horseman from Gates Mills, Ohio, has spent most of his adult life brooding about what he considered inadequate jumping courses at shows in the United States.

Twenty-five violinists from nine countries have been chosen to compete in the 25th International Competition sponsored by the Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation. The semifinals and finals will be held at Carnegie Hall May 15 and 16.

MONTREAL The American traveler in Canada this summer will find that his Unit ed States dollar stretches a bit once he crosses the border. It is worth about $1.08 in Canadian money, depending on the day-to-day fluctuations of the official exchange. Banks are authorized to pay the difference, called a premium, on demand. And most large businesses gladly take it into account to encourage buying by tourists.

A fanciful piece of Victoriana the Jefferson Market Courthouse in Greenwich Village will open in the fall as a public library branch that will combine modern comforts such as air-conditioning with the 19th-century charm of Gothic stained-glass windows.

HOMEOWNERS in or near industrial areas where air pollution is an acute problem are advised to select landscape plants with special care. BIRMINGHAM, Ala., May 6 (UPI) A tornado cut an erratic path through a 20-block area of Birmingham's west end tonight, killing one person and injuring at least 100.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 (UPI) The War Western Conference placed Sacramento State on probation today for at least one year on charges of "violating the letter and spirit of the conference constitution."

The reverse spin of the screwball, ordinarily a most difficult pitch to hit, has inspired, Wes Westrum, the manager of the New York Mets, to contemplate the use of reverse strategy ink one of today's two games with the Houston Astros at Shea Stadium.

General Chung Hee Park's decisive victory in South Korea's Presidential election rewards six years of responsible government, economic growth and a gradual return toward the democratic processes interrupted by his military coup in 1961.
The National Association for the Advancement of Colored People said last week it had 22,147 life members. In 1953, the organization had 221 such memberships. They cost $500 each.

ATLANTA There is a smalltown banker in Georgia who sometimes refers to Gov. Lester G. Maddox as "Ax-Handles," but such epithets have lost much of their bite in the state's present uncertainty about its new Chief Executive. When Mr. Maddox was sworn in as Governor last January he was known chiefly as a virulent racist who spouted shrill invective and brandished ax handles to block the desegregation of his Atlanta restaurant.
The city mailed postcards to 32,000 real estate owners yesterday reminding them that they must have an incinerator operating certificate from the Department of Air Pollution Control by May 20.
Soil found on the moon by Surveyor 3 is like fine sand, with each grain estimated to be about one-fiftieth of an inch in diameter, according to a scientist at the California Institute of Technology.
BOSTON, May 6 The new Boston of proliferating skyscrapers was assured this week of an old-fashioned donnybrook for the mayoralty with the entry of Mrs. Louise Day Hicks as a candidate.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The sufferer from multiple sclerosis is likely to have a good education and economic status and a high level of antibodies against measles and he probably was reared in a cold climate.

THERE comes a time when children are eager to abandon the world they know cars, trucks, baby carriages for that fantastic realm of tale and legend where, for a change, justice and wisdom are on their side. MUSHROOM clouds fade away and now even the last remnants of the Hiroshima bomb give off too faint a sound to be distinguished against the background of 500 subsequent bursts. The first A-Bomb explosions have become a prolonged overcast. Underneath the gloom, a post-war generation needs to be reminded that what happened once can happen again.
Mr. and Mrs. Max Rovner of the Bronx have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Roberta Rovner, to Steve R. Pieczenik, son of Dr. and Mrs. S.D. Pieczenik of New York and Toulouse, France.

Miss Gail Marie Morris, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Frank C. Morris of Riverdale, the Bronx, was married yesterday to Charles Anthony DeMartino, son of the late Mr. and Mrs. Frank DeMartino of New Rochelle, N.Y.

MESCALERO, N.M. High in the Sacramento Mountains of southern New Mexico, the Mescalero Apache Indians will hold their world-famous crown dances the first four days of July. This event is one of the many Indian celebrations that take place in New Mexico all summer at annual encampments, in age-old pueblos and in cities, where they are staged for tourists.

The 1967 Salute to Youth International Ball on May 24 at the Waldorf-Astoria's Grand Ballroom, a benefit for the International Cultural Centers for Youth, will pay tribute to the youth of the Americas.

STOCKBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 St. Paul's Episcopal Church was the setting this afternoon for the marriage of Miss Natalie Bayard Howard and Peter Alan Gordon.

WILLINGBORO, N.J., May 6 Levitt Sons has returned to the market that gave the small family concern impetus to become the world's largest home builder. Levitt's newest selection of homes is like nothing the company has built before.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 6 Miss Louise Ann Durbin, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gilbert H. Durbin of New Rochelle, was married here today to Dr. Oliver Quentin Hyder, son of Dr. Louise S. Hyder and Dr. Roland I. Hyder of Ipswich, England.

PARIS, May 6 Marcel Cerdan Jr.'s ambition to follow in his father's footsteps hung in the balance today when the French Boxing Federation confirmed the suspension of his license pending a medical reexamination of a defect of the lens of his left eye.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 6 Cornell's varsity crew won the Carnegie Cup the hard way today. The Big Red eight let the opposition take the lead, which became as much as threefourths of a boat length for Yale, and then captured the race on Lake Carnegie in the last quarter of a mile.

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 6 (AP) Karl Mildenberger, the European heavyweight boxing champion from West Germany, stopped Amos (Big Train) Lincoln of Portland, Ore., in the sixth round of a scheduled 10-round bout tonight.

Under the leadership of President Johnson's close friend, Senator Russell of Georgia, the Senate Armed Services Committee has endorsed the Administration's plan for a moderate revision of the draft system.
SWARTHMORE, Pa., May 6 (AP) Lehigh won the Middle Atlantic Conference doubles tennis title today while Jim Predmore of Swarthmore successfully defended his singles crown.
TUSKEGEE, Ala., May 6 Florida A. and M. dominated the Tuskegee relays today with seven first-place finishes before a crowd of about 3,000.

LOUISVILLE, May 6 Bobby Ussery plunged his mud-spattered face into the bouquet of roses that a valet handed him in the jockey quarters after the 93d running of the Kentucky Derby in a drizzle at Churchill Downs today. He inhaled deeply. It was the sweet smell of success.

A kilo of heroin with a possible value of $300,000 in the illegal retail market was seized from three Cubans yesterday morning at Kennedy International Airport as their plane arrived from Los Angeles.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 6 Orison W. MacPherson of the host Larchmont Yacht Club sailed his newly acquired International sloop, as yet unnamed, to a victory today with a late rally in the annual "tune-up" race for the One-Design Class of 33-footers on Long Island Sound.
SYRACUSE, N.Y., May 6 (AP) Larry Csonka scored twice as the Syracuse varsity routed the alumni, 36-9, today before 5,000 fans in a spring football game.

ONE problem facing gardeners today is finding sources of unusual plants and seeds. Lim ited demand does not allow nurseries to grow the more unusual types and commercial sources of seed are few. This is where a plant society can help. Many have seed exchanges for members which offer a wide variety of seed often unavailable commercially.
The course of the Parke-Bernet Galleries with Sotheby's at the helm has been in the direction of ever-proliferating sales. The coming week's auctions illustrate the trend.

WARWICK, England Paging all plan gonologists! Their number is legion in England, as well as the United States. Tourists who are also plangonologists (the English name for doll collectors) will discover that there is a rich mine of rare and antique dolls on view in museums throughout the British Isles.

OTTAWA, May 6 Canada's Parliament will begin Monday a new session devoted to improving what Prime Minister ter B. Pearson calls "the quality of Canadian life."
ANAHEIM, Calif., May 6 (AP) The California Angels obtained Bill (Moose) Skowron from the Chicago White Sox today for a minor league player and an undisclosed amount of cash.

ROBERT MORLEY, who decided when he was merely "a plump, spotty, rather unloved boy" that he was going to be an actor, has long since become a good one. As the star of "Oscar Wilde" and of "Edward, My Son," he has appeared with notable success in New York.

TUCKAHOE, N.Y., May 6 Miss Rita Maureen Bundschuh, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Gabriel Joseph Bundschuh of Bronxville, was married here today to Paul Michael Fitzpatrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Michael Anthony Fitzpatrick of the Bronx.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 6 Harvard met the challenge today of the Eastern crew rated as its most formidable rival, Pennsylvania, and won by the decisive margin of almost three lengths for its 24th successive victory in college competition since 1963.
LONDON, May 8 (UPI) Hard-hitting Judy Tegart of Australia upset Mrs. Ann Jones of Britain, 6-1, 2-6, 6-3, in the final of the London hard-court tennis championship at Hurlingham today.

DETROIT, May 6 Sales of foreign-made automobiles continued to rise in the United States in April, reports from importers show. A check at nine major car importers showed 53,138 retail car sales in April, up from 45,512 a year ago. Sales of United States-made cars last month were 710,479, off from 764393 a year before.

UP IN the Berkshires, where the people in volved with the fledgling Berkshire Theater Festival have grown a year older and, they hope, wiser, plans are moving toward a second season this summer. The wisdom gained can be summed up in the thought Roger L. Stevens expressed recently during a ...
Howard Bonnell Spencer, a painter of landscapes and still lifes, died Thursday in the Dresden Madison Nursing Home, 36 East 67th Street. He was 96 years old.

Cathedral ceilings, which long ago moved into private homes, have now turned up in apartment houses. The vaulted ceilings cover the second-floor living rooms in a 128-unit development called Town and Country Apartments, off Montauk Highway in Hampton Bays, L.I.

LONDON, May 6 (UPI) Chris Pardee, a 20-year-old freshman from Harvard, set a meet high-jump record of 6 feet 7 inches today as Oxford defeated Cambridge, 101-52, in their 93d varsity track and field meet at White City Stadium.

MONTICELLO, N.Y. As the scores of resort hotels and bungalow colonies in the southern Catskills get ready for their umpteenth season in the sun, one of the area's main after-dark attractions, Monticello Raceway, will celebrate its 10th anniversary this year. The halfmile harness-racing track, just a short drive from Monticello, opens next Friday.

ORANGE, N.J., May 6 The Rev. Dr. Charles Thorley Bridgeman, historiographer and former curate of Trinity Episcopal Church in New York, died today in Orange Memorial Hospital. He was 74 years old and lived in Vineyard Haven, Mass.

ATHENS The military triumvirate that seized power here upset all the secular gods of modern Greece. The triumvirate was out to smash the extreme left but, to do this, it opposed the King (while purloining his name), the Premier (who is under house arrest), the major political parties and the military hierarchy.

HONOLULU, May 6 Before adjourning early this week, Hawaii's legislators approved a hotly debated land reform program, set a timetable for a constitutional convention and authorized the appointment of an "Ombudsman," or Government watchdog.

Iona College's varsity crew, rowing at a steady 34 strokes a minute, took an early lead and held it to triumph in the Metropolitan Intercollegiate Rowing Association championship at Orchard Beach yesterday.

The latest bitter political anecdote in Spain is that the new Spanish constitution has been renamed "Populorum Regressi," a play on the Latin title of Pope Paul's new encyclical, "Populorum Progressi" ("On the Development of the Peoples"). The Spanish twist renders it "the regression of the peoples."
MIAMI, May 6 There is a certain mystique en- veloping such fish as trout wherein fans and at least a couple of organizations can get fairly precious about their angling purity.

PITTSBURGH, May 6 Miss Katharine Mills Hannah, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. A. Douglas Hannah, was married this afternoon to Edward Albert Servick, son of Mrs. Edward Ross Servick of Rocky Hill, Conn., and the late, Mr. Servick. The Rev. Dr. John Baiz performed the ceremony in Calvary Episcopal Church.

"These apartments are strictly for the cabbage trade you need a lot of cabbage to live here," said a builder recently as he showed a visitor through a spacious, glasswalled penthouse looking out across a far reach of New Jersey hills toward the New York skyline.

NEW VERNON, N.J., May 6 Mr. and Mrs. William Franklin Rae Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Nancy Ann Rae, to Philip Andruss Burrows, son of George Pollard Burrows of Summit and the late Mrs. Burrows.

A new sport with an old name came to the United States last week. The only familiar details in modern table tennis are the standard 9-by-5-foot table and the name itself. All else has changed, and the innocent lie strewn along the wayside.

SAN FRANCISCO. WHO is Petulia, what is she? An Arch Kook? Who is Julie Christie? A hippie? What is a hippie? Or, more to the point, why are there questions and questions on this glowing day when the city is bright and shining after weeks of relentless gray rain?

THE jazz climate in New York has been going through a sub- tle change in the last year. The sense of isolation in which many jazz musicians work, their feeling of alienation from the community at large, is being broken down slowly in small but pertinent ways by the activities of a group called Jazz Interactions.
JERUSALEM (Israel), May 6--Terrorists, believed to be Syrian, shelled as Israeli settlement last night from Lebanese territory in the Upper Galilee, Israeli officials reported.

TOMORROW at 10 P.M., NBC looks at "The Pursuit of Pleasure" in the Swinging Sixties and the change it has brought in our morality. This pursuit, as reported by news correspondent Sander Vanocur, takes many forms; one of the latest is the increasing use of drugs, especially LSD.

LOUISVILLE, May 6 A security force of 2,500, including 1,500 National Guardsmen, patroled the grounds at Churchill Downs today, lending an air of tension to the usually gay and festive Kentucky Derby program.
With a third of the year already down the corridors of time, the business community is inclined to relax a little.

SOLEDAD, Calif. There are two practical ways to drive to Pinnacles National Monument, now that an old country road leading up the west side of the extinct volcano where the monument is situated has been graded and graveled. This road might even become a paved through road if the National Park Service has its way.

At the city's property assessment offices in all five boroughs, hearing officers sighed in relief this week as they prepared to close their books. Over the last three months, they had heard the impassioned pleas of property owners for reduction of their annual assessed valuations.

MOUNT KISCO, N.Y., May 6 The engagement of Miss Dianne Pen Dilmaghani to John Martin Aronian 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. J.M. Aronian of Philadelphia, has been announced by the parents of the future bride, Mr. and Mrs. Mehdi Dilmaghani.

SALT LAKE CITY The old wagon trains that rolled across the Indian country when the West was wilder have a modern counterpart of sorts today. Caravans of air-conditioned motor-coaches are carrying busloads of sightseers on lowcost package bus tours of the national parks and forest lands.

WASHINGTON, May 6 An advisory panel to the Atomic Energy Commission cautioned yesterday that a black market was likely to develop in fissionable materials, with criminal or terrorist groups attempting to divert the materials into secret production of atomic weapons.
"Black Panthers" armed with rifles and shotguns interrupt the proceedings of the California Legislaure. Stokely Carmichael, speaking in Tennessee, houts, "To hell with the laws of the United States."

There is the temptation to say, as May spreads the leaves and opens the blossoms, that spring has come again just as it has come for untold eons. But the fact is that no two springs are exactly alike. Man contrives machines that turn out countless duplicates; but nature is not a machine. Change is the one constant in this living world, the essential element of life.

For many vocal, but paunchy, followers of the New York Ran- gers, the hockey season ended more than three weeks ago. But for a quiet, sturdy group of young men living along the Eastern seaboard, the "hockey" season is just getting started.

NO CANT is more resistant to destruction than that about the rewards of parenthood. Francis Bacon may have found the griefs and joys of parenthood to be secret, but this only proves that he never sat on a mid-morning park bench, or attended a suburban dinner party. In such purlieus, the rewards of parenthood receive unanimous and vociferous support long after all other enthusiasms, from patriotism to religiosity, have fallen into question.

The New York Committee of the Wellesley College Friends of Art is sponsoring private showings of the Lehman collection of art on Tuesday afternoon and evening. The collection of works of art of Western Europe from the late Middle Ages to the 20th century in Mr. and Mrs. Robert Lehman's town house at 7 West 54th Street.

ALGIERS, May 6 Emancipation of Algeria's white-veiled women, which many here thought would be accelerated by the country's independence, has made little headway in the face of unyielding tradition and lack of economic opportunity.
DEER ISLE, Me. Residents of this land of countless seaward vistas accept as their just due the only Maine "towns" named Sunset and Sunshine.

SAN FRANCISCO IT WAS long past mid night at the Geary Theater, but nobody really wanted to go home. Two psychiatrists, one rabbi and most of the ticket-holders were too busy trying to unravel the mysteries of Edward Alboe's "Tiny Alice."

ABOARD U.S.S. BENEWAH, off South Vietnam, May 5 There are, militarily speaking, two ways of looking at the Mekong River Delta, the rich rice-growing region in which a third of South Vietnam's 15 million people live.
"Aggressive, tough, but very fair, and also damned good at playing gin rummy and dominoes."

NEW DELHI General Ne Win is a national leader of remarkable resolution whose conviction that Burma can progress under "non-Communist socialism" and the strictest neutrality is under an increasingly heavy strain.

SHAKER HEIGHTS, Ohio, May 6 Mr. and Mrs. Siegbert Daniel have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Beverly Ruth Daniel, to Charles Irwin Kaplan, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Kaplan of Waban and Centerville, Mass. The wedding is planned for Aug. 20.
SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 6 Operating control of the University of Notre Dame was shifted today to laymen after 125 years of religious rule.

The often fierce rivalry among the North Atlantic ports of Boston, Philadelphia, Baltimore and Norfolk, Va., for all types of ocean cargo is increasing as the result of the growing volume of container shipments.
The total volume of commercial paper--short-term unsecured corporate notes--outstanding rose sharply during March to a new record, the Federal Reserve Bank of New York has reported.

WASHINGTON, May 6 Legislation to reduce the charges and fees paid by the nation's three-and-a-half-million mutualfund shareholders was sent to Congress by the Administration last week, and behind that simple and ordinarily routine act lies a story of a fight to come and a failure that is already history.
OWNERS of vacation cottages and homes located in rural or suburban areas where there are no municipal water supplies usually have to depend on their own wells for water.
Establishment of a monthly independent freight service between United States Gulf ports and the Far East has been announced by Marchessini Lines.

LEONIA, N.J., May 6 Miss Barbara Elaine Braun, daughter of Dr. and Mrs. Joseph C. Braun of Palisades Park and Avon-by-the Sea, was married here this morning to Douglas Ix, son of Mrs. Alexander Ix of Englewood and Spring Lake and the late Mr. Ix.
An "obstructed" view is being offered to prospective buyers of condominium townhouses in a development in Westchester County a view obstructed by trees on one side and trees and hills on the other.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 6 Dame Pattie again demonstrated her superiority over Gretel today in an America's Cup trial off Sydney Heads and made it virtually certain she would be Australia's challenger for the cup in September, off Newport, R.I.
RIDGEWOOD, N.J., May 6 Miss Nancy Jane Van Riper and Keith Jeremiah Pratt were married here this afternoon in the West Side Presbyterian Church by the Rev. Dr. Melvin R. Campbell.

New York State, about to launch a ticket lottery of a type that is a staple of public finance in Latin America, has an older lottery that's booming bingo. It's in so big a boom annual receipts have soared to $80 million than the authorities are about to tighten up its regulations.

FROM Russia this year the impression spreads that nearly everyone is reading the mate- rials of the Great Bolshevik Revolution, age 50. Happily, there is evidence that a good many Soviet families are also still reading a great compendium of homely wisdom, age 30.

"THIS book," writes the suthor, "was published in England in 1964 to tell English boys and girls about our Revolution. It is a small book and the Revolution was a long war ... I tried to select the generals and battles which had the greatest effect on the outcome ... I have tried to give both sides of the story."

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 6 Miss Linda Ann Lord, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. George Ransom Lord Jr. of Pelham, was married this afternoon to Donald Stephen Antilla, son of Oscar Antilla of Mamaroneck and Mrs. Henri Claudet of New Rochelle. The Rev. Charles E. Lange officiated at the ceremony in Christ Episcopal Church.

HUNTINGTON, Conn., May 6 Mrs. Francis M. Burns has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Frances Burns, to Lawrence H. Billingsley, son of Mr. and Mrs. Howard P. Billingsley of New London, N.H.

PITTSBURGH, May 6 (UPI) Matty Alou dashed home from second base with the winning run when Tito Fuentes threw wildly on George Spriggs's infield hit in the 10th inning today to give the Pittsburgh Pirates a 6-5 victory over the San Francisco Giants.
JACKSON, Miss., May 6 A Mississippi civil rights leader said today that Negroes in the state would refuse to enter military service unless Negroes were appointed to local draft boards.
HONG KONG, May 6 The Indonesian armed forces plan to begin a campaign this month to improve their reputation in the nation they now dominate.
It all started on May 17, 1792, when 24 merchants and auctioneers agreed to meet daily under a buttonwood tree on Wall Street to buy and sell securities among themselves.

Moscow. TWO children at the Central Music School were playing some two-piano pieces by Shostakovich for an American visitor the other day, One was a boy, about 10 years old, a thin kid with a serious face. The other was a chubby girl, about the same age.

BOSTON, May 6 (AP) A 15-year member of the New York City Police Department has been acquitted of murder in the shooting of Donald Byars, 41 years old, during an argument in which a woman also was shot to death.
WHITE PLAINS, May 6 The Idea of shipping large bundles of compacted garbage out of Westchester by train is gaining attention as a possible remedy for the county's garbage disposal problem.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 5 The leftist regime in neighboring Syria averted a threatened mass protest Friday by enlisting the aid of Imams, or prayor leaders, and by arresting the writer of an "atheistic" article that appeared in the weekly newspaper of the Syrian armed forces.

CONCORD, N.H. New Hampshire is celebrat ing a bit of a milestone in the mountainlift department this year. The state is sponsoring a "Come Out on Top Day," in commemoration of a revolutionary step it took just 10 years ago.

UNDERWOOD, N.Y. Although the last stretch of the 176-mile-long, toll-free Adirondack Northway (Interstate 87) is not scheduled to be completed until the end of summer, resort-area operators are eagerly anticipating the opening of the nextto-last section, the 26.1 miles of ex pressway extending from Pottersville a north to this Adirondack community.
New York State has "clear national leadership" in trying to control crime, but even the state is "not winning the fight on organized crime; in fact, we are going backward."
BUENOS AIRES, May 6 United States military experts express growing concern about the operations of guerrillas in southeastern Bolivia.

TORONTO There is more to Canada's cen tennial celebrations than Expo 67. From a naval assembly of 40 Canadian and foreign warships off the coast of Nova Scotia to a mountain-climbing tournament along the YukonAlaska border, Canada is filling its centennial summer with special events of interest to American, as well as Canadians.

ATLANTA, May 6 Mr. and Mrs. James Mitchell Thurman have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara Gail Thurman, to Berrien Moore 3d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Moore Jr. The wedding will take place Aug. 4 at the Northside Methodist Church here.

BREWSTER, N.Y., May 6 Mrs. M. Kelly Eliot of Brewster and Sandy Springs, Md., has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Celia Jane Eliot, to Richard Peter Fried. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Fried of Great Neck, L.I.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 6 The United States Merchant Academy team held an 18-point lead over the host United States Military Academy yachtsmen today after the first three races in the annual interservice academies championship regatta. The races were sailed in snow and cold on the Hudson River.
The Ford LGT is an aging hot-rodder's delight.

MONTPELIER, Vt. One of Vermont's most famous landmarks, the 81-year-old Pavilion Hotel here in Montpelier, has received a stay of execution. The State Legislature has voted $20,000 for a study to determine what to do with the quaint old building.

SWARTHMORE, Pa., May 6 In Trinity Episcopal Church here this afternoon Miss Margaret Randolph Bullitt, daughter of Mrs. James B. Bullitt Jr. and the late Mr. Bullitt, was married to F. Harvey Pough Jr. of Los Angeles. He is the son of Dr. Frederick H. Pough of Santa Barbara, Calif., and the late Mrs. Pough.

PITTSBURGH, May 6 Dr. and Mrs. Sidney Alexander Rosenburg have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Harriet Louise Rosenburg, to Alan Jay Greenfield. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Morton Greenfield of Highland Park, N.J.
NEW DELHI, May 6 The Indian Government has liberalized the issuance of import licenses under its rethinking of economic policies that began with devaluation of the rupee last June.

IN the Senior High School Individual Tournament, a six-round Swiss system, Anthony Deutsch and Marc Lonoff, both of Francis Lewis High, tied for first place. Each scored 5-1. All their games showed a high degree of sophistication in the opening, middle game and ending.
A funny thing happened to the nation's steel companies on the way to their annual meetings. Funny is probably not the word the companies or their shareholders would choose to describe the experience.

LAST week my local supermarket was featuring a special on post-Easter candies, and I brought home what appeared to be a bag of jelly beans. The candies turned out to be shaped and colored like jelly beans, only even sweeter and blander, made of something the manufacturer called "Mellocream": texture smoothly the same outside as inside, and the flavorings--lemon, lime, vanilla, orange, cherry--all bearing not the faintest differentiation in flavoring.
WEST BABYLON, L.I., May 6 A 22-year-old sheetmetal worker, who had been convicted earlier of rape, was charged early today with the first degree murder of an other woman.

FOUR nationally recognized camera authori- ties will be featured this afternoon at Flower Photography Day from 1:30 to 3:15 o'clock in the Museum Building at the New York Botanical Garden in Bronx Park. It is free to the public.
MADRID, May 6 The Roman Catholic Archbishop of Madrid has forbidden a memorial mass for Hitler in any church in this archdiocese.
EDINBURGH, Scotland, May 6 (Reuters) Whisky exports from Scotland in 1968 set records both in volume and value.

SEATTLE, May 6 (AP) Gerry Lindgren of Washington State set one stadium record today and pushed Dave Roberts of Washington U. to another in a Pacific Eight Conference dual track and field meet. The Huskies won, 88-57.

In the Episcopal Church of the Epiphany here yesterday afternoon, Miss Anne Pendleton, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Ogden Pendleton of Westport, Conn., became the bride of Laurence Colin Ward 3d. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Ward Jr. of Princeton, N.J., and Hyannis Port, Mass.
LONDON, May 6 (AP) The British Ford Motor Company has unveiled a new line of "tailor-made" heavy trucks.
BERLIN, May 6 (Reuters) Prisoners at Tegel prison in West Berlin have produced and smuggled out of jail keys for their own and practically all other prisons in West Germany, it was discovered today.

EVER, since "Harriet the Spy" crashed into the juvenile book world, an odd disease has been afflicting its authors. They are beginning to tell the truth. Children are behaving like children, and parents are being revealed as the vulnerable souls they are. I rejoice in this and in "Ellen Grae": a serio-comic work which deals with a matter of conscience.
DETROIT, May 6 (AP) Frank E. Fitzsimmons, acting president of the teamsters, today angrily challenged reports that there had been a change in the power structure of the 1.8 million member union.
Spain, France, Poland, South Africa and Japan advanced to the second round of the Davis Cup competition yesterday by clinching zone victories, The Associated Press reported.
City College last week dropped a controversial requirement that campus student groups submit the names of their members to college authorities.

Mr. and Mrs. Donald D. Ash of Port of Spain, Trinidad, have announced here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Carolyn Elizabeth Ash of London, to Bedford Hoyt Lydon Jr. of New York. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Lydon of Cranford, N.J. The wedding is planned for June 24 in Port of Spain.
The Young Committee of the Friends of the City Center will give a dinner dance at Tavernon-the-Green following the opening of the Leonard Bernstein musical "Wonderful Town" on May 17 at the center.
DANURY, Conn, May 6 Miss Mary Murnane and Anthony John Matejczyk of Boston lan to be married Sept. 16 Bradford, Mass.

MONZA, Italy World speed reccords have been broken often at the autodrome in the 2,000-acre public park of this small north ern Italian city. What delights the tourist, however, is that the park itself could easily win a Grand Prix if prizes were awarded to public recreation areas.
Mayor Lindsay, in an unexpected gesture of amity to a severe critic, yesterday appointed Councilman Joseph Modugno a goodwill ambassador to Lucerne, Venice, Florence, Rome and Geneva.

An agency that polices international airlines to guard against unauthorized fare cutting and other "violations" of airline agreements will get a new chief and a new name after July 1. It may also be reorganized.

IF ever there was a fictional character I felt like meeting again it was Harryboy Boas, a full-time gambler and part-time garment worker from the East End of London, who made his debut a season ago in Alexander Baron's "The Lowlife."

Welfare Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg, whose department pays some 45 per cent of the bills for the Association for Homemakers Service, will try tomorrow to mediate a dispute between the association and the homemakers it employs.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 6 (Reuters) South Africa has told world Olympic officials that it will make no concessions in order to be allowed to compete at next year's Olympic Games in Mexico City.

Anthony White, 16 years old, came racing out of the wing of the school auditorium into full view of the audience. Three more steps and he was off the ground in a high, twisting "no hands flip-over." It carried him over five bodies crouched on the stage and he landed, as he had begun, on his feet.

BRIELLE, N.J., May 6 Mr. and Mrs. Frank N. Bowers have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sherry Ellen Bowers of Hewlett, L.I., to James Charles McBride, son of Mr. and Mrs. James A. McBride of Rockville Centre, L.I.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 6 The marriage of Miss Mary Elizabeth Nolte, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. William Devereux Nolte, to Dr. Robert Montague Wein, son of Dr. and Mrs. Gustave F. Wein of Bronxville, N.Y., took place here at noon today.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 6 Poplar Evalynda, idle throughout 1966 because of lameness, started in the first stakes event of her career tonight at Roosevelt Raceway and won. With George Sholty thinking and acting in a manner befitting a topflight professional reinsman, Poplar Evalynda captured the eighth edition of the Lady Maud Pace, beating the 18-to-1 Ravina Hanover by two lengths. The odds-on favorite, Meadow Elva, finished third, a length farther back.

HUMMINGBIRDS, the butterflies of the bird world, and gaiety, color and natural beauty to any garden as they deftly move from blossom to blossom. Both nectar from blooms and tiny insects find their way into the hummingbird's diet. To keep these little sprites visiting the garden regularly, it will be necessary to supplement their food source, beginning in spring.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 6--The Kentucky Derby was run without incident today, as civil rights forces contented themselves with a parade through almost deserted downtown streets.

BOGOTA, Colombia, May 6 (UPI) The editor in chief of the newspaper El Tiempo, who said yesterday that two members of his staff had been beaten and threatened by an American bodyguard for Lynda Bird Johnson, declared today that it was all a mistake.

Mrs. Frances Gillespie Wickes, a writer, a lay psychoanalyst and a psychological counselor, died Friday in a nursing home in Peterborough, N.H. She was 91 years old and lived in the Adams Hotel, 2 East 86th Street.

Advice to builders: Get hip to the housing needs of the "young swingers" and profit opportunities will widen like the eyes of a young man ogling a go-go girl.

ATHENS The military junta that seized power in Greece on April 21 enters the third week of its rule with only one well defined aim: to stay in power. What it plans to do with that power remains frustratingly unclear to observers and, many suspect, to the junta itself.
After 33 years at New York University, Dr. Abraham I. Katsh, the director of its Institute of Hebrew Studies, will become president of Dropsie College for Hebrew and Cognate learning in Philadelphia.

GENEVA, April 30 Despite complaints by Swiss isolationists, who say there are too many foreigners here as it is, the Government is supplying the money for a new construction program that will consolidate Geneva's supremacy as an international conference center.

Five years ago the late Rachel Carson drew a gloomy portrait of a "Silent Spring" which she said could become a reality if man continued his misuse and overuse of pesticides. In this startling bestseller, she called America's attention to numerous actual and potential hazards to all living forms created by these potent chemicals.

BERLIN, May 6 A roundfaced little boy, black skullcap on the back of his head, looked up from his plate and smiled. "School was dull today," he said, "because the teacher only repeated things I knew already."

It is a tired tune, long sung by high school guidance counselors to high school seniors and their parents, that there are many good colleges in the United States, and that students need not go to a big-name campus to get a good education. Nevertheless, year after year, the admissions scramble continues for a few places at a few select colleges, while many accredited institutions go begging for a full freshman complement.

The United Cerebral Palsy Association of Nassau County will receive the proceeds of the International Art Show to be held Friday through May 19 at the Carnegie Endowment International Center at 345 East 46th Street.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 6 (Reuters) Eight Vietnamese women and 16 children were killed when caught up in a Vietcong attack on a Mekong Delta administrative center early today, a Government spokesman said.

SAN ANTONIO, Tex., May 6 The Rev. Joseph Deane, one of four priests suspended in connection with the publications of an interview critical of the Most Rev. Robert E. Llucey, Archbishop of San Antonio, in the San Antonio Express-News last Sunday, was reinstated today.

DERBY, Conn., May 6 Harvard's undefeated lightweight crew captured the Goldthwaite Cup for the 10th straight time today, winning in a regattarecord time of 6:10.3. After trailing by no more than a length for most of the race. Princeton finished that distance behind in 6:14.5, while Yale was clocked in 6:21.5.

CINNAMON BAY, St. John, V.I. The way the local naturalists tell it, this small, sunny island was once beset by black rats. To control them, one problem-solver suggested importing mongooses from India. He reasoned that the mongoose, which dotes on rats as well as on snakes, would drive all unpleasant creatures from the island and that that would be that.

The United States delegation to the United Nations recently made a complaint to the Soviet delegation about "anti-Semitic aspersions" by a Soviet delegate against an American member of the Human Rights Commission of the United Nations.
ATLANTA, May 6 (AP) Marty Riessen defeated Arthur Ashe, the top-seeded player, today in a duel of Davis Cup stars in the semi-finals of the Atlanta invitation tennis tournament.

Amateurs and experts in the fast-growing sport of scuba diving (with the use of self-contained underwater breathing apparatus) believe the greatest reason for owning a boat is that it provides a jumpoff point into a new world.

Increased speculative activity kept the stock market busy and buoyant last week and propelled the major averages upward for the fourth week in a row.
WARRENTON, Va., May 6 (AP) David L. Ferguson's Leeds Don survived a tumble and retired the Virginia Gold Cup with a third straight victory in the 22-fence timber event today.

The Manhattan School of Music's Opera Theater closed its season Friday night with a rare performance of Ambroise Thomas's "Hamlet." The performance was at the school on East 105th Street.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 5 A scientific advisory group, predicting a world food crisis in proteins, has called for a $300-million United Nations program in the next decade to increase protein supplies to hungry peoples.
A 41-year-old Brooklyn man shot and killed his wife and their 12-year-old son and critically wounded his mother-inlaw, before turning his carbine on himself and committing suicide early this morning.

CHICAGO, May 6 Gov. George Romney of Michigan, reacting angrily to a question about alleged lack of civil rights legislation in his state, said here today that Michigan was leading the nation in civil rights.
PASADENA, Calif., May 6 (AP) A flying photographic laboratory to map features of the moon as small as 200 feet across continued its journey on target today.
LIMA, Peru, May 6 Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon is receiving an enthusiastic reception here on the first stop in his "prvate citizen's tour of Latin America."

GENEVA, May 6 William C. Foster, United States representative at the Geneva Disarmament Conference, left for Tokyo today in a new attempt to convince Japan that the proposed treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons would not hamper her growing nuclear industry.

MONTREAL, May 6--Proposals to make permanent use of the site of Expo 67 and some of the fair buildings, possibly as a new university, attracted support this week, as sightseers continued to flock to the world exhibition.
A consortium of private companies should begin finding market places for applied technology gleaned from the country's space investment, a corporation president suggested.

ROSEMONT, Pa., May 6 Mr. and Mrs. George LeGrand of Rosemont have made known the engagement of their daughter. Miss Cynthia Boyd Rush, to Theodore Lowell Hake. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Theodore Russel Hake of York.

VICTORIA, B.C. The newest automobile approach to Alaska is by way of the so-called Marine Highway, a combination of ferry service along the scenic Inside Passage and pavement along the eastern coast of Vancouver Island. The route was established a year ago, and offers an alternative to the Alaska Highway, which runs from Dawson Creek, B.C., through Yukon Territory to Fairbanks.

DAYTONA BEACH, Fla. A return engagement of the Lon don Symphony Orchestra, which last year instituted the Daytona Beach International Music Festival, is the highlight of a busy summer season for this resort area.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 6 Three United States Air Force fighter-bombers were shot down yesterday during new raids in the outskirts of Hanoi, a military spokesman reported today.

ITALY'S fantastic Blue Team will be trying to win its tenth World Championship title in Miami Beach, Fla., at the end of this month. Four of the players Walter Avarelli, Giorgio Belladonna, Massimo D'Alelio and Pietro Forquet hold nine world titles apiece. Forquet's partner, Benito Garozzo, has "only" six titles. D'Alelio's partner, Camillo Pabis Ticci, has a mere four.

If he played his cards right, Tom Dillon might have been city editor of The Minneapolis Tribune today. He didn't, though, so he's only president and chief executive officer of Batten, Barton, Durstine Osborn, the world's fourthlargest advertising agency, with an estimated $312-million in billings last year.
SEOUL--A costly American investment in Asian democracy seemed to be paying off this week as more than 11 million South Koreans went to the polls to choose a President.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 6 (AP) A former Presidential assistant, Richard N. Goodwin, accused the Johnson Administration tonight of wanting a complete military victory in Vietnam rather than a negotiated settlement of the war.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The White House is understood to have quietly shelved a confidential and politically controversial report suggesting specific steps for easing border friction between the United States and Mexico.

THE concept of the photograph as an object in itself, rather than as a medium for com- munication, unites the atti- tudes of the three European photographers whose work went on display last week at the Museum of Modern Art. The show, which introduces to this country the work of Denis Brihat and Jean-Pierre Sudre of France, and Pierre Cordier of Belgium, will con- tinue through June.

YORK, Pa., May 6--Mr. and Mrs. Frederick Lind Young Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Judith Anne Young, to Robert Daniel Morris. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Peter James Morris.

A couple of weeks ago a salesman from Montreal flew to New York aboard an Air Canada plane on business. On arriving, he found his luggage was not at the airline's claim area. Not until he was ready to return home, three days later, did it turn up. The airline had found it in Athens.

PHILADELPHIA, May 5 Mayor James H.J. Tate, rejected by the Democratic organization in his bitter fight for renomination, now seems a likely victor over the organization candidate, Alexander Hemphill, in the primary May 16.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The nation's railroads and the railway labor unions today gave a preview of the positions they will take in the Congressional fight over President Johnson's bill to settle the current rail labor dispute.
Philadelphia business leaders, headed by the Chamber of Commerce, are seeking to drum up public support for a $13-million bond issue to be voted on at the May 16 primary election.
An "alarming" set of indicators has been noted in the monthly bulletin of the National Association of Purchasing agents.
Monroe Wheeler, head of the Department of Exhibitions and Publications at the Museum of Modern Art since 1939, will resign July 1. He will assume a nonstaff post as counselor to the trustees.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The Republican party took another small discreet step away from its 1964 identification with Barry Goldwater today, and disgruntled conservatives immediately threatened a new party split.

PORT-OF-SPAIN, Trinidad Carl Baker, 195 pounds, Trinidad, knocked out Aaron Breasley, 188 , Miami 2 rounds. Leotis Martin, 195, Philadelphia, outpointed Ulric Regis, 190 , Trinidad, 5.
WASHINGTON, May 6 The first United States showing of a series of recent paintings by a Brazilian artist, Dallas Alves opened yesterday at the Brazilian - American Culture Institute here.

So proclaimed the convention chairman of a national professional organization in outlining his requirements to the convention manager of a large resort hotel here.

MONTE CARLO, May 6 Jack Brabham of Australia set an unofficial course record today in capturing the pole position for the 25th running of the Grand Prix de Monaco auto race tomorrow.

THE exhibition called "American Sculpture of the Sixties," which opened last week at the Los Angeles County Museum of Art, is not what its name suggests.

Proud Clarion of John W. Galbreath's Darby Dan Farm, a 30-1 shot ridden by Bob Ussery, took the lead in the stretch and won the 93d Kentucky Derby at Churchill Downs yesterday. Barbs Delight, who had set the pace from the start, was second and Damascus, the favorite, was third.

WHEN is a bargain really a bargain? This question is posed by the recent release of Weber's Der Freischutz on the low-priced Seraphim label. It is a pertinent question since Seraphim, a branch of Angel, is one of many such labels now available in quantity.

PARGUERA, P.R. Here in the southwest corner of Puerto Rico, where swimming pools and luxury hotels are few and far between, visitors are offered a two-in-one vacation: generally moderate prices and dramatically different scenery. The rates are low because not too many tourists make their way to this comparatively isolated part of the island, and the scenery is different because this is Puerto Rico's desert.
The case of Dr. Herman Taller, author of "Calories Don't Count," is expected to go to a jury in Brooklyn Federal Court on Tuesday after five weeks on trial.

WASHINGTON, May 6 "When Rockefeller was running for a third term as Governor last year, I was against him," a New York business executive said this week. "Now I'd like to see him elected President. I'm not sure I understand it myself."

DALLAS, May 6 (AP) Freshmen were made eligible for varsity golf and tennis and a new plan to increase the efficiency of football officiating were among matters handled by the Southwest Conference in a spring session today.

OKLAHOMA CITY, April 30 Oklahoma has undertaken to stop a new migration of "Okies" out of the state. "These are not Steinbeck Okies," said Dr. Pat Choate, who developed a new type of antipoverty program for Oklahoma. They have education.

NEXT Thursday morning the 1967 interna- tional stamp exhibition will open in Amsterdam, the Netherlands. Titled Amphilex 67, it will be presented in the Europa Hall of the Rijwiel and Automobiel Industrie (RAI) building, originally constructed for display of Dutch-made bicycles and automobiles. The show will be open daily through May 21. In 1966 Washington was host to the exhibition.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The Administration seems at last to have come up with a sensible idea for reducing public opposition to the Vietnamese war. The proposal is to set up several War Rehabilitation Centers to which war objectors of all stripes may voluntarily commit themselves for therapy.

A prominent Reform rabbi who recently returned from a special tour as a chaplain in Vietnam has asserted that those seeking peace in Vietnam by attacking the Johnson Administration are helping to prolong the war.

ASTOUT, wavy-haired truck driver was steering a diesel tractor-trailer loaded with 900 cases of whisky down Nelson Street in Brooklyn one raw morning when a passing motorist blew his horn and pointed urgently toward the trailer's rear axle. Instinctively waving "thanks" and stepping on his brake, the driver parked, then walked back to see what was wrong.

THE World Trade Center, the controversial (the Empire State Building hates it) twin-towered colossus designed for lower Manhattan by the architect Minoru Yamasaki, is beginning to spend the $2 million budgeted for its art and landscaping. SYRACUSE, May 6 Brown University's heavyweight varsity crew raced to a 9 -length triumph over Syracuse today on Onondaga Lake.

COLLECTORS of coins of the world can now pursue their hobby in an orderly, systematic man- ner, comparable to that enjoyed for many years by collectors of United States coins. Three books are principally responsible for this "upgrading" of foreign coins.

He introduced interplanetary flight before NASA was thought of. His luxuriant imagination has conjured up wicked goddesses, warriors with long tails and hideous monsters of the ice age for earthmen to contend with.

The nation's labor experts have been predicting for months that the greatest threat of new antistrike legislation in 1967 would accompany the contract negotiations between the railroads and six shop craft unions. Both predictions now have come true.

KANSAS CITY, May 6 Continued rain forced another postponement on the New York Yankees this evening, and reduced their series with the Kansas City Athletics to a double-header tomorrow afternoon. It was the third postponement in five scheduled games so far on this Western trip.

NEW HAVEN, May 6 The marriage of Miss Priscilla Reynolds to Kermit Roosevelt Jr. look place this afternoon in the Marquand Chapel of the Yale Divinity School. The Rev. William Sloan Coffin Jr., Yale's Protestant chaplain, performed the ceremony. A reception was held at the Yale Faculty Club.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 6 Rene Coudert of Larchmont recaptured the King Edward VII Gold Cup for his Long Island Sound club yesterday when he outsailed Peter Richold of the Royal Bermuda Yacht Club to win by more than two minutes the last of three match races. The series was sailed in International One Design Class sloops.

LOUISVILLE, May 6 Proud Clarion boldly sounded the call of victory for the Darby Dan Farm in the 93d running of the Kentucky Derby today. Under the guidance of the cool, skillful and extremely lucky Bobby Ussery, Proud Clarion won the 11 -mile classic by a length over Barbs Delight, with the strong favorite, Mrs. Edith Bancroft's Damascus, another length and a quarter back in the field of 14.

ARMONK, N.Y., May 6 John Mangan of Harrison, who heads the draw, led the way into the third round of the 34th Westchester County tennis championship at the Armonk Club today. Rain forced all matches onto the club's indoor courts in the opening torney of the Eastern season.

KENNETH ADAMS of Bakersfield, Calif., and Steph en Wood, of Van Nuys, Calif., rode an Austin Healey to first place in the Sports Car Club of America's Great Canyon National Rally last weekend. The finish was unusually close, with less than 5 seconds separating the first three cars.

AT their annual April banquet, the Mystery Writers of America conferred the Edgar Allan Poe awards, with the warm agreement of this department, upon Nicolas Freeling's "The King of the Rainy Country" (Harper Row, $4.50) as the best crime novel of 1966 and Ross Thomas's "The Cold War Swap" (Morrow, $3.95) as best American first novel and it's pleasant to note that Thomas's second novel is already scheduled for late May.
