Miss. Linda Diana Young, daughter of Lewis B. Young of 1075 Park Avenue and the late Mrs. Young, was married here yesterday afternoon to George Emerson Barnes 2d, son of Mr. and Mrs. Robert G. Barnes of 245 East 87th Street. The Rev. D. Reginald Thomas performed the ceremony in the chapel of the Brick Presbyterian Church. A reception was held at the St. Regis-Sheraton.

HEWLETT, L.I., May 6 The engagement of Miss Ellen Goodman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. David Goodman, to Paul Eric Wattenmaker, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Wattenmaker of Freeport, has been announced by the future bride's parents.

Eugene Sborovy of New York has announced the engagement of his daughter, Miss Katherine Eva Sboroby, to James Arnold Janowitz, son of Mr. and Mrs. Arnold Janowitz of Forest Hills Gardens, Queens, and Hollywood Hills, Fla. The wedding is planned for August.

THEIR fire died one bloody night and the Oulhamrs fled through the darkness, with bones broken and spirits forlorn. How could the tribe survive without firm fire to ward off beasts, to temper their spears, to roast meat, to warm their bodies and cheer their hearts?

STEPNEY, Conn., May 6 Dr. John D. Rosenfeld, a dentist who practiced in New York from 1926 to 1941 and here from 1945 until he retired two years ago, died of cancer today at Stamford Hospital. He was 68 years old and lived in Stepney.

SILVER SPRING, Md., May 6 Millard Cass, Deputy Under Secretary of Labor, and Mrs. Cass have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sandra Jean Cass, to Jeffrey A. Burt, son of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel M. Burt. Both families live here.

St. James' Episcopal Church was the setting here yesterday for the marriage of Miss Deirdre Stillman Marsters, daughter of Mrs. Katherine Stillman Marsters of 520 East 86th Street and Theodore Newton Vail Marsters of Madison, Conn., to Ens. Benjamin Ward McCleary, U.S.N.R. He is a son of Mr. and Mrs. George William McCleary of Asheville, N.C.

SCARSDALE, N.Y., May 6 Mr. and Mrs. Clifford G. Dalzell have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Heidi Howland Dalzell, to James Douglas Miller, son of Mr. and Mrs. Horace F. Miller of Williamsville, N.Y. An August wedding is planned.

Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan has asked the Board of Education to drop its plans to set up a single system of comprehensive high schools that would offer both academic and vocational courses.

A Mozart evening with the pianist Vivian Rivkin, and the New York Orchestral Society under Joseph Eger, is getting to be an annual event. Friday night was the fourth such concert at Carnegie Hall in as many years. The program listed one of the little Marches, the "Haffner" Symphony, the two Concert Rondos and the E Flat Piano Concerto, No. 22.

WILLIAM FAULKNER wrote one children's book in his life, as early as 1926, typed and bound it himself, and presented the single copy to an 8-year-old child named Victoria Franklin, who later became his stepdaughter. Except for the author's name, there seems little reason to publish it now.

MIDLAND, Tex., May 6 (UPI) Carol Mann sank three birdies in a four-hole stretch today and posted a two-underpar 70 and a 36-hole total of 143 to take a one-stroke lead in the $12,500 Tall City open golf tournament.

WASHINGTON With a complirated political-diplomatic double play involving gold as will as troops, the United States last week appeared to have averted a major crisis in the North Atlantic Treaty Alliance and neutralized domestic political pressure for a substantial reduction of U.S. forces in Europe.

MORRISTOWN, N.J., May 6 The marriage of Miss Constance Marilyn Bennett, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. W. Sheldon Bennett, to Lieut. David Russell Meunier. U.S.A.F., took place here today. The bridegroom is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Russell W. Meunier of Peshtigo, Wis. The Rev. Robert C. Holland, assisted by the Rev. Robert L. Schmidt, performed the ceremony in the Presbyterian Chapel on the Green.

WEST POINT, N.Y., May 6 Cardinal Spellman today became the first member of the clergy to receive the Sylvanus Thayer Award, issued annually by the Association of Graduates of the United States Military Academy.
"HALLELUJAH, BABY!" gives us one shred of certainty and six chances of hope.

An initial listing of 10 boats, some quite large, to carry spectators to the America's Cup races off Newport starting Sept. 12 has been compiled by the Rhode Island Development Council. The vessels range from the four-decked S.S. Bay Belle to a new steel yacht, Canyon Flyer.

WASHINGTON, May 6 The 165th anniversary of Washington's incorporation as the District of Columbia and the national capital was marked this week by preliminary steps to end the long controversy here over taxation without representation.

BRIARCLIFF MANOR, N.Y., May 6 Mr. and Mrs. Barney Strom have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jo Ann Strom, to Alan H. Raphael, son of Mr. and Mrs. Benjamin R. Raphael of Brooklyn. The wedding is planned for June 11.
CLOVIS, N.M., May 6 Capt. Dale E. Noyd Will be assigned as Cannon Air Force Base housing officer for officers and enlisted men, a base spokesman announced.

GO SLOWLY One or two bright and sunny days are enough to stir the laziest of gardeners outdoors. Sometimes there is so much enthusiasm, there is a rush to get every planting detail accomplished in one day. Not so fast.

Theodore W. Kheel, chief mediator in contract bargaining by 10 unions with four newspapers here, said last night the talks would go ahead without having the closing of The World Journal Tribune "materially affect" negotiations.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 6 The new Jordanian Premier, Sand Jumaah, told the Jordan Parliament today that the only way to mobilize Arabs "to check and encircle the Zionist threat and regain Arab rights in Palestine" was to resume top-level meetings of Arab chiefs of state.

ONE of the penalties for being President these days is having books like these written about you and then inflicted upon children. KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 6 Harry S. Truman, his brisk stride slowed by age, will spend his 83d birthday quietly Monday at his home in nearby Independence.

New England commercial banks adjusted to an expanding economy in the first half of the nineteen-sixties in four directions. These were mergers, branch banking, correspondent banking and computers. Toward better size and caliber of services, merger was one of the most important structural changes.
An important legal dispute involving workmen's compensation for seamen entering ports of Puerto Rico has been settled in favor of a group of shipping lines, admiralty lawyers reported here yesterday.
About 150 women students at Fordham University have petitioned the administration to add courses on birth control to the curriculum.

VALHALLA, N.Y., May 6 An 18-year-old boy told a youth conference here today that several of his friends were using drugs and was promptly challenged by policemen to reveal their names.

ZIHUATANEJO, Mexico The problem with many vacation spots is how to stay ahead of the crowds. Acapulco, which used to be a gem of tranquility here on the Pacific coast of Mexico, is now Miami Beach with mountains. But there are still a few places farther along the coast where one can enjoy the gifts of beauty and privacy.
ALBANY May 6 Information centers on apprenticeship opportunities have been established by the State Department of Labor in New York City and Buffalo.
CANNES, France, May 6 (UPI) "Ulysses" was officially withdrawn from the Cannes International Film Festival tonight.
An architect, using what he describes as a "shoehorn" technique, has been able to squeeze an unusually tall, spacious house onto the smallest-sized let allowed in Brooklyn's Manhattan Beach section.

WORCESTER, Mass., May 6 (AP) A committee of Roman Catholic theologians said today there appeared to be no "legitimate basis" for Catholic and Greek Orthodox Christians to receive the Eucharist in each other's churches.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 6 Five faculty members at the University of Notre Dame Law School took issue yesterday with the dean's attack on civil rights leaders for linking their movement with opposition to the Vietnam war.

NEWPORT, R.I., May 6--Beacon Hill House, once the residence of the late Arthur Curtiss James, railroad industrialist, and more recently owned by the Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence, was destroyed by fire today.

WASHINGTON, May 6 (AP) The National Labor Relations Board termed illegal today the refusal of A.F.L-C.I.O. unions in St. Louis to work with Negro plumbers from an independent union in construction of the memorial arch in that city.
NEWARK, May 6 An English spring will be the setting at the Bonnie Brae Farm for Boys in Millington, N.J., on May 16 and 17 for the 34th annual benefit card party and fashion show there.
Stockbroker A: "This market reminds me of 1961."
NEW HAVEN, May 6 Bob Porter scored three goals to lead Princeton to a 7-4 lacrosse victory over Yale today.

MAMARONECK, N.Y., May 6 Mr. and Mrs. Paul Henry Kirshon have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Katherine Kirshon, to James Stevens Davis, son of Mr. and Mrs. Charles Orr Davis of Kansas City, Mo.

TRENTON, May 6 Miss Virginia Anne Long, a Deputy Attorney General of New Jersey, was married this morning to Russell Wilford Annich Jr., son of the Rev. Dr. Annich, minister of the Bethany Presbyterian Church here, and Mrs. Annich.

LOS ANGELES, May 6 (AP) A crack foursome of University of California, Los Angeles, sprinters equaled the world record of 39.6 seconds in the 440-yard relay today as the Bruins, the 1966 national champions, defeated Southern California, 83-62, in a Pacific Eight Conference track and field meet.

WASHINGTON, May 6 Cyrus R. Vance, Deputy Secretary of Defense, sought tonight to calm what he called the "heated and intolerant" extremes of the national debate between the Government and its critics over the Vietnam war.
LONDON, May 6 (Reuters) Manchester United won the English Football League championship today by crushing West Ham United, 6-1.
PRESSMEN'S HOME, Tenn., May 6 The International Printing Pressmen and Assistants' Union will move its headquarters from Pressmen's Home in the hills of East Tennessee to Washington.
LOUISVILLE, May 6 Rain drenched the winner's-circle ceremony after the 93d Kentucky Derby today, but for Loyd (Boo) Gentry, it was pure sunshine.

Fresh purple and white lilacs will seem to grow in the Cooper Union building between Astor Place and Cooper Square when the "In Lilac Time" ball is held there May 22. The evening will raise funds for new acquisitions for the Cooper Union Museum of Decorative Arts.

PARIS, May 6 (Reuters) President de Gaulle's Government unexpectedly presented to the National Assembly today a controversial bill that provided for government by decree in large areas of the French economy.
HOUSTON, May 6 Arnold Palmer retained the lead in the $115,000 Houston Champions international golf tourney today as Billy Casper put on an unexpected charge.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 6 The 14th annual house and garden tour for the benefit of the Institute of Physical Medicine and Rehabilitation of the New York University Medical Center will be held May 18, from 11 A.M. to 6 P.M. here and in northern Westchester.

PEKING, May 6(Reuters) The Chinese Communist Government today ordered the expulsion of the correspondent of Pravda, the Soviet Communist party newspaper. He was the fourth Russian newsman ordered home since the beginning of China's Cultural Revolution last summer.

DETROIT, May 6 A campaign to oust Detroit's Mayor, Jerome P. Cavanagh, is under way. Backers of the recall movement say that growing crime is the major issue, but there is a strong racial overtone to the effort.

A citywide fact-finding study of the problems of New York City newspapers and ways "to encourage the birth and growth of other papers if at all possible" was suggested yesterday by City Council President Frank D. O'Connor.
WASHINGTON, May 6 The Department of the Interior proposed regulations today to govern the leasing of Western oil shale lands for research and development.

NHATRANG, South Vietnam Phan Gial Ky is the undisputed birds' nest king of South Vietnam, a distinction much appreciated by fanciers of Oriental food from Singapore to San Francisco and possibly even Shanghai.

BONN, May 6 An article purporting to shed new light on the identity of the novelist B. Traven, the mysterious author of "Treasure of the Sierra Madre," and other books, was published this week by West Germany's Stern magazine. The author of the article, Gerd Heidemann, said he had met and spoken with Mr. Traven and his wife at their home in Mexico City.

BOSTON Although most of the New England states lie a bit east of the principal routes to Montreal, more than $1-million is being spent this year to promote the area. The aim, of course, is to attract more vacationists on the way to or from Expo 67.

QUANTICO, Va., May 6 Fordham and Villanova, which staged a memorable battle in the two-mile relays last Saturday, did it again today. The outcome was the same with a slight variation. Fordham won as two anchor men, not one, fell at the finish from exhaustion.
The following editorial opposing Britain's entry into the Common Market appeared in a recent issue of the London Daily Express, a usually proConservative paper.

ROCHESTER, May 6 (AP) Elsie Karow, a retired telephone company worker from Bloomfield, N.J., rolled a 650 series tonight to claim third place in Division I singles at the Women's International Bowling Congress tournament.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 6 Mr. and Mrs. Robert Huyot have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Rita Huyot, to Eddward Baker Roesler, son of Edward Roesler Jr. of Glen Cove, L.I., and the late Mrs. Roesler. A July wedding is planned.

When Bertram A. Powers, president of the New York printers' union, was leading his first 114day strike against the city's seven daily newspapers in 1962-63, he made no secret of his conviction that the number of citywide dailies here would eventually shake down to three The Times and The Daily News in the morning and a single survivor in the afternoon.
Donations to the Greater New York Fund mean more because the fund is the world's largest network of communiity services, and helps nearly four million persons annual ly.

The Marines have still to name the 12-day operation that last week finally dislodged North Vietnamese troops from heavily bunkered and stoutly defended mountain-top positions commanding the isolated Khesanh Valley. But already the "Grunts" the Marine riflemen are calling it "our successful Dienbienphu," an allusion to the dramatic battle in which the Communist Vietminh defeated the French in 1954 and won final victory in the first Vietnam war.

AMHERST, Mass., May 6 Greg Landry, a junior quarterback from Nashua, N.H., led the University of Massachusetts "Red" team to a 19-0 victory over the "White" team today in the final spring practice game in Alumni Stadium.

TALLAHASSEE, Fla. Florida has no trees that compare with the great redwoods and sequoias of the Pacific Coast, but it does have 19 giant ones that have been listed in the "Social Register of Big Trees." The register is a compilation of the American Forestry Association in Washington.

BRYN MAWR, Pa., May 6 Mrs. Edwin M. Rhea has announced the engagement of her daughter, Miss Elizabeth Elliotte Rhea, to Duncan Whelen Van Dusen, son of Mr. and Mrs. Lewis H. Van Dusen Jr. of BalaCynwyd. A July wedding is planned.

McALLEN, Tex., May 6 Mr. and Mrs. Charles Francis Alexander Pagenstecher 3d have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Louise Anne Pagenstecher, to James William Simpson, son of Mr. and Mrs. Eugene Myers Simpson of Columbia, S.C. The wedding is planned for July 3.

ST. LOUIS, May 6--Mainland China and Thailand's own underground Communist party are what most Thais believe to be the greatest threat to their security, Kenneth T. Young, former United States Ambassador to Thailand, said here this week.

WE know almost nothing about man's origins. There are lots of theories, but few facts and the facts fit many theories.
AMHERST, Mass., May 6 The Amherst Rugby Club topped Wesleyan, 6-0, today in an Eastern Rugby Union match on muddy Hitchcock Field.
ANAHEIM, Calif., Map 6 (UPI) The Continental Football League set up a seventeam Western Division today and established a June 3 deadline for selection of coaches and players.

MARIETTA, Ohio, May 6 (AP) Marietta, the small-col- lege national rowing champion, took all four divisions of the third annual Mid-America re- gatta today on the rain-swollen Ohio River.

PORTOLA VALLEY, Calif., May 6 (UPI) Tony Roche and John Newcombe, the two topseeded players set up an allAustralian final in the California state tennis tournament today. Each won in straight sets.

The Argentine delegate to the world's ruling body of soccer, who also is the secretary of a team he would like to see play here, intimated yesterday he would recommend sanction for the "outlaw" National Professional Soccer League.

ATHENS, May 8--Interior Minister Stylianos Patakos announced today that constitutional amendments would be drafted and submitted to the people in a referendum. He declined to predict when this would happen.

ROCKVILLE CENTRE, L.I., May 8--Jim Wright, a 28-yearold professional from the Inwood Country Club, posted a 34, 36--70 to take a one-stroke lead at the start of the 54-hole open championship sponsored by the Long Island Golf Association at the Rockville links today.

PASADENA, Calif, May (UPI)--The Lunar Orbiter 4 circled the moon today in a high, looping, polar orbit that will enable the twin-lensed camera on the American spacecraft to photograph about 97 per cent of the lunar surface.

CANNES, France, May 8-- "Blow-Up," a British film made by one of Italy's foremost directors, Michelangelo Antonioni, became one of the leading contenders for the Grand Prix following the first of its two showings at the Cannes festival today.
WBAI, a listener-supported FM radio station, reached its goal yesterday morning of $100,000 in its third annual fund-raising marathon.

The Cunard announcement of the impending withdrawal from service of the Queen Elizabeth and Queen Mary--the world's largest and second largest pas- senger liners--came as a sharp surprise to local shipping circles.
HONG KONG, May 8--Li Ching-chuan, 59-year-old leader of Southwest China, increasingly appears to be the biggest center of opposition to the Maoist Cultural Revolution in that part of the nation.
WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) --The Supreme Court gave a seaman today the right to try to prove that a vessel being docked could be made unsea- worthy when its officers as- signed too few crewmen.

Bobby Ussery, fresh from his unexepected victory aboard the 30-to-1 Proud Clarion in the Kentucky Derby last Saturday, was applauded vigorously yesterday as he paraded to the post for the first race at Aqueduct.

WASHINGTON, May 8.--The sure way to arouse an American about great political issues is to let them be intruded into his sport. And so, when the Louisville open-housing agitators threatened to take their case to the Kentucky Derby on Saturday, the authorities sent the National Guard to the race track.
Oil discoveries in Alaska are spurring Indians and Eskimos there into spirited political activity to assert land claims, Senator E.L. Bartlett, Democrat of Alaska, said here last night.

WASHINGTON, May 8-- Robert M. Gardiner, chairman of the board of government of the National Association of Securities Dealers, was named today as head of a nine-man committee that will conduct the search for a new head of the Association.
WAR is a human activity. Wars are waged by men," a Polish general tells an American war correspondent in this novel of the Nazi onslaught on Poland at the beginning of World War II.

ALTHOUGH the halo is not too readily discernable, Paul Hornung is on his way to becoming a Saint. The one-time Golden Boy of the Green Bay Packers was once such a terror on the gridiron that he gained recognition as the most valuable player in his league. But he also was such a mischief-maker off it that he gained the dubious distinction of being hailed as the Playboy of the Western World.

Welfare Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg had what he called a "clarifying and sym pathetic discussion yesterday with representatives of a nonprofit welfare agency whose employes want to be unionized.

The establishment of an annual professional tennis tournament at Madison Square Garden and plans for pro tournaments "in other major arenas of the United States, Canada and Mexico" were announced yesterday

TEHERAN, Iran, May 8(AP) --Athletes competing in the 1968 Olympic Games and in future Olympics will have to sign a pledge that they will not use drugs to improve their performances, and must agree to submit to medical examinations, the International Olympic Committee ruled today.

The chancellor of the City University charged yesterday that Mayor Lindsay's administration, in violation of its promise, had cut the university's expense-budget request without consulting him and other officials of the institution.

Silver futures added to their speculative luster yesterday, showing substantial gains for the distant deliveries and a record volume of 442 contracts.

LONDON, May 8--Sir Francis Chichester, the doughty--65 year-old Briton, who is nearing the end of his single-handed sailing voyage around the world, will ,be knighted by Queen Elizabeth II at Greenwich next month.
Two Negro welders filed suit yesterday in Federal Court charging that Pan American
WEST POINT, N.Y., May 8-- The New York Mets went calling on their cousins today and went home with something that has been so far unavailable in their own backyard--a third straight shutout victory.
PEKING, May 8 (Agence France--Presse)--President Liu Shao-chi was accused today of deviation from Marxism-Leninism and betrayal of the "dictatorship of the proletariat."
ATHENS (AP)--The seeds of a plane tree, reported to be 2,500 years old, are helping to build a medical center on the picturesque Greek island of Kos.
A surge of rain and melting snow has transformed brooks and streams from feeble trick- les to robust gushes throughout the state.
A four-point plan to improve the ethnic balance at Andrew Jackson High School in Queens was submitted to the State Education Commissioner yesterday by Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan.

NORTH CREEK, N.Y., May 8 (AP)--Robert Heinzerling and John Osborne of New York, won the two-man, covered-canoe event yesterday in the 10th annual White Water Derby, defeating third-place team of Senator Robert F. Kennedy and Bill Bickham, a seasoned rapids-runner from State College, Pa.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 8-- Michael Burke, the president of the New York Yankees, and Lee MacPhail, his chief executive, were here with the club today as the Yankees prepared for a three-game series with the California Angels.
Three persons arrested last July have been sentenced to two years' imprisonment by a Soviet court in Riga, according to private notes on the trial made available here.

LOS ANGELES, May 8--Doris Day has signed "a multiplefilm agreement" with the Columbia Broadcasting System's new theatrical film division, it was announced today by Gordon Stulberg, president of the subsidiary.
Two Fairleigh Dickinson home runs in a three-run 11th inning sent New York University to an 8-5 defeat yesterday in a Metropolitan Conference game at Ohio Field in the Bronx.
MONTREAL, May 8--Expo 67's attendance has soared be yond the 3-million mark. Officials of the fair forseen possibly more than 50 million admissions for the six months of the fair.

GENEVA, May 8--Kennedy round negotiations for the Unit ed States and the European Common Market went into an all-night marathon session tonight in a final dramatic effort to get agreement on lower world trade barriers.
STOCKHOLM, May 8--A North Vietnamese colonel said tonight that his Government maintained "an attitude of goodwill" toward the question of finding a settlement of the in Vietnam.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 8--American Marines beat back an assault by more than a thousand North Vietnamese troops today in savage fighting two miles south of the demil- tarized zone, a United States spokesman said.

Emphasizing its drive to diversity, the Signal Oil and Gas Company yesterday entered its second merger transaction within a few days, this time with the Arizona Bancorporation. The Phoenix-based holding company would be acquired for stock exceeding $17-million in value.

DETROIT (UPI)--There probably is not a motorist who does not gripe about gasoline prices. But leaving price out of it would you believe your car is getting about 40 per cent more mileage to the gallon than it would have 30 to 40 years ago?
NEWBURYPORT, Mass., May 8 (UPI)--A young Roman Catholic priest stunned his pa rishioners yesterday by an nouncing from the pulpit that he was leaving the priesthood.
RIVERHEAD, L.I., May 8-- The Suffolk Board of Supervisors acted today to eliminate long delays in removing dead bodies from the scenes of accidents.
ALBANY, May--Carl Spad announced today that he was as Republican state chairman to work in the Romney-for-President campaign.
WASHINGTON, May 8-- Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois recounted to the Senate recently the remarkable story of two men from his state who ran for the Presidency in the same year.

The United Aircraft Corporation had the highest quarterly shipments and commercial deliveries in its history in the three months ended March 31. Earnings for the first quarter were the third largest for the period, according to the financial results announced yesterday.

BOMBAY, India--The disreputable-looking broker leaned forward and shouted to make himself heard over the din of trading on the exchange floor. "Without money you can buy," he said with an ill--concealed leer. "Without stocks you can sell."
The African Medical and Research Foundation plans a Safari Ball with jungle decorat, Tavern-on-the-Green next Tuesday. Proceeds will go specifically to its flying doctor service in East Africa.

CRANBURY N.J.--Rows of Chinese cabbage ran straight as a quivering arrow into the wooded distance. Nearby, tender sprouts of Chinese spinach pushed through the rich soil towards the glass frames that protected them from the still uncertain weather. And a geometric-progression of greenhouses, with a snug in ternal temperature of 80 degrees, nursed tiny plants that would one day bring forth giant winter melons.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The Supreme Court declined today to consider a charge that New York City violated the Federal Constitution when it paid only 4 per cent interest on a debt incurred in the take-over of the Fifth Avenue Coach Lines.
A rally continued in the stock market yesterday for the fourth consecutive session, although gains did not quite match those of the three preceding sessions.

WASHINGTON, May 8--The Supreme Court ruled today that mail order houses could be required to collect state or local "use" taxes on interstate transactions conducted entirely by mail or common carrier.

DETROIT, May 8--An expen- sive tire promoted as an extra- safe product failed to pass in- dustry safety tests, it was learned today. The manufac- turer, however, challenges the validity of the tests and insists that the tire is safe.

Barbra Streisand, the 24year-old stage, television and recording star, has been signed for the film version of the longrunning. Broadway musical "Hello Dolly!" She will play the the role created by Carol Chan ning.
WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., WELLESLEY HILLS, Mass., May 8--Miss Anne Elizabeth Godfrey and John Knox Marshall plan to marry next month.
Zubin Mehta and the Los Angeles Philharmonic, on their first Eastern tour, returned to Carnegie Hall Sunday night, and once again Van Cliburn joined them as guest soloist.
PITTSBURGH (UPI)--Joe Stanley is looking for the "Good Samaritan" who offered to push his stalled automobile one night.

PARIS, May 8 (Reuters)-- A special two-day meeting of the organizations that make easy-term loans to developing countries opened here today with Britain, France and West Germany opposing a major United States proposal.

BOSTON, May 8--The interfaith National Conference on the Role of Conscience wound up today with an appeal to religious leaders to confront today's "competent barbarian" with a renewed sense of "ethi cal wisdom."
The Mechanical Contractors Association of New York has elected Harold K. Raisler president.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 8--Premier Nguyen Cao Ky has opened negotiations toward a reconciliation with a general he banished from South Vietnam last year following the Buddhist crisis.

WASHINGTON, May 6--The Supreme Court agreed today to decide whether pretrial depositions in the civil litigation over the failure of the Continental Vending Machine Corporation must wait until related criminal charges are tried.

STAMFORD, Conn., May 8-- Alfred E. Lyon, former chairman of the board and president of Philip Morris, Inc., died last night in Stamford Hospital. He was 81 years old and lived on Cameron Drive in Greenwich.

MONTREAL, May 8 (AP)-- The number of passengers killed during flights made on the scheduled air services of the world rose from 684 in 1965 to 908 in 1966, the International Civil Aviation Organization said in a statement yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 8--An investigation of the Defense Department's purchasing poli cies, aimed at determining whether they have an adverse effect on competition, is planned by the Senate Antitrust Subcommittee.

New York University honored its women athletes last night at the annual women's athletic awards dinner on the University Heights campus in the Bronx.

ROME, May 8 (AP)--Latin may be dropped from the heart of the Roman Catholic mass beginning June 29 under worship changes approved by Pope Paul IV and announced at the Vatican today. The changes are subject to the approval of each country's bishops.

WASHINGTON, May 8 (AP) --The Office of Education awarded $22-million in grants today to help underdeveloped colleges. More than half the money goes to schools in 10 Southern states.

PARIS, May.,--The FrenchBritish project for the joint prpduction of a swing-wing com bat jet plane moved one step closer to implementation today when the defense ministers of the two countries reached agreement on proposals to be submitted to their governments.

KANSAS CITY, Mo., May 8 (AP)--The ornate, cane-backed chair where Harry S. Truman should have been sitting was empty, but the 225 friends who gathered in his honor, sang "Happy Birthday" anyway. The former President, 83 years old today, no longer feels able to withstand the ordeal of handshaking.
SEOUL, South Korea, May 6 --Communist North Korea is pictured by sources in Seoul as burdened by a huge military establishment and suffering from economic insecurity.

WASHINGTON, May 9--One of the more optimistic pieces of recent economic news--the Government's figures on retail sales in March--all but evaporated today in a revision of the statistics.

PARIS, May 9--A United States proposal to put restrictions on additional contributions to the International Development Association, the "softloan" agency of the World Bank, met a generally critical reception here at a two-day meeting of member countries. At the same time, the other members remained reluctant to increase their contributions as much as the United states is offering to do.

ANAHEIM, Calif., May 9-- While Mickey Mantle continued to be frustrated in his quest for home run No. 500, he nevertheless made a contribution tonight to the latest weapon the New York Yankes are perfecting-- the mini-rally.

NEW DELHI, May 9--One day in 1920, Mohandas K. Gandhi went to Aligarh University, a renowned Moslem institution, to appeal to the students to back his noncooperation campaign against British rule by withdrawing from the state-supported school. A young law student had to miss the speech because of a rendezvous with a physician. When he returned to the campus he was told

DENVER, May 9 (UPI)--A three-judge Federal appeals court took under advisement today a plea by a veteran Air Force captain that he not be commanded to contribute to what he calls the "immoral and unjust war in Vietnam."

FRANKFURT, Germany, May 9 (AP)--Bache Co., Inc., of New York announced today the opening of a German bank subsidiary, making Bache the first United States brokerage company with direct access to a European stock exchange. The new subsidiary, Bankhaus Bathe Co., G.m.b.H., a member of the Frankfurt exchange, will start business Thursday.
The following quotations are selling prices in United States dollars and cents for banknotes at New York. These rates do not apply to regular exchange business transacted by banks.

THE superlative mastery, strength and heroic power that the statues and paintings of Michelangelo reveal have fascinated audiences from his own day to this. Almost as fascinating have been the personality and psychology of the maker.
After a 12-year search, American scheduled airlines believe that a system can be devised to prevent mid-air collisions, the Air Transport World reports.
Art Heyman, who said he had matured enough to return to major-league basketball, signed yesterday with the New York Freighters of the newly formed American Basketball Association.
MIAMI, May 9--Rodney Arismendi, the leader of the Communist party of Uruguay has announced that he will try to restore Communist unity in Latin America.
IF YOU BELIEVE one informal barometer of stock market activity, speculation may be getting a bit out of hand.
STOCKHOLM, May 9--The so-called International War Crimes Tribunal sponsored by Bertrand Russell met in closed session today.

Mr. Beaubouef said that some days later he and his lawyer went to the district attorney of Jefferson Parish, the county next to Orleans Parish, and played the tape recording for Frank Langridge, the district attorney there.
RYE, N.Y., May 9--The owners of homes and estates in this upper-income suburban city have a new neighbor--the international headquarters of the Dictaphone Corporation-- and nobody seems to object.
WASHINGTON, May 9-- President Johnson assured the Vice President of Nationalist China today that the United States remembered its commitment to defend it.

The shadow of Cassius Clay's heavyweight championship lurks in every corner of the boxing world. In New York yesterday, a boxing commissioner, a contender and a colonel tried to take quick walks in the sun.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 9 (UPI)--Avery Brundage, the president of the International Olympic Committee, announced today new I.O.C. rules, designed to keep "dishonest amateurs" out of the Olympic Games.
The midtown towaway zone for illegally parked cars will be extended Monday to include all of Manhattan between 23d Street and 72d Street, Mayor Lindsay announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) --Senate leaders announced today that the resolution to censure senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut, for financial misconduct would be taken up May 22.

FORT DIX, N.J., May 9-- A 2-month-old son of an airman stationed at McGuire Air Force Base died of a blood disease after being discharged from Walson Army Hospital here, an Army spokesman announced today.

Mayor Lindsay's task force on the Constitutional Convention has fudged its proposals for giving New York City home rule. Its recommendations would strengthen the city's powers, but still leave it under onerous restrictions.

WINNETKA, Ill., May 9-- Mr. and Mrs. John J. Jachym have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jacqueline Jachym, to Barry C. Fitzpatrick, son of Mr. and Mrs. Clyde J. Fitzpatrick of Wilmette, III.

Marshall McLuhan, the author of "Understanding Media" and "The Medium Is the Massage," recorded yesterday an LP album based on the latter book at the Columbia Record studio here at 49 East 52d Street.
The floundering and confusion in antipoverty skirmishes here have come to the surface this week in speeches and at hearings before a Senate subcommittee.

The Procter Gamble Company, the large soap producer, announced yesterday in Cincinnati the election of John G. Smale as vice president of the toilet goods division. He was formerly manager of the division.

The annual convention of the Episcopal Diocese of New York called yesterday for the inclusion of the National Liberation Front in negotiations to end the war in Vietnam, but shied away from demanding that the negotiations be "immediate and unconditional."
NEW DELHI, May 9-- George D. Woods, the president of the World Bank, said today it was almost certain that India would not have to pay a major part of her foreign debt due this year.

The very personal world of the art song has had many champions over the last century. the is Carolyn Reyer, a mezzospprano, who believes in commissioning and performing new local works. Last night she took Carnegie Recital Hall's stage to give the world premieres of songs and cycles by three American composers and to give the second local perform ance of David Diamond's Shakespeare sonnet cycle, "We two."
Roscoe Henderson Hupper, long a leading admiralty lawyer here, died yesterday in Roosevelt Hospital. He was 84 years old and lived at 36 East 72d Street and at Tenants Harbor, Me.

NEW ORLEANS, May 9-- District Attorney Jim Garrison has begun an investigation of the Federal Bureau of Investigation and the Central Intelligence Agency, charging that both agencies are trying to withhold evidence about the assassination of President Kennedy.

A Texas oil millionaire has been told by the Art Dealers Association of America that 44 paintings, water-colors and drawings he bought for $1-million as works by Modigliani, Picasso, Dufy, D gas, Chagall, Bonnard, Derain and other prominent painters are for geries.

Eli B. Enzer, a reporter on The Boston Globe, has been awarded the Seymour Berkson Foreign-Assignment Grant of $1,000, which carries with it a six-month assignment as a foreign correspondent for United Press International.
The Israeli composer Nachum Nardi was honored at a concert in Carnegie Hall last night by a large troupe of performers and a warm audience of about 1,000 persons.

The Wiltwyck School for Boys will be the beneficiary of a variety show the evening of May 21 in Carnegie Hall. Joel Grey will be master of ceremonies, and among the entertainers will be Diahann Carroll, Melina Mercouri, Florence Henderson, Orson Bean, Paul Draper aad Bud and Cece Robinson.
"A Night at the St. Regis," a benefit for the Long Island League of the Brooklyn Home and Hospital for the Aged, will be held on Saturday at the St. Regis-Sheraton Roof.

WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP) --After more than six years of fighting in Vietnam, the Pentagon has issued its first state-bystate tabulation of combat deaths. California accounts for the largest number, followed by New York, Pennsylvania, Texas and Ohio.

BUFFALO, May 9--Thirtyseven men were arrested in a raid on a suspected little Apalachin meeting of Mafia figures last night, but a city court judge dismissed the charges against them this morning after it turned out the gathering was merely a bachelor dinner.
The Morgan Guaranty Trust Company announced here yesterday the election of Ellmore C. Patterson as chairman of the executive committee and Walter H. Page as a director.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 9 (Reuters) --The armed forces and the police here were alerted today to combat a wave of terrorism that, President Joaquin Balaguer charged, is part of a Communist plot to topple his 10month-old Government.
Welfare Commissioner Mitchell I. Ginsberg called yesterday for a complete revision of the nation's welfare system, which he told a Senate subcommittee was "bankrupt" as a social institution.
"The Immediate reform of archaic laws" concerning abortion was urged yesterday by the Medical Committee for Human Rights.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The Administration told a House subcommittee today that immediate postal rate increases were necessary to begin modernizing the postal system and preparing it for the mail burdens of the future.

New Brunswick elected its first woman Mayor and City Commissioner yesterday in an upset victory over a five-man slate backed by incumbent Mayor Chester Paulus as 27 New Jersey municipalities held elections yesterday.
DANANG, South Vietnam, May 9--Philippa Duke Schuyler, American pianist, was killed today in the crash of a United States Army helicopter in Danang Bay. A Vietnamese child also was killed.
CHATTANOOGA, Tenn., May 9--Lawyers for James R. Hoffa unexpectedly refused today to proceed with a scheduled District Court hearing on their motion for a new trial.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 9 (AP)--Trustees of Allen University today appointed a fiveman "redress" committee to meet with administration, faculty and student leaders of a class boycott to try to resolve differences.
Policemen will no longer act as prosecutors in Women's Court after May 15. This, in effect, means the end of the court that has been handling prostitution cases since 1910.

A 20-year-old man suspected of having held up a Columbus Circle drugstore and shot its cashier was captured by a policeman last night after a chase in which two taxicab drivers braved bullets and oncoming one-way traffic.
ST. LOUIS, May 9 (UPI)-- A Federal poverty worker said today he had been dismissed from his job in a training program here because he did not ask applicants about their sex lives.
WINCHESTER, England, May 9 (Reuters)--A school principal who stripped his students and beat them until bled was sent to jail for five years here today.
ROME, May 9--Pope Paul VI welcomed Catholicos Khoren I, the Armenian Orthodox spiritual leader, to the Vatican today and then prayed with his visitor in the Sistine Chapel.

Sugar traders had a busy day yesterday but volume in the No. 8 world contract fell slightly below the record levels of Monday. Some 5,044 contracts changed hands, compared with an all-time high of 5,810 the day before.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 9--Although Premier Nguyen Cao Ky has confided his plans to few countrymen and fewer foreigners, well-informed diplomats and politicians are convinced that he has decided to run for President.
A Queens grand jury heard an unidentified witness yesterday in the mysterious deaths of the two young children of Edmund and Alice Crimmins.
EAST MEADOW, L.I., May 9--The Long Island Athletic Club handed the Australian National lacrosse team its seventh straight loss in the United States tonight, 18-4, at Salisbury Park.
ATHENS, May 9--A leading member of the junta that rules Greece said today that he did not expect that Andreas Papandreou would be sentenced to death even if he was convicted of high treason.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 9 --Radcliffe College has been awarded a $2.5-million grant from the Ford Foundation con tingent on its raistag $5-million more in the next three years;
A modification of zoning regulations to permit New York University to construct a 12story library on the south side of Washington Square Park was approved yesterday.
Meshulam Riklis, a securities analyst who made good, told securities analysts yesterday how he built a $1-billion business complex in 15 years.

ROSLYN HARBOR, L.I., May 9--Edward C. Milau, president of Milau Associates, Inc., a construction company, died in Manhasset Hospital today. He was 53 years old and lived at 1 Engineers Road, Roslyn Harbor.
NEW DELHI, May 9--Dr. Zakir Husain, a Moslem educator, was elected President of India today by a wide margin.

WASHINGTON, May 9--Secretary of Labor W. Willard Wirtz and members of the Congressional Joint Committee on Atomic Energy differed sharply today on what can be done to protect uranium miners against the danger of lung cancer.
Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson will join retired members of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union this afternoon at 2 at a concert by the American Symphony Orchestra in Carnegie Hall.

Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York, the defending cochampion, led the 11-women field after completion of the seventh round of the 1967 United states women's Chess Championship this afternoon at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

SAN JUAN, P.R., May 9-- The University of Puerto Rico has suspended 42 students-- including the leaders of proindependence and pro-statehood organizations--as a result of a violent clash last Thursday that caused the cancellation of an R.O.T.C. parade.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The Administration's family planning assistance was criticized today by two former Government officials as being grossly inadequate to meet the population problems confronting developing nations.
How word came to the men of the giant liner Queen Elizabeth that their ship had been given "a death sentence" was a study in quiet dramatics.

CHICAGO, May 9 (UPI)-- Sam Battaglia, reputed leader of the Chicago crime syndicate, was found guilty today of extorting $48,500 from a construction company. He was locked up immediately as "dangerous to the community."
ATLANTIC CITY, May 9-- Hosiery shipments will set new highs in the remainder of 1967, Reuben C. Ball of Charlotte, N.C., predicted today.
Stock prices turned sharply downward yesterday, ending a four-day succession of strongto-moderate gains.
Essex County in New Jersey, Piping Rock in Long Island and Round Hill in Westchester took over division leads in the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches yesterday.

TRENTION, May 9--Gov. Richard J. Hughes declared this afternoon that "the two-year session just ended has unquestionably been a period of the greatest legislative achievement in New Jersey's history." In a statement issued from his office here, the Governor added:

No facet of Dr. Zakir Husain's victory in the Indian Presidential election is more important than the demonstration that India is what Jawaharlal Nehru and other progressive Indians claimed it to be--a secular, not a Hindu, state. There are other notable features of the election, not the least being the personal triumph of Nehru's daughter, Prime Minister Indira Gandhi, who insisted on the candidacy of Dr. Husain, the Moslem Vice President.

OSSINING, N.Y., May 9--The iron gates of Sing Sing Prison swung open today and then clanked shut, and three members of the New York Mets were locked inside, safe at least from violent assault by the more brutish members of the National League.

Film as Art has become the most popular of the 37 subject divisions of the American Film Festival that starts today at the Biltmore. Two and a halt hours will be devoted to such films tonight at 8 P.M. at the hotel, where the ninth annual festival begins its four-day sessions this morning.
Deputy Police Commissioner Franklin A. Thomas resigned yesterday to become executive director of the controversial Community Development Corporation of Brooklyn's BedfordStuyvesant district.
WASHINGTON, May 9--The Senate Foreign Relations Committee approved today the nomination of R. Peter Straus of New York to be assistant administrator of the Agency for International Development.
HONG KONG, May 9--The Communist party leader of Southwest China, who has been one of Mao Tse-tong's most dogged opponents, was reported today to have been toppled from power.
Charles J. Prange, director of personnel development of REA Express, 219 East 42d Street, died Monday in Brocton, Mass., at the age of 54.

George Abbott, who will reach his 80th birthday June 25, will bring "The Education of H*Y*M*A*N K*A*P*L*A*N" face to face with the critics Dec. 27 at the theater bearing his name at 152 West 54th Street. The $500,000 musical will be the director's first show there since the 54th Street Theater was renamed in his honor early last year.
Shareholders of four upstate New York banks approved yesterday the formation of a $1.15billion bank holding company to be named the Lincoln First Group, Inc.

Thomas F. McEntee, president of Adams McEntee Co., Inc., municipal bond dealers of 40 Wall Street, died Monday night in Mercy Hospital, Rockville Centre, L.I., after a long illness. He was 68 years old and lived at 39 Nassau Boulevard, Garden City, L.I., and Point o' Woods, Fire Island, N.Y.

The gloss pervading the bond market seemed to spread yesterday. Many bond men grew increasingly concerned about the heavy schedules of new offerings and they tended to play down the importance of some usually encouraging news.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Wednesday, May 10--Fierce fighting broke out again yesterday in the northwest corner of South Vietnam, near Khesanh. United States Marine units reported having killed 31 North Vietnamese soldiers in a fivehour battle.

HONG KONG, Wednesday, May 10 (AP)--United States planes did not strafe the British-flag freighter Dartford two weeks ago in the harbor at Haiphong, North Vietnam, as the North Vietnamese charged, according to a British second mate who said he witnessed the incident.
WASHINGTON, May 9 (AP)--President Johnson today proclaimed May 22, the anniversary of the first transAtlantic voyage by a steamship, as National Maritime Day.
About 1,000 policemen and policewomen will be added in the next few weeks to patrols in parks, beaches and other recreation areas, First Deputy Commissioner John F. Walsh said yesterday.
MONTREAL, May 9, (AP)-- A search for "anti-aggression pills" could well be the main goal of psychiatrists and biochemists by 1980 to 1990, a prominent, psychiatrist said today.
WASHINGTON, May 9-- George Meany said today he had found no evidence that the troubled painters' union should be cited for being under corrupt influences.

ROME, May 9 (UPI)-- Jaime Pinto Bravo of Chile rallied from the brink of defeat today to upset fourthseeded Cliff Drysdale of South Africa in the second round of the Italian tennis championships, 3-6, 4-6, 6-2, 6-3, 6-1.
Alfred A. Giardino, the new president of the Board of Edudation, called yesterday for a massive effort to improve the basic skills of pupils in the early grades.
WINNETKA, Ill., May 9 (AP) --Andrew M. Baird, a former governor of the New York Stock Exchange and a retired investment banker, died today in his sleep at his home. He was 70 years old.
ALBANY, May 9--The banks that will be selling state lottery tickets told, the state today that they should be paid handling costs of as much as 10 cents for each of the $1 tickets they sell.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 9-- Some fans may wonder why the richest event in harness racing history--the Messenger Stakes for a gross purse of $178,064,79 --needed a publicity gimmick, but news of the draw for post positions for the one-mile classic for 3-year-old pacers Saturday night at Roosevelt Raceway was delivered this morning by eight homing pigeons.

The Thomas A. Dooley Foundation will benefit for the second year from the "Feria de Sevilla," a costume party patterned after the colorful fair held in the streets of Seville the week after Easter. The party is scheduled for May 25 at the Tavern on the Green.

Cynthia Ashe, 1 years old, wore a pretty pink dress and a look of utter bewilderment yesterday as her mother received the keys to a glistening new apartment on East 100th Street between First and Secand Avenues. The apartment is in what was once called the "worst block" in the city.
For $2, the man in the family can take his mother-in-law, wife and children to the New York Generals-Los Angeles Toros soccer game at Yankee Stadium tonight.
Mayor Lindsay's task force on the Constitutional Convention proposed yesterday that New York City be granted greatly broadened home rule powers in the fiscal and general legislative fields.
It was Kern County Land Company day on the New York Stock Exchange yesterday.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 98.6 on Monday from 98.4 on Friday.

CANNES, France, May 9--A dark horse, the Yugoslav film, "I Have Even Met Happy Gypsies," appears to have joined "Blow-Up," the Swedish entry, "Elvira Madigan" and "Accident," as a jury favorite at the Cannes festival.
Children who attend the Eisman Day Nursery at 304 West 88th Street obtained an industrial status symbol yesterday--a brightly decorated backyard playground that is partly carpeted.

DAMASCUS, Syria, May 9-- The Syrian Government announced today that it had seized 45 commercial companies and confiscated the property of an arrested religious leader in a new move to punish agitators opposed to the regime.

A Criminal Court judge found a topless cellist guilty yesterday of indecent exposure and, in a lengthy opinion, criticized long-haired beatniks, mod outfits and fashion designers who "make women look like they are not women."

Mrs. Lethbridge Rynd of 444 East 75th Street and Madrid and Capt. Robert Wheeler Rynd, U.S.N., of Honolulu, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Heather Carson Rynd, to Carlos Garcia Montoya Jr. of the Army. He is the son of Mr. Montoya, the guitarist, and Mrs. Montoya of New York and Madrid.

JERUSALEM (Israel) May 9 --Border terrorists infiltrated five miles into Israel last night and set off an explosive charge as a military vehicle was passing the main highway north of the Sea of Galilee, an Israeli official said today.

Countering the usual Broadway formula, Elmer Rice won success by being serious, by using the stage as a forum to expound the human condition. His enduring plays--"The Adding Machine," "Street Scene," 'Counsellor-at-Law"--all dealt with some aspect of man's struggle to adjust himself to larger social forces. What inspirited those plays was Mr. Rice's uncompromising passion for human dignity.

New York City could become "uninhabitable within a decade" unless its efforts to control air pollution are stepped up sharply, the chairman of the Mayor's Task Force on Air Pollution said in a special report yesterday.
AUSTIN, Tex., May 9 (AP) --The Citizens National Bank of Austin announced yesterday that Patrick J. Nugent, sonin-law of President Johnson, had been elected to its board of directors.
The Board of Education adopted plans yesterday for its most ambitious summer program, involving a series of Fed erally financed projects for the disadvantaged at a cost of $10.5-million.

Prof. Arthur L. Corbin, an authority on the law of contracts and a member of the Yale University Law School faculty from 1903 until his retirement 40 years later, died last Thursday at his home, 21 Robinwood Lane, Hamden, Conn. He was 92 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 9-- President Johnson told a partisan crowd here this evening that the Democratic party's success in next year's election depended upon its ability "to persevere when the going is tough."

THE suprise is that no one had ever done it before I refer to an indigenously American, wholly professional production of the full-length "Swan Lake." But no one had, until American Ballet Theater, and it was this company that gave its new production its New York premiere last night at the start of its annual month's season at the New York State Theater.
WASHINGTON, May 9--A Japanese "cartel" has used unfair methods of competition to takeover much of the United States market for ceramic tile, the Tariff Commission was told today.
MIAMI, May 10--Betty Mae Jumper, a 44-year-old working mother, today became the first woman elected as chairman of the tribal council of the Seminole Indians of Florida.

Special to The New York Times NEWARK, May 9--Charles Tenenbaum, a founder in 1905 of the C. Tenenbaum Furniture Company, which operates a retail furniture store at 128 Ferry Street here, died today at his home, 117 Parkview Terrace. He was 83 years old.
ATHENS, May 9--As of tomorrow, Allen Ginsberg, Ho Chi Minh and Santa Claus would face a hurdle if they tried to come to Greece as tourists: They would have to cut off their beards at the border.
Mrs. Carol Rudin Sills, wife of Leonard H. Sills, a real estate man, died yesterday in her home at 1085 Park Aveune. Her age was 59.
CHICAGO, May 9--A May 26 wedding is planned by Mrs. Polly Priest Palmer and Edward A. Hurd Jr.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 9 (UPI)--Amsterdam's anarchist youths, who call themselves "Provos," (provokers), brought about the downfall of the city's mayor today.
At Carnegie Hall tonight: Ronald Turini, pianist, 8:30 P.M.; Carnegie Recital Hall: Aspasia Brussaly, soprano, 8:30.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The public utility commissioners of three states, who have been sitting wih the Federal Communications Commission in an advisory capacity in the American Telephone and Telegraph Company rate case, split 2-1 today on the rate of return the company ought to be permitted.
The American Geographical Society yesterday announced the appointment of Dr. Shannon McCune as director.

LISBON, May 9--A letter signed by 545 Portuguese Catholics protesting the closing last month of a Roman Catholic cultural association in Lisbon was delivered to Manuel Cardinal Concalves Cerejeira and all the Portuguese bishops today.

Another triumph for Harvard oars is portended in the ratings of the crews that will race Saturday in the sprint regatta of the Eastern Association of Rowing Colleges for heavyweight and 150-pound eights on Lake Quinsigamond at Worcester, Mass.

ONE of the byways of bridge that perhaps gets less attention than it deserves is the double-dummy problem. Few experts are prepared to devote the hours needed to solve puzzles, or still less the days needed to compose them, but there is no doubt that a player can increase his powers of card analysis by giving some attention to this specialized area of the game.

SOUTH ORANGE, N.J., May 9--Mrs. Grace Krudop Laufer, who established one of the first formal teen-age volunteer hospital programs in the country, died yesterday at New York Hospital after an illness of eight weeks. She was the wife of Edward B. Laufer, oil analyst for Lehman Brothers, New York.

SYDNEY, Australia, May 9 --The crew of the 12-Meter Yacht Gretel, disappointed at the syndicate's decision not to send her to the United States for further America's Cup trials against Dame Pattie, launched today a $168,000 appeal to take her there themselves.
BENEATH the slapstick of "Herald" and "Sondra," the two one-act plays that opened at the Provincetown Playhouse last night, one sees the serious and familiar theme: Man as Beast.

ACCRA, Ghana, May 9 (UPI)--Two junior officers waved at a jeering crowd today. Then were shot by a firing squad for having led the unsuccessful coup attempt of April 7 against Ghana's military government.
Out in Bloomfield Hills, Mich., yesterday afternoon the troops of MacManus, John Adams marched off to a local school auditorium to hear the news about the changes in the high, high command.
Edward P. Morgan, the radiotelevision commentator and political analyst, has been engaged as senior correspondent of the new Public Broadcast Laboratory of National Educational Television.

A 17-year-old high school senior from Kansas City, Mo., has won first prize in a national film-reviewing contest jointly sponsored by the Motion Picture Association of America and Scholastic Roto, a monthly publication for high schools.
GENEVA, May 9--The world's major trading nations today gave themselves until Sunday night to reach agreement in the Kennedy Round negotiations to lower world trade barriers.

While conceding that they had been demanding a lumpsum executive budget for several years, a number of civic organizations urged Mayor Lindsay yesterday to be more specific about how he intended to spend the lumps.

Dr. I.H. Goldberger, director emeritus of health education for the Board of Education and a specialist in children's diseases, died yesterday of a heart attack at his home, 2420 Sedgewick Avenue, the Bronx. His age was 78.

Mr. and Mrs. Angus C. Littlejohn of New York and S o Paulo, Brazil, have announced the engagement of Mrs. Littlejohn's daughter, Miss Elizabeth de Guevara Riggs, to Walter Gordon Fischer Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Fischer of Weston, Conn. A June wedding is planned.

SAIGON, May 9--United States pilots put a North Vietnamese MIG airfield out of op eration yesterday for the first time in the war. The attack occurred 20 miles west of Hanoi, at Hoalac, where Air Force fighter-bombers blasted huge craters in the runway.

WASHINGTON, May 9--Testimony by a Pentagon official confirmed today that the United States was developing a missile defense system that would use tremendous bursts of X-rays from thermonuclear explosions to destroy incoming missile warheads.

Three unions representing 200,000 city employee announced yesterday that they would raise more than $1-million to pay, if need be, the penalties of the state's new antistrike law for public employee, and to defeat the legislators who voted for it.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 9-- The United States Ambassador to Kenya, Glenn W. Ferguson, accused his predecessor today of having violated ethical standards of diplomacy by rushing into print with information that had been given to him in confidence.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The Senate broke a four-week dead lock today by voting to make the 1966 Presidential campaign financing law inoperative until Congress enacts legislatloa establishing new administrative guidelines. The vote was 93 to 4.

NEW HAVEN, May 9--Harvard took first and second places in the javelin, the final event, to score an 80-74 victory over Yale today in a dual track meet. The victory evened the outdoor series record between the ancient rivals at 35 victories each, with one tie, since 1891.
The Sunbeam Corporation reported yesterday in Chicago that its net income fell sharply in the fiscal year ended March 25, although sales rose to a new record for the seventh consecufive year.

CAPETOWN, May 9--Prime Minister Balthazar J. Vorster, warning against a recurrence of a recent clash in Johannesburg between Jewish and German youths, declared tonight that "Europe's old vendettas must not be imported into South Africa."

WASHINGTON, May 9 (UPI) --The cigarette industry today denounced as deceptive, distorted and unreliable a cancer researcher's finding that many filter cigarettes were at least as hazardous to health as nonfilter brands.
The Defense Personnel Support Center, a division of the Defense Supply Agency, has begun a new f.o.b. policy on clothing and textile and medical procurement shipments within the United States.
WASHINGTON, May 9--Unemployment continued to hold essentially steady at a low level in April despite the continued slowdown of the economy, the Labor Department reported today.
Issues on the American Stock Exchange dropped sharply yesterday on a broad front.

Tension among Negroes, Puerto Ricans and residents of Italian descent in the Coney Island section of Brooklyn erupted into scuffling and fistfights at a noisy, confused antipoverty meeting late Monday night.
WASHINGTON, May 9-- Members of the House Interstate and Foreign Commerce Committee expressed skepticism today about President Johnson's bill for settling the railroad labor dspute.

Even if the Kennedy round of tariff talks falls or is a Hmited success, other ways will have to be found to lower trade barriers, Kurt-Allan Belfrage, a leading Swedish industrialist asserted yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 9--Major revisions in the nation's moon program were announced today. Among them was a reduction in the responsibility of the Apollo spacecraft manufacturer, North American Aviation, Inc.

Dr. Helena Kozeluha Prochazka, a member of the faculty of Dean Junior College, Franklin, Mass., and a former member of the Parliament of Czechoslovakia, died on Saturday in a Wrentham, Mass., nursing home. She would have observed her 60th birthday on Sunday.

THE trauma more than a million high school sen iors each spring undergo as they await notification from the colleges of their choice was the subject of an informative, moving and sometimes amusing documentary on the Columbia Broadcasting System last night. It was
Eclipses, even third-rate solar eclipses, fall into the first order of magnitude in the life of Richard S. Luce.
The New York Mets defeated the league-leading Cincinnati Reds, 3-2, in the 11th inning last night when Tommy Davis lined a home run over the leftfield fence off the previously unbeaten Mel Queen.
Joseph Vincent Santry, who retired in 1963 as chairman and chief executive officer of Combustion Engineering, Inc., died yesterday at Bal Harbour, Fla. He was 83 years old.

Paperboard production fell 2.5 per cent to 458,000 tons in the walk ended May 6 from 469,600 tons in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paperboard Association reported yesterday.
A member of the board of governors of the Federal Reserve System called yesterday for a more flexible tax policy to help keep the national economy on an even keel.
PITTSBURGH, May 9 (AP) --Orlando Cepeda got four hits in four times at bat, drove in two runs and scored twice as the St. Louis Cardinals defeated the Pittsburgh Pirates, 6-3, tonight.

A local school board on the Lower East Side plans to seek the support of its community and the city's 29 other school boards in its fight to have the Superintendent of Schools accept the district superintendent it favors.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 9-- Preliminary gifts exceeding $1-million were announced tonight at the official start of a matching fund campaign to raise $3-million for the San Francisco Symphony Orchestra during the next four years.

WASHINGTON, May 9--The United States and Europe have gone through four great crises since the last World War and are faced with a fifth--threatening the fabulously successful economic system of the postwar era.

FARMINGDALE, L.I., May 9--The Farmingdale Public Library voted unanimously tonight to censure a trustee-elect who wouldn't return to the library a magazines that contained a story he considered obscene.

WASHINGTON, May 9--A shortage of ground stations is holding up development of a complete international satellite communications network, the two top officers of the Communications Satellite Corporation (Comsat) said here today.

About 1,000 welfare workers spent their lunch hour yesterday picketing the office of the city's labor relations director to protest what they charged was "bad faith" in the handling of contract negotiations.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)--The Senate confirmed today the nomination of Robert H. McBride, a Foreign Service Officer, as Ambassador to the Republic of the Congo.

William H. Goetzmann of the University of Texas has won the 1966 Francis Parkman Prize of the Society of American Historians for a book that received the 1966 Pulitzer Prize for history earlier this month.

Mr. and Mrs. Imre Satzger von Balvanyos of Vienna have made known here the engagement of their daughter, Miss Maria Elisabeth Satzger, to J. Vinton Lawrence of New York and Washington, son of Mr. and Mrs. James F. Lawrence of 215 East 72d Street and Norfolk, Conn.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) --The Defense Department today issued a July draft call for the induction of 19,900 young men to serve with the Army. It is the largest draft call this year.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- The United States said that an American destroyer had been scraped by a Soviet destroyer in the Sea of Japan today. The Soviet warship was said to have maneuvered, despite "repeated warnings," too close to a United States naval task group engaged in training exercises.

THE most stupid question that can be asked a boxer on the eve of a fight is: "How do you feel?" At that point in his training regimen it should be presumed that he's bursting all over with vim, vigor and vitality. But when it was tossed yesterday at Jose Torres, it was both pertinent and necessary.

NUREMBERG, Germany, Ma 10--This Bavarian city, host to Hitler's Nazi rallies 30 years ago, today barred a congress of the radical rightist National Democratic party at a cost of $2,500 to Nuremberg taxpayers.

INGLEWOOD, Calif., May 10 (AP)--Fleet Discovery, ably guided by Bill Shoemaker, rallied in the stretch today to win the $27,550 Premier Handicap as Holliywood Park began its 28th annual meeting. The winner paid $11.80 for $2.
Eighteen wooden boxes containing a ton of ice from the Antarctic are aboard the MooreMcCormack Lines freighter Mormaclynx in mid-Atlantic.
SWINDON, England, May 10 (AP)--Arthur Carron, the first Englishman to sing at New York's Metropolitan Opera House, died today at the age of 66.
Prices recovered slightly yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 10-- Best of All completed the third of four one-mile training paces today in preparation for Saturday night's $178,064.79 Messenger Stakes at Roosevelt Raceway by pacing the final quarter-mile in the fast time of 0:27 4-5.
Stocks weakened and closed off in moderately active trading; volume, 10.41 million shares. Corporate bonds declined in less-active trading; transactions, $14.97-million.
A six-week-old baby is due to leave University Hospital today following two pioneering operations in which parts of his heart were rearranged to correct four separate defects.
PARIS, May 10--France, Britain and West Germany failed to reach complete agreement yesterday on plans for the joint development of a giant civilian transport plane to reduce travel costs.

As though dazzled by the Los Angeles Toros' shocking-pink uniforms (and matching knee socks), the New York Generals again failed to present a united front last night and suffered a 2-0 loss at a cold and dreary Yankee Stadium.
The Newspaper Guild of New York called yesterday for government investigations of the reasons for the closing of The World Journal Tribune last Friday.
TWENTY-FIVE years ago, Vera Neumann offered her first collection of scarves, using her own fabric designs in patterns of leaves, ferns and flowers.
The New York Mets shuffled eight players last night in organizing their roster to get down to the 25-man midnight limit.

TUSCALOOSA, Ala., May 10 --Hope for a better relationship between two long-time rivals in the inland transportation field--the railroads and the barge lines--was voiced here today by a leading barge executive.
The Sperry Rand Corporation yesterday announced record profits and increased sales for the fiscal year ended March 31, 1967.

The Kennedy Round of negotiations to liberalize world trade is following a predictable course. Tensions are mounting as the deadline, now set for Sunday, approaches. Displays of brinkmanship become more studied and dramatic. For a time it seemed as if the negotiations were destined to fail; but now there is word of an agreement on wheat. Things may be looking up on the industrial side as well.
JACKSON, Miss., Thursday, May 11 (AP)--Several hundred students rioted early today on the campus of Jackson State College, Mississippi's largest allNegro college.
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Tuesday the level it reached Monday, which was 98.6.

THE Trenton Kennel Club dog show last Sunday, subjected to heavy rain, high wind and icy cold, suffered a substantial financial loss, but Dr. Armour C. Wood, the president, was amazed at some of its more cheerful as pects.
CLEVELAND, May 10 (AP) run homer tonight as the Detroit Tigers defeated the Cleveland Indians, 4.2, to post their fifth straight victory and eighth in their last nine games.
Federal Judge Sylvester J. Ryan confirmed yesterday the bankruptcy reorganization plan of American Express Warehousing, Ltd., a subsidiary of the American Express Company, Inc.
The United States Walker Cup team, fully equipped with golf clubs, bags, small British golf balls, long thermal underwear and white gloves, was prepared to fly to England today.

ATHENS, May 10--The Greek military junta has enacted a law that gives it almost total power over the Greek Orthodox Church, removes the entire ruling panel of bishops and forces out of office the primate, Archbishop Chrysostomos of Athens.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- Democratic national leaders, intent on rescuing President Johnson's re-election prospects, are devising a campaign strategy keyed to winning a series of three-cornered battles in the South.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- The Defense Department announced today the signing of a $1.82-billion contract for initial production by the General Dynamics Corporation of Fort Worth, Tex., of the controversial F-111 multipurpose jet.

The Champion Spark Plug Company has reached an agreement to purchase 438,800 shares of the De Vilbiss Company of Toledo and certain additional shares from other De Vilbiss interests at $34 a share. The entire transaction would involve about $25-million, according to the proposal announced yesterday.
PARIS, May 10--"Four governments are having trouble because of me; why add a fifth?"
INDIANAPOLIS, May 10 (UPI)--Chris Amon of New Zealand hit the wall today during a 160-mile-an-hour practice run for the 500-mile Indianapolis Speedway race on Memorial Day.
Directors of Prentice-Hall, Inc., proposed yesterday a twofor-one stock split of the common shares to take effect Oct. 3 if it is approved by stockholders at a special meeting on Sept. 6.
LONDON, May 10--When it comes to the Middle East, trouble is Sir Humphrey Trevelyan's business.

The engagement of Miss G. Alison Raymond of New York to Albert Gallatin Lanier, also of New York, has been announced by Miss Raymond's brother and sister-in-law, Col. Edward A. Raymond, U.S.A., retired, and Mrs. Raymond of Litchfield, Conn.

WASHINGTON--Henry Haller, the White House chef, has two offices. One is the main kitchen at 1600 Pennsylvania Avenue, where he turns out haute cuisine for official functions such as state dinners for 200, lunches for 12 or receptions for 1,500.
A 19-year-old kitchen worker was arrested yesterday and charged with the rape and robbery of a number of women in the Wagner Houses project in East Harlem.

Mr. and Mrs. William L. Mendlinger of Riverdale, the Bronx, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Jane P. Mendlinger, to Mark Finkelstein, son of Mr. and Mrs. Carl Finkelstein of Brooklyn.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- The Selective Service System has discontinued college qualification tests pending a decision by President Johnson on whether to continue the present policy of educational deferments from the draft.
LENINGRAD, May 10--The Soviet Union's second largest university has quietly tried to break the lock step of traditionbound Russian higher education.
Drexel Harriman Ripley, Inc., New York investment banker, announced yesterday the election of Eugene M. Cheston Jr., as a vice president.

NEW ROCHELLE, N. Y., May 10--Planning consultants here filed recommendations today for the conversion of David's Island, an 80-acre tract a half-mile out in Long Island sound, into a scenic waterfront complex of homes, offices, marinas, beaches lodgings and a convention center.
BAYONNE, N.J., May 10-- Mr. and Mrs. Solomon Mangel have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Florence Ellen Mangel, to Dr. Sheldon Lerner, son of Mr. and Mrs. Louis Lerner of Dover.

BRUSSELS, May 10--Ministers of the European Common Market today accepted an American Kennedy round proposal on grains and in so doing came near a solution to this vital area of the trade liberalization negotiations.

A TRICKY offshoot of the Tarrasch Defense to the Queen's Gambit Declined is the Van Hennig Scharra Gambit, involving a black pawn sacrifice for fast development and complications. It is always a reasonably good try if Black is a spirited tactician and his opponent is unfamiliar with its details.
Aspasia Brussaly, a soprano from Montclair, N.J., made her second solo appearance at Carnegie Recital Hall last night. She had made her local debut there Oct. 18, 1959.
Fordham University will begin a program of "full and candid" sex education in the fall, including lectures on contraceptive devices.

A Hadassah luncheon drew 700 pickets, many of them rabbinical students, to the sidewalk outside the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel yesterday to protest what they called enforced autopsy procedures at the Hadassah Hospital in Jerusalem.

Prudential Lines and the Pacific Far East Line received Government approval yesterday for the construction of 11 merchant ships of a new design, in what could be one of the largest single commercial shipbuilding orders to be placed with an American shipyard.
SANA, Yemen, May 10-- The boom of distant artillery fire has been sounding in Sana this week as Egyptian forces have carried out a series of punitive attacks on dissident tribesmen to the south.
An independent research agency has taken a long, disapproving look at municipal hospital policy here and proposed a powerful super agency "to get on top of the whole system."

WASHINGTON, May 10-- New York City and the General Services Administration are "very close" to an agreement on the price of the site of the former Brooklyn Navy Yard, sources close to the negotiations said today.
VIENNA, May 10--Hungarian workers are being given full freedom to change their jobs without being penalized.
WASHINGTON, May 10--Dr. Timothy Leary, the guru of psychedelia, was playing with fire the other night when he urged a national television audience to go on drugs and "cop out."
Twelve persons were injured yesterday afternoon when a Transit Authority bus, a truck and an auto collided at Utica and Snyder Avenues in Brooklyn. Five of the injured were hospitalized.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- Space agency officials came under sharp attack today from Congressmen for withholding facts in the past about serious cost and management problems with North American Aviation, Inc., the prime Apollo spacecraft contractor.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 10 --John Kenneth Galbraith, the Harvard economist, asserted tonight that so many millions of Americans were critical of United States policy in Vietnam that there was "very little chance of shutting them up."
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)--A committee of Regular Army, National Guard and Reserve generals has secretly voted 11 to 10 for a plan to drop 15 National Guard divisions and four Reserve brigades.
GRANDIN CONOVER'S "The Party on Greenwich Avenue," which opened at the Cherry Lane Theater last night, is one of the lesser events of the season.
CHICAGO, May 10 (UPI)-- Adolfo Phillips stole home for the deciding run and Ken Holtzman, the pitcher, delivered a two-run single as the Chicago Cubs beat the San Francisco Giants, 5-4, today.
WASHINGTON, May 10--Administrators of all programs within the Department of Health, Education and Welfare were stripped today of civil rights enforcement powers.
NEW ORLEANS, May 10-- Show business and Holly wood appear to be exerting a greater influence and interest than ever before in the professional golf tour.

A wave of new competition by hundreds of small mailorder companies may be the eventual offshoot of the United States Supreme Court's decision this week barring the collecting of state and local taxes by mail-order companies in states where they have no physical location.
ATLANTA, May 10--The Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. spoke out today against the critics of his antiwar program and declared that there "ain't nobody gonna turn me "round" on the issue.

WASHINGTON, MAY 10-- Dr. Leo J. Gehrig, acting Surgeon General of the United States Public Health Service, said today that immediate action was needed to reduce the radiation exposure of uranium miners.
OTTAWA, May 10--Prime Minister Lester B. Pearson "emphatically denied" today a newspaper report that Canadians on the International Control Commission in Vietnam had spied for the United States.

A series of statewide television and radio debates on the issue of state aid to private schools was proposed yesterday by the Committee for Public Education and Religious Liberty. The organization opposes the use of state funds for nonpublic schools.
