ROME, May 10--Pope Paul VI conceded today that the controversy with non-Catholics over the Roman Catholic Church's teachings on the Virgin Mary, though calmer in tone in the last few years, remains "for them one of the major obstacles" to unity.

James E. Webb, head of the National Aeronautics and Space Administration, was asked on April 17 by a member of the Senate Space Committee whether North American Aviation was the first choice of NASA's Source Evaluation Board--a group of almost 200 technical experts--as the winner of the 1961 competition for building the Apollo capsule. Mr. Webb replied "yes."

Announcement has been made here of the engagement of Miss Elisabeth Zbinden, daughter of Hans Zbinden of Bienne, Switzerland, and the late Mrs. Zbinden, to Frederick Herzog Shipley. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Linwood Parks Shipley of Summit, N. J.

THE man whose store-window displays often stop traffic at 57th Street and Fifth Avenue is designing jewelry. "I have no desire to be known as a jewelry designer," said Gene Moore, the gray-haired, blue-eyed man who is responsible for the weekly whimsey in the the 3-by-4-foot windows of Tiffany Co. "I'm happy to be known as the world's best window trimmer."
FORT JACKSON, S.C., May 10--Ten combat officers, one of them disfigured by a mine explosion in Vietnam, began sitting in judgment today on Capt. Howaed B. Levy of Brooklyn.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (UPI)--Joe Torre slammed two home runs and Hank Aaron and Mack Jones added one each as the Atlanta Braves gained a 7-2 victory over Philadelphia tonight after the Phils had taken the opener of a doubleheader, 4-3.
"I Do! I Do!," the twocharacter musical with Mary Martin and Robert Preston, has been suspended until Miss Martin recovers from a virus infection affecting her nose, throat, larynx and vocal cords.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Thursday, May 11--Ambassador Ellsworth Bunker today placed Gen. William C. Westmoreland, the United States military commander, in over-all charge of the American role in pacification.
A three-judge Federal court ruled unanimously yesterday that the Legislature's 1961 reapportionment of Congressional districts in New York State violated the United States Constitution.
CARLISLE, Pa., May 10 (AP)--David L. Watkins of Montclair (N.J.) State College was named today basketball coach at Dickinson.

DOWNEY, Calif., May 10-- The new team of Apollo astronauts expressed confidence today in the comprehensive program being pressed to avert any repetition of the spacecraft fire that killed three astronauts at Cape Kennedy, Fla., on Jan. 27.
Three thousand New Yorkers . turned up their topcoat collars last night and shivered through the city's 10th annual Salute to Spring.
CHICAGO, May 10 (UPI)-- Clay told a University of Chicago rally tonight that he had refused to be drafted because "in war it's kill, kill, kill and kill some more."
A survey of 450 ad men has come up with some interesting statistics on their attitudes, their desires, their salaries and their gripes.
Dr. Herman Taller, author of "Calories Don't Count," a bestseller six years ago, was found guilty yesterday on 12 counts of mail fraud, conspiracy and violating Federal drug regulations.

PHILADELPHIA, May 10 (AP)--The backers of unbeaten Joe Frazier said today they wanted no part of a proposed eight-man elimination heavyweight boxing tournament to determine a champion to succeed Cassius Clay.

AS I WALKED out of the last night, one standee emitted a stentorian boo. It was directed at the ballet "Paradise Lost," which was having its American premiere and, despite the efforts of this highly vocal nonconformist, was being cheered to what I believe is known in the busi-...

Ruling that the existing Congressional district lines in New York State are unconstitutional because of flagrant inequalities in population, the Federal court not only has wiped out a notorious gerrymander but has created a problem demanding speedy action by Governor Rockefeller and the Legislature.
HONG KONG, May 10--Mao Tse-tung's wife was depicted today as the person who fired the opening shots in the Chinese Communist Cultural Revolution.
The appointment of H. Kenneth Busch as executive director of manufacturing and engineering of the Celanese Corpo ration was announced yesterday.
Jack I. Straus, chairman of the board of trustees of Roosevelt Hospital, was cited last night by the Greater New York Hospital Association as "a dynamic leader" in hospital community affairs.
Five small banks in the metropolitan area are being invesfigures involved in the jukein connection with questionable loan transactions with Mafia figures involved in the juke box industry.

New York University defeated Manhattan College, 8-2, in baseball yesterday at Van Cortlandt Park, the Bronx. N.Y.U. scored two runs in the first inning on three Jasper errors and added three runs on five hits in the ninth.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10-- Senators studying the Federal antipoverty effort found today that condemned World War II public housing in the San Francisco Hunter's Point area was superior to housing they observed earlier in Mississippi, New York City and the District of Columbia.
The Coast Guard yesterday suspended one search for survivors of a pleasure craft accident in Long Island Sound, but continued looking for another craft in the Atlantic.
VATICAN CITY, May 10 (UPI)--The Catholic Church cannot approve of miniskirts, the Vatican City weekly Osservatore Della Domenica said today.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 10 (AP)--More than 250 students at 25 medical schools across the nation have signed pledges to refuse to serve with United States armed forces in Vietnam, a group of them announced today.

LONDON, May 10--A new effort to achieve a peaceful transition to independence for the South Arabian Federation next year was indicated today with the decision to send a former diplomat to Aden as the new British High Commissioner.

CANBERRA, Australia, May 10 (Reuters)--An Australian syndicate is continuing negotiations to buy the Cunard liner Queen Mary, the syndicate's head, Dr. Malcolm Mackay, said here today. But he declined to confirm or deny that the syndicate had made a firm bid. The Cunard line said it had received no offer from the group.

BURLINGTON, Conn., May 10--When I was a small boy in northern Michigan 30 years ago and more, one of the favorite time-killing expeditions promoted by parents was a visit to the state fish hatchery at Oden on Crooked Lake. The sight of zillions of fingerlings being raised to bite worms, flies and other lures seemed so ordered and so simple.
WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)--Antiwar demonstrators, singing "We Shall Overcome," were carried by Government policemen from inside the Pentagon tonight after a vigil of more than 29 hours.

Democratic leaders were generally optimistic and Republicans generally noncommittal yesterday about the impact of the Federal court ruling requiring the reapportionment of the state's Congressional districts by 1968.

GENEVA, May 10--A message from Pope Paul VI will be read at the opening session of the second Pacem in Terris Conference on May 28, it was learned today. The message will be read by Charles Cardinal Journet of Fribour one of the ranking Swiss prelates.

Three of the city's most powerful unions of public employes are raising a million-dollar fund to fight the new state law designed to make civil service strikes both unnecessary and illegal. The unions' resolve to build a war chest to defy the strike ban and to defeat legislators who voted for it typifies the "public-bedamned" attitude that has characterized the union approach to the problem.
Busy horseplayers normally don't waste time on girl-watching, but they had no alternative yesterday at Aqueduct. Unless they wanted to watch Braulio Baeza.

Desmond Guinness, president will give an illustrated lecture on the arts and architecture of 18th-century Ireland on Tuesday at 9:30 P.M. at the ParkeBernet Galleries, 980 Madison Avenue. Proceeds will go to the society, which he founded 10 years ago to rescue Georgian buildings in Ireland threatened with destruction.

GREENWICH, Conn., May nell have announced the engagement of Mrs. Rennell's daughter, Miss Nancy Mackall Hoover, to Richard J. Zeckhauser. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Julius N. Zeckhauser of Great Neck, L. I. The brideto-be is the daughter also of the late Gordon Phillips Hoover of Grosse Pointe, Mich., who was lost on submarine duty in World War II.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 10--A United Nations report pointed today to the importance of British private investment for the buoyancy of South Africa's economy and Britain's balance of payments.

GENEVA, May 10--Dr. Fred L. Soper of the United States was presented by the World Health Organization today with the Leon Bernard Foundation Prize for "outstanding service in the field of social medicine."
LONDON, May 10--The London art market's traditional doctrine of caveat emptor (let the buyer beware) is being challenged by an act recently adopted by Parliament.

The Lindsay administration assured the City University yesterday that it would be given enough budgetary "flexibility" next year to guarantee admission of all qualified freshmen and to permit the use of funds where they are needed most in the institution.
MONTE CARLO, Monaco, May 10--Lorenzo Bandini died today of the injuries he suffered in a crash during the Grand Prix de Monaco last Sunday. Italy and Ferrari have lost their leading racing driver.
HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 10 (AP)--Lady Helmsman of Britain won the first race of the world Class C catamaran championships today, defeating two United States contenders by almost two minutes.
CHICAGO, May 10--More than a third of the clergy in the Episcopal Church lack the prescribed seminary education, an 18-month study shows.
CHICAGO, May 10 (UPI)-- Sears, Roebuck Co. filed an $18-million-antitrust suit today against a burglar alarm maker and an alarm service, charging them with controlling an unfair share of the market.
SAIGON, May 10--United States Navy fighter-bombers struck within Haiphong today in the second such attack of the war. They also attacked a nearby MIG airfield for the first time.
RICHMOND, May 10--George C. Wallace, after two weeks of barnstorming through the East and Middle West, brought his unannounced independent Presidential campaign into the South today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) --The House Banking Committee approved today a bill to step up by $150-million the United States contribution to the special operations fund of the Inter-American Development Bank.
DALLAS, May 10 (AP)-- Southern Methodist University said today that it was investigating the authenticity of 36 old-master paintings Mr. Meadows donated to the school in 1962.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (UPI)--Two British experts surprised a Senate subcommittee today with testimony that 20 years of research had been unable to fix sulphur dioxide as the cause of death-producing air pollution.
The recent rise in interest rates in several sections of the bond market was halted yesterday.

PLEIKU, South Vietnam, May 10--"We tell people that we grease the body and wings to make them go faster," Maj. Ed Maxson was saying as he climbed into his cockpit, "but the plain truth is that the engine sprays oil over everything."
Jig-saw boundaries and incongruous shapes characterize the Congressional districts cited yesterday by a Federal court in ordering reapportionment in New York State.
BALTIMORE, May 10 (AP) --The Baltimore Orioles optioned Mike Epstein to Rochester of the International League tonight, but the 1966 minor league player of the year said he would not report.
City Council President Frank D. O'Connor urged yesterday that the city expand the treatment of narcotic addicts with methadone--a drug that has enabled addicts to hold jobs and go to school.

John D. Rockefeller 3d has purchased four buildings near the United Nations and will donate the land under them to the Japan Society, which plans to build a new headquarters there, it became known yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- Retail sales held almost unchanged in April at the March level, the Commerce Department estimated today. This means that sales have been essentially stable for six months.

The annual Golden Door Award Dinner will be held next Thursday in the Biltmore's Grand Ballroom. Frederic O. Hess, inventor and industrialist, will be guest of honor at the event, arranged by the American Council for Nationalities Service.
The London Stock Exchange advanced yesterday in moderate trading.

GUATEMALA, May 10--The Roman Catholic Bishops in Guatemala, meeting under Archbishop Mario Casariego, issued a pastoral letter today expressing deep concern over a recent wave of organized terror, and offered to mediate between opposing groups.

MIAMI BEACH, Fla., May 10 --Miss Phyllis Sue Rosenstein, who expects to graduate next month from Jackson College for Women of Tufts University, and Eric Chester Stoller, who expects to receive a degree then from Harvard Law School, plan to be married here in the early fall.

Former Supreme Court Justice J. Vincent Keogh, who was paroled after serving eight months of a two-year prison sentence for conspiracy to obstruct justice, sought in Federal Court yesterday to set aside his 1962 conviction and get a new trial.

NEW BRUNSWICK, N. J., May 10 (AP)--Rutgers won the New Jersey College track and field championships today, winning eight of the 18 events and posting five of the nine meet marks set. Rutgers had 108 points. Princeton was second with 75 and Seton Hall third with 19.
Tony Jackson who scored 1,603 points in three seasons at St. John's University, signed yesterday with the New York Freighters of the American Basketball Association.

WASHINGTON May 10 (UPI) --A New Jersey businessman, whose cloak and dagger exploits led to the expulsion of a Soviet agent last year, told Congress today that the Soviet Union was conducting industrial espionage.
AT LONG LAST, the American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corporation may have found a merger partner that would give it insurance against seasonal and cyclical setbacks.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 10 (UPI)--Louis H. Schwitzer, who won the first auto race ever held at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway, died last night in his home at the age of 86.

GENEVA, May 10--Between 3:45 A.M. and 3:52 P.M. yesterday the Kennedy Round hung in the balance with American chief negotiator William M. Roth threatening to break off negotiations and return to Washington.
MONTREAL, May 10 (UPI) --Four Chicago Black Hawks and two members of the New York Rangers were named today to the official National Hockey League All-Star team.

RONALD TURINI's ostenpiano recital last night at Carnegie Hall was to salute his native land, Canada, during its centennial year. But any pretext to get this epicurean young pianist to play here again would be welcome.
BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 10-- A new Cabinet was sworn in today by President Abdel Rahman Arif of Iraq.
SPRINGFIELD, Ill., May 10 (AP)--The Illinois House passed tonight the first open occupancy measure to clear either chamber in the current legislative session.

CANNES, France, May 10-- The Soviet Union's official entry at the Cannes Film Festival, a motion picture version of Dmitri Shostakovich's Opera, "Katerina Ismailova," is interesting evidence of the cultural revisions that are taking place in Russia.

BANGKOK, Thailand, May 10--Thai officials reported today evidence of links between the pro-communist Pathet Lao in Laos and the Hanoi-backed Patriotic Front guerrillas operating across the Mekong River in northeast Thailand.

HASTINGS-ON-HUDSON, N.Y., May 10--William A. Briesemelster, a cartographer of the American Geographical Society, Broadway and 156th Street, New York, from 1913 until his retirement four years ago, died yesterday in his home at 124 High Street. He was 72 years old.
UNITED NATIONS, N. Y., May 10--Secretary General Thant made a new appeal today to the United States to "take a calculated risk" and halt the bombing of North Vietnam.
The often heavy financial burdens borne by families with mentally retarded children are being eased because of recent changes in New York State and Federal Social Security laws.
WASHINGTON, May 10-- Members of two Congressional committees suggested today changing the approach that President Johnson has proposed for resolving the rail labor dispute.
IT is invigorating to read about Ambrose Bierce. His black humor, tersely flaunted, irradiates what Goya called the sleep of reason.
Vertical accents of granite and aluminum will mark a 27-story office building that will rise on the north side of 42d Street just east of Fifth Avenue.
The Cincinnati Reds re-established their stature as the leaders of the National League last night at Shea Stadium despite an historic hit in the career of Ken Boyer.
DETROIT, May 10--Discrimination charges by a Jewish diemaker brought action today by the General Motors Corporation.
WASHINGTON, May 10--The Office of Economic Opportunity and its business leadership Advisory Council announced today plans for an on-the-job training program to be called "Success Insurance."
CORONADO, Calif., May 10--The Navy's oldest retired admiral, Richard Harrison Jackson, was honored on his 101st birthday today with a luncheon at the Hotel del Coronado.

BERLIN, May 10 (Reuters)-- Ernst F. Wollweber, a German Communist credited with being the mastermind behind the sabotage of shipping to Nazi Germany during World War II, and head of the East German secret police from 1953 to 1957, has died a forgotten figure in East Germany.

WASHINGTON, May 10 -- Senator Robert Kennedy of New York loudly criticized the public welfare program the other day as "a system of handouts, a second-rate set of social services which damages and demeans its recipients."

MONTREAL, May 10 (AP) --Roger Clark of England and Jim Peters of Don Mills, Ont., driving a Lotus Cortina, were declared the provisional winners today of the Shell 4,000 rally as the cars trickled into the Expo 67 Autostade.
The American Stock Exchange reported yesterday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

Franklin A. Thomas, the newly appointed director of Bedford Stuyvesant's controversial Community Development Corporation, said yesterday he hoped to act as "a cohesive force" among Brooklyn groups competing to run the area's proposed multi-million dollar rehabilitation programs.

Trading stopped in May potato futures promptly at 1:30 yesterday afternoon. In a roaring market stoked by bullish enthusiasm despite heavy supplies, May futures rose to $4.82 a hundred pounds on Jan. 6, and then proceeded to fizzle down to $1.81 on April 17. Yesterday they closed at $2.72-2.90, which was quite a good recovery.
ALBANY, May 10--Hotels and motels asked the state today for a commission of up to 12 per cent for selling tickets in the forthcoming lottery, 2 per cent more than the banks asked for yesterday.

JERUSALEM (Isreal), May 10--Foreign Minister Abba Eban said today the expected boycott by major Western nations of Israel's independence day parade in Jerusalem next Monday was not courteous or logical.
A privately financed, $1.1million community center will be constructed on city-owned land in the Lillian Wald housing project on the Lower East Side.
MEXICO CITY, May 10-- Margaret Larkin, American writer and an editorial assistant to Oscar Lewis, the sociologist, died here Monday after a short illness. She was 67 years old.
Vera Zorina will make her New York debut as a director of opera during the fall season of the New York City Opera in Lincoln Center.

The New York Times Company has completed an agreement to purchase the Microfilming Corporation of America, Hawthorne, N. J., Arthur Ochs Sulzberger, publisher and president of The Times, announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 10--The House of Commons tonight overwhelmingly approved the Government's decision to apply for membership in the European Common Market.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- The United States aid agency has begun to process requests for large-scale contraceptive supplies from developing countries under a liberalized policy on birth control assistance.

The military junta now governing Indonesia has agreed that birth control should become an official project. It may already be too late for this sorely needed change in policy; but any move to slow the country's birth rate, now almost 3 per cent, would help.
DETROIT, May 10--Americans should be encouraged to enjoy their leisure instead of working at it, a psychiatrist said today.
HONG KING, May 10 (Reuters)--The Hanoi radio reported today that North Vietnam had shot down five Ameri- can planes, four of them with antiaircraft fire and missiles over Haiphong.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- New York Senators Jacob K. and Robert F. Kennedy joined today in sponsoring legislation to grant for the first time Federal supervisory authority over foreign banks in the United States.
American television audiences may soon be able to see how foreign TV stations--possibly including those in the Soviet Union--cover and interpret news stories breaking in this country.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 10 -Mrs. Margaret Coe Blake, widow of Clinton Hamlin Blake, Mayor of Englewood from 1915 to 1917, died today in Hightstown. She was 81 years old and a lifelong resident of Englewood. She also maintained a home in Sugar Hill, N. H.
NEW LONDON, Conn., May 10 (AP)--Dr. J. Warren Horton, a pioneer in electronic communications, died yesterday in Lawrence and Memorial Hospital. He was 77 years old.
Edward T. Shean, a Wall Street banker reported missing on March 12, has returned home, it was disclosed yesterday in State Supreme Court.

HITTING on a method of play that offers better prospects than the obvious line that other players would adopt is usually a source of satisfaction. The diagrammed deal is one of the exceptions for the declarer's pride in his analysis was mixed with grief: any other line of play would have succeeded. The treatment was unquestionably right, but the patient died.

NEW ORLEANS, May 10-- District Attorney Jim Garrison today subpoenaed Richard Helms, head of the Central Intelligence Agency, to answer questions before a New Orleans grand jury next week about a C.I.A. investigation of the assasination of President Kennedy.
HONG KONG, May 10-- Hsinhua, the Chinese Communist press agency, today pictured the mass of American Negroes as a body of active opposition to the war in Vietnam.
SIMSBURY, Conn., May 10-- J. Kell Brandon, retired chairman of the Ensign-Bickford Company, died Tuesday in the Hartford Hospital. He was 87 years old and lived at 21 West Street.

STOCKHOLM, May 10--Earl Russell's so-called International War Crimes Tribunal gave as its opinion today that the United States was guilty of the crimes of aggression and "widespread, deliberate and system atic" bombardment of civilian targets in Vietnam.
Robert P. LeVine has been elected president of the PennDixie Cement Corporation, it was announced yesterday.

BALTIMORE, May 10 (UPI) --Local 340 of the American Federation of Teachers broke off contract negotiations with the city school board tonight and went on strike briefly in defiance of a court injunction.
SAN DIEGO, Calif., May 10 (UPI)--Barbara Payton, an actress and a former wife of Franchot Tone, the actor, died Monday at the home of her parents, Mr. and Mrs. E. Lee Redfield. She was 39 years old.
ATLANTA, May 10--The International Telephone and Telegraph Corporation reported at the annual meeting here today that first-quarter sales and earnings reached new highs.
DALLAS, May 10 (UPI)-- An experimental vertical takeoff aircraft, simulating an airsea rescue mission, crashed into the south shore of Mountain Creek Lake today, killing all three crew members.
ADEN, May 10 (Reuters)-- Three attacks were made on British troops in the Aden area today, but there were no casualties, a military spokesman said.
The nation's electric power production in the week ended May 6 rose 5.2 per cent from the level in the corresponding 1966 week, it was reported by the Edison Electric Institute yesterday.

RAHWAY, N. J., May 10-- Carmine A. Bongiovanni of 215 Albermarle Street, a design engineer with the Singer Manufacturing Company and manager of its cast-iron milling department in Elizabeth, died yesterday at the Alexian Brothers Hospital in Elizabeth. His age was 46.
Ten major Catholic, Protestant and Jewish social action agencies have formed a foundation to help mobilize poor communitites throughout the country to play a greater role in solving their problems.
New York City's Civil Court, where 95 judges grapple with civil suits involving claims up to $10,000, is continuing to "lose ground," with 150,000 cases piled up.

PITTSBURGH, May 10 (UPI) --Willie Stargell's 450-foot tworun homer sparked the Pittsburgh Pirates to a 4-1 victory over the St. Louis Cardinals tonight as Bob Veale became the major league's first five-game winner of the season.
The Governors Rockfeller-- Nelson of New York and Winthrop of Arkansas--were the principal speakers last night at the annual dinner of Brotherhood-in-Action, Inc. at the Americana hotel.
Alfred H. Kliegl, an executive of the Universal Electric Stage Lighting Company Inc., manufacturer of klieg lights, died Tuesday at his home, 245 East 87th Street. He was 67 years old.

When an executive at the American Broadcasting Company decided the other day that too many old, unused sets were clogging the network's studios, he ordered some of them taken to the city dump for burning.
Stock prices fell yesterday for the second successive day but the decline was nothing like the sharp setback suffered Tuesday.
The Soviet Union appears to have applied economic pressure on other Communist countries last year by cutting down its purchases from them, Western observers suggest.

City College celebrated its 120th anniversary yesterday in its cavernous, neo-gothic Great Hall, bedecked with the flags of medieval universities and dominated by a mural evoking the college's proletarian beginnings.

PARIS, May 10--The Government spokesman noted with satisfaction today that Britain was moving "closer to Europe." But he added that France was aware of the "difficult problems" raised by Britain's candidacy for membership in the European Common Market.

HANOVER, N.H., May 10-- Dartmouth beat Princeton, 2-1, today as Jim Shaw, a senior pitched a no-hitter. The Indian southpaw struck out 10 Tigers and walked three for his seventh victory against one loss.

Sharp clashes developed yesterday between officials of Columbia University and the Student Homophile League, an organization seeking equal rights for homosexuals at Columbia that has been officially recognized by the University.
Survivors of World War I's famed Lost Battalion and other members of New York's "own 77th Division" of the two World Wars will mark golden and silver anniversaries next fall.
OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May 10--Mrs. Evelyn L. Fisk Gould, widow of John Warren DuBois Gould, died today in Greenwich Hospital at the age of 88. She lived at 22 Arnold Street.
CHATTANOOGA, May 10 (AP)--James R. Hoffa's fourth motion for a new trial on jurytampering charges was denied today by Judge Frank W. Wilson of the United States District Court.

DETROIT, May 10--The American Motors Corporation said today that it was recalling 13,245 Rebel and American automobile models to correct a possible safety defect that could lead to a loss of steering.
ANAHEIM, Calif., May 10-- Jose Cardenal's triple and Rick Reichardt's single, with nobody out in the ninth inning, gave the California Angels a 3-2 victory over the New York Yankees tonight.
Thousands of fake art works have been sold recently for millions of dollars, leading to extensive investiga- tions now being pursued by Federal, state and local law enforcement agencies.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP) --The Senate Commerce Committee approved today a bill to create a nonprofit corporation to provide financial support for the development and distribution of noncommercial radio and television programs.

LA PAZ, Bolivia, May 10 (UPI)--Four Bolivian soldiers were killed yesterday in a clash with pro-Communist guerillas in the mountainous southeastern part of the nation, a military spokesman reported today.

WASHINGTON, May 10 (AP)--Senators Everett McKinley Dirksen of Illinois and Roman L. Hruska of Nebraska called anew today for a Constitutional amendment to undo the Supreme Court's 1964 ruling that both houses of state legislatures must be apportioned on a population basis.

WASHINGTON, May 10-- The Defense Department has decided to recommission a Navy battleship for service in the Vietnam war. The New Jersey, one of four World War II veterans in the Navy's reserve fleet, will probably be ...
TALLAHASSEE, Fla., May 10--Florida legislators were assured today that not a single case under investigation in Gov. Claude R. Kirk Jr.'s privately financed war on crime was politically motivated.
NAIROBI, Kenya, May 10 --An Arab dhow of the sort that has been sailing on the Indian Ocean for thousands of years was towed out of Mombasa today on the first leg of a voyage to New York.

"I'm still very bullish about the stock market," says William' L. Jiller, president of the Trendline division of Standard Poor's Corporation. "That's what the technical factors and the pattern of stock buying tells us."
WASHINGTON, May 10-- Attorney General Ramsey Clark advised Congress today that the number of flag burners was "infinitesimal" and that he would prefer to leave the prosecution of them to the states.
Mrs. Lyndon B. Johnson spent the day in New York City yesterday honoring the very old and the very young.

SOUTH BEND, Ind., May 11--Any doubt about the ability of Coach Ara Parseghian to find suitable replacements for the all-America caliber players in the Notre Dame line lost through graduation were dispelled last week in the Old-Timers game. The annual climax to the spring training season showed that the Fighting Irish will again have a high-powered offense and a strong defense.

The head of the printers union proposed yesterday a broad study of automation problems in the newspaper industry here, but officials of The Long Island Star-Journal insisted that their paper needed concessions on automation now.

Thomas J. Kappock has been elected a vice president of the Inter-County Title Guaranty and Mortgage Company and will be with the company's office in Hackensack, N.J. Mr. Kappock retired as vice president of the Title Guarantee Company last month. He started with that company as an office boy 62 years ago.
Two men who are both 54 years old and were classmates at Yale University, were named yesterday to the senior management posts at the Discount Corporation of New York.

ROANOKE, Va., May 11 The president of the Norfolk Western Railway today challenged reports that most of the nation's railroads would petition the Interstate Commerce Commission this week for an increase in freight rates.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) Restoration of the 7 percent investment tax credit won't push machine tool sales back to last year's peak, but it should help convince companies to modernize their equipment, an industry spokesman said today.

Gohar Gasparyan, an Egyptian-born soprano who lives in Soviet Armenia, made her New York debut last night in a recital at Carnegie Hall sponsored by the Diocese of the Armenian Church of America. This was the 6th of 12 concerts Miss Gasparyan is giving in major United States cities in her first tour here.
New York's big stores have been heavily solicited by masscirculation magazines, suburban periodicals and even some outof-town newspapers since The World Journal Tribune quit publishing a week ago.

WASHINGTON, May 11 The Senate passed tonight a bill to extend the Selective Service Act for four years without major change. The roll-call vote was 70 to 2. The negative votes were by Senators Wayne Morse of Oregon and Ernest Gruening of Alaska, both Democrats.

THE COLGATE COMEDY HOUR," a Sunday eve ning staple during the early nineteen-fifties, returned to television last night for a onenight stand on the National Broadcasting Company. It was a pleasant brisk and occasionally hilarious review, in which some of the major comic talents who have emerged in the last 10 years performed the routines that made them famous.

IT was, at least I certainly hope it was, Robert Schumann who said of Frederic Chopin's music: "Hats off, Gentleman, a genius!" My memory is awful and my sense of chronology coarse. Perhaps it was Chopin who said it of Schumann. (Would Chopin have been that perceptive?) After all these years, who cares? My point is that a kind of divinity fringes a genius, a kind of divinity that cannot be mistaken.

LA GRANGE, Ga. May 11 (AP) Mrs. A. Landon Morrow Sr. was watching a late news program on television, and a film report on fighting in Vietnam caught her attention. Suddenly there was a familiar face in battle gear.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) Nationalist China's Vice President and Premier, C.K. Yen, ended an official visit with President Johnson today and departed on a two-week tour of the United States.

BONN, May 11 The Federal Bank lowered its discount rate today from 3.5 to 3 per cent, effective tomorrow. This is the fourth reduction this year and makes the rate the lowest of the world's major industrial nations.
Single women are being encouraged to adopt children under an experimental program by a division of the Welfare Department, Mayor Lindsay said yesterday.
DETROIT, May 11 (UPI) The defection of Mrs. Svetlana Alliluyeva, Stalin's daughter, had a "certain element of treason in it," a visisting Soviet writer said yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 11 Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara has warned the Greek military junta that the United States may cut off military aid unless Greece is returned to constitutional government.

J. Lee Rice Jr., president since 1957 of the Allegheny Power System, Inc., was elected to the additional post of chairman at the annual meeting, held here yesterday. Mr. Rice, 64 years old, is a native of Butte, Mont. He succeeds Earle S. Thompson, who has retired.

BONN, May 11 Premier Willy Stoph of East Germany has written a letter to Chancellor Kurt Georg Kiesinger of West Germany that A.D.N., the official East German press agency, said relayed suggestions for "normalizing relations between the two German states."

BATES LOWRY, who will become director of the Museum of Modern Art in 1968, might have become an engineer, a physician, a muleskinner or a lawyer. He was pressed toward one occupation after the other while in the Army in World War II. That he resisted these pushes...
Bronx regular and Reform Democrats, signaled an easing of warfare last night at the annual dinner of the Bronx County Democratic organization.
WASHINGTON, May 11 Defense Department officials said today thet a 5,600-man Army infantry brigade to be formed this month at Fort Hood, Tex., would eventually be sent to South Vietnam.

The Chase Manhattan Bank announced yesterday the introduction of a new card that will help checking-account customers of the bank to cash checks up to $100 in restaurants, stores and other retail establishments easily and quickly.
The modest bond market rally that began Wednesday continued yesterday and spread to include the lagging long-maturity Government Issues.
Steeplechase stakes racing made its season's debut at Aqueduct yesterday and, despite the rain and cold, 24,324 fans were on hand for the occasion.

Reasons why the New York State Insurance Department should grant permission for insurance companies here to be come holding companies were advanced yesterday by J. Victor Herd, chairman and chief executive officer of the Continental Insurance Companies.
The Metropolitan Museum of Art, concerned about widespread art forgeries, is planning an educational program on fakes for its 22,000 members.

DETROIT, May 11 The Ford Motor Company said today it was calling back 16,000 trucks to replace possible defective parts. Owners of 28,000 other Fords and 570 other Mercury Comet car models built at a Los Angeles plant were being advised to get a replacement bumper jack column and case assembly from Ford dealers.
The directors of Dan River Mills, Inc., and Fieldcrest Mills have agreed to plans for a merger, top officials of both companies said yesterday.

Edith Evans Asbury of The New York Times won the James Wright Brown award for excellence in journalism last night. The award is given by the Deadline Club, which is the New York chapter of Sigma Delta Chi, the professional journalism society.
When the first of No-Cal's 1967 print ads begin to appear next month, look deeply into one and perhaps you'll catch the reflection of Marty Solow, Brooklyn-born adman, nosh-lover and amateur dieter.

WASHINGTON, May 11 James E. Webb, the space agency administrattor, defended again, today the selection of North American Aviation, Inc., for the prime Apollo spacecraft contract, despite an evaluation board's recommendation of another company.
PASADENA, Calif., May 11 (AP) Lunar Orbiter 4 radioed its first pictures of the moon tonight. They showed a broad panorama of the rugged south pole that had not previously been photographed.

Net income of Dresser Industries, Inc., in the six months ended April 30 rose to $10,145,000, or $1.14 a share, from $8,250,000, or 96 cents a share, in the corresponding last year, John Lawrence, chairman and president, announced yesterday.
The Mets and Cincinnati Reds were rained out at Shea Stadium yesterday by more of the monsoon-style weather that has plagued the opening month of the baseball season.
More than 250 surfers from the East Coast, California and Puerto Rico will begin competing tomorrow in the second annual Southampton spring championships at Hampton Bays, L.I.
HONG KONG, May 11 Ships flying the flag of Communist China fired at American planes bombing Haiphong, British officers from a merchant vessel said today.

A nationally recognized authority on the Mafia criticized the leaders of the American Italian Anti-Defamation League yesterday for their selection of Frank Sinatra, the actor and singer, as national chairman of a campaign to discourage identification of gangsters in ethnic terms.
WASHINGTON, May 11 Princess Lalla Nezha, the wife of the new Ambassador from Morocco, Ahmed Osman, looks very much a member of the international set.
The Ballet Folklorico Mexico, which does not dance on hats, will return here for a two-week engagement from May 30 through June 11.

Since its premiere performance to Bordeaux in 1789, "La Fille Mal Gardee," under one choreographer or another, has proved one of the most durable of ballet confections. Re-choreographed completely by Sir Frederick Ashton in 1960, it continues to enchant in its latest re-incarnation.
WASHINGTON, May 11 The Government disclosed today the reforms being considered to eliminate flaws in private pension plans.

MONTICELLO, N.Y., May 11 At 5 o'clock as afternoon, four hours and five minutes before post time, the thickest and stickiest rain and fog this side of Londontown threatened to wreck the launching of Monticello Raceway's 10th season of harness racing. At that time,...

PASCAGOULA, Miss., May 11 The automated cargo ship President Taft, third in a fleet of five new cargo carriers for American President Lines, will be launched Saturday at the Ingalls Shipbuilding Division plant of Litton Industries here.

PUTNAM, VALLEY, N.Y., May 11 The teaching of satire to seventh-grade pupils in the Putnam Valley Central School by the use of a phonograph record satirizing Roman Catholic beliefs and brotherhood has touched off an investigation by the Board of Education.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) Fifteen antiwar dem onstrators were carried from the Pentagon today for the second day in a row after they camped outside the ofces of the Joint Chiefs of Staff.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 1l (AP) A $l.5-million trebledamage antitrust suit has been filed in Federal District Court here against three manufacturers of fabricated metal products used in Vietnam.

Mr. and Mrs. Samuel Loeb of New York and Bellport, L.I., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Mason Ann Loeb, to Nahum Joel Waxman, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Waxman of Vineland, N.J., and St. Petersburg Beach, Fla.

NOW I know what they mean by behind the scenes," 11-year-old Douglas Birns said as he wielded a cherry pitter to remove the pits from wrinkled Italian olives. Douglas, a sixth-grader at the City and Country School, 165 West 12th Street, stayed after school on Wednesday to work in the kitchen.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 98.7 on Wednesday from 98.6 on Tuesday.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 11 A good natured George C. Wallace spoke at Princeton University tonight, quipping his way through boos, cheers, walkouts and the display of a Confederate battle flag.
Prices advanced yesterday on the American Stock Exchange amid increased volume.
CHERRY HILL, N.J., May 11 (UPI) Jacinto Vasquez rode five winners at Garden State Park today, including the victors in the first and second races to account for a daily double payoff of $37.20.
WASHINGTON, May 11 Total construction expenditures, seasonally adjusted, declined in March, the Commerce Department reported today.

ACCORDING to the Paris weekly, L'Express, Witold Gombrowicz, the Polish born novelist and playwright, is the latest "greatest unknown writer of our time." This can mean much or little; one wonder how many more "greatest unknown writers" still exist to be discovered, and how good they really are. From the evidence of these...

NEW ORLEANS, May 11 (UPI) The United States Court of Appeals for the Fifth District threw out two appeals today by Cassius Clay, designed to keep the Government from prosecuting the former heavyweight boxing champion for refusing to enter the Army.
ROME, May 11 (AP) The last American was eliminated as the seeded players swept into the quarter-finals today in the Italian tennis championships.
MOSCOW, May 11 (Reuters) Soviet soccer chiefs called today for a ban on the sale of liquor at Russian stadiums to stop growing hooliganism.

PLAINFIELD, N.J., May 11 Elliott Hilback of Morris County and Frank Hay of Colonia, both vice presidents with the Chevron Oil Company, today won the annual John Hickey booster tournament with a net better-ball 30, 36 66 at the Plainfield Country Club.

LONDON, May 11 George Brown, the Foreign Secretary, told Parliament today that the British High Commission in Allen needed a diplomat rather than a colonial administrator at its head because the international ramifications of the South Arabian issue were becoming increasingly important.

The Soviet Union's objections to the inspection provisions in the new draft treaty on nonproliferation suggest more interest in stirring Western disunity than in halting the spread of nuclear weapons.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 11 (AP) Graham Hill of London, last year's winner of the 500mile race, spun around completely in his Lotus-Ford for the second time in the northeast turn today, but also for the second time, neither he nor his car suffered injury or damage.

WASHINGTON, May 11 An American expert on air pollution today described as "peculiar" and not very convincing a statement yesterday discounting sulphur dioxide as a major cause of air pollution injury to human beings.
The yawning emptiness of the Jerome Park Reservoir slowly disappeared beneath a cascade of clear upstate water yesterday after a five-month scrubbing and refurnishing had cleaned it of debris.

WASHINGTON, May 11 The United States has recently renewed its effort to win North Vietham's'agreement to an exchange of prisoners of war but so far Hanol has shown no interest, United states officials said tonight.
Governor Rockefeller's desire to get the biggest possible sale of tickets for the new monthly state lottery has placed potential venders in the driver's seat.
British Government bonds declined yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
LAS VEGAS, Nev., May 11--Seven licensed Nevada casino operators were indicted by a Federal grand jury today on the tax evasion charge of "skimming."
PHILADELPHIA, May 11 (AP) Mike Ditka, one of the best tight ends in pro football, today signed his 1967 contract with the Philadelphia Eagles of the National Football League.
ROMA, Tex., May 11 A Mexican union joined today in the 11-month-old strike of United States farm workers in the Rio Grande Valley.

Data on the value of shipments for the women's apparel industry for 1966 and a portion of 1965 are being revised by the Bureau of the Census as a result of errors that have been discovered in the statistical process.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 11 (AP) The United Nations has announced that an agreement to enable landlocked countries to ship their goods freely to and from the sea will take effect June 9.
HANNIBAL, Mo., May 11 (AP) Rescuers were trying to decide today whether to drill or blast their way into a cave where three latter-day Tom Sawyers were believed to have been trapped by a cave-in.
Former King Peter II of Yugoslavia will be guest of honor at a military ball to be given tomorrow at the Biltmore by the Royal Club Kind Alexander I.
A rare occurence in sport, a challenge match for the world open championship is court tennis, will take place here in 1968, and for the first time on record, two amateurs will play for the title.

SANTO DOMINGO, Dominican Republic, May 11 (AP) Two members of the-Dominican Revolutionary party were found shot to death today in an automobile parked in an isolated area. Authorities said they feared another outbreak of terrorism.

A 38-year-old advertising man and mail order promoter was charged with 60 counts of mail fraud yesterday in connection with an advertising campaign for a fishing lure said to "broadcast irresistible messages" to fish.
Two-35-foot cargo containers, swept overboard recently from a containership, were still reported bobbing yesterday in the Gulf Stream waters off the South Carolina coast.
"Victoria and Albert," a new musical tracing the life of Britain's Queen Victoria, will be presented on Broadway next season by David Merrick.

Roy Innis, militant leader of the Harlem chapter of the Congress of Racial Equality, yesterday became the first civil rights fellow-in-residence of an organization that analyzes urban and civil rights problems.

A selective list of restaurants in New York and vicinity is given on this page on Friday. The restaurants are rated on the basis of four stars to none. Tte criterion is the food and service in relation to the cost of dining in any particular establishment.

FORT JACKSON, S.C., May 11--Defense counsel at the court-martial of Capt. Howard B. Levy made an impassioned attack today on the Uniform Code of Military Justice--the basis of military law--charging that it deprived all servicemen of the right of free speech.

William F. Buckley Jr.'s conservative journal of opinion. The National Review, has notified subscribers that it must discontinue publication unless they pledge gifts to meet its 1966 publishing deficit of $250,000.
Bob McIntyre, the fourthhighest scorer in the history of basketball at St. John's, signed yesterday, to play with the New York Freighters of the American Basketball Association.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 12 Vietcong gunners shelled the major United States airbase at Bienhoa, 16 miles northeast of Saigon, today with about 125 rounds of mortar, rocket and recoilless rifle fire.
The Macy's New York division of R. H. Macy Co. announced yesterday the appointment of Stanley E. Abelson as senior vice president.
PITTSBURGH, May 11 (AP) Bob Bruce pitched a threehitter tonight as the Atlanta Braves beat the Pittsburgh Pirates, 9-2.

DETROIT, May 11 Following are excerpts from a paper presented today at a meeting of the American Psychiatric Association by Dr. Seymour L. Halleck, director of student psychiatry at the University of Wisconsin:
Stock splits were proposed yesterday by Teledyne, Inc., the Franklin Stores Corporation, Esquire, Inc., and Ramada Inns, Inc.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The value of mortgages bought in the 1967 first quarter by the Federal National Mortgage Association (Fanny May) dropped to its lowest level in a year and a half because of easier credit conditions.

Two individuals and a corporation were acquitted yesterday in Federal Court of a fraud conspiracy involving the shipment of machinery to produce black market cigarettes six years ago in the Philippines.
WASHINGTON, May 11 The United States Forest Service has recommended that the Administration seek legislation to prevent the Kennecott Copper Company from mining in a wilderness area.

Representatives of interAmerican public agencies and private business wound up a two-day conference here yesterday and promised to seek greater coordination among themselves to accelerate the growth of business in Latin America.
There were none of the feathers, fans or flowers that mark the charity-ball look in the Plaza's Grand Ballroom last night.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 11 Secretary General Thant said today that he feared that "the initial phase of World War III" was being fought in Vietnam.

PHILADELPHIA, May 11 In a blinding, ear-splitting evening of music, light and gymnastics, the Young Men's/ Young Women's Hebrew Association last night opened an exhibition of artist-designed furniture and fashions.

An ombudsman empowered to investigate complaints that city offficials are rude, arrogant, inefficient of dishonest was called for yesterday in legislation filed by City Council President Frank D. O'Connor.

Mr. and Mrs. Ralph Treves of Jamaica Estates, Queens, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Treves, to William C. Lieblich, son of Louis Lieblich of San Diego, Calif., and the late Mrs. Lieblich. The wedding is planned for June 11 at the Forest Hills Inn in Queens.

Three hundred twenty-one faculty members from Columbia University sent a letter to President Johnson yesterday urging the United States to halt the bombing of North Vietnam as one step "to extricate the nation from a detestable war."

EVANSTON, Ill., May 11 John M. Will, a retired Navy admiral, who is the chairman of American Export Isbrandtsen Lines, gave a group of transportation management men a primer today on what the Federal maritime policy debate was all about.

BUENOS AIRES, May 11 (UPI) Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon voiced hearty approval of Argentina's military Government today. He said President Juan Carlos Ongania "is one of the best leaders I have known."

NEW HAVEN, May 11 Kingman Brewster Jr., the president of Yale University proposed today that the Federal Government finance the college education of any student who would agree to pay a lifetime surcharge on his income tax.

DALLAS, May 11 (UPI) Jo Ann Prentice and Shirley Englehorn slashed four strokes from par with 33, 34 67's today to take a two-stroke lead in the first round of the $16,000 Dallas Civitan open golf tournament.

HAMILTON, Bermuda, May 11 (AP) Dalliance, a yacht out of Stonington, Conn., won her second straight race in the Class C world catamaran sailing championships today but lost the next race in the series and was tied for the over-all lead by Britain's Lady Helmsman.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 11 Ninteen students at Radcliffe College, the women's division of Harvard College, began a hunger strike today to protest a system for selecting seniors who will be allowed to live in their own apartments off campus next year.

The Liberal party urged Governor Rockefeller yesterday to call a special session of the Legislature to carry out a Federal Court order calling for reapportionment of the state's Congressional districts.

The American Radiator and Standard Sanitary Corp. purchased about 46 per cent of the Mosler Safe Company stock yesterday from members of the Mosler family and other interests. American Standard also has offered to buy all the rest of the 2,249,563 outstanding shares.
On or about Aug. 1, Chinatown's commercial banking institutions will be increased by one, when the Chinese American Bank opens for business at 225 Park Row, capitalized at $1.5-million.

ROME, May 11 Pope Paul VI, after leaving the Shrine of the Madonna at Fatima, Portugal, on Saturday, will visit a historic church that was dedicated to a battle victory in the 14th century, according to his schedule published today by the Vatican.

BRUSSELS, May 11 Sir James Marjoribanks walked into Room 610 of the Palais des Congres in downtown Brussels this morning with a short letter applying for Britain's membership on the Common Market. It was the second British effort in six years to join the European Economic Community.

The nation's first "design-in" was born yesterday on the Central Park Mall, amid such symbols of the future metropolis as a geodesic dome, electric cars, an air-supported edifice and a playground device of nylon ropes, rubber tires and pipes called a "jiggle structure."
Federal Reserve figures issues yesterday once again proved that one week does not make a trend.
The City and Country School will hold its 29th annual spring fair tonight to benefit its scholarship fund.

A 14-story apartment house and an adjoining three-story office building nearing completion in Fort Lee, N.J., has been purchased and leased back to the sellers by the Investors Funding Corporation of New York. The development, known as Le Cross House, is on a 34,000-square-foot-site at 201 Cross Street in the George Washington Bridge Plaza.
Frank E. Keener, who founded and ran the Antrim Lodge in Roscoe, N.Y., died yesterday at the Maimonides Hospital in Liberty, N.Y. He was 77 years old.

MOSCOW, May 11 Soviet University students today are in a mood similar to that of America's "silent generation" of the late fifties. They are more concerned with their studies, their personal careers and economic betterment than with debates of national and international policies.

ENGLEWOOD, N.J., May 11 Miss Barbara Joan Winograd and Lowell David Fishman will be married June 18. The couple's engagement has been made known by the future bride's parents, Mr. and Mrs. Oscar Winograd. The bridegroom-tobe is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Fishman of Rego Park, Queens, New York.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) Senator John L. MeClellan, Democrat of Arkansas, predicted today the Pentagon would pay up to $12-billion to get 1,300 F-111 planes in the air. This is double the cost officials of the Department of Defense once estimated for 1,700 of the controversial aircraft.

A new independent report on New York's municipal hospitals cites an estimate by Dr. George James, a former Health Commissioner here, that in a recent year 13,000 deaths in the city's low-income areas could have been avoided if the patients had 'been given "middle-class medical care."
BOSTON, May 11 (AP) Tony Conigliaro, the Boston Red Sox outfielder, joined an Army active, reserve unit today under a Defense Department edict to join up or face fulltime active duty.
WASHINGTON, May 11--A House Appropriations subcommittee has tentatively agreed to Southern demands for Congressional curbs on school desegregation guidelines.

BELLEVILLE, N.J., May 11 Edward J. Lister, who retired in 1964 after serving as recreational director here for 25 years, died yesterday at the East Orange Veterans Hospital. He was 75 years old and lived at 93 Union Avenue.
PEKING, May 11 (Reuters) Fighting and disputes among rival Cultural Revolution organizations in Peking appeared today to be increasing despite appeals for order and discipline.
LONDON, May 11 (UPI) The following exchange took place in the House of Commons today.
DDT has been found in the tissues of wildlife in a Long Island marsh in amounts that "occasionally reach acutely lethal levels in both birds and fish," three scientists reported yesterday.

The Greatamerica Corporation, a bank and insurance holding company, is making a tender offer to purchase a maximum of 3.56 million shares of the Glidden Company's stock at $30 a share, it was announced yesterday. This would involve $106.8-million if all the shares are tendered.
The Museum of Modern Art has found a new director.

Wheat traders took note yesterday of the latest Government crop report predicting 1,195,000,000 bushels of winter wheat this year and did some buying. Later in the day they had an even more bullish report as a base for further purchases, sending prices up.
BOATING'S version of Con Edison's "dig we must" is about to be resumed in the still-shallow waters of Little Neck Bay, Queens.

MAPLEWOOD, N.J., May 11 Ron Refiner of Fairmount and Mrs. Jane Simson put together a 32, 36 68 in a drenching downpour today to win a state Professional Golfers' Association pro-woman tournament at the Maplewood Country Club.
ELIZABETH, N.J., May 11 James E. MeGrath, a retired steeplechase jockey who had lived here, died at his home yesterday in Arcadia, Calif. He was 59 years old.
SPRINGFIELD, N.J., May 11 Frank S. Malm, who had been a chemical engineer and research chemist for the Bell Laboratories, died today in his home here at 31 Forest Drive. He was 81 years old.
A consumer group accused the food industry here yesterday of widespread overcharging, short-weighting, questionable advertising and "other deceitful practices."

Secretary General Thant of the United Nations is convinced that a direct confrontation between the United States and China is inevitable if the present course of the Vietnam war continues. And once again he says that the only hope of reversing the current trend toward a possible World War III is to halt the bombing of North Vietnam.

NEW ORLEANS, May 11 Frank Beard and Gardner Dickinson, who finished one, two in the tournament here a year ago, scored 68's today to share the opening-round lead in the $100,000 Greater New Orleans open. Knight, Race Car Driver, Dies
The Rheingold Corporation announced yesterday the election of Edgar M. Bronfman and Philip H. Milner as directors, increasing the board to seven.

HANOVER, N.H., May 11 Dartmouth College students who admit they "overtly" participated in the disturbances surrounding the May 3 visit to the campus by former Alabama Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama will be suspended "conditionally" at the end of this semester, it was announced tonight.

THE man who had the most profound effect on the coaching career of Vince Lombardi, the colossus of Green Bay, was Col. Earl (Red) Blaik of West Point. It was under the brilliant redhead that Vince learned his trade during six formative years as an assistant Army coach. It also was on the Plains that the two developed a mutual affection that has never faded. Perhaps it has even grown in intensity.

LONDON, May 11 Queen Elizabeth has invited the Duke and Duchess of Windsor to attend the unveiling of a plaque in memory of Queen Mary, the Duke's mother and the Queen's grandmother, in London June 7.
Manhattan residents unhappy with the quality of their television picture will have to wait many months and possibly years before cables can be installed to improve reception.

The Civil Aeronautics Board may add a number of Eastern, Middle Western and Western cities as co-terminals on Seaboard World Airline's trans-Atlantic cargo service to European airports. It may also permit Seaboard to carry domestic cargo between United States terminal points on through flights to or from Europe.

PENN YAN, N.Y., May 11 Senator Jacob K. Javits accused Democrats and Richard M. Nixon today of a "ploy" to split moderate Republicans by mentioning Governor Rockefeller as a possible Presidential candidate in 1968.

The estate of Harvey E. Sampson Sr., has been negotiating for several weeks with a private investors' group represented by Burnham Co. for the sale of about 350,000 shares of Harvey common stock, it was announced yesterday.
LONDON, May 11 Britain reported today that her trade deficit widened again in April and that the high level of exports achieved late last year had not been sustained.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 11 (AP)--Dean Chance fired a one-hitter, a single by Danny Cater in the fourth inning, at the Kansas City A's tonight as the Minnesota Twins scored an 8-0 victory.
JERUSALEM (Israel), May 11 Premier Levi Eshkol warned today that Israel would not hesitate to use air power in response to continued border terrorism.

HONG KONG, May 11--Rioting encouraged by sympathizers of Communist China was renewed in Hong Kong today and continued sporadically into the night despite a partial curfew. Police squads in steel helmets arrested 90 persons.
The widow of a slain bookmaker won the legal right yesterday to sue the convicted slayer, the son of a millionaire, for money damages because of the mental anguish she suffered.
CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) Attorney General William G. Clark of Illinois announced today that the state had accepted a stipulated settlement of a Great Lakes water diversion suit.

New York State is now selling the names and addresses of 6,400,000 motor vehicle owners to a marketing service. This is all duly legal it was authorized by the Legislature in 1959 under section 202 of the Vehicle and Traffic Law and it will net the state some $86,000, which will be a great help in balancing its $4-billion budget.

The Administration's optimism about the state of the economy seems premature. It had hailed the sizable gain in retail sales in March as evidence that the adjustment in business activity was confined to the first two months of the year. Now it turns out that March sales were overestimated, while the preliminary figures for April showed a slight drop.
The rally in the stock market, now about four weeks old, resumed its upward march yesterday after two consecutive sessions of sinking prices.
PARIS, May 10 The United States has suggested two new approaches toward bolstering the exposed northern and southern flanks of the Atlantic alliance in a crisis situation.

ROME, May 11 (Reuters) The Italian Ambassador in Washington, Vergio Fenoaltea, handed in his resignation following Foreign Minister Amintore Fanfani's criticism of United States bombing in Vietnam, the Foreign Ministry said today.

WASHINGTON, May 11 The American destroyer Walker was scraped today for the second time in two days by a Soviet destroyer in the Sea of Japan. The United States immediately called upon the Soviet Union to take prompt steps to halt "harassment" of American naval vessels.

CHICAGO, May 11 (AP) Milk truck drivers, whose combination strike-lockout earlier this month left Chicago with a two-day milk crisis, voted today to reject a contract arbitrated May 3 by Mayor Richard J. Daley.

An international chemical company was pictured yesterday as having had its metered Brooklyn water bills "understated by over $40,000" in four years and apparently engaging in "alleged improper payments to city officials."
NEW DELHI, May 11 India at home presents a picture dramatically different from India at the United Nations or India in the capitals of the world.

OLD GREENWICH, Conn., May, 11 Dr. and Mrs. John F. Noonan have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Barbara. Anne Noonan, to Raymond Edwards Gordon Jr., son of Mrs. Ruth McGlynn of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., and Mr. Gordon of Marshalls Creek, Pa. An August wedding is planned.
ISAAC STERN was soloist with the New York Phil harmonic in Bartok's Violin Concerto No. 2 last night at Philharmonic Hall, and he didn't allow the orchestra a moment's rest all the way through.

There is apparently no reform of Congressional operations and procedure so modest that it will not encounter stubborn opposition from the defenders of the status quo. The Monroney-Madden reorganization bill, which passed the Senate earlier this year, is a mild measure that does not touch the seniority system, the filibuster, the "in Tuesday and out Thursday" club in the House, or any of the other serious problems that require reform.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 11 Officials of Roosevelt Raceway held an Alibi Breakfast today at nearby Island Inn in preparation for the $178,064.79 Messenger Stakes, the world's richest harness race, set for Saturday night.
BALTIMORE, May 11 About 130 striking teachers, members of the American Federation of Teacher, were arrested here today for defying a court order against picketing public schools.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 11 Following are the texts of a statement read today by Secretary General Thant at a luncheon of the United Nations Correspondents Association and of a reply issued by Arthur J. Goldberg, the United Nations representative:

PRINCETON, N.J., May 11 Announcement has been made by Mr. and Mrs. Alexander Leitch of the engagement of their daughter, Miss Margaret Lancaster Leitch, to Robert Keane Copeland, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack Greene Copeland Jr. of Westtown, Pa.
The 700 laborers and truck drivers who work in the sewer division of the city's Department of Public Works went on strike last night in a dispute with the city over the elimination of 75 jobs.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 11 A special Syrian military tribunal handed down sentences of life imprisonment at hard labor today to three Army officers involved in the publication Of an article attacking religion.
John Fischer, editor in chief of Harper's magazine for 14 years, will resign his post effective July 1 to devote more time to his own writing.

The United States Court of Appeals has ruled here that the Chemical Fund is not obligated to account to the Xerox Corporation for a profit of $153,972 from the sale of part of its investment in Xerox.
St. Paul, Minn. Jim Beattie, St. Paul, outpointed Dick Wipperman, Cheektowaga, N.Y., 10 rounds, heavyweights.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) Representative Richard S. Schweiker, Republican of Pennsylvania, said today it was likely that the Defense Department would bring a battleship out of mothballs for duty in Vietnam. The Pentagon, however, denied that a decision had been made.
WASHINGTON, May 11--The Office of Economic Opportunity has decided to grant $399,967 to an Alabama cooperative of Negro farmers despite the opposition of the state's concerted political power.

MEXICO CITY, May 11 (UPI) The confirmed death toll in a heat wave in most of Mexico passed 70 today. All the victims were young children killed by dehydration, many of them in water-poor slum districts in northern desert cities.
CAPETOWN, May 11 South Africa's President-elect, Dr. Theophilus Ebenhaezer Donges, was said to be in "very serious" condition today after having suffered a brain hemorrhage.

PARIS If a medieval Moorish king died on the eve of battle, retainers would dress his stiffened corpse, bind it astride a warhorse, and lead it against the enemy to encourage the troops. The system worked well and was adopted by the Spaniards when El Cid fought the Moors.

The 750 commercial and editorial workers who lost their jobs with the closing of The World Journal Tribune last week have been asked to apply for more than, 1,500 jobs, ranging from hourly-paid messengers to a $50,000-a-year vice presidency at a book publisher.
COLUMBIA, S.C., May 11 (UPI) The weeklong student revolt at Allen University was apparently ended tonight by an appeal to students from the man whose resignation had started it all.
JAMESTOWN N.Y., May l1 "Next to getting re-elected," Nelson Rockefeller said with a wry smile, "this is going to be the toughest campaign I've ever been in."

TOKYO, May 11 (Reuters) Japan's gold and foreign exchange reserves amounted to $2.092-billion at the end of April, the Ministry of Finance announced. This was an increase of $15-million from the level of the preceding month.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 12 Premier Nguyen Cao Ky told his Cabinet at a private meeting today that he would run for President in the election Sept. 3.

At Lincoln Center today: New York Philharmonic, Philharmonic Hall, 2:15 P.M.; Hugh Masekela, program of African music, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30; Gabriel Banat, violinist, and Mario Miranda, pianist, Library and Museum of Performing Arts, 6:30, admission free.

Capt. George Sahlberg and the crew of the tugboat Julia Moran are the recipients of the annual Tradition of the Sea Award, Gerard M. McAllister, chairman of the awards committee of the international section of the New York Board of Trade, has announced.
AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 11 The cadences of Sousa's "Washington Post March" and a prancing group of Dutch drum majorettes opened the 1967 international stamp show, Amphilex 67, today.
Industry in the United States will spend $16.6-billion for research and development this year, a figure double that of 10 years ago, McGraw-Hill, Inc., reported yesterday.
A woman State Supreme Court justice dismissed a yestitute husband's attempt yesterday to obtain alimony from his employed wife.
WASHINGTON, May 11 The American Merchant Marine Institute urged Congress this week to approve 23 requests for navigational improvements at a cost of $56.9-million during the coming fiscal year.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (AP) The chief spokesman for six rail shopcraft unions denounced today President Johnson's legislative proposal to avert a threatened nationwide railroad strike.

THE 1967 Championship of the National Industrial Recreational Association was won by a pair from Waterbury, Conn. In the finals held in Chicago last month, Tom and Irene Chapman, representing' the Scovill Manufacturing Company, headed a field of 24 pairs who had qualified from tonal tournaments throughout North America.
CHICAGO, May 11 Montgomery Ward Co. today reported sharply lower earnings for the first quarter, which ended May 3. Sales were down slightly.
MIAMI, May 11 (AP) Populous Dade County (Miami) and 20 others in the middle and southern part of Florida became eligible for emergency loans yesterday because of a threemonth drought.
Bernard D'Essen, who with his wife, Lorrain, built an organization that provides animals for opera, television and the stage, died Tuesday at his home, 331 West 18th Street. He was 52 years old.

WASHINGTON, May 11 The world spends little time these days complimenting the United States on any aspect of its foreign policy, but, before the distracting tumult of Vietnam overwhelms everything else, something should be said for Washington's long and steadfast efforts to encourage the unification of Europe.

Mrs. Ruth Tabacksblatt Kirschenbaum Shafran, a former dramatic soprano in operatic and concert roles here and in Europe, died Wednesday at the Mount Eden Hospital in the Bronx. Her age was 68, and she lived at 2076 Honeywell Avenue in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 11 Authorities in Yemen have been preventing American diplomats there from retrieving classified documents from the damaged American aid mission headquarters, United States officials reported today.
JAMES JOYCE once said, when taxed with the dif ficulty of his works, that he had spent a lifetime at them and expected his readers to do the same.

After a 15-month absence, Woody Allen, boy philosopher ("Is knowledge knowable? If not, how do we know it?") and self-described sportsman and spoiler of women, is back performing in a New York nightclub, the Americana Hotel's Royal Box, for a base salary of $9,000 a week plus a percentage of the gross.
At the end of the nurseryschool year a little girl named Lucy waited her turn in a special program for parents. For a long time she had attended therapy sessions at a Greater New York Fund agen

DETROIT, May 11 A Wisconsin psychiatrist said here today that the growing problem of alienated students who talk about being "washed up" at 25, take drugs or smoke pot and seem bored, apathetic and unhappy might be lessened if students had more genuine contacts with adults.

WASHINGTON, May 11 Intercity truck tonnage and revenue freight traffic generated by carloadings on United States 'railroads in the week ended May 6 were both below the volume of the corresponding week of 1966.

LOUISVILLE, K. May 11 (UPI) One of the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr's top aides led an open housing march through the predominantly white south end tonight and convinced two white teenaged girls to join the demonstration.

The Buildings Committee of the City Council voted yesterday to exempt one and twofamily homes occupied by their owners from periodic inspections by the Buildings Department, a move that could jeopardize Federal housing aid to the city.
WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) A Federal judge ruled today that Government officials who write and deliver speeches on their own time can copyright them.
LONDON, May 11 (UPI) Britain's Conservatives dealt another serious blow to the prestige of the governing Labor party today in elections for control of urban boroughs in England and Wales.
THE Boston electronic and nuclear research company EG, Inc., marketed $10million of 3 per cent convertible debentures yesterday and they went like hot cakes.

BRUSSELS, May 11 Ministers of the European Common Market took a relatively tough line today against the United States, the Scandinavian countries and Britain in their final deliberations over world trade liberalization.

DUMONT, N.J., May 11 Barton S. MeConaty, who had been a chauffeur for the late Bernard M. Baruch, the financier, philanthropist and adviser to Presidents, died today at his home here at 360 East Madison Avenue. He was 91 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 11 Most of the economic strain imposed by the war in Vietnam "is now behind us," a high Government economic official said today.

WASHINGTON, May 11 (UPI) The Pharmaceutical Manufacturers Association charged today that a Food and Drug Administration survey last June on drug potency was inaccurate and asked the agency to "repudiate the survey outright."

GUATEMALA, May 11 (AP) Fingerprints of an aged man with "foreign physical features," arrested in the Guatemalan countryside while working as a peasant, have been sent to Germany after reports that he might be Hitler's missing deputy, Martin Bormann, it was announced tonight.
The City Planning Commission ended its public hearing on the projected World Trade Center yesterday and indicated it would expedite action on the $575-million project.

The Real Estate Board of New York, Inc., has voted to take legal action to try to block enforcement on May 20 of city regulations requiring the upgrading of apartment-house incinerators. The city rules are intended to curb air pollution.

TOKYO, May 11 Willy Brandt, the Vice Chancellor and Foreign Minister of West Germany, expressed confidence today that the United States and the Soviet Union would agree to a "reasonable" treaty to halt the spread of nuclear weapons.

JACKSON, Miss., May 11 National Guardsmen, carrying carbines with fixed bayonets and led by three armored cars, took over the campus of the Jackson State College for Negroes tonight and imposed virtual martial law in the downtown section.

ATHENS, May 11 A 14year-old Tarrytown, N.Y., girl, Susan Osgood Farrell, has written Greece's Interior Minister that by banning miniskirts and Beatle haircuts he has insulted the memory of the Greek gods, and goddesses, who wore few clothes and lots of hair.
The world champion Baltimore Orioles, surrounded by trouble and standing ninth in the American League, will make their first appearance of the baseball season in New York tonight.

The Citizens Union celebrated its 70th anniversary last night with a dinner at the Roosevelt Hotel at which the former Parks Commissioner, Thomas P.F. Moving, received the organization's award for outstanding public service.

HARTSDALE, N.Y., May 11 Mrs. Joseph A. Nesbitt of the Westchester Country Club carded 46, 43 89 at the Scarsdale Golf Club today for a 2stroke victory in a Women's Westchester and Fairfield Golf Association one-day tournament.
PARIS, May 11 David Galula, a former French Army officer and an expert on counterinsurgency warfare, died today in Arpajon, near Paris. He was 48 years old.
STOCKTON, Calif., May 11 Three Senators on a poverty investigating mission looked critically today at California, migrants' housing. Their reac tions ranged from pleasure to shock and disbelief.

ALBANY, May 11 Charles A. Schoeneck Jr., a Syracuse lawyer who lost his Assembly seat as a result of his supporting Governor Rockefeller's fiscal program eight years ago, was designated today to be the Republican state chairman.
No progress was reported yesterday in negotiations to end a strike of 700 city sewer workers that began Thursday night.
WASHINGTON, May 12 Industrial production resumed its moderate decline in April, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.

President Johnson's excellent proposal for a quasipublic corporation to spark the development of noncommercial television has cleared its first hurdle with its approval by the Senate Commerce Committee. If progress through the full Senate and the House is swift, as it should be, the new body can begin addressing itself this year to the basic issues on which depend the future of public television.
LONDON, May 12 (Reuters) China plans to airlift $137million worth of gold from London to Shanghai. The London Times reported today.

DETROIT, May 12 The philosophy of "black power" in the Southern civil rights movement grew largely out of the Negro's resentment and sexual jealousy of white civil rights workers, a Negro psychiatrist said here today.

LONDON, May 12 Dr. John Kenneth Galbraith, the economist, advised British students of the United States today not to confuse what America says with what America does.

FORT JACKSON, Miss., May 12 The chief accuser of Capt. Howard Brett Levy told a general court-martial today that the young dermatologist from Brooklyn had refused, on the ground of medical ethics, to train aidsmen of the Green Berets in the treatment of skin diseases in Vietnam.
ALBANY, May 12 "New approaches" to public welfare will be sought at a top-level conference of business and labor leaders at Arden House next Nov. 2 and 3, Governor Rockefeller announced today.
Marc B. Rojtman, founder and former president of the American Tractor Company, died of cancer yesterday at his home, 22 East 64th Street. He was 49 years old.
Rutgers and Army are the teams to beat today in major track and field championships.

MELBOURNE, Australia, May 12 (Reuters) The syndicate backing Dame Pattie, the Australia challenger in the America's Cup yacht race, is considering offers of three yachts, two British and one American, to serve as trial horses in training in American waters.

MIZUSHIMA, Japan, May 12 Prospects for the export of steel products are not bright this year. The industry puts its estimate at about 10 million tons, or about the same as last year.

NEW, ORLEANS, May 12 George Knudson of Toronto found the hot weather no deterrent today as he scored a 66 and assumed the lead in the $100,000 Greater New Orleans open golf tournament. With the temperature 88 degrees, the 29-year-old Canadian brought his 36-hole aggregate to 137 for a stroke margin.
A three-part benefit will be held Tuesday evening for the Children's Health Service, of which Mrs. Helen C. Morgan is president.
Bond prices rose again yesterday, forcing down interest rates for the third straight day. The late-week rally, however, could not erase declines of long-term issues on Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday.
Four Yale University drama students must stand trial on charges of desecrating an American flag during the performance of a play in a drama workshop on the East Side.
PARIS, May 12 France's two biggest privately owned aircraft companies Marcel Dassault and Breguet are planning to merge, under Government pressure.
