PASADENA, Calif., May 12 Lunar Orbiter 4, entering its ninth orbit today, continued returning clear photos of the moon's south polar region.

MONTREAL, May 12--No one seems to have noticed it internationally yet, but the World Festival in Montreal, associated with Expo 67, is going to be a fantastic parade of the world's performing artists.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 12 (UPI) Mario Andretti, the national driving champion, roared around the Indianapolis Motor Speedway track at an unofficial season-record speed of 168.382 miles an hour today on the last day of practice before time trials open for the 500-mile race on Memorial Day. Andretti, driving a Brabham-Brawner- Ford beat the unofficial track mark of 168.2 that he set last year.
The wholesale commodity price index rose to 98.8 on Thursday from 98.7 on Wednesday.

CHICAGO, May 12 (AP)--Downing B. Jenks, president of the Missouri Pacific Railroad, was elected president of the Chicago Eastern Illinois Railroad today as the Mopac assumed control of the latter road.
DANANG, South Vietnam, May 12 A North Vietnamese missile believed to be emplaced just north of the demilitarized zone brought down an A-4 fighter-bomber Wednesday night, Marine sources said today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 12 (AP)--The United States decorated a South Vietnamese general for gallantry in action today.
BOMBAY, India Thanks to a shortage of land and a sur plus of "black," this most cosmopolitan of Indian cities is developing the country's first modern skyline.

HANNIBAL, Mo., May 12 The search for three boys missing since Wednesday in Tom Sawyer cave country widened today.

Cowles Communications, Inc., has announced the election of Merrill H. Clough, Gilbert C. Maurer and Thomas R. Shepard Jr. to its board.

ATLANTA, May 12 Stokely Carmichael, a leading exponent of black power, was succeeded today as the chairman of the Student Nonviolent Coordinating Committee by H. Rap Brown, the organization's Alabama state director.

A group of hospital administrators, who think the current emphasis on college-based nurses' training is harmful to hospital diploma programs, lost out yesterday in an effort to have the National League for Nursing give equal recognition to the hospital programs.

The State Department is leaning over backward in its efforts to interpret the two Soviet collisions with an American destroyer near Japan as having no relationship to the Vietnam war. Whether Moscow will play along with this view is another question.
Prices dipped on the London Stock Exchange yesterday, reflecting in part April's disappointing foreign trade figures.
CARACAS, Venezuela, May 12 The Government announced tonight that it had intercepted a 12-man guerrilla landing force led by officers of the Cuban Army. The leader of the party was reported killed.

GENEVA, May 12 A Kennedy round package Sunday night appeared almost certain today as the chief negotiators for the world's major trading nations made further progress in narrowing their differences.
CANNES, France, May 12 As predicted, Michelangelo Antonioni's "Blow-Up" won the top prize today at the 20th Cannes Film Festival.

Bernard (Toots) Shor, the restaurateur, was arrested early yesterday along with a bartender and a headwaiter at his restaurant on charges of felonious assault in connection with an alleged attack on a patron.

City Finance Commissioner Roy M. Goodman is convinced that licensing the 40,000 retailers who sell cigarettes in this city is necessary to check contraband cigarettes, smuggled in to evade the payment of city and state taxes that together add sixteen cents to the cost of every pack.

LONDON, May 12 John Masefield, Poet Laureate of England since 1930, died at his Berkshire home today. He was 88 years old.

Jim Palmer pitched a practically perfect game, a onehitter in which he faced only 27 batters, as the Baltimore Orioles humiliated the New York Yankees, 14-0, before a crowd of 22,300 at Yankee Stadium last night.

An hour-long demonstration in support of naming Dr. Elliott Shapiro, a Harlem principal, as the superintendent of a school district in lower Manhattan was held in front of his school yesterday by 40 teachers, parents and students.

Piping Rock virtually clinched its district title yesterday as the fourth round of the Women's Metropolitan Golf Association's interclub team matches were completed.

New York State is negotiating with an advertising agency and a public relations concern to promote its coming lottery.

But the composer is not afraid to build up to planned pandemonium if his fanciful ideas lead in that direction.

ARMONK, N.Y., May 14-- Richard Stockton Jr. of Garden City, L.I., a sophomore at Hackley School, Tarrytown, N.Y., won the 34th annual Westchester County amateur tennis championship today at the Armonk Tennis Club.

Nine high school seniors will vie this week for $10,000 in college scholarships on the National Broadcasting Company's "Jeopardy" program. They were chosen from hundreds of top students around the country whose names had been submitted by their principals. The daytime program, which normally has adults as contestants, is produced by Merv Griffin Productions. On "Jeopardy" participants are given answers and must make up suitable questions for them.
ATHENS, May 18--Sweeping but vaguely defined changes in Greek education are being prepared by the military junta that seized power last month.
PITTSBURGH, May 14 (AP) --Roberto Clemente rapped three hits, scored twice on singles by Bill Mazeroski and batted in a third run today as the Pittsburgh Pirates trimmed the Atlanta Braves, 5-2.

FLAGSTAFF, Ariz., May 14 --The establishment of a branch campus of Arizona State University at the planned city of Litchfield Park was approved yesterday by the Arizona Board of Regents following its acceptance of a gift of 525 acres of land in that area from the Goodyear Tire Rubber Company.
THREE major furniture manufacturers have set out to breathe new life into mass-produced furniture.
Many insurance men have long cautioned drivers against tailgating ambulances because of the added danger of running down lawyers.

MOUNT VERNON, N.Y., May 14--Miss Leslie Ellen Raissman, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Jerome Raissman, was married today to Samson J. Wellbaum, son of Mrs. Georges Bernique of Hollywood, Calif. Cantor Paul Silberscher performed the ceremony in his study at the Free Synagogue of Westchester.

WASHINGTON, May 14-- Secretary of labor W. Willard Wirtz ordered today that the Federal Government refuse all bids from contractors who have failed to certify against racial discrimination in their facilities.
LOS ALTOS, Calif., May 14 (UPI)--Mark Spitz, a 16-yearold swimmer from Santa Clara High School, broke two national records yesterday during a meet at Foothill College.
ST. LOUIS, May 14--The New York Mets defeated Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals today for the first time since 1964, and they did it on the strong right arm of Jack Fisher.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 14--American pilots reported shooting down three MIG's in dogfights near Hanoi today, for a total of 10 in the last two days.
Alexander Davidson Jr., librarian of the Grolier Club and before 1959 a rare-book dealer specializing in Americana, died after a stroke Saturday in his home, at 164 East 72d Street. His age was 56.
Dr. Sol Hirsch, a specialist in medicine and nutrition, died yesterday in his home, 750 Grand Concourse, the Bronx. His age was 76 and his office was at 910 Grand Concourse.
A new Roman Catholic Church of the Epiphany has been built over the ruins of its former building, destroyed by fire three years ago.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 14--Thomas J. Watson Jr.'s Palawan won the opening race of the Indian Harbor Yacht Club's annual four-part season series for cruising yachts on Long Island Sound today. The races are held for the Whitmore Trophy.
New York State, which does not permit its state police to hold other jobs, now tells New York City to let its city police moonlight.
Mayor Lindsay has proclaimed this week as American Merchant Marine Book Week as part of the American Merchant Marine Library Association's annual book drive.

Dr. Fager, the winner of the Withers Mile at Aqueduct on Saturday, will not run in next Saturday's $150,000added Preakness at Pimlico, Johnny Nerud, the 3-year-old colt's trainer, announced yesterday.
PACIFIC PALISADES, Calif., May 14--Miss Diantha Darling Cushman and George Chester Harrington plan to be married July 22.

INDIANAPOLIS, May 14-- Mist and fog and a drizzling rain put off the second day of qualifying for the 500-mile race here on Memorial Day. Not one car got onto the track, to the disappointment of the management as well as a crowd of 50,000 hardy souls who showed up despite the wet overhead and the mud underfoot.
Warehousing facilities, once in plentiful supply in Manhattan, are becoming increasingly scarce.

THE literary question this morning, fellers, gals and colleagues all, is: Is dazzlement enough? That is: Is the brilliant display of verbal pyrotechnics alone enough to sustain even the most hopefully empathetic concern with the art of the novel? All this comes under the heading, Whither Goest Fiction?, and subheading, Spoofs, plotless.
Eleven firemen were injured last night by a gas explosion in a four alarm fire that destroyed a clothing store at 985 Southern Boulevard, near Aldus Street, in the Bronx.

Knickerbocker Hospital announced yesterday that Edward J. Quirin has been selected as its new president. Mr. Quirin is president and chairman of the board of Frederic B. Harris, Inc., engineering consultants.

Charles S. Raizen, one of the country's major toy manufacturers, died Saturday night while attending a charity dinner at the Plaza Hotel. He was 74 years old and lived at 309 Beechmont Drive in New Rochelle, N.Y.

Bonnie Hampton, a cellist with extensive performing credits on the West Coast (and at the Marlboro festivals in Vermont), made her debut here late yesterday afternoon at the Carnegie Recital Hall. Her partner was Nathan Schwartz, a pianist who has toured with Russell Oberlin, Joseph Schuster and other notable soloists and teaches at the University of California's music-extension division.
WASHINGTON, May 14-- Former Gov. George C. Wallace of Alabama wound up a fiveday campaign tour of the East today.
MONTREAL, May 14--Two imaginative pavilions dedicated to contemporary religious thinkinging have proved popular with visitors at Expo 67. One of them has stirred sharp controversy.
TEHERAN, Iran, May 14 (AP)--Premier Amir Abbas Hoveida denounced "so-called foreign experts and advisers" today for underestimating the "will and power" of Iranians to redevelop their country.
WHITE PLAINS, May 14-- Seventy four Democratic city committeemen from seven Westchester communities have signed petitions opposing the Administration's conduct of the Vietnam War.
Mrs. Gisela Kahn Gresser of New York City, the defending women's chess champion, won the United States title yesterday in competition at the Henry Hudson Hotel.

Dr. Charles J. Gubitose, a staff member of the Veterans Administration Hospital in the Bronx, died on Saturday at his home at 19 Meadow Avenue, Bronxville, N.Y. He was 61 years old. Dr. Gubitose was also on the surgical staffs of Fordham, Misericordia and Union Hospitals in the Bronx.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP) --Sonny Siebert allowed only two hits--one of them a homer by Frank Howard--in pitching the Cleveland Indians to a 2-1 victory over the Washington Senators today in a game shortened to five ipnings because of rain.
WASHINGTON, May 14 (UPI)--Gen. Lewis W. Walt, United States Marine, commander in Vietnam, said today that more troops would guarantee a quicker and more lasting victory in Vietnam.

MOSCOW--Dining out in Moscow can be an educational experience. The cuisine may lag considerably behind that of Paris, but there is always superb caviar, fine bread, a good sturgeon in aspic and, of course, MOSCOW borscht made with meat stock.

The Ford Foundation has made a grant of $434,000 to establish a Negro Ensemble Company here next season. The company, whose organization began late in 1965, will combine a professional theater and workshop.
FARMINGTON, Conn., May 14--Gone Flyin' kept his perfect record for the year intact today when he rallied in the final class to win the open jumper championship at the Children's Services horse show.
MOSCOW, May 14--The Soviet Union is working on plans for an enormous drilling rig to pierce the earth's crust to a depth of 10 miles or more.
BUFFALO, May 14 (UP)-- Buffalo's 1,250 uniformed firemen voted tonight to postpone indefinitely a "sick walkout" planned for Tuesday morning.
A LIVELY morning was spent by 17 youngsters Saturday in the graveyard of one of the oldest churches in New York.

Sanitation Commissioner Samuel J. Kearing Jr. said yesterday that his department would be unable to handle added garbage collections from 90 per cent of the buildings that will be allowed to cease operation of their incinerators next Saturday.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14 --Mr. and Mrs. Walter W. Hoffmann have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Hoffmann, to J. Nelson Happy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Jack M. Happy of Lawrence, Kan. The wedding will take place next month at the Riverside Church in New York.
NEW ORLEANS, May 14-- George Knudson of Toronto, who caddied on the tour 10 years ago to find out "what it was all about," carded a 70 today to win the Greater New Orleans open by one stroke.
The City Civil Service Commission has proposed revoking a regulation that automatically bars persons convicted of petit larceny from becoming eligible for jobs as policemen or firemen.
At a dinner dance in the Americana Hotel's Imperial Ballroom Friday night, the American Television Commercials Festival rewarded the 1966 creative efforts of the advertising industry.

CHICAGO, May 14 (UPI) --Christian Century, a leading ecumenical Protestant weekly took to task the Rev. Billy Graham today for not speaking out against the United States role in Vietnam for criticizing clergymen who have done so.
PHILADELPHIA, May 14 (AP)--About 2,500 "hippies" and "teeny-hoppers" gathered in front of Independence Hall this afternoon for what was billed as a "Happy Un-Birthday Be-In."

Postmaster General Lawrence F. O'Brien made a persuasive plea for higher postal rates before a House committee the other day. But neither his eloquence nor his impressive factual case is likely to win the increases President Johnson requested without overcoming very difficult and well-financed opposition. Powerful vested interests of many types will be hurt in the pocketbook if rates go up, and they will not submit without a fight.

WASHINGTON, May 14-- The State Department had no official comment today on the Chinese statements reported by Simon Malley, but officials said privately that they had detected nothing essentially new in them.
Two fine artists from Chicago were in town Saturday, offering an evening of flute and piano sonatas, at Carnegie Recital Hall.
LIVERPOOL, England, May 14--Liverpool's massive new Roman Catholic cathedral, uncompromisingly contemporary in design, was consecrated in today solemnity and pageantry.

SAIGON, May 14 (Reuters)-- Vietcong terrorists assassinated two candidates for local office in South Vietnam today as villagers began voting for hamlet chiefs in more than 4,500 Government-controlled communities.

"Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead," London's biggest current hit, which was put on by the government-supported National Theater, will be David Merrick's Christmas gift to Broadway. It will be the first New York visit of the National Theater, founded in 1963 by Sir Lawrence Oliver.
The American Civil Liberties Union urged yesterday that class rankings, grades and test scores be eliminated in determining draft deferments.
JACK PAAR has lost none of his distinctive ability to fashion an hour of diverting viewing out of a random grab bag of monologues, interviews and whatever else may strike his fancy.

LOS ANGELES, May 14 (UPI)--Ken Holtzman, the winning pitcher, singled in the 11th inning today to start a threerun rally for a 6-3 Chicago Cubs' victory after the Los Angeles Dodgers had taken the first game, 2-1, on Willie Davis's run-scoring single in the 10th.
SALT LAKE CITY, May 14-- Mr. and Mrs. Loile J. Bailey have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Loi Anne Bailey, to Harden Romney Eyring, son of Dr. and Mrs. Henry Eyring.

YONKERS, May 14--Somewhere in Dobbs Ferry early this afternoon, while hundreds of cars were backed up and horns were honking, a man looked out of his station wagon at another man running up a steep hill, wearing shorts and an undershirt, and turned to his wife and yelled, "What? What is it? What?"

ROME, May 14--Pope Paul VI told thousands in St. Peter's Square today that he brought them the blessings of the Madonna of Fatima--"good inspirations that should guide each of us, and society as well, to the good roads of justice and peace."

THE l5th international tournament at Bognor Regis, England, produced a triple first-place tie among N. Padevski of Bulgaria, D. Drimer of Rumania and the junior world champion, B. Kurajica of Yugoslavia. Each scored 8 points in this 15player, 11-round Swiss system.

AVERY Brundage and the other fuzzyminded idealists who run the Inter national Olympic Committee have just embarked on a project that hasn't been matched since King Canute ordered the waves to cease and desist. These dreamers refuse to accept the facts of life as the jet age has revised them, but cling to the outmoded tenets fashionable at the time of Queen Victoria.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 14 (AP)--About 1,450 Princeton University students passed up dinner tonight to raise money for use against the famine in India.
WASHINGTON, May 14-- Republicans and Southern Democrats, old allies in the House of Representatives, are becoming bitterly estranged in the 90th Congress.

Bob Scott, the Johns Hopkins lacrosse coach, reflected happily yesterday about his team's victory over undefeated Navy on Saturday, but a note of concern crept into his voice on the phone when he spoke of next weekend's encounter with Maryland.
For three hours yesterday afternoon in Philharmonic Hall, the 70th anniversary of The Jewish Daily Forward was celebrated in Yiddish songs and speeches.

SRINIGAR, Kashmir, May 14--Rugho Nath Vaishnavi, one of the 118 opposition candidates in the Vale of Kashmir whose names were kept off the ballot in February's election, is preparing to have his day in court.
WASHINGTON, May 14--A diplomatic conference on maritime law will be held in Brussels from Tuesday to May 27.

Arthur Fiedler and the Boston Pops Orchestra provided a varied introduction to the wonders of a major ensemble in last night's tape recording of a concert for children. The program was seen on the National Broadcasting Company's "Children's Theater."
For the first time, the Metropolitan Opera will give free performances in city parks this summer.

HANNIBAL, Mo., May 14-- Grasping at the faint possibility that their two boys, missing since Wednesday, are alive, Mr. and Mrs. Michael Hoag broadcast a television appeal tonight for them to come home.

A traveler who recently returned from Hong Kong reports that among the graffiti he saw there was the assertion: "Mao Tse-tung is a Hippie." The suspicion must be strong that the author was a frustrated China-watcher expressing his conviction that only a user of LSD or marijuana could have been responsible for this past year's convulsions in China.
WASHINGTON, May 14-- The war in Vietnam appears to United States officials to have placed a new chill on Washing ton-Moscaw relations but not to have frozen the path to a relaxation of tension.

PARIS, May 14--The Congress for Cultural Freedom has refused to accept the resignation of its executive director, Michael Josselson, who was responsible for accepting funds for the organization from the Central Intelligence Agency for 16 years.

City Investigations Commissioner Arnold G. Fraiman said last night that within three months all taxicabs in the city would he required to install bullet-resistant partitions between the front and rear seats.
LONDON, May 14 (UPI)-- Sir Barnett Stross, a former Laborite member of Parliament known as a campaigner against cigarette smoking, died of a heart attack yesterday. He was 67 years old.
Longshoremen in the Port of New York are planning to use a recent Supreme Court decision on prefabrication to limit the use of containers in shipping ocean cargo.

SAIGON, Monday, May 15 (AP)--Enemy mortars shelled United States Marine positions just south of the demilitarized, zone early today and North Vietnamese regulars mounted probing attacks against Marine outposts in a growing battle in which 14 Marines have been killed and 100 wounded.
The Two-Sided Drawing Game, the Paint-In and the folk-sing were the most popular things until The Group Image started playing and drew the crowds away.

IT has become increasingly apparent in recent years that players of the highest rank have little interest in normal duplicate games at club level. The international match point seems to be the appropriate cure for their jaded palates, as Alvin Roth has shown in a variety of ways at his Mayfair House of Bridge.
WASHINGTON, May 14-- Following are the votes of delegations from New York, New Jersey and Connecticut on the major roll-call in Congress during the week ended yesterday:

BANMETHUOT, South Vietnam, May 14--The leader of a dissident ethnic minority movement that has twice staged bloody uprisings against the Central Government has promised the Saigon authorities an additional, period of peace for at least six months.
PITTSBURGH, May 14-- Steel producers received two items of encouraging news last week.

PELHAM MANOR, N.Y., May 14--Jack M. Brown's 43foot sloop, Callooh, became the winner of the Winged Foot Trophy today by posting the lowest corrected time for the New York Athletic Club's 58th annual overnight race.
THURMONT, Md., May 14 (AP)--President and Mrs. Johnson enjoyed a restful interlude today at a mountaintop retreat, but the weather was not so pleasant.

GLOUCESTER, Mass., May 14--Mrs. Natalie Shipman Worcester, who as Natalie Shipman was the author of 12 novels and many short stories, died of cancer Friday in her home here. She was 64 years old and the wife of Gurdon Saltonstall Worcester, a consulting psychologist, inventor and himself a novelist.

PEKING, May 14 (Agence France-Presse)--The body of a young Red Guard who was killed in fighting with antiMaoist workers in Szechwan Province eight days ago was placed in the shrine of Chinese Communist heroes here this weekend.
BEVERLY HILLS, Calif., May 14 (AP)--Frank McGrath, an actor, last seen as the cook on the "Wagon Train" television series, died yesterday of a heart attack. He was 64 years olds.
The floral decorations at a "Mary's Day" mass last week at Immaculate Heart College in Los Angeles were displayed in 76 deep oil cans as a symbol of "Christian involvement in the world."

The 90-voice Zamir Chorale, made up of university students from this area, gave a Town Hall concert last night, in celebration of Israel's Independence Day. The conductor, looking younger, if anything, than his collegiate charges, was Stanley Sperber, who was a founder of the chorus seven years ago.
DETROIT, May 14--In the 1930s, Emil Mazey carved a reputation as one of the most fearless organizers in the then fledgling United Automobile Workers Union.

Newsweek magazine said yesterday that Richard M. Nixon was the first Presidential choice of 28 state Republican organizations with a total of 622 votes at next year's party convention. This figure is 45 short of the 667 required to nominate.

The New York All-Stars, taller and heavier than their "cousins" from County Galway in Ireland, took a long step toward winning the National (Gaelic) Football League championship yesterday at Gaelic Park in the Bronx.
The Rev. Dr. Frederick Neumann, a Protestant clergyman and Biblical educator, died Saturday at the Maimonides Hospital in Brooklyn. He was 68 years old and lived at 44 Butler Place in Brooklyn.

Council Majority Leader David Ross announced yesterday that the City Council would get a bill tomorrow proposing the use of methadone, a synthetic drug, to treat narcotics addicts now in Rikers Island city jail.

PHUOCLY, South Vietnam, May 14 (AP)--Vietcong guerrillas overran a battalion compound of the South Vietnamese Army five miles southwest of Saigon early today, killing three of the four American advisers and 27 South Vietnamese.

WASHINGTON, May 14--For For the first time a motion picture was chosen as a winner of a 1967 National School Bell Award announced today. "Up the Down Staircase," a Warner Brothers screen adaptation of the Bel Kaufman best-seller, was cited for its portrayal of a teacher in a city school. The film is scheduled for national release in early summer.

PYONGYANG, North Korea May 14--What is clearly visible here is that the armed forces and people are being prepared physically and psychologically for the idea that a new shooting war could break out anytime in Korea.
TOKYO, Monday, May 15 (AP)--Premier Chou En-lai has decided that Foreign Minister Chen Yi must submit to criticism rallies in Communist China's cultural purge, reports from Peking said today.
MEMPHIS, May 14 (AP)-- Flash floods struck widespread areas of middle Tennessee today for the second day in a row because of thunderstorms as creeks and rivers overflowed.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 14 --Construction of the $8-million Mather House, the 10th educational and social center for undergraduates in Harvard College, will begin this fall, it was announced today.

GIBRALTAR, Monday, May 15 (UPI)--The Spanish Foreign Ministry warned Britain cast night that Spain is determined to see that regulations restricting flights through air space surrounding Gibraltar are respected.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 14 (AP)--A group of white hecklers today harassed clergymen who held a march urging an open housing ordinance in this city.
A Jerseyan was charged with killing a man yesterday by pushing him into the path of a subway train.

More than 800 residents of Mount Pleasant, Iowa, have taken up a New York publisher's offer of a free copy of Elia Kazan"s "The Arrangement" the nation's No. 1 fiction best seller that has been barred by their city's library as obscene.
ADEN, May 14 (Reuters)-- Two Americans accused of attacking military installations in Yemen will face the death penalty if found guilty, the Sana radio said today.
BLOOMINGTON, Minn., May 14 (AP)--Mike Hershberger hit a two-run double today to highlight a four-run first inning for Kansas City as the Athletics downed the Minnesota Twins, 4-2.

RYE, N.Y., May 14--John J. Toohy, who retired in 1966 as a senior vice president of E.R. Squibb Sons, Inc., a subsidiary of the Olin Mathieson Chemical Corporation, died yesterday in his home on Pine Island. His age was 65.
At Town Hall today: Yoshiko Ito, soprano, 5:30 P.M.; Music in Our Time, 8:30.

An Iberia Air Lines jet plane inbound from Madrid with 60 persons aboard skidded off a runway yesterday after landing at Kennedy International Airport and came to rest in a patch of sand. There were no injuries.
The body of a 71-year-old mu sician and entertainer was found in his Greenwich Village apartment last Saturday night the police reported yesterday
A little over a century ago, down, where the Fulton Fish Market stands, the slender bowsprits of Yankee clipper ships reached halfway across South Street when they docked.
Representative Emanuel Celler expressed "serious doubts" yesterday as to whether Gov George Romney of Michigan is eligible for the Presidency.

WASHINGTON, May 14 (AP)--The Commerce Department announced tonight a reduction in the amount of refined copper that producers must reserve for defense use during the third quarter of this year. It also announced reductions in set-asides for most other copper products categories.

HONG KONG, May 14-- When the Executive Coun cil of this British Crown Colony was summoned the other day to discuss the recent rioting, which has been accompanied by strident Communist-press attacks on the British authorities, members of these advisers appointed to

The New York Infirmary Strang Clinic will offer a reception and tea Wednesday from 4 P.M. to 7 to open its new quarters, at 320 East 15th Street. The reception will be in the garden of the Booth House, the hospital's residence building.

BEIRUT, Lebanon, May 14-- A Saudi Arabian broadcast said today that Ilyushins of the United Arab Republic bombed the Saudi port town of Qizan at dawn, killing one woman and injuring 11 women and children.
ROME, May 14 (AP)--Martin Mulligan, seeking his third Italian international tennis championship, gained the semifinals today, defeating Hungary's Istvan Gulyas, 6-0, 6-1, 1-6, 6-4.

Don Balsamo of Long Island University struck out 12 men and allowed City College only three hits yesterday as the Blackbirds scored a 12-1 victory in a Metropolitan Conference baseball game on the winner's field.
C.K. Yen, vice president and Premier of Nationalist China, said yesterday his country would "do anything necessary" to help the free world in Vietnam, but he avoided a direct commitment of troops.

OMAHA, Neb., May 14 (AP) --Rear Adm. Charles Lyndon, commander of the Naval Reserve Training, Command, suffered a fatal heart attack on his way to Omaha from Atchinson, Kan., where he had attended the graduation of his son Arthur from St. Benedict's College. He was 54 years old.
WALDEN, N.Y., May 14-- David L. Cowger, of 33 Wileman Avenue, a retired project manager for the Walsh Construction Company of New York, died yesterday at St. Barnabas Hospital in the Bronx.

The Coast Guard and an industrial contractor will try again this week to place a new Ambrose Light Station--a Texas tower platform at the Atlantic entrance to the Port of New York on the ocean bottom 75 feet down.

JERUSALEM, (Israel), May 14 (Reuters)--Twelve bonfires at a ceremony tonight on Mount Herzl on the outskirts of Jerusalem ushered in Israel's 19th independence day celebrations. Fireworks followed the ceremony.
MOSCOW, May 14 (UPI)-- The first Soviet jet plane crashed on its seventh test flight, less than a year after it became operational in 1942, Tass, the Soviet press agency, reported today.
One of four American adults favors the use of atomic weapons to gain a military victory in Vietnam, according to a Gallup Poll finding made public yesterday in The Washington Post.

CHICAGO, May 14 (AP)-- Gary Peters pitched a one-hitter to enable the Chicago White Sox to defeat the California Angels, 3-1, and sweep a double-header today and move into first place in the American League.
LONDON, May 14 (Reuters) --A Liberal Member of Parliament said on his return from a tour of Southeast Asia today that Britain should give much more civilian aid to South Vietnam.

Senator Robert F. Kennedy was called upon yesterday to lead a Senate fight against a bill that critics insist would outlaw the Congressional redistricting in New York ordered by a special Federal court.

With words and music, the Nassau Community College in Great Neck completed yesterday a six-day celebration of Henry David Thoreau--the Concord pencil maker and handyman, the proponent of civil disobedience, the man someone called a "walking declaration of independence," who made a half-mile-wide pond famous over the planet, who had a hand, years after his death, in pushing the British out of India, who found a cosmos in Concord, Mass.

CHICAGO, May 14--Premier Chou En-lai is quoted as having told an interviewer that Communist China would send its armies into Vietnam if the North Vietnamese were threatened with invasion or in the event of a "sellout peace."

CLEVELAND, May 14 (AP) --An explosion rocked the home of a Negro early today in the predominantly white section of suburban Cleveland Heights. It was similar to an explosion at the same house last June.

TRENTON, May 14--The state's new Commissioner of Community Affairs will propose the concept of developing a city of up to 300,000 persons in New Jersey's Hackensack Meadows, a largely vacant marshland within the shadow of the Manhattan skyline.

PATNA, India, May 14 (Reuters)--A violent storm swept the famine-struck state of Bihar today, killing seven persons and forcing officials to close seven food kitchens where 5,000 destitute people were fed daily.

CINCINNATI, May 14 (AP) --Gary Nolan, a rookie, scattered five hits and Tony Perez doubled home the only run in the first inning as the Cincinnati Reds topped the Philadelphia Phillies, 1-0, today for a sweep of their double-header.
More than 300 persons yesterday watched and photographed a dozen graduate sculpture students of the Brooklyn Museum Art School at work outdoors.
New York University announced yesterday that it was abandoning support of its club football program.

Agencies dealing with the law, from the police to the courts, were urged yesterday "to put their house in order and refrain from improper disclosures" about defendants in criminal cases to minimize unfair trials.

Efforts on both sides of the Atlantic to establish a smoothly functioning low-fare international air charter service are running into difficulties.

TOKYO, May 14 (AP)-- The Defense Agency announced today that its warships were forced to suspend antisubmarine maneuvers with United States vessels for a brief time last Thursday because a Soviet destroyer and Soviet aircraft made close approaches in the Sea of Japan.
GENEVA, Monday, May 15-- The world's major trading nations were within inches of agreement this morning in the Kennedy round of tariff-cutting negotiations being held here.
GREENVALE, L.I., May 14 -Four generations of the C.W. Post family attended ceremonies today dedicating Long Island University's Merriweather Campus here.

Latin America's latest quest for an economic "Eldorado" began with a march of Hemisphere presidents from the gambling hall of a hotel in Punta del Este, Uruguay, a month ago.

Theodore W. Kheel, the mediator in the current New York newspaper labor negotiations, said yesterday that unions and management should seek expert advice on how to plan the futore of the newspaper industry here.

Mickey Mantle's 500th home run finally arrived yesterday, in style. He hit it off Stu Miller of the Baltimore Orioles with two out in the seventh inning at Yankee Stadium, and it proved to be the winning run in the New York Yankees' 6-5 victory.

MIDDLETOWN, N.Y., May 14--Mr. and Mrs. Michael A. Gurda have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elaine Valerie Gurda, to Lawrence Xavier Kennedy, son of Mr. and Mrs. Henry Kennedy of New York.

The Studebaker Corporation and the Worthington Corporation are discussing a merger, both companies announced yesterday. No details of the proposed move could be gleaned from the announcement made by Frank J. Nunlist, chairman of Worthington, and Randolph H. Guthrie, his opposite at Studebaker.
At 10 A.M. this morning, a Senate subcommittee is scheduled to start public hearings in Washington on the sensitive subject of drug prices.

LARCHMONT, N.Y., May 14 --John B. Slack of the Rocky Point Club in Old Greenwich, Conn., at the helm of Sabre, won the third race of the annual Western Long Island Sound Star Class "eye-opener" series today during the Larchmont Yacht Club's final preseason regatta for Yacht Racing Association fleets. The Y.R.A. championship season begins next weekend.
WIESBADEN, Germany, May 14 (AP)--Kathy Kusner of Arlington, Va., riding Untouchable, won the individual jumping event today at the Wiesbaden international horse show.
They laughed when the cigarette company bought the distributor of Scotch whisky.

The University of Colorado defeated Millikin University of Decatur, Ill., on the "G.E. College Bowl" program on the National Broadcasting Company yesterday, but it took a tie-breaking question to do it. It was Colorado's fourth straight victory.
The annual house and garden tour of the Stamford (Conn.) section of the National Council of Jewish Women will be conducted Thursday in Greenwich and Stamford.

BOSTON, May 14--Rico Petrocelli and Carl Yastrzemski led the Boston Red Sox to 8-5 and 13-9 victories over the Detroit Tigers today as the two teams combined to set an American League record for extra-base hits.

STANFORDVILLE, N.Y., May 14--Jose Torres was put through a two-hour closed-door "briefing" today by his tutor, Joey Fariello, in preparation for his light-heavyweight title fight against the champion, Dick Tiger, at Madison Square Garden Tuesday night.
Secretary of the Treasury Fowler's admission that the Administration will not press for tax increases in July is a welcome recognition of political and economic realities.
Walter Matthau and Omar Sharif will be featured opposite Barbra Streisand in the movie versions of "Dolly!" and "Funny Girl." It will be the first time either actor will appear in a musical film.
LITTLE ROCK, Ark., May 14 (AP)--Senator J.W. Fulbright, Democrat of Arkansas, faces his most serious election threat after a quarter-century as politician, challenger of Presidents and dissenter.
"GALILEO GALILEI," the 90-minute Columbia Broadcasting System News program seen yesterday, completely solved the problem of presenting a moving musical experience over a strongly visual medium.
SOLEBURY TOWNSHIP, Pa., May 14--Brig. Gen. George 0. Van Orden, U.S.M.C., retired, died yesterday in his home here. He was 60 years old.

Employes in the coat and suit industry in the metropolitan area will not work after their current contract expires May 31 unless their employers make a "practical proposal," the New York Cloak Joint Board warned yesterday.

Hicksville High School of Long Island upset the favorite, Blessed Sacrament High School of New Rochelle, N.Y., yesterday in the senior eight-oared event of the metropolitan high school championship regatta at the Orchard Beach Lagoon in the Bronx.
WASHINGTON, May 14-- The Department of Health, Education and Welfare is planning a two-day national conference next month on the rising costs of medical care.
A ski lodge, a bank, an art gallery, a priory and a Hawaiian hotel were among 20 recent projects cited yesterday for the annual honor awards of the American Institute of Architecture.

Broader powers for meter maids to issue summonses for traffic and parking violations now beyond their jurisdiction are, as Mayor Lindsay suggests, plainly in the public interest. Expansion of the authority of meter maids would not only release regular policemen for other tasks, but would also, by stepping up parking enforcement, facilitate the cleaning of the streets by the Department of Sanitation.
HOLLYWOOD, May 15 (UPI) --Fire burned through nine or 10 buildings on several movie and television sets at Universal Studios today, causing damage estiamted at $1-million, firemen reported.
WASHINGTON, May 15--Two House Republicans broke sharply with their party's leadership today by endorsing an embattled Democratic school aid bill.
Libby, McNeill Libby, the large food packer and processor, which has been without a president since February, now has one.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 (AP)--Ernie Banks' threerun homer and two-run clouts by Lee Thomas and Billy Williams powered the Chicago Cubs today to a 9-3 victory over the San Francisco Giants.

Margaret Leighton has relinquished the leading role of Regina in the Lincoln Center Repertory Theater's production of "The Little Foxes" for a lesser part because of her concern that American performers might resent the use of a foreien actress.
Suffolk County Judge Floyd Sarisohn was removed from office yesterday by the Appellate Division of State Supreme Court and prohibited from holding any future judicial post by appointment or election.
Prices declined in quiet trading on the London Stock Exchange yesterday.

KANSAS CITY, May 15 (AP)--Bert Campaneris started two scoring rallies with singles tonight in leading the Kansas City Athletics to a 5-2 victory over the California Angels. It was the A's fourth straight triumph and the Angels fifth loss in a row.
Fourteen city departments have been directed by the City Council's Finance Committee to submit by today the details of lump-sum allocations totaling $276-million in Mayor Lindsay's 1967-68 budget.
A University of Oregon geneticist has found an unusually high incidence of genetic damage in the blood cells of a small group of persons who have taken the mind-expanding drug LSD.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 15-- With a steady performance that produced 27 pars and five birdies, Paul E. Kelly of Sleepy Hollow Country Club retained his Westehester Professional Golfers' Association championship today playing in the rain and fog at Willow Ridge Country Club.
ATHENS, May 15--Greece abrogated an eight-year-old frontier agreement with Yugoslavia today.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 15 (UPI)--The police and sheriff's deputies raided two suburban Belmont homes late last night and early today and seized an arsenal including machine guns, bombs and large artillery shells.

LOS ANGELES, May 15 (AP) --Bob Aspromonte crashed a two-run triple in the 10th inning tonight to give the Houston Astros a 5-3 victory over the Los Angeles Dodgers and end the Astros' five-game losing streak.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15-- Michael Gold, author of "Jews Without Money" and other works of social protest, died yesterday of complications following a stroke, at Kaiser Foundation Hospital in nearby Terra Inda, where he had been a patient since February. He was 74 years old.

WESTBURY, L.I, May 15 --Alvin L. Weil resigned as the president of Roosevelt Raceway today over what he said were "differences between myself and several of my associates on the executive committee." He said the differences had existed "for some time."

Mrs. George S. Franklin, a founder and former chairman of the board of trustees of Bennington College, died yesterday in her home at 1120 Fifth Avenue. Her age was 79. She also lived at Cold Spring Harbor. L.I.
A committee of Roman Catholic priests seeking a change in canon law to permit clergymen to marry began yesterday to poll more than 7,000 priests in the metropolitan area on their views on the issue.
President Johnson has caught up with Gov. George Romney in popular appeal, according to a Louis Harris poll published yesterday in The New York Post.

CAIRO, Tuesday, May 16-- The United Arab Republic staged last night its biggest public show of force since the 1956 Suez crisis. The usually well-informed Cairo newspaper A1 Ahram said today that the nation was placed on a "war footing" because of tensions along the border between Israel and Syria.

BOSTON, May 15--Shuttle air service between New York and London, similar to that on the northeast corridor between Boston, New York and Washington, was predicted today by Sir Giles Guthrie, chairman and chief executive of the British Overseas Airways Corporation.
The Book-of-the-Month Club has acquired for $325,000 the right to include Svetlana Alliluyeva's memoirs among its book selections. It is the largest sum ever paid in such a purchase by a book club.
When Evelyn Peirce was a slip of a girl at the Keith Country Day School in Rockford, Ill., she was bitten by the acting bug and never recovered.
The Cleveland Museum of Art has purchased a Rembrandt, its fourth, for more than $480,000. It goes on display today with three others.
WASHINGTON, May 15--The Supreme Court ruled today that Senator James O. Eastland cannot be sued on charges of conspiring to violate the civil rights of a group of civil rights advocates in Louisiana.
WASHINGTON, May 15-- Consumers are likely to find their food bills 1 to 2 per cent higher by this summer, the Department of Agriculture said today.

ALTHOUGH William James's name is on the title page of this book, Gay Wil son Allen, the author of a fine life of Whitman, has given us a bonus. For his book is also about the James family: siblings; parents, in-laws, children. And what a remarkable clan they were.

BOSTON, May 15 (AP)--The Boston Bruins acquired two centers, Phil Esposito and Fred Stanfield, and a winger, Ken Hodge, in a multi-player National Hockey League deal with the Chicago Black Hawks tonight.
Steel production in the week ended Saturday was almost unchanged in comparison with output the preceding week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported Yesterday.

If George Washington's home were in danger of being turned into a pizza parlor or torn down for a high-rise apartment, every patriotic organization in the country and every member of Congress would be thundering in protest. Yet as everyone knows who has visited Mount Vernon, much of its charm and one of the principal reasons that Washington loved it is its serene view across the Potomac River toward the green, rolling fields of Maryland.
MOSCOW, May 15 (UPI)-- Communist China's "negative stand" is responsible for United States escalation in Vietnam, the Polish Foreign Minister, Adam Rapacki, said today.

It is understandable that Secretary of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler wants to do something about his frequent and time-wasting appeals to Congress to raise the "temporary" ceiling on the national debt. But his proposal to lift the "permanent" debt ceiling from $285 billion to $365 billion will not really do the trick.
PANAMA, May 15 (AP)-- The most comprehensive study of Panama Canal tolls ever undertaken is entering its final phase.
WASHINGTON, May 15--The Supreme Court ruled today that juvenile courts must grant children many of the procedural protections required in adult trials by the Bill of Rights.

GENEVA, May 15--The major trading nations reached agreement tonight in the Kennedy round of tariff negotiations, paving the way for the most ambitious attempt ever made to achieve the liberalization of international trade.

AMSTERDAM, the Netherlands, May 15--The souvenir sheet containing three stamps commemorating Amphilex 67, the international stamp show here, is still the main attraction for philatelists from around the world who have come to Amsterdam for the show.

LAS VEGAS, Nev. May 15 (UPI)--Seven resort hotels in three states were emptied of more than 2,500 guests today after a live bomb, with an extortion note threatening to blow up two other hotels also, was discovered in the Sahara Hotel on the Las Vegas Strip.
A new master--Capt. George A. Georgiou--was on the bridge of the Greek Line flagship Queen Anna Maria when the 21,716-ton liner arrived here yesterday from Mediterranean ports.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15 (UPI)--Gangs of Negro youths set minor fires with homemade bombs and shattered store windows with rocks tonight in the Hunters Point section, the scene of two days of racial rioting last September.
A Soviet Government employe believed to be a minor figure in a celebrated 1954 Russian defector case is reportedly working as a chauffeur at the Soviet Mission to the United Nations.
Returned here from weekend at Camp David, Md,; flew to Windsor Locks, Conn., to address a New England Governors' conference.
Doris Freedman, a New York artist working in enamel, has been appointed special assistant for cultural affairs to August Heckscher, Administrator of Recreation and Cultural Affairs.
ATHENS, May 15--The baldish leaders of the military junta have decided to rescind their ban on tourists with Beatle hairdos, beards and skimpy purses.
LONDON, May 15--Britain's economic policy makers find themselves, at least for the moment, in a difficult situation.

A three-man medical missior that recently returned from South Vietnam announced yesterday that it had selected 13 war-injured children to be brought to the United States for medical treatment they were unable to get in South Vietnam.

Commissioner Ken Macker of the National Professional Soccer League said yesterday he had ordered an investigation of statements attributed to Peter Rhodes, a referee, in Toronto that he had called 11 false fouls in last Sunday's Toronto-Pittsburgh game to permit time for TV commercials on the Columbia Broadcasting System.
Directors of the Paramount Pictures Corporation, a subsidiary of Gulf and Western Industries, Inc., announced a major realignment of the company's executive structure yesterday.
The bond market suffered another sinking spell yesterday, mostly in response to requests by the Johnson Administration for more flexibility in managing the nation's debt.

WASHINGTON, May 15Charles G. Mortimer, chairman of the executive committee of General Foods, urged a gathering of big capitalists the other day to get in there and save the American consumer from the Government.
WASHINGTON, May 15-- Foundations identified as channels for funds of the Central Intelligence Agency have financed the development of cooperatives in a member of countries.

C.K. Yen, the Vice President of Nationalist China, tonight urged more American companies to invest in his country, which, he said, has "just turned the corner on our way to a modern, open, industrialized society.
WASHINGTON, May 15--A New York Representative demanded today that the Internal Revenue Service review the taxexempt status of the National Rifle Association.

Thomas Lloyd will become executive director of the Association of American University Presses on July l. Mr. Lloyd, a graduate of the University of North Carolina, is chief of research publishing for the Social Security Administration.

ROME, May 15--At least one of four Western countries, the United States among them, has questioned the Italian Foreign Ministry over the activities in Iraq of Ente Nazionale Idrocarbun, the Italian state oil agency, it was disclosed today.

Mrs. Alice M. Kaplan, a trustee of the American Federation of Arts, was elected its president yesterday, succeeding Roy R. Neuberger, who held the post for nine years. Mrs. Kaplan, a member of the federation since 1958, developed a visual-education program for fifth graders that brought the federation a grant of about $500,000 from the Ford Foundation last year.

THE trans-Atlantic discussion between articulate students of Europe, Asia, Africa and England and Senator Robert F. Kennedy, Democrat of New York, and Gov. Ronald Reagan, Republican of California, was a provocative hour last night on the Columbia Broadcasting System.

HARVARD'S undefeated varsity heavweight crew probably will not be permitted to handle the fancy, custom-made shell the university ordered from England. The crew is simply too big for the 50-foot, $2,700 rowing machine.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15-- The nation is in a period of "pock-marked prosperity," the chief economist for the country's largest bank declared here today. One of the pock marks, said Walter E. Hoadley, senior vice president of the Bank of America, is the degree of "unhealthy speculation in some of today's investment markets."
The police abandoned their 57-year-old role as prosecutors in Women's Court yesterday, and charges of prostitution against three women were dismissed.

"IT'S a pity they're called blintzes," Benjamin Gra ble said recently, as he watched neat little doughwrapped packages roll out of a new automatic blintz-making machine at the rate of just over one a second. "It's such a harsh word. If they were called cheese pancakes, they'd sound more edible. But then they'd lose their person. ality."
The wholesale commodity price index maintained on Friday the level it reached on Thursday, which was 98.8.
WIESBADEN, Germany, May 15 (AP)--Anton Ebben of the Netherlands won today the Grand Prize of Wiesbaden, the feature of a five-day international horse show jumping tournament.

DANVILLE, Va., May 15 (UPI)--Seven tornadoes ripped from border to border across Virginia late today destroying homes and farm buildings, ripping power and communication lines and injuring at least 11 persons.
ROME, May 15 (UPI)--Maria Bueno of Brazil, a three-time winner of the title, reached the women's singles final today for the fifth time in the Italian tennis championships.
The Association for Homemakers Service, a sic-year-old nonprofit agency here, announced yesterday that it would recognize a union that has been seeking to represent the agency's 160 employes.
INDIANAPOLIS, May, 15 (UPI)--Chuck Arnold of Gardens, Calif., escaped serious injury today when his car crashed into the wall on the northwest turn during a practice lap at the Indianapolis Speedway.

The president of the Board of Education has agreed to meet with the local school board that wants a Harlem principal for its district superintendent to whom City Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan has objected.

COLD SPRING, N.Y., May 13--The development by the state of a park and marina on Little Stony Point in the scenic Hudson River Highlands north of here became today the first recommendation of the Hudson River Valley Commission. The state set up the commission a year ago.
MAIDENHEAD, England, May 15--Almost 1,000 private and professional collectors flocked to the great house of Cliveden near here today to buy something that belonged to the Astors.

DALLAS, May 15 (UPI)--Jo Ann Prentice, scrambling with numerous bogeys, won the Dallas Civitan open golf tournament and $2,475 today with a final round 37, 38--75 and a 72-hole total of 281. She triumphed by a stroke in play that was postponed yesterday because of rain.
RIVERSIDE, Conn., May 15. --Miss Gaylyn Payne Nicholl and William Daniel Boone plan to marry here Aug. 19.

THE GIRL IN THE FREUDIAN SLIP, comedy by William F. Brown, starring Alan Young, Marjorie Lord and Russell Nype, tonight and tomorrow, at 8:30, at the Booth Theater, 222 West 45th Street. It opens Thursday at 7:30.

HOUSTON, May 15--Mr. and Mrs. John A. Bodin have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Juliet Emilie Bodin, to George Marquis Converse 3d, son of Mrs. Converse Jr. of Summit and Bay Head, N.J., and Mr. Converse Jr. of Paris. A wedding here in August is planned.
Stocks closed off with investment-grade and glamour issues the weakest in slowest trading in a month; volume, 8.32 million shares. Corporate bonds eased; 12.34 million.
CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 15 --Charles Abrams, the housing authority, gave strong support today to proposals to facilitate home ownership by the poor.

LONDON, May 15 (AP)-- Henry Bowen-Davies, a British financier who headed a multimillion-dollar business empire that crashed four months ago, was found shot dead today. His wife, their 12-year-old son and 6-year-old daughter were also found shot to death in their Wimbledon home.

On Monday, June 8, 1964, at about 10 A.M., Gerald Francis Gault and a friend, Ronald Lewis, were taken into custody by the Sheriff of Gila County. Gerald was then still subject to a six months' probation order which had been entered on Feb. 25, 1964, as a result of his having been in the company of another boy.

ACCRA, Ghana, May 15-- John W.K. Harlley, Inspector General of the Ghanaian National Police and vice chairman of the nation's ruling National Liberation Committee, pledged today an early return to civilian government.

PALM BEACH GARDENS, Fla., May 15 (AP)--Arnold Palmer continued to lead professional golfers this week in money earned with $87,073 in official Professional Golfers' Association earnings and a total of $95,086 over all for the year.

Measles, one of childhood's most common diseases, can be eliminated in the United States within two years now that a safe and effective oneshot vaccine has been developed, public health authorities report.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 15--George J. Tomeh, the representative of Syria, warned the Security Council today that a "Suez type" of crisis was developing in the Middle East.

The nine-story apartment building at 141 East 89th Street, on the northeast corner of Lexington Avenue, has been sold by Herbert Albert of the Eight City Realty Corporation for cash over a first mortgage of $1.5-million.

WASHINGTON, May 15 (AP) ----The Secretary of Agriculture, Orville L. Freeman, urged the United States Tariff Commission today to quickly reduce imports of dairy products to about one-fourth their present volume.

Bhaskar, at the Village Theater last night, took the high road of bubbling good spirits to produce a color travelogue of Indian dance rather than the more austere type of cinema verite documentary.
PRINCETON, N.J., May 15 (AP)--The English Union allstar lacrosse team ended its tour of the United States today by tying Princeton, 11-11, on a goal with seven seconds of play remaining.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Tuesday, May 16--North Vietnamese attacks have killed or wounded more than 100 United States Marines just south of the demilitarized zone at the border between South Vietnam and North Vietnam, a United States spokesman said yesterday.

CHICAGO, May 15 (UPI)--Circuit Court Judge Herbert C. Paschen refused today to grant a new trial to Richard F. Speck, the convicted murderer of eight young nurses.

"Up the Down Staircase," a Warner Brothers film adaptation of Bel Kaufman's novel, has been chosen as the official United States entry at the Moscow film festival, July 5-20.
JERUSALEM (Israel), May 15--Israel today celebrated her 19th independence day with a modest parade in Jerusalem that was scaled down to conform with armistice regulations.

WASHINGTON, May 15-- Representative Gerald R. Ford of Michigan, the House Republican leader, has laid the lash of scorn on the Southern Democrats with whom his party made such sweet music in Congress over the years. More astonishing than that is Ford's rationale: he said he would rather win the elections next year than compile a few legislative victories now.

CHICAGO, May 15 (UPI)-- North Vietnam's offer last January of peace negotiations if the United States would unconditionally end the bombing of North Vietnamese territory was made over the objection of Communist China, The Chicago Daily News reported today in a copyrighted dispatch.

YOSHIKO, ITO, a 27-yearold Japanese soprano, ap peared at Town Hall late yesterday afternoon as winner of Town Hall's 1967 Recital Award. She was selected earlier this year from the participants in "The Joy in Singing," a lecture-recital course in song literature conducted at Town Hall by Winifred Cecil.

Four violinists were Chosen yesterday to compete in the finals of the 25th international competition of the Edgar M. Leventritt Foundation. They will be judged at Carnegie Hall today starting at 1 P.M. by 15 leading violinists and conductors.

ALBANY, May 15--A proposal that prospective judges be given written and oral examinations by a screening panel of lawyers and psychiatrists drew laughter today from delegates to the Constitutional Convention--even from the judges who are delegates.
Prices declined yesterday on the American Stock Exchange in fairly active trading.
The consulting engineering firm of Parsons, Brinckerhoff, Quade Douglas has appointed Alfred T. McDonough as director and coordinator of its work on airport projects.

McKesson Robbins, Inc., topped the billion-dollar mark for the first time while earnings set a record for the sixth straight year, Herman C. Nolen, chairman, reported yesterday in the preliminary unaudited statement covering the fiscal year ended March 31.

ROCKVILLE, Md., May 15-- The life prison terms of two young Negroes, convicted six years ago of having raped a white girl, were set aside today. A committee of white persons whose members believe the men are innocent had conducted a long campaign for a new trial.

GLENS FALLS, N.Y., May 15--Dr. Henry T. Moore, second president of Skidmore College in nearby Saratoga Springs died today at the age of 80.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 15 --Mr. and Mrs. Charles C. Tillinghast Jr. have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Anne Shaw Tillinghast, to J. Michael Meretta Jr., son of John Meretta, professor of music at the University of Cincinnati, and Mrs. Meretta. A June wedding in Providence, R.I., is planned.
GIOLINH, South Vietnam, May 15--Maj. Al Gray sat on a folding aluminum and plastic chair on the roof of his bunker, chewing tobacco and gazing north into the darkness.

SAN FRANCISCO, May 15-- A group led by Warren Hinckle 3d completed its takeover of Ramparts magazine last night when Mr. Hinckle was elected president and chief executive officer at a stockholders' meeting. He succeeds to the powers Edward M. Keating held before his ouster as publisher two weeks ago.
WASHINGTON, May 15--A United States Air Force fighterbomber was hit by antiaircraft fire over North Vietnam today and may have crashed in or near China, the Defense Department announced tonight.

Operating results from scheduled all-cargo services for certificated route air carriers last year showed continued improvement, according to carrier reports, the Civil Aeronautics Board said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 15-- The Johnson Administration, reporting slightly higher budget deficits in store, asked Congress today to increase the ceiling on the national debt permanently to $365-billion, up $29-billion from the "temporary" ceiling of $336-billion in effect now.

HONG KONG, May 15--Informed sources said today that the British authorities in Hong Kong might consider restricting the number of United States warships visiting the Crown Colony in the light of Communist China's demands.
TOKYO, May 15--Premier Eisaku Sato proposed today that the United States restore Japanese jurisdiction over American-held islands near Okinawa that are not serving a military use.

RIO DE JANEIRO, May 15 (AP)--Former Vice President Richard M. Nixon says he will enter primary contests if he decides to make a run for the 1968 Republican Presidential nomination.

CHICAGO, May 15--Orlando W. Wilson, the university professor who reorganized Chicago's once scandal-ridden police department into a model force, announced today his retirement as superintendent, a post he has held for seven years.

ELIZABETH, N.J., May 15-- Mrs. Mary Leahy Brophy of 1 Salem Park, widow of Joseph A. Brophy, former New Jersey Secretary of State and former Mayor here, died yesterday at a nursing home in Neptune. She was 73 years old.

Mr. and Mrs. John Langeloth Loeb of 730 Park Avenue and Purchase, N.Y., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deborah Loeb, to David John Davies of London and New York. Among other things, the President promised the group more intensive Federal study of the plight of the New Haven Railroad.

BALTIMORE, May 15 (AP) --Proud Clarion, the Kentucky Derby winner, was sent out today for an unusual midday practice for Saturday's Preakness at Pimlico. The best evidence of his performance was the stop watch, since it was done in thick fog.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 15--Venezuela placed her evidence of a Cuban-led guerrilla landing before diplomats of the Western hemisphere today as reports of a new clash with guerrillas reached this capital.

The First National City Bank announced yesterday a new, retail credit-card plan, which it expects to have in opeartion by Aug. 1.

SEOUL, South Korea, May 16 --The Seoul District Criminal Court began today the trial of S. Sgt. Billy J. Cox of the United States Air Force, the first American serviceman to go before a Korean court under the United States-South Korean...

WASHINGTON, May 16--The insurance commissioners of two states told Congress today that consumers were being over charged more than $100-million annually for what is known as "credit insurance"--insurance that pays off installment credit and other debts if the insured person dies.
The curtain has gone down on the Kennedy Round of trade negotiations, but the suspense will linger on until details of the package assembled at Geneva are revealed.

WASHINGTON, May 16-- Trans World Airlines, one of 18 United States carriers seeking new trans-Pacific routes, proposed today fare cuts of more than 40 per cent in testifying before the Civil Aeronautics Board.

SRINAGAR, Kashmir, May 16 --The authorities here are bracing for the visit in the next few weeks of a Moslem woman who is planning to spend some time with her grandchildren and pray at the local mosques.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 16--The next South Vietnamese president can be elected by a plurality, the Constituent Assembly decided today, rejecting suggestions that the country needed a leader backed by the majority of the nation.
BOSTON, May 16 (AP)-- Paul Blair smashed a threerun pinch home run, his first of the year, to lift the Baltimore Orioles to an 8-5 victory over the Boston Red Sox tonight.

Paperboard production fell 6.2 per cent with 445,800 tons in the week ended May 13, from 475,100 tons in the corresponding 1966 week, the Paperboard Group of the American Paper Institute reported yesterday.

ALBANY, May 16--The state disclosed today that it had made major, progress in compelling insurance companies to sell fire insurance on eligible ghetto housing that had previously been denied such protection, particularly, in New York City.

The Waterfront Commission has scheduled a hearing for next Wednesday for two longshoremen whose registrations have been suspended temporarity for lending money without licenses and at usurious rates of interest.

A nationwide drive was opened here yesterday by the National, Association for the Advancement of Colored People to bring heavy pressure on Congress, particularly on Republicans, to pass civil rights legislation.
Alfred M. Botsford, a retired motion picture company publicity man, died Monday in West Valley Hospital, in Encino, Calif., where he lived. He was 83 years old.
The Merv Griffin Show will move out of its late evening slot into prime time in New York on June 12.

LOS ANGELES, May 16 (UPI)--John Roseboro got three straight hits tonight, including his first home run of the season, and scored three runs in leading the Los Angeles Dodgers to a 6-1 win over the Houston Astros. Claude Osteen pitched his fifth victory.
MIAMI, May 16 (AP)-- Drought-scorched Florida was declared an emergency area today, on a day when thousands of residents felt raindrops for the first time in more than a month.

DENVER, May 16 (UPI)--A Federal appeals court rejected efforts by a veteran fighter pilot today to stay out of combat because, he said, he is a conscientious objector to the "unjust and imoral" Vietnam war.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 16 --An armed bandit stole $40,292 in small bills from a branch of the First National City Bank of New York here today and held the assistant manager hostage for 20 minutes to assure his escape.
The Urban League of Greater New York disclosed plans yesterday to open a fully accredited private preparatory school in central Harlem next fall.

CLEVELAND, May 16 (AP) --"We're not begging for freedom anymore," the Rev. Dr. Martin Luther King Jr. told a news conference here today. He said either give the Negroes "their freedom or exterminate them."

WASHINGTON, May 16-- The Administration proposed to Congress today legislation intended to provide American Indians with better economic and social tools, including a $500million loan guaranty and insurance fund.
PHILADELPHIA, May 16-- Incomplete returns indicated approval tonight for Gov. Raymond P. Shafer's plan for a sweeping modernization of Pennsylvania's 89-year-old Constitution.

LISBON, May 16--Three men went on trial here today accused of an attempted bank robbery to obtain funds for an armed rebellion.

MADRID, May 16--Students held a protest sit-in in one building of Madrid University today. In Barcelona, the university will be closed tomorrow to avert student demonstrations against the war in Vietnam.

The International Edition of The New York Times will join Monday with The New York Herald Tribune-The Washington Post in Paris to publish a single daily newspaper, it was announced last night by the publishers of the two papers.

WILMINGTON, Del., May 16 (AP)--Henry McComb Winchester, a former director of the Office of Price Stabilization here and an unsuccessful candidate for Congress in 1950, died Sunday at his home. He was 75 years old.
The appointment of Crocker Nevin, president and director of Marine Midland Grace Trust Company, as campaign chairman for the Police Athletic League was announced yesterday.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (UPI)--In Congressional testimony released today, J. Edgar Hoover linked Stokely Carmichael, a leading advocate of black power, with leftists seeking to overthrow the Government.

Walter N. Frank, who has just completed two years as chairman of the board of governors of the New York Stock Exchange, was honored last night at a testimonial dinner at the Waldorf-Astoria Hotel by an estimated 1,600 friends and associates.

The J. C. Penney Company reported yesterday a small decline in first-quarter profits and cautioned that its earnings in all of fiscal 1967, which ends next Jan. 31, might be lower than in fiscal 1966.
WASHINGTON, May 16 (AP) --The Government rejected today a railroad union offer to move essential goods and equipment in event of a nationwide strike next month.

PARIS--Once-imperial Britain has been spending the past few months doing everything Harold Wilson can imagine to prove that England is part of Europe--that is, everything except filling in the Channel. It even wants to tunnel under the Channel to France. It is pulling out of vestigial Asian toeholds and demonstrating "Europeanness" by letting China kick it around. But this doesn't seem to be enough to convince Charles de Gaulle.

A letter by George Washington that fulfills all the requirements of a dazzling showpiece--the date, July 4, 1776; the place, New York; the contents, a plea for arms for troops facing overwhelming odds--was auctioned yesterday for $20,000.
BRONXVILLE, N. Y., May 16--Henry Beaumont Pennell Jr., a retired New York investment banker, died here last night in his home at 33 Elm Rock Road. He was 80 years old.
Gimbel Brothers reported yesterday at its annual meeting a small sales gain and a virtual standstill in earnings for the first quarter.

CINCINNATI, May 16 (AP) --John H. Druffel, a United States District Court judge here for 27 years, died today at the age of 81. He retired from the bench in 1964.
Stock prices rebounded yesterday to recover part of Monday's broad decline.

Prices recovered yesterday on the American Stock Exchange, led by a diverse mixture of industrial issues.
CHICAGO, May 16--Carey Orr, Pulitzer Prize-winning cartoonist, died today at the age of 77. He lived in suburban Wilmette.

Pretense, the speedy 4-yearold colt owned by Mary Elizabeth Tippett, the mistress of Llangollen Farm, will make his 1967 Aqueduct debut today.

Silver futures trading set a new record yesterday by a slim two contracts. Volume totaled 444 contracts--10,000 ounces each--passing the previous high achieved on May 8 of 442.

Governor Rockefeller, seeking labor support for his $2.5-billion transportation bond issue, said yesterday that the program would generate 184,000 new jobs.

WASHINGTON, May 17-- This week's Senate debate on Vietnam had a different tone. Last winter's loud and strenuous argument between hawks and doves has given way to a kind of distracted anxiety. The President's critics are no longer shouting at him to turn back, but imploring him to be careful. It is not that they are resigned to the steadily rising violence, but merely that they feel helpless to do anything about it.

FASHION designers are falling into step with hosiery manu facturers to celebrate the year of the leg. As their hemlines continue to climb, they are acknowledging the fact that stockings are today's dominant accessory by designing them themselves. Women will be able to buy stockings next fall by designers' names as well as by brands, color and weight.

LISBON, May 17 (AP)--The police reported today that gunmen wearing false mustaches and drak glasses had held up a branch of the Bank of Portugal at the coastal resort of Figueira da Foz and had escaped with 29.8-million escudos, about $1million.

AN occult and arcane art is horse-training, one never meant for the uninitiated. However, Eddie Neloy is one equine nursemaid with so sharp a sense of humor that he can best gently at both his trade and some of its loftier pretensions. As a trainer for the Phipps family cavalry troop, he was the No. 1 man in his profession last year although his luck has been running thin thus far this season.

The top executive in the Cunard Line's passenger operations, Gustave L. Bowen, has resigned from the company, the line announced yesterday. Cunard carries the largest number of traps-Atlantic passengers of any of the shipping lines.

A PROFESSIONAL handler must be honest with his clients at all times, sincere in his opinions about dogs and willing to devote whatever time is necessary to the dogs regardless of hours or conditions, according to Robert S. Forsyth of Chappaqua, N.Y., a leading professional handler.

Mstislav Rostropovich has been one of the busiest musicians around New York in recent months, but last night he found time to contribute his magnificent services to an Emanuel Feuermann memorial concert presented as a benefit event at Hunter College Playhouse by the Violoncello Society.

LaMotte Hyman's victory in the 220-yard dash, the final event, gave Andrew Jackson its 16th straight team title in the Queens Public School Athletic League track and field championships at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, yesterday.

HOUSTON, May 17--The Standard Oil Company (New Jersey) expects to achieve record earnings this year, Michael L. Haider, chairman and chief executive officer, said today at the annual stockholder meeting here.

Norman Grulich has been elected president and chief executive officer of Papert, Koenig, Lois, replacing Julian Koenig, who becomes chairman of the newly-established executive committee. The head of a union of building service workers said yesterday that his local was preparing to strike "hundreds" of Manhattan apartment buildings on Sunday because the owners had not signed a new contract.

ATHENS, May 17--The Greek Orthodox Church, which for years addressed other Christian churches with suspicious hostility, found a new voice today: one that spoke confidently of the common duty of Christians to work together.
