DES MOINES, Iowa, May 17 (AP)--The Iowa Senate refused by a 26-33 vote today to consider a resolution urging adoption of the so-called Dirksen amendment to the United States Constitution.

MOSCOW, May 17--Flights of the Soyuz-type spaceship in which a Russian astronaut was killed last month will be seriously delayed by the need for investigation and correction of the causes of the accident, it was disclosed today.
Eastern Air Lines has pledged $500,000 to the Metropolitan Opera to pay for the company's new production of Wagner's cycle, "Der Ring des Niebelungen," to be presented over the next four seasons.
Mr. and Mrs. Syed Jalal-UdDin Qadri of Srinagar, Kashmir, have announced the engagement of their daughter, Dr. Nilofar Qadri, to Yussouf M. Mir, son of Mr. and Mrs. Habib-Ullah Mir, also of Srinagar.
Long Island University completed its baseball schedule yesterday with a 4-2 victory over Trenton State College on the L.I.U. field. It was the Blackbirds' fifth straight triumph and 17th in 22 games.
WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)--The Senate passed by voice vote today a bill to establish a corporation to help finance the production and distribution of educational television and radio programs.
LONDON, May 17--Sterling and Government securities prices weakened again today but same analysts thought they saw signs that the twin downward trends of recent days were ebbing.

FORT WORTH, May 17-- The $115,000 Colonial Country Club golf tournament, which starts here tomorrow, has a number of innovations. There will be scoreboards designed by Ben Hogan, a baby-sitting service for contestants' children and a push-button electronic communications systen.
BOSTON, May 17 (AP)--The Baltimore Orioles crashed seven home runs, four of them in a nine-run seventh inning, and outslugged the Boston Red Sox, 12-8, tonight.

WASHINGTON, May 17, (AP)--The Internal Revenue Service said today it would no longer contest deductions, as medical expenses, of the premiums paid on disability and accident insurance for years prior to last Jan. 1.

WASHINGTON May 17-- United States tariff reductions on textiles in the Kennedy round "average less than 25 per cent" and are "much less than that on the more sensitive product areas such as woolen and man-made textiles," it was said today.

Dr. Walter P. Anderton, a retired Manhattan internist and former medical educator, died Tuesday in Harkness Pavilion, Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center. He was 81 years old and lived at 910 Park Avenue. He was a former president of the New York County Medical Society.

A small group of adults and 11 schoolchildren discovered nature yesterday in the middle of Manhattan as they left noise and congestion behind for nearly two hours to clamber among the wooded hills of northern Central Park.

Charles T. Bryan, chairman of the board of trustees of Pace Institute from 1942 to 1954, died yesterday at St. John's Hospital, Elmhurst, Queens. He was 77 years old and lived at 84-09 35th Avenue, Jackson Heights, Queens.

CARACAS, Venezuela, May 17--The capture in Venezuela of Cuban Army officers heading an infiltrating guerrilla band has increased hostilities here between the pro-Cuban revolutionaries and the Moscoworiented Communist party.

WASHINGTON, May 17-- The deficit in the United States' international payments was $539-million in the first quarter, the Commerce Department reported today. This was less than in the first quarter last year but above the quarterly average for 1966.
In the industrial group on the London Stock Exchange, steel, chemical, oil, automobile and aircraft issues eased a bit. Tobacco shares registered minor gains.
Fiction THE CAGE, by Andrea Newman (Dial, $4.95). Novel dealing with a "claustrophobic" marriage. Paperback Original. CALINA, by Lee Gardner (Award Books, 60 cents).

LOCUST VALLEY, L.I., May 17--The annual benefit for the Community Hospital of Glen Cove, an al fresco luncheon and show and obedience class of the Long Island Kennel Club, will take place on Saturday on the grounds of the Piping Rock Horse Show. The kennel club has donated $40,000 to the hospital in 12 years.
Details were made public yesterday of the 41-story and 16story office buildings whose foundations are being prepared in the block bounded by Park and Madison Avenues and East 48th and 49th Streets.
ATLANTA, May 17--Tom Seaver, the Frank Merriwell of the New York Mets, held the Atlanta Braves to seven hits tonight, hit two doubles, batted in two runs and even stole a base.

Stanley Young announced his resignation yesterday as executive vice president of the American National Theater and Academy, effective June 15. Mr. Young said he would resume playwriting, and serve as senior professor of drama and assistant to the president on the arts at Hofstra University in Hempstead, L.I.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)--The Senate Labor Committee approved today a bill liberalizing the cold war G.I. law that was passed last year to provide education and other benefits to veterans who served since the Korean war.

WASHINGTON, May 17-- All early political indicators suggest that the Republicans have an excellent chance of beating President Johnson next year if they resist the temptation to run a Republican against him.
JACKSON, Miss, May 17-- Gov. Paul B. Johnson Jr. announced today that he would become a candidate for lieutenant governor in this summer's Democratic primary.
The 10,500-ton United Statesflag freighters Sapphire Etta and Sapphire Gladys were sold at auction at Rotterdam, yesterday. The Etta brought a total of $448,318 and the Gladys a total of $311,271.
Mayor Lindsay, 15 speakers, three clergymen, two singers and the Department of Sanitation Orchestra dedicated the Hunts Point Terminal Market in the Bronx yesterday morning.
WASHINGTON, May 17-- The Senate Appropriations Committee approved today President Johnson's request for $75million more in antipoverty funds to finance summer programs.
"My ship has sails that are made of silk, the decks are trimmed with gold," Julie Andrews sang wistfully yesterday, playing the role of the late Gertrude Lawrence for the cameras filming "Star!"

A Housing Authority official said at a public hearing yesterday that the State Public Service Commission should find out why the average residential consumer of electricity here paid so much more than consumers in the nine other largest cities in the nation.
MADRID, May 17--Students of Madrid University smashed the offices of the dean of the School of Sciences today and then fought for three hours with mounted and foot policemen.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 17 (AP)--The South Vietnamese Government began moving the first of about 11,000 peasants today from the area south of Giolinh, near the demilitarized zone where burned-out homes, shell craters and fresh burial mounds bear witness to the fighting.
QUITO, Ecuador, May 17 (Reuters)--About 2,000 proChinese Communist students were unsuccessful today in an armed bid to take control of the Central University here.

KINSHASA, the Congo, May 17--Gen. Joseph D. Mobuto, the President of the Congo, forecast today sweeping political and economic reforms, including the return to a twoparty system and stabilization of the shaky Congoleae franc

OF the many consequences --nearly all of them dis- astrous--that have followed on the terrible Italian floods of last November, what is without question the most delectable has now materialized in New York. This is the exhibition called "The Italian Heritage," which opened last night at Wildenstein Co., 19 East 64th Street, for the benefit of the Committee to Rescue Italian Art.
Irving W. Bailey, a leading botanical researcher who specialized in the cell structure of wood, died of a heart attack Tuesday at the Stillman Infirmary of Harvard University. He was 82 years old.

The N.A.A.C.P. Legal Defense and Educational Fund, Inc., announced yesterday plans to provide legal and research services to all legislators who request it and especially to newly elected Negro officials in the South, including legislators and those in other posts.

The rich and famous who inhabit the United Nations Plaza got a little tired of merely smiling at one another in the elevators of that vast year-old residential palace, so they did something about it. They paid $10 apiece to be introduced last night at a cocktail party and buffet supper.

IN the Grove Press edition of Bertolt Brecht's "Drums in the Night," the translator Frank Jones tells us that Brecht came to regret having written such a vigorous defense of a man's right to duck political commitment in the face of danger.

A large, friendly, musiciansprinkled audience was at Carnegie Hall last night for Ray Lev's welcome-home party. The American pianist was appearing here for the first time in five years, having been teaching and giving concerts in Europe, Africa and the Far East.
Lawrence J. McManus, a former assistant district attorney in Manhattan, died of a heart attack on Tuesday in his home at 452 West 49th Street. He was 61 years old.

FORT JACKSON, S.C., May 17--The court's chief officer ruled today that the defense in the court-martial of Capt. Howard B. Levy could introduce evidence attempting to prove that the Green Berets were guilty of war crimes and crimes against humanity.
More than 150 persons paid $500 each to attend a dinner party last night at the WaldorfAstoria Hotel for Sol Wachtler, the Republican candidate for Nassau County Executive.
PARIS, May 17--President de Gaulle has made himself clear on membership in the Common Market for the British. He does not want them in. But can he keep them out?

BRUSSELS, May 17--The successful conclusion of the Kennedy round of tariff negotiations has considerably increased the chances that Jean Rey, the chief negotiator for the European Economic Community, will become the next president of the E.E.C. commission.
LOS ANGELES, May 17 (AP)--Don Sutton pitched a seven-hitter for his first victory of the season as the Los Angeles Dodgers drubbed the Houston Astros, 7-0, tonight.

Leaders of the pressmen's and photoengravers' unions reported yesterday that officials of The Daily News had talked with them about setting up a new newspaper or extending the present morning newspaper.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 17 (AP)--United Presbyterians gathered in this Northwest city from throughout the country today, facing a struggle over a new creedal call to pursue peace, "even at the risk to national security."
The New York Life Insurance Company announced yesterday the election of Jerome W. Hull and Carlisle H. Humelsine as directors.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 17--United States Marine pilots attacked two surface-toair missile sites in the demilitarized zone separating North and South Vietnam, a military spokesman reported today.

HONG KONG, May 17-- Bands of rioting teen-agers brought new violence to Hong Kong today, shattering the uneasy peace of the last three days. Communist followers demonstrated outside the residence of Sir David Trench, Governor of the British crown colony.
Senator Jacob K. Javits said last night that persons on public assistance should have a voice in the "planning and conduct" of the nation's welfare programs.
ROME, May 17 (AP)--Marty Mulligan, an Australian living in Rome, upset top-seeded Tony Roche of Australia, 6-3, 0-6, 6-4, 6-1, to win the Italian tennis championship for the third time today.
PLEASANTVILLE, N.Y., May 17--Mrs. Anne Hyde Clarke Choate, who devoted more than 50 years to furthering the Girl Scout movement, died here today at the age of 80.
BONN, May 17--The West German Government named 17 members of a committee today to investigate the economic state of the German press and the result of press concentration on freedom of opinion.
MT. VERNON, N.Y., Thursday, May 18--Members of the Vernon Heights Congregational Church, after a long and sometimes angry debate, voted at 1:45 this morning to retain their 36-year-old minister.
SAN FRANCISCO, May 17 (A)--The United States Court of Appeals upheld the Securities and Exchange Commission today in ordering the San Francisco Mining Exchange to close its doors.

HANOI, North Vietnam, May 17 (Agence FrancePresse)--The North Vietnamese press published a photo today of an American sailor who fell overboard from the cruiser Canberra off the coast and was captured by militiamen.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)--The United States Coast Guard announced today that it had assigned three cutters and 500 additional men to intercept North Vietnamese vessels carrying men and supplies to South Vietnam.

GRAND RAPIDS, Mich., May 17 (AP)--Stokely Carmichael refused today to confirm or deny a charge by J. Edgar Hoover, a director of the Federal Bureau of Investigation, that he had associated with a Chinese Communist--oriented organization. He suggested that Mr. Hoover resign.
The Chicago Tribune will resume publishing its weekly list of fiction best-sellers next Sunday "rather, queasily" after skipping it for a week, Walter Simmons, Sunday, editor, said yesterday.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP) --The United States has suppressed for nearly 22 years confiscated Japanese films showing gruesome aftereffects of the 1945 atomic bombing of Hiroshima, United States officials disclosed today.

BUENOS AIRES, May 17-- The Federal police announced today that they had seized three members of a pro-Cuban underground group of Communists. The men were described as agents who financed guerrillas by forging dollar bills, travelers checks and passports.
The prime mover of last Saturday's Fifth Avenue parade in support of United States troops in Vietnam questioned yesterday a New York Times report that 70,810 persons had marched in the demonstration.

More than 5,000 plant workers employed by the New York Telephone Company left their jobs 45 minutes early yesterday in a dispute over a request to have a second man accompany an employe who had been assigned to go into a "highcrime area."

The city's Health Services Administrator proposed yesterday that the new State Constitution allow the setting up of a local, nonprofit public service corporation to operate health facilities for New York City.

GENEVA, May 17--With the Kennedy round negotiations out of the way, the underdeveloped countries of the world will step up their campaign for special tariff concessions from major industrial countries on exports of manufactured and semimanufactured goods.

WESTFIELD, N.J., May 17 --Parley S. Ketcham of 264 Prospect Street, a former sales manager for the New York area for the Quaker Oats Company, died yesterday at Muhlenberg Hospital, Plainfield. He retired in 1951 after 34 years with Quaker Oats. He was 81 years old.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 17-- A Federal court judge ruled here today that the state could not enter into contracts with four companies for the construction of a $12.8-million medical science building at Ohio State University because discriminatory hiring practices were permitted by the contractors.
AMERICA'S WESTERN FRONTIERS. The Story of the Explorers and Settlers Who Opened the Trans-Mississippi West. By John A. Hawgood. 440 pages. With maps and pictures. Knopf. $10.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (UPI)--The House Armed Services Committee voted today to write into the draft law restrictions on the President's authority for drafting college undergraduates and setting up a lottery system.

Alarm and anxiety over the growing intensity of the Vietnam war are behind the pleas and threats coming out of the United States Senate in recent days. Sixteen Senators, led by Frank Church, Idaho Democrat, yesterday published a statement intended for Hanoi saying that despite their criticism of President Johnson's policies they are against a withdrawal of American forces. They are only the latest in a growing list of anguished and helpless onlookers.

NEXT Monday Representative Paul A. Fino, who created a stir last week by placing a sign at the Bronx line excluding that borough from Fun City, will unleash another somewhat flamboyant attack on Mayor Lindsay. It will be a song, sung to the tune of "Sidewalks of New York."
The Board of Education, alarmed by an increase in venereal disease among teenagers, is teaching juniors in half the city's high schools about the dangers of gonorrhea and syphilis.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 17-- In an effort to make Nassau County a cleaner and greener place, Nassau County Executive Eugene H. Nickerson said today he has asked business concerns to help beautify hundreds of unimproved parcels of land that dot the county.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The House today decided, by a substantial margin, to halt the controversial rent supplement program. The decision was a major defeat for the Johnson Administration.

CEDAR RAPIDS, Iowa, May 17 (AP)--The Order of Railway Conductors and Brakemen announced today the settlement of a dispute that had threatened a strike on April 1 against 90 per cent of the nation's major railroads.

SANTA FE, N.M.--Achievement in the customary sense of secondary school education is a constant, knotted challenge for the 250 boys and girls of Indian extraction at the Institute of American Indian Arts here. But in the arts they suddenly discover that they have a voice and a facility.
WASHINGTON, May 17-- An $8.7-million program to find the causes and cures of traffic accidents was announced today by the Federal Highway Administration.

IRVINGTON, N.J., May 17 --Two girls, one 8 years old and the other 11, were arrested today after the police here said they had admitted breaking into five homes and taking $550 in cash and $350 in jewelry.
WILMINGTON, Del., May 17 --The Southern Pacific Company, like all other railroads in the nation, continues to experience a slowdown in its freight traffic.

Representative Paul A. Fino yesterday urged Republican leaders in the city and state and other party members to join him in a fight "to save our party structure from the Lindsayites who are working to grab control of our organizations."

Mrs. Edward Lasker's Indulto, unable to reach the winner's circle since taking the Jim Dandy at Saratoga last August, caused a surprise at Aqueduct yesterday by capturing the 25th running of the $27,750 Roseben Handicap.

The euphoria that enveloped the conference of hemispheric Presidents at Punta del Este in April is being dissipated with unusual speed. A meeting of the United Nations Economic Commission for Latin America, which has just ended in Caracas, seems to have been consumed by the old intractable problems of underdeveloped Latin America versus the developed industrial nations.
WASHINGTON, May 17--The United States called today for expanding the activities of the United Nations peace-keeping
The memory of Stanley M. Isaacs, the late Manhattan Borough President and City Councilman, was honored yesterday at the annual meeting of the Woman's City Club of New York.

BRONXVILLE, N.Y., May 17 --Thomas J. Muldowney, a founder in 1961 and president of Brawn Wholesale, Inc., 500 Fifth Avenue, New York, wholesalers of general merchandise, died of a heart attack yesterday at his home at 2 Cross Street. He was 47 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 17-- Corporate profits, before taxes, declined by $4.5-billion, to an annual rate of $77.3-billion, in the first quarter this year, the Commerce Department reported today.
LONDON, May 17--The British Government, defying the now open opposition of President de Gaulle, vowed today to press for early negotiations on its bid to join the Common Market.
Amrican Airlines announced here yesterday the election of George A. Spater to the new post of vice chairman of the board of directors.
WASHINGTON, May 17-- Janos Radvanyi, the top-ranking Hungarian diplomat in Washington, has defected and sought political asylum in the United States.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)--Gen. Nguyen Chanh Thi, a controversial South Vietnamese officer who was involved in Buddhist extremist efforts last year to topple the Government of Premier Nguyen Cao Ky, has asked permission to return home as quickly as possible.

YESTERDAY (May 17, 1967) THE PRESIDENT Met with American Bar Association committee on judicial selections; held Cabinet meeting; saw Belgian Vice Premier Willy de Clerq: met with state education leaders; held military reception.

Sugar prices drifted down a bit in the world market yesterday in fairly active volume of 2,585 contracts. The September delivery closed at 2.75 cents a pound, down from Tuesday's close of 2.85. The spot price remained at 2.55 cents a pound. Talk of low priced sugar offered to Spain and the purchase of 20,000 tons of semirefined sugar by Iran from Russia may have been depressing factors.
Several executive appointments were announced yesterday in the Macy's New York division of R.H. Macy Co., Inc., by David L. Yunich, president of Macy's New York.

There are so many electricity lines, gas pipes, highand low-pressure water mains and hydrants, telephone conduits, fire-alarm wires and drainage pipes underground at the site of the new Police Headquarters near City Hall that the city is hiring a company to sort them out and coordinate efforts to move them.
HANNIBAL, Mo., May 17 (UPI)--Searchers dug into a fresh highway roadbed with earth-moving equipment today, seeking a cavern or fissure into which three boys may have disappeared a week ago.
The annual Sidney Hillman Foundation awards for outstanding achievement in mass communications were presented to six men yesterday for their work in 1966.

Judging from the pitch Look made at a lunch yesterday to more than 1,000 agency and advertising people, the $665,000 it spent to serialize William Manchester's "The Death of a President" was money well spent.

LONDON, May 17--Highly placed British sources said today that Foreign Secretary George Brown would urge the Soviet Union this week to remove some combat troops from East Germany, just as Britain and the United States plan to remove such forces from West Germany.
A merger plan between Hayes Industries, Inc., and the Albion Malleable Iron Company was approved in principle yesterday. The deal would involve stock worth about $23-million.
BONN, May 17--The West German cabinet formed a special committee today to deal with three letters addressed to the Government during the last fortnight by the East German regime.
HOUSTON, May 17--A policeman was killed and two other policemen and a student were wounded early today in an exchange of rifle fire during a five-hour riot at Texas

THE DOUR VIEW of William McChesney Mar tin Jr. on in-and-out trading as expressed by the Federal Reserve Board chairman on Tuesday did not make the hit parade of the big institutional investors--as anyone might predict.
The sons of two widelyknown businessmen were elected yesterday to the board of Trans World Airlines, Inc., increasing the number of directors to 20.

TWO years ago two British experts were charged with cheating at the World Championship in Buenos Aires and found guilty by the World Bridge Federation. Fifteen months later a British inquiry reached a verdict of not guilty and the matter is on the agenda of the World Bridge Federation when it meets in Miami in a week's time.
New York State has turned down New York City's plans for controlling incinerator pollution in the city's own housing projects.

WASHINGTON, May 17-- Representative Joseph E. Karth criticized the press, Congress and the Administration today, contending that all had failed to put the space program--and particularly the Apollo fire-- into the proper perspective.
MADRID, May 17--Spain demanded today that Britain resume immediately the interrupted talks that the United Nations had recommended on the "decolonization" of Gibraltar.

Mrs. Roberta Barton Dufton, who operated an employment agency in the Empire State Building from 1945 to 1960, dealing in executive posts in advertising, radio and television, died Monday in a hospital in Orangeburg, N.Y., after a long illness. She was 66 years old and formerly lived at 50 Park Avenue.

The Beaunit Corporation, textile producers, reported an operating loss of $1,188,707 in the fiscal year ended March 31 in contrast to a net income of $7,872,051, or $2.02 a share, shown for the preceding fiscal year, the report disclosed yesterday.

"I WAS halfway through the meal," Herbert Skoble said with a frown to cloud a Montrachet or curdle a bearnaise, "and they still hadn't poured the wine." "They" were waiters at one of New York's posh dining establishments. And that was the moment he decided to turn chef and sommelier and to entertain clients in his own office, which is Herbert Skoble Associates, producers of television commercials.

The highest bidders at an auction yesterday walked off with souvenirs that, costly or not, will be constant reminders of such perennially hit tunes as "Night and Day," "Begin the Beguine," "Anything Goes," "It's DeLovely."

GREENWICH, Conn., May 17--Mrs. Ethel T. Fletcher, a founder of the Greenwich Community Chest Council, died last night in Greenwich Hospital at the age of 86. She was the widow of Henry Fletcher, a New York lawyer.

CHICAGO, May 16 (AP)-- Simon Malley, Western writer who visited Peking in March, reported today that top Chinese leaders believed a shooting war on the Soviet-Chinese border was "possible and even probable."

A pontifical mass will be offered for Miss Philippa Duke Schuyler at 11 o'clock this morning in St. Patrick's Cathedral. Miss Schuyler, an American pianist, was killed in a helicopter crash May 9 in Vietnam, where she was working as a correspondent.
LOUISVILLE, Ky., May 17 (UPI)--An open-housing demonstration broke up in a fist fight and a barrage of eggs and stones, thrown by hecklers in the city's predominantly white South End tonight.

The City Council's Finance Committee voted in executive session yesterday to restore a $315,000 item in the 1967-68 expense budget, that would save the 55-year-old Sanitation Department Band, which Mayor Lindsay wants to abolish.

WASHINGTON, May 17 (AP)--Waste and inefficiency by the Navy and a major contractor pushed cnstruction costs up unnecessarily during the rapid buildup of United States forces in Vietnam, the General Accounting Office charged today.

DISASTER, delicately perfumed but unmistakable, struck the Royal Ballet at the Metropolitan Opera House last night. It came from an unexpected source, John Cranko, one of the Royal Ballet's three major choreographers and creator of "Germany's ballet miracle," the Stuttgart Ballet. The disaster was called "Brandenburg Nos. 2 4." The music, not unexpectedly in the circumstances, was by Bach.
In its largest grant to an individual college, and its first to one not yet in operation, the Ford Foundation has awarded $3-million on a matching basis to Hampshire College, Amherst, Mass.
Dr. Edwin B. Knowles, a professor of English at Pratt Institute, died Monday in New York University Hospital. He was 64 years old.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)--Pete Richert held the Baltimore Orioles to three hits tonight and the Washington Senators scored on a sacrifice fly and an error to beat the Orioles, 2-0.

The Great Atlantic Pacific Tea Company, the nation's largest food chain, had the best annual increase in earnings in four years and turned in record sales for the fiscal year ended Feb. 25, the report disclosed yesterday.

The key to preventing a strike in hundreds of New York apartment houses this weekend lies in City Hall. Local 32-B of the Building Service Employees Union has kept its members on the job through seventeen strikeless years, even though rent controls caused wages in the apartment houses to drop $16 a week behind those received by the union's members in office and loft buildings.

The Ford Foundation announced yesterday two more substantial grants to the theater, $474,000 to the American Place Theater of New York and $870,000 to the Minnesota Theater Company of Minneapolis. They follow the foundation's announcement earlier in the week of a $434,000 grant to aid the recently organized Negro Ensemble Company.
DETROIT, May 18--Henry Ford 2d warned today that "substantial price increases" on new cars would be coming next fall because of the cost of new safety and anti-smog equipment.

WASHINGTON, May 18--The United States won "very significant" reductions in some barriers to America's agricultural exports in the Kennedy round of trade talks, the chief United States farm negotiator said today.
DETROIT, May 18--Earlier this week, the Detroit Institute of Arts planned a news conference to announce an art theft. By the time the conference was held today, there were two thefts to announce.

STRAMOND LAKE, Que., May 18--The behavior of lake trout and pike at iceout time is not easily figured. In theory they are supposed to be ravenously hungry, bolting down bait fish and anglers' lures with greed and abandon.

PITTSBURGH, May 18 (AP) --Cees Groot scored two goals and assisted on two others in leading the Pittsburgh Phantoms to victory over the New York Generals, 5-3, tonight in a National Soccer League game.
Trading volume expanded yesterday on the American Stock Exchange but the price pattern at the close was irregular.
Julius F.E. Nickelsburg, business manager of the American Lutheran Publicity Bureau for 38 years, died Wednesday at a nursing home in Kansas City, M.o. He was 92 years old and lived in Kansas City.

Two men were arrested yesterday on bribery charges after they had allegedly given $20 to a woman clerk in the office of United States Attorney Robert M. Morgenthau for the names and addresses of two defendants under indictment in a pornography case.

The Colorado Interstate Gas Company made public yesterday a proposal to acquire the Pacific Northwest Pipeline Cor- poration, which the Supreme Court has ordered divested from the El Paso Natural Gas Company.
When Burton R. Wolf, traveling book salesman, was in a strange town he could never find anything.
FORT WORTH, May 18-- Ben Hogan took a double-bogey 6 at the 17th today and it cost him a chance to tie for the first-round lead in the $115,000 Colonial Country Club invitation tournament.
WASHINGTON, May 18--Following is the official transcript of President Johnson's news conference today:

The Western Hemisphere's central Reform Jewish group has written 2,000 Jewish leaders charging that Congregation Emanu-El of New York has opposed many "dynamic and important programs" in the last quarter century.
HONG KONG, May 18--Chinese Communists here and in Peking made new threats today against the Hong Kong Government. The British colonial authorities met them with apparent calm and firmness.
WASHINGTON, May 18-- Revenue freight, traffic gonerated by carloadings on United States railroads and intercity truck tonnage in the week ended May 13 were both below the corresponding 1966 week.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)--The National Transportation Safety Board today scheduled a heartng June 6 on a plane collision near Urbana, Ohio, March 9 in which 26 persons died.

GENEVA, May 18--The disarmament conference resumed today, and Brazil served notice that she would refuse to sign the proposed treaty to stop the spread of nuclear weapons unless it was changed to permit nonnuclear powers to conduct atomic explosions for "great engineering works.
BONN, May 18--The conflict between church and state in North Rhine-Westphalia, West Germany's largest state, on parochial schools in the state school system has been eased by a compromise solution.

Martha Raye will receive the United Service Organizations of New York Woman-of-the-Year award Tuesday for entertaining servicemen in South Vietnam. The presentation will be made at a supper dance at the Rainbow Room following the evening performance of "Hello, Dolly!", in which she is starring at the St. James Theater. Some 400 persons will go on to the supper dance after the show.

A Coast Guard outter took Arthur J. Goldberg, the United States delegate to the United Nations, off a sightseeing boat in New York Harbor last night so he could be briefed on developments at the United Nations relating to the situation in the Mid dle East.

UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 18 --Secretary General Thant said today that he had decided to withdraw the United Nations Emergency Force from the armistice line between Israel and the United Arab Republic.
Attorney General Ramsey Clark said yesterday that he did not believe there was a crime wave in the nation.

Mrs. Elisa Parada de Migel, widow of M.C. Migel, chief founder of the American Foundation for the Blind and its first president, from 1922 to 1945, died Wednesday at her home, 580 Park Avenue. She was 90 years old.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 17-- A major effort to end the long and unpredictable political career of Senator Wayne Morse, the stormy Democrat of Oregon, is expected in 1968 by leaders of both parties here.
John Wesley Work, composer of "Go Tell It on the Mountain" and a retired professor of music at Fisk University in Nashville, Tenn., died there yesterday following a long illness. He was 66 years old.
The leadership of the Liberal party has split on the issue of state aid for parochial schools.

COLUMBUS, Ohio, May 18 (AP)--The administration of Gov. James A. Rhodes has "welcomed" yesterday's Federal court decision by which it was enjoined from signing construction contracts with four concerns until they could prove that equal job opportunities exist for Negroes.
Stock prices drifted downward in active trading yesterday, with losses outnumbering advances by a small margin at the close.

WHITE PLAINS, N.Y., May 18--Anthony J. Vileno of the Whippoorwill Club won the 33d annual spring tournament of the Westchester Seniors' Golf Association by seven strokes today with a 71 at Westchester Hills Golf Club.
THE GIRL IN THE FREUDIAN SLIP" is a play about, and in need of, a psychiatrist.
GREENWICH, Conn., May 18 --Mrs. Joan Patricia Skakel, widow of George Skakel Jr., a brother of Mrs. Robert F. Kennedy, died tonight at her home on Vineyard Lane. She was 39 years old.

COLD SPRING HARBOR, L.I., May 18--The engagement of Miss Dorothy Callaway, daughter of Mr. and Mrs. Samuel R. Callaway, to Michael Howard Paul Belknap, son of Mr. and Mrs. Paul E. Belknap of New York, has been announced by her parents.

BRUSSELS, May 18--The predominant view in the capitals of the five members of the European Common Market that support British entry into the community is that President de Gaulle's attempt to dampen the British initiative is the tactics of any negotiator before bargaining.
If the directors of the National Association of Broadcasters agree with their television code board, TV viewers will get substantial relief, starting next year, from the many program interruptions.
IN RETROSPECT, Control Data this year has been an investor's dream. Yesterday's action was the icing on the cake.
WASHINGTON, May 18--The Treasury took emergency action today to halt a sudden run on its remaining stock of silver.

THREE teams will contest the final of the New York double elimination knockout championship for the Von Zedtwitz Trophy. The first of two round-robin sessions will be played tonight at 8 o'clock at the Mayfair Club, 119 West 57th Street, and there will be accommodation for kibitzers. The second session will be played Sunday at 1 P.M.

WASHINGTON, May 18--The House Armed Services Committee approved today new legislation on the draft that would give Congress a potential veto over President Johnson's power to induct eligible 19-year-olds by lot.

GREENWICH, Conn., May 18 --Mr. and Mrs. J. Sterling Rock efeller have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Christina Rockefeller, to J. John DuBois. He is the son of Mrs. Nunez Broussard DuBois of Kaplan, La., and S. Louis DuBois of Port Arthur, Tex.
PARIS, May 18--Leaders of the opposition to the Gaullist regime filed a motion of censure in the National Assembly today against the government of Premier Georges Pompidou.
The bond market milled around in yesterday's session and ended unchanged to a little lower in price.

BONN, May 18--Dr. Gustav Heinemann, West German Minister of Justice, disclosed today that he and officials of the Interior Ministry were examining the question whether a rightwing radical newspaper had violated the federal Constitution.

WESTBURY, L.I. May 18-- As 2-year-old trotters are bad betting risks because of their greenness, there will be no wagering on the Volomite Futurity tomorrow night at Roosevelt Raceway. In fact, unless those interested in seeing these juvemiles in action arrive early, they will miss the opportunity for a look-see at the potential stars of tomorrow.
Governor Rockefeller coined a phrase yesterday for esthetic blight--"visual pollution."
The directors of the Columbia Pictures Corporation recom mended yesterday a two-for-one split of the common stock to be distributed to shareholders of record July 27.
A contingent of 2,800 West Point cadets will lead the 18th annual Armed Forces Day parade down Fifth Avenue from 90th Street to 62d Street tomorrow afternoon.
The American Stock Exchange reported Wednesday the changes carried below in the shareholdings of officers, directors and major stockholders of listed companies.

BERLIN, May 18--A hardening of the attitude of East European countries toward West Germany was indicated today with the announcement that they had refused to attend West Berlin's cultural festival this year.
HONG KONG, May 18, (Reuters)--The Chinese gold and silver exchange had one of its most active trading sessions in months today.

Six Harlem youths gently tapping drums led a funeral procession down Fifth Avenue yesterday for Philippa Duke Schuyler, American pianist, composer and writer who was killed in the crash of a United States Army helicopter in Danang Bay, South Vietnam.
CHICAGO, May 18--New York's Senators enlivened a Senate antipoverty hearing today with a caustic verbal exchange.
Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan will reconsider naming a popular Harlem principal as district superintendent of an area in lower Manhattan.
WASHINGTON, May 18-- New orders received by manufacturers of durable goods--a key indicator of future econnomic trends--rose slightly in April, the Department of Commerce reported today.
RIO GRANDE CITY, Tex., May 16--Rio Grande City, parched and dusty, sits uncomfortably astraddle modern, wellpaved U.S. 83, which runs down the valley 100 miles to Brownsville and the Gulf of Mexico.
British Government bonds registered widespread gains in active trading yesterday on the London Stock Exchange.
WASHINGTON, May 18.-- The Senate Judiciary Committee approved today the key section of a bill that was apparently designed to delay the reshaping of New York State's Congressional districts.

Miracle Mart, Inc., a discount-store chain, which filed a petition under the Chapter XI provision of the Bankruptcy Act in December, 1966, reached a settlement yesterday to pay 30 per cent of its debts to unsecured or trade creditors.

YOU know those people who say they are only number one, or number two or number six and a half and then try to rent a bicycle or some such conveyance to you--I can offer them a new field for rivalry. Rent-a-ballet! It is a well-known fact of dance life that to get a good ballet you need a good choreographer.

Gifts and pledges totaling more than $27.3-million have been received by Columbia University since the opening of the school's three-year fund drive late last fall, Grayson Kirk, president, said last night.

MARTHA ELIZABETH PETERSON, who describes herself as "a healthy looking Scandinavian," will bring to her new position as president of Barnard College the conviction that students can handle more responsibility than many adults think.
Telephone installers and repairmen who had struck in a dispute over protection for employes assigned to high-crime neighborhoods were expected to be back at work today.
SANDWICH, England, May 18--The United States will meet Britain in the 21st competition for the Walker Cup over the undulating dunes of Royal St. George's seaside links tomorrow and Saturday.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, Friday, May 19--An enemy battalion trapped and overran a platoon of 48 United States infantrymen yesterday in the central highlands of South Vietnam. The Americans called artillery fire on their own position, then fell silent.

The New England Governors who expressed concern to President Johnson this week over the future of the New Haven Railroad have good reason for their fears. Vital as the railroad is to the area's transportation and economic needs, there is once again a real danger that its trains may stop running within the next few months for lack of cash.

FOR nearly 90 years, architects and designers have done their best to keep lighting under wraps. Now the bare bulb is making a comeback in some circles, bringing with it spaghetti-like tangles of exposed wiring.
These elder boppers got that way with Cotts root beer because, as a coming commercial puts it, "New Cott Draft Root Beer Swings."
LANSING, Mich., May 18-- Michigan's Senate passed today an income tax and fiscal reform package, a major victory for Gov. George Romney's efforts to win fiscal reform in the state.
The Federal Reserve System's hand on the credit throttle remained steady in the week ended Wednesday, statistics released yesterday indicated.

Mr. and Mrs. Francis H. Horan of New York and Cornwall Hollow, Conn., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Elizabeth Frances Horan, to David Leighton Edgerly, son of Mrs. Josephine K. Edgerly of Brownsville, Vt., and the late Dr. Sherburn Edgerly, a physician, of Englewood, N.J. The wedding is planned for July.
Walter Everett has been appointed director of the American Press Institute of Columbia University, a 21-year-old professional center for the improvement of newspapers.

MILWAUKEE, May 18--Mr. and Mrs. Vernon A. Swanson have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Ann Elizabeth Swanson, to William H. Vanderbilt Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. Vanderbilt of Williamstown, Mass., and New York.

ROCHESTER, May 18--John G. Mulder, the Eastman Kodak Company executive who signed an agreement--later repudiated by the company--to hire 600 unskilled Negroes, was dropped today as an assistant vice president of Kodak.
LANSING, Mich., May 18 (UPI)--Mrs. George Romney resigned from a private club in Detroit today to protest the club's alleged anti-Negro policy.
The chairman of the New York City Housing Authority said yesterday he was exploring all possible means to avoid raising rents to meet the costs of upgrading incinerators.

Despite the fresh widening of the deficit recorded by the United States in its balance of payments for the first quarter, Secretary, of the Treasury Henry H. Fowler has found something to cheer about. Pointing out that the dollar outflow attributable to the Vietnam war is still increasing, he insisted that the results give evidence that "we continue to hold our own."

Spark's Pub South, 123 East 18th Street, GR 5-9696. If you have a taste for art nouveau and reasonably wellprepared Italian food, there might be much to your liking at Spark's Pub South. It is a long, narrow restaurant with dim lighting and posters pinned to the wall and a jukebox, which seems, oddly enough, appropriate to the mood of the place.

DALLAS, May 18 (AP)-- Francois Pavilla, the Frenchman who has never lost to an American, makes his bid for the world welterweight title tomorrow night against Curtis Cokes of Dallas, the champion, in a 15-round fight. Cokes has never lost to a European.
Transportation over the next 20 years will remain a private enterprise industry, the board chairman of the Transportation Association of America predicted here yesterday.

HOUSTON, May 18--A student leader said today that "hate" caused Tuesday night's riot at Texas Southern University, where a Houston policeman was killed and two policemen and a student were wounded by gunfire.

PARIS--Three factors have dominated political life in modern Greece: (1)--the popular vote, whether honest or rigged; (2)--the army, symbolically headed by the King; (3)--the "foreign factor," meaning first Britain and then, since the Truman Doctrine, the U.S.A.

Last Thursday, Leo O'Brien crashed with Mrs. James J. Walsh Jr.'s Orpheo at the first jump of the spring steeplechase at Aqueduct. He was taken to the hospital where seven stitches were required to sew up his left instep.

The American Ballet theater's "Fall River Legend," presented for the first time this season at the State Theater on Wednesday evening, included a moving performance by Sallie Wilson as Lizzie Borden. But the ballet's inability to transcend the choreographically obvious caused interest to drain away long before Lizzie's rendezvous with the gibbet.

LOUISVILLE Ky., May 18 (UPI)--A barrage of stones and bottles hurled from a dark alley disrupted a peaceful march held tonight by open housing advocates through the city's predominantly white South End.

The downturn in sales and earnings of the International Harvester Company continued into the second fiscal quarter, increasing the decline in results for the half year period ended April 30, according to the report issued yesterday.
BALTIMORE, May 18--Melvin (Sunshine) Calvert had long since departed from Pimlico's Barn EE for Garden State Park, where he had two horses to saddle today.
MADRID, May 18--Virtual occupation of the Madrid University campus by the Spanish police went into effect today in the wake of rioting yesterday.

Cyclists and strollers, who now have Central Park to themselves on most of each weekend without having to dodge automobiles, probably will also get exclusive rights to the park on Tuesday nights during the summer.
DAMASCUS, Syria, May 18 --The radical young rulers of Syria pledged implacable hostility to Israel this week as Israel entered her 20th year of nationhood.
WASHINGTON, May 18--The Interior Department has recommended that the Soviet Union be eliminated from bidding on three giant new electric generating units at Grand Coulee Dam on the Columbia River.

JOHANNESBURG, May 18 --A newspaper reporter was sentenced today to six weeks in jail for refusing to reveal his sources of information in connection with his articles on neo-Nazi activities in South Africa.
HAVANA, May 18 (AP)-- The Communist party acknowledged today that three Cubans had helped a guerrilla band land in Venezuela, and said it would continue to aid guerrillas all over the world.
Thomas P.F. Hoving moved the Metropolitan Museum of Art out of doors yesterday, but not very far.
Arthur Ashe of Richmond, the ranking amateur tennis player of the country, was named formally yesterday on the Davis Cup team that will oppose Mexico May 27, 28 and 29.

A father accompanied by his 12 children, most of them usually beaming but one tot sometimes teary-eyed, was among 106 Sanitation Department workers promoted in a ceremony on The Mall in Central Park yesterday.
The short interest position of shares traded on the New York Stock Exchange rose last month to the highest level in the 36 years the exchange has compiled such figures.

COLUMBIA, S.C., May 18-- The defense for Capt. Howard B. Levy, the young Army doctor who is being court-martialed at Fort Jackson for willful refusal to obey an order, broadcast an appeal today for witnesses who can offer testimony...

WASHINGTON, May 18-- Robert S. McNamara, the Secretary of Defense, held out the possibility today of a limit on missiles by the United States and the Soviet Union that would still permit each country to defend itself against nuclear attack by Communist China.

The police Department admitted last night that a 1967 Thunderbird belonging to a New Jersey driver, which had been picked up for illegal parking in the de partment's Operation Towaway, had been stolen from the department's Pier 96 towaway pound.
DENVILLE, N.J., May 18-- Three golfers were tied for first place after the second round of the fourth annual $25,000 Dodge Open today.
The Scott Paper Company has announced the election of George Olmsted Jr. and Walter H. Wilcox as vice presidents and directors.
MIAMI, May 18 (UPI)-- Cassius Clay was arrested today on a seven-month-old traffic charge and later went free on $75 bond.

The Lenox Hill Neighborhood Association will benefit from a Zoocotheque Thursday at the Terrace Cafe and Restaurant of the Central Park Zoo. There will be live music for dancing on the terrace and a buffet dinner will be served.

WILMINGTON, May 18 (UPI)--The Defense Department identified today 65 United States servicemen who had been killed in action in Vietnam. Among them were: Pfc. Daniel E. Togneri of the Bronx and Specialist 4 David A. Dixon of Weedsport, N.Y., both of the Army.

Plans to establish neighborhood outpatient medical-care centers where they are needed were announced yesterday by Dr. Edward O'Rourke, the city's Health Commissioner. Some may be set up in store fronts.
A $250,000 engineering study that may lead to a new East Side subway was approved yesterday by the Board of Estimate, subject to a favorable report by Controller Mario A. Procaccino.
MONTREAL, May 18-- Prompt action for the reform of the international monetary system was urged today by George S. Moore, the president of the First National City Bank, New York.
BERLIN, May 18--Highranking sources said here today that East Germany has offered arms to the United Arab Republic and to the Palestine Liberation Organization for use against Israel.

JERUSALEM (Israel) May 18--Israel said today that she was taking "appropriate measures" in the wake of a buildup of United Arab Republic forces in the Sinai Peninsula. This was interpreted as indicating a partial call-up of reserves to guard against sudden attack, but not full mobilization.

DONGHA, South Vietnam, Friday, May 19--United States and South Vietnamese troops have launched their first fullscale assault into the demilitarized zone separating the two Vietnams, a military spokesman announced today.

Hooting and chanting, several hundred pickets from three public employe unions marched outside the St. George Hotel in Brooklyn last night to protest Anthony Travia's role in amending state strike legislation.

NAIROBI, Kenya, May 18-- Kenya's ruling political party bitterly attacked United States policies abroad today. It accused the United States of taking a naive approach to Africa and seeking "to make the Far East safe for CocaCola" by fighting in Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)--The Roman Catholic bishops of the United States said today that the use of the English language in the mass, and other liturgical reforms coming from the Vatican Council, had made worship a more vital and meaningful experience for American Catholics.

WASHINGTON, May 18-- Senator Russell B. Long asked the Democratic and Republican leaders of the Senate today to postpone for six weeks the calling up of the resolution of censure against Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP) --Gov. John A. Volpe of Massachusetts decried today what he called a lack of consistent policy for the United States merchant marine.
WASHINGTON, May 18--A vaccine against a common virus infection of military recruits has dramatically choked off epidemics of illness similar to colds and flu, it was reported today.

IT'S more than four decades since they rode dramatically across the football firmament and yet the legend of the Four Horsemen of Notre Dame has so much resiliency that it endures. In an inspired mo ment at the 1924 Army-Notre Dame game Grantland Rice hung this distinctive label on a remarkably gifted backfield quartet, en dowing this unbeaten national championship team with a degree of immortality.

PATERSON, N.J., May 18-- Abram B. Cohen, a partner in Samuel Cohen Sons, glass and hardware merchants, died today in the Barnert Memorial Hospital. He was 72 years old and lived at 480 East 29th Street here.
Seventy-five members of a Reform Democratic club voted last night to oppose the renomination of President Johnson in 1968 because of their opposition to his Vietnam policy.
Richard Conte of Cardinal Spellman High set two meet records yesterday in the Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championships.

The Republican leadership in the House has again turned its back on the cities of the nation. Fulfilling the gloomiest predictions, Representative Ford of Michigan, the minority leader, and his colleagues worked with the more reactionary Southern Democrats to kill the model-city and rent-subsidy programs.

BALTIMORE, May 18 (AP) --Officials of the United Steelworkers of America announced prematurely today the formation of a nationwide on-the-job training program partly aimed to increase the rate of promotion of Negro workers.

Bertram A. Powers, head of the printers union local, said yesterday that negotiators for The Long Island Press were seeking to rescind a number of previously agreed upon sections of their proposed contract.
MOSCOW, Friday, May 19 (Reuters)--Yuri V. Andropov, a national secretary of the Soviet Communist party, has been appointed chief of the secret police, it was officially announced today.

WASHINGTON, May 18-- The Administration will almost certainly seek restoration in the Senate of authority that the House denied it yesterday for selling to private investors some $2.3-billion worth of financial assets the Government now holds.
NASHVILLE, Tenn., May 18 (UPI)--Gov. Buford Ellington signed a bill today repealing Tennessee's so-called "monkey law," which prohibited the teaching of evolution in the state's public schools.

Eastern and Western railroads filed with the Interstate Commerce Commission yesterday for freight rate increases that would average out at about 3 per cent to 3 per cent. Southern railroads are expected to file today.

An 8-year-old Bronx boy who bragged about extorting money from smaller children in his neighborhood was charged yesterday with having thrown a 4-year-old boy off a roof to his death because he had no money.

LEXINGTON, Mass., May 18 --An analysis by one of the nation's top photographic laboratories has demolished a widely circulated theory that a second gunman was involved in the assassination of President Kennedy.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)--A major trucking industry group approved today a national contract with the International Brotherhood of Teamsters to end a dispute that earlier led to strikes and lockouts around the country.

New York University's Graduate School of Arts and Science will start a program in theater history and criticism of drama and films this fall. The courses will lead to an M.A. degree; next year the university plans to offer Ph.D degrees in the program.

WASHINGTON, May 18-- George R. Wackenhut, general of the Florida Governor's private "war on crime," swore to Congress today that nobody in his detective agency had ever tapped a telephone "so help me God."

WASHINGTON, May 18-- President Johnson sat at the edge of his rocking chair for a half hour today and discussed his cares and affairs with questioning reporters. He made no new disclosures, but showed himself resigned to protracted struggles both in Vietnam and Congress.
LONDON, May 18--A nightshift grocery clerk in Yuba City, Calif., may become the 10th Earl of Essex.
LAGOS, Nigeria, May 18-- Britain announced today that she would give careful consideration to a call for British troops to provide security for a top-level Nigerian meeting.
There were no swings, sandboxes, seesaws or merry-gorounds, but the oval-shaped playgrounds that opened yesterday in the midst of Cypress Hills Houses in East New York were a hit with the youngsters.

David Nederlander, the Detroit theater operator who will be 81 years old Wednesday, and his five sons have purchased half-interest in the Brooks Atkinson Theater, at 256 West 47th Street, from Michael Myerberg, the owner. Mr. Myerberg said yesterday that he and the Nederlanders would be joint managers of the 1,088-seat house.

The General Electric Company is looking for 90,000 people who have purchased large-screen color television receivers since last June. The company said yesterday that it wanted to "modify" these sets against what is described as "X-radiation in excess of desirable levels."
The Actors Equity Association yesterday charged that rank discrimination still existed against the Negro actor in the legitimate theater despite a five-year agreement providing for open casting.
There was no sign of a break yesterday in the contract dispute between a union of building service employes and the owners of many apartment buildings--most of them rentcontrolled--in the city.
The city's reservoirs were only 2 per cent short of brimfull yesterday, according to the Department of Water Supply, Gas and Electricity.

The League of Women Voters, which finished its three-day state convention here yesterday at the Barbizon Plaza, may bring action against the hotel, charging that it failed to provide rooms reserved by the league six years ago.
ALBANY, May 18--The state decided today to let all lottery agents keep a 5-cent commission for each $1 lottery ticket they sell, or less than half of what many of them had asked for.
Lincoln Center: All Hallows Institute Spring Musicale, Philharmonic Hall, 8:30 P.M.

SCENE: Yacht Haven, a spacious, popular marina at Stamford, Conn. A customer, who shortly will be irate, enters. He purchased a new $25,000 cabin cruiser last winter and for the past month he has been ready for it, but it has not been ready for him.
ALBANY, May 18--Secretary of State John P. Lomenzo held today that a special election should be called to decide the tie vote for a Bronx district delegate to the Constitutional Convention.
PORTLAND, Ore., May 18 (UPI)--The Rev. Dr. Eugene Smathers of Big Lick, Tenn., was elected today as the moderator of the United Presbyterian Church in the U.S.A. at its 179th General Assembly.

The Glidden Company, in an unusual court decision, won a temporary restraining order yesterday against the Greatamerica Corporation, which has made a tender offer for 3,560,000 shares of Glidden at $30 a share.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (UPI)--A top union official told Congress today that the nation's railroads would agree on a contract to avert a strike "within 48 hours" if the Government stayed out of the dispute.

Paul S. Dopp, president and chief executive officer of Butler Aviation Company, announced yesterday he had exercised his option to acquire the other 50 per cent interest in Butler Aviation from Paul Butler and the Butler Company.

Carter Hotels, Inc., owner of hotels in New York and other cities, is completing negotiations to purchase the 1,065-room Statler Hilton Hotel in Buffalo from the Hilton Hotels Corporation. The Buffalo hotel is the largest in the state outside Manhattan.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)--"We must no longer allow the atmosphere to be used as a garbage can, without at least knowing the nature of the garbage," a health specialist said today in decrying current approaches to clean air laws.

PHUBAI, South Vietnam, May 18 (AP)--A United States Marine sergeant who said he killed a prisoner because his lieutenant ordered him to, was sentenced today to life imprisonment. Sgt. Charles D. Wilkerson, 23 years old, of...

NEARLY every little girl who saw Anna Pavlova in the flesh contracted an acute desire to dance and undoubtedly many more will do so after having seen Channel 13's perceptive Thursday evening program, "The Creative Person," devoted to her art. For Pavlova clearly displayed the "charm, projection and electricity" descidbed by her American impresario Sol Hurok.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP)--Jim Banning blanked the National League-leading Cincinnati Reds without a hit or a run after the first inning tonight as he pitched the Philadelphia Phillies to a 7-1 victory. Bunning allowed three hits in the first inning.
LISBON, May 18--A political organization is believed to have been behind the theft of $1-million from the Bank of Portugal by five masked gunmen who made their getaway in a stolen plane.
REGGIO EMILIA, Italy, May 18 (AP)--Kathy Harter of Seal Beach, Calf., and Rosemary Casals of San Francisco advanced today in an international tennis tournament.

MADRID, May 18--Spain took the first formal step this week to begin the development of Spanish Sahara's phosphates deposits, believed to be among the largest in the world, through an international consortium.
In Washington early this spring, it was called "Naughty Limericks." In New York last night, it was called "Mischievous Folk Ditties."

VICTOR SERGE used only 17 pages in his "Memoirs of a Revolutionary, 1901-1941" to describe the events that crowd into his 288-page novel, "Birth of Our Power." It is an epic of would-be revolutionaries behind the lines during the last years of the First World War, told by a stateless young social agitator.
CAPE KENNEDY, Fla., May 18 (AP)--Maj. Gen. John G. Shinkie, Apollo program manager for the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Kennedy Space Center, resigned today for "personal reasons."

WASHINGTON, May 18-- The water transportation committee of the Federal Bar Association announced plans today for a one-day forum in September, to explore the principle of maritime subsidies established in the Merchant Marine Act of 1936.

WASHINGTON, May 18-- Secretary of State Dean Rusk said today that the Johnson Administration, prodded by Mike Mansfield, the Senate majority leader, was considering a new appeal to the United Nations to help resolve the conflict in Vietnam.
HOUSTON, May 18--District Judge Allen B. Hannay has named a special master to conduct hearings into the events which led to the halting of trading in Westec Corporation stock last Aug. 25.

LOS ANGELES, May 18 (UPI)--Andy Clyde, star of numerous two-reel silent comedies and William Boyd's partner in the early Hopalong Cassidy movies, died in his sleep in his home here today. His age was 75.
OKLAHOMA CITY, May 18 (UPI)--Gov. Dewey Bartlett, a Roman Catholic, signed today a bill authorizing state-operated birth control centers for all persons regardless of financial condition.

Even before the news came out yesterday after the close that the Government had taken action to limit its sales of silver, there was a riptide of enthusiasm for silver futures. Prices once again set new highs for the distant deliveries and so did the trading volume.

WASHINGTON, May 18-- Everybody is being elaborately polite about President de Gaulle's latest pronouncements out of the Elysee Palace in Paris. He said "No" to the British in 2,000 elegant words and the Foreign Office and the State Department are saying that maybe he said "Maybe."
City College athletes were honored last night at the college's annual All-Sports Dinner at the Statler-Hilton. Mike Pearl, the basketball star, received three awards.
The elimination of all school buildings that are not fireproof was urged yesterday by Superintendent of Schools Bernard E. Donovan in his tentative capital budget request for 1968-69.
PALO ALTO, Calif., May 18 --A demand that the Mormon church immediately remove all restrictions on Negro members has been made by Stewart L. Udall, Secretary of the Interior.

NEW CANAAN, Conn., May 18.--It will be Modern House Day here on Sunday. The ninth biennial tour for the benefit of the New Canaan Community Nursery School will visit houses by seven noted architects: Frank Lloyd Wright, Philip C. Johnson, John Hill, Allan J. Gelbin, John Black Lee, Harrison DeSilver and Hugh Smallen.

WASHINGTON, May 18-- The Securities and Exchange Commission announced today the suspension from trading of a Canadian stock that had been suspended earlier in the day by the Securities Commission of Alberta.

BALTIMORE, May 18--Although he has not raced since April 1, In Reality, who campaigns in the silks of Mrs. Frances A. Center, is the long-range favorite for the 92d running of the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday.

PHILADELPHIA, May 18 (AP)--F. Markoe Rivinus, the president of Smith Kline French Laboratories, said today that critics of the United States drug industry were "unwilling to accept the fact that medicines must be priced to allow for financial risks."

SANTA CRUZ, Calif., May 18--Lagging faculty salaries at the University of California brought a sharp warning today from Edward W. Carter, former president of the Board of Regents, to his fellow Regents, including Gov. Ronald Reagan.
BAY SHORE, L.I. May 18-- Mrs. Pat Cici of the Cedarbrook Club shot a 38, 41--79 today and won the low gross prize in the women's Cross County Golf Association tournament at Southward Ho.
MOCHOA, South Vietnam, May 18--In this secluded corner of South Vietnam, many people consider the Vietcong a secondary enemy.
Seven of the 13 reputed Cosa Nostra, or Mafia, leaders seized eight months ago at a "little Apalachin" meeting in a Queens restaurant were indicted last night on charges of criminal contempt.
John Chancellor, director of the Voice of America since September, 1965, will resign shortly to return to commercial broadcasting.
The Louisiana Land and Exploration Company announced here yesterday the election of Ford M. Graham as chairman and chief executive officer.

WASHINGTON, May 18.-- Lieut.-Gen. Lewis W. Walt, the comander of the Marines in South Vietnam, is being reassigned to Washington to become the new director of personnel at Marine Corps Headquarters, Secretary of Defense Robert S. McNamara said today.
Frederick O. Hess, Germanborn president of the Selas Corporation of America, received the Golden Door Award last night from the American Council for Nationalities Service.

Peter J. Riordan, a 45-yearold former Internal Revenue Service supervisor, was sentenced in Federal Court yesterday to four years in prison for operating a scheme that almost cost the Government $600,000.
Taxpayers owed refunds on their 1966 city income taxes should generally begin receiving them between June 15 and July 15, Finance Administrator Roy M. Goodman said yesterday.
A drinking glass less than 3 inches high was sold in London yesterday for $53,000. Sotheby's auction house said that was the highest figure ever paid at auction for a glass art object.

After a nationwide quest of nearly a year, the board of trustees of Barnard College decided unanimously yesterday that the new president of Barnard was to be Dr. Martha E. Peterson, the dean of student affairs at the University of Wisconsin.
PARIS, May 18--A deserter from the United States Army in Germany has been sentenced to 10 days in prison for vagrancy in a case that has possible diplomatic implications.

MINNEAPOLIS, May 18 (AP) --Lou Hudson, the St. Louis Hawks' rookie star, signed a three-year contract today with the Minnesota Muskies of the new, rival American Basketball Association. A legal battle for his services appeared certain.

The annual dance concert of the School of Performing Arts last night at the New York School of Printing auditorium provided parents with the opportunity to beam and amateur talent scouts to scout the talent. There was a great deal to please both groups.

DOVER, N.J., May 19 (UPI) --A mysterious explosion of a secret experimental munition in an assembly building at the Picatinny Arsenal killed one civilian technician and injured another, it was disclosed today.

Tad Mosel, Pulitzer Prizewinning playwright and author of some of the top plays from television's so-called "golden age," has been commissioned by the Columbia Broadcasting System to write an original work for its "C.B.S. Playhouse" next season.

MADRID, May 19--The Spanish Government and the University of Massachusetts signed a contract today for the joint publication of a limited edition of the two volumes of Leonardo da Vinci's manuscripts that were allegedly rediscovered in 1965 in the National Library of Madrid.

MINEOLA, L.I., May 19 (AP) --Eight men accused of taking bets on sports events surrendered to Nassau County District Attorney William Cahn today. A ninth was arrested by Rackets Bureau detectives and released on $500 bail.

Two makers of television sets sought yesterday to assure potential buyers that their color sets pose no radiation problem such as the one that has caused the General Electric Company to adopt a "modification" program on console and table models of large-screen sets made between June, 1966, and February, 1967.
WASHINGTON, May 19--Senate leaders agreed today to postpone for three weeks the debate on a resolution of censure against Senator Thomas J. Dodd, Democrat of Connecticut.
ATLANTIC CITY, May 19-- Senator Thomas L. McIntyre criticized the American Bankers Association today for "its unadulterated opposition" to the "truth-in-lending" bill.
Legislation to protect small shippers against allegedly arbitrary and restrictive practices by the trucking industry was urged on the Senate this week.

CHICAGO, May 19--Changes in attitudes toward sex, now sweeping college campuses in the United States, are affecting the mental health of some students, the director of student psychiatry at the University of Wisconsin reported today.
Twelve firemen who were killed here last October in their department's worst disaster were led into a "fatal trap," a board of inquiry said yesterday.
A union of building service employes postponed yesterday at the request of Mayor Lindsay a strike threatened for this weekend against many apartment buildings in the city.

Maurice Spalter, an assistant district attorney of New York County from 1931 through 1937, died yesterday in the Columbia-Presbyterian Medical Center, after a short illness. He was 66 years old and lived at 25 Knolls Crescent in Riverdale, the Bronx.

The Maritime Administration informed unsubsidized American steamship operators yesterday that that segment of the mrchant marine could put in bids again for 11 C-4 vessels under the terms of the Ship Exchange Law.

Over the past two years the Communist Hukbalahap guerrillas in the Philippines have been gradually recovering from the defeat inflicted on them by the late President Ramon Magsaysay, so that now, according to a well-documented study just released by the Philippine Senate Defense Committee, they run "an invisible, alternative government commanding the obedience of considerable masses" in provinces barely two to three hundred kilometers north of Manila.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (UPI)--President Johnson de- clined an invitation today to speak to a group of peace demonstrators who have appeared at the White House gates, for three consecutive days to demand that the war in Vietnam be ended immediately.
The Smith College Club of Long Island will hold its annual house and garden tour Monday from 1 to 5 P.M. in the Kings Point-Great Neck area.

ATHENS, May 19--Cyprus began today a cautious probing of the intentions of the Greek junta. There were reports that the new Greek leaders were considering an extension of their coup to the island, an independent republic.

MONTREAL, May 19--In addition to freedom from tariffs and other restraints, international business must have a monetary system that fits its needs, Arthur K. Watson told a closing session of the 21st biennial congress of the International Chamber of Commerce.

Broadway will get its first "new" movie theater in years tomorrow night when Joseph L. Mankiewicz's "The Honey Pot" has its invitational premiere in the 800-seat Trans-Lux West at Broadway and 49th Street.

WASHINGTON, May 19-- John W. Gardner, Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare, told civic leaders tonight to stop "grumbling" and get out and do something about the problems of the country's cities.
TOKYO, May 19--Musicians visiting the Far East are often warned that the Japanese are extremely sparing with applause, but you can't prove it by Eugene Ormandy.

The chief opponents of the proposed World Trade Center accused city television stations yesterday of "greedily filling their pockets with $40million in toll money" collected by the Port of New York Authority.

An examiner for the Federal Maritime Commission has recommended that the regulatory agency approve the merger of three major Pacific Coast steamship operations with services across the Pacific to the Far East. The proposed merger would put American President Lines, Pacific Far East Lines and American Mail Line into one operation.
HAVANA, May 19 (Reuters) --Cuba today signed a controversial $44.8-million contract for the construction of a large British fertilizer plant here.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, Saturday, May 20--United States pilots bombed downtown Hanoi yesterday for the first time. Five planes were lost, an American military spokesman said.
ROSLYN, L.I., May 18-- The Knothole, the tiny rustic cabin there Christopher Morley wrote "Kitty Foyle" and "The Haunted Bookshop," will be opened here as a Nassau County historical site Sunday.
The Monsanto Aviation Safety Award for 1966 was presented this week to David D. Thomas, deputy administrator of the Federal Aviation Administration.

WOODBURY, L.I., May 19 --Steve Turner, a Long Island University sophomore; Tom Roesch of Huntington and Vern Morgan of New York gained the semi-finals of the Eastern hard-court tennis championship at the Woodbury Country Club today.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 19--The General Assembly adopted a resolution today providing for United Nations administration of South-West Africa. The vote was 85 to 2, with 30 abstentions.
The New York Mets don't have too much success with some National League pitchers. Bob Gibson of the St. Louis Cardinals has been especially rough on them.

PARIS, May 19--Former Premier Pierre Mendes-France urged the National Assembly today to reject Premier Georges Pompidou's bid for special powers for six months because the economic policies of the Gaullist regime had been ineffective and socially unjust.
FORT WORTH, May 19-- Dave Stockton saw this Texas course for the first time four days ago, and today he set a 36-hole scoring record in the $115,000 Colonial Country Club invitation golf tournament.
MIAMI, May 19 (AP)--The United States today lifted a temporary order banning from the country a Cuban exile, Felipe Rivero, because of his anti-Castro activities.

LONDON, May 19 (AP)-- Britain, France, Italy, South Africa and Chile got off to 2-0 leads today by winning opening singles matches in the second round of the European Zone Davis Cup tennis competition.

PROBABLY the first thing to be said about the Ken neth MacMillan version of "Romeo and Juliet," which Britain's Royal Ballet introduced for the first time this season at the Metropolitan Opera House last night, is that it is big. It is big, sumptuous and splendid. Also it offers grateful and magnificent chances to the dancers, all of which were gratefully and magnificently taken.
The Xerox Corporation said yesterday it was not worried about a $25 copier made by a toy manufacturer.

ROME, May 19--Egidio Ortona, Secretary General of the Italian Foreign Ministry, was named today as Ambassador to the United States. His nomination was officially announced after word had been received from Washington formally approving the selection.

An organization of Episcopal lawyers and clergymen here has urged that an income tax be imposed on real estate and other untaxed commercial interests owned by churches, but not used for religious purposes.

NORMAN, Okla., May 19 (AP)--Jim Ryun of Kansas, the world's fastest miler, ran a 1:52.6 half-mile today in winning his 880-yard heat and qualifying for tomorrow's finals of the Big Eight outdoor track championships.

MOSCOW, May 19--A striking series of apparent intelligence mishaps preceded the removal of the long-time head of the Soviet security apparatus and his replacement by a senior Communist party politician.

WHITE PLAINS, May 19-- A dentist who put anesthetic in the right side of a patient's jaw and then pulled a tooth from the left side while she tried to scream through a mouthful of instruments was ordered to pay for his blunder today.

Mrs. Sandra Neave Benton, widow of Clark Benton, was married yesterday afternoon to Robert Armistead Wooldridge Brauns. The Rev. D. Reginald Thomas of the Brick Presbyterian Church performed, the, ceremony at the bride's apartment, 155 East 72d St.

I WOULD never put a Louis XVI chimney in this room," said David Hicks, a top London decorator, yesterday, issuing another of his polite, but firm, pronouncements that his high-born and working-class clients have come to expect.
LONG BRANCH, N.J., May 19--Morris Wood, holder of a number of ice skating records, died yesterday at Monmouth Medical Center. His age was 85.

The Army Corps of Engineers, which has responsibility for clearing New York Harbor of debris, expects a flood of flotsam in city waters because of the antiburning ordinance that goes into effect today.
SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 19--Lieut. Gen. Nguyen Van Thieu, South Vietnam's chief of state, said today that he had decided to oppose Premier Nguyen Cao Ky for the presidency.

DALLAS, May 19 (AP)-- Curtis Cokes, the world welterweight champion, kept his record clear against European challengers by stopping Francois Pavilla of France tonight in the 10th round of a scheduled 15-round title fight.

BRUSSELS, May 19--Premier Paul vanden Boeynants said today that conditions existed for the six countries in the European Common Market to open negotiations with Britain on her application for membership.

"A groundswell feeling" that the head of the Union of American Hebrew Congregations should be a layman is a factor in the dispute between the union and Temple Emanu-El, a prominent rabbi said yesterday.

BEAUMONT, Tex., May 19 (UPI)--Marilynn Smith, carrying a sizzling putter that rapped in three birdie putts on the back nine, carded a 36, 31--67, three under par today to take the first-round lead in the $10,000 Babe Zaharias open golf tournament.

The Collegiate Chorale gave an enthusiastic Carnegie Hall audience its money's worth last night. The spring concert wrapped up the group's season with three big choral works. There was Haydn's powerful Mass in D minor, "Lord Nelson"; Beethoven's Choral Fantasy and Robert Starer'S dramatic cantata, "Ariel."
GEOFFREY WAGNER's "The Sands of Valor" could easily become the most respected statement of how men lived, fought and died in the British tank corps in North Africa, Especially the last.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)--A Senate-House conference committee asked today for mandatory four-year terms for the chiefs of all the major military services.
UNITED NATIONS, N.Y., May 19--The United Nations Emergency Force ended today its 10-year-old mission to keep peace between Israel and the United Arab Republic.
The Xerox Corporation was praised yesterday by a militant civil rights group. It promptly defended the Eastman Kodak Company, which had been criticized by the same group.
