KANSAS CITY, May 19 (AP)--Don Buford hit two triples and Tommie Agee stole three bases tonight to lead the Chicago White Sox to a 9-1 triumph over the Kansas City Athletics. It was Chicago's 12th victory in their last 13 games.
Prices on the London Stock Exchange declined yesterday along a broad front.

WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)--Janos Radvanyl, the Hungarian diplomat who defected to the United States this week, indicated in a statement today that he had broken with his Government because of policy differences.
BALTIMORE, May 19-- Dizzy, the fast-talking king of the local touts, likes Damascus in the Preakness. At Pimlico today, he was blabbing the colt's name all over the track.

BALTIMORE, May, 19--With the richest prize in the history of the stakes as the magnet, a field of 10 thoroughbreds will compete in the 92d running of the Preakness tomorrow. To the winner will go $141,500 of the $194,000 that makes up the gross purse of the race, the middle jewel of the Triple Crown for 3-year-olds.
HANOI, North Vietnam, May 19--Three or perhaps four United States fighter-bombers were shot down in Hanoi today by the most terrible barrage of antiaircraft fire I have ever seen.
Three teen-agers held up a student-operated store at Jamaica High School yesterday afternoon and made off with about $200.

Since the Public Service Commission has granted the Consolidated Edison Company a $32-million-ayear rate increase without hearings, it is the Commission's responsibility either to justify that increase or rescind it. That is the purpose of the public hearings now in progress.
DENVILLE, N.J., May 19-- Wes Ellis of the Westchester Country Club won the fourth annual $25,000 Dodge open golf tournament today at the Rockaway River Country Club.

WASHINGTON, May 19-- The United States Government said today that the American- South Vietnam military thrust into the southern half of Viet- nam's demilitarized zone was a "purely defensive measure" against a "considerable buildup" of North Vietnamese forces.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP) --The Senate voted $75-million additional in anti-poverty funds today to try to head off rioting in big cities this summer.
The squeeze was under way yesterday in silver futures trading as an aftermath to the Government's announcement of the day before limiting silver sales.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 19 --George (Pete) Bostwick Jr., who defeated Charlie Slicklen on the 18th hole to win the 1966 Walter J. Travis Memorial golf tourney, charged home through a strong wind today to beat out Slicklen and two others by a stroke for medal honors in the 57th annual Travis competition at the Garden, City Golf Club.
BUENOS AIRES, May 19-- The Buenos Aires stock exchange has been booming in the wake of what has been termed Argentina's "second revolution."
EREZ, Israel, May 19--Soldiers of Israel and the United Arab Republic watched from opposite sides today as the United Nations flag was lowered at Checkpoint King's Gate in the Gaza Strip.
ROCHESTER, May 19--Mr. and Mrs. J. Wallace Ely have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Suzanne Farnham Ely, to William Winters McQuilkin Jr., son of Mr. and Mrs. McQuilkin.
PHILADELPHIA, May 19 (AP)--Rich Allen's two-out throwing error led to three unearned runs in the eighth inning tonight and helped the Cincinnati Reds to a 6-1 victory over Philadelphia.
MINEOLA, L.I., May 19--A special judicial inquiry aimed at overhauling the Suffolk County District Court was announced today as an outgrowth of the recent dismissal of Suffolk Judge Floyd Sarisohn.

EAU CLAIRE, Wis., May 19 --The State College Board of Regents granted promotions today to two professors whose promotions had been withheld because they signed an advertisement opposing United States policies in Vietnam.

The McCrory Corporation and S. Klein Department Stores, in which McCrory has a majority interest, are discussing a merger in an effort to provide capital for S. Klein's expansion needs, Meshulam Riklis, chairman of McCrory, said yesterday.
Prices declined yesterday on the American Stock Exchange.

ST. JAMES, L.I., May 19-- Mrs. H. Sheppard Mussom's Ch. Ballykelly Colin from Louisville, Ky., handled by Clint Harris, was judged best in show today in the 38th annual specialty show of the Irish Wolfhound Club of America at Mr. and Mrs. Gordon F. Graham's Shadow Hill.

Sixty-five Congressmen have come to New York City this weekend for their annual lark. The purpose of their visit is overwhelmingly pleasure, with a dash of frivolity thrown in. But today, just before noon, there will be an interlude of serious purpose.

PRINCETON, N.J., May 19 --Mr. and Mrs. A. Munroe Wade have announced the engagement of Mr. Wade's daughter, Miss Mary Gerdiner Wade, to Norman Robert Crozier McGrath, son of Mr. and Mrs. Raymond McGrath of Dublin, Ireland.

SAIGON, South Vietnam, May 18 (Reuters)--War has scorched the six-mile-wide demilitarized zone between North and South Vietnam for the past year, though American and South Vietnamese troops had never been committed there before yesterday.

Abercrombie Fitch, a sporting goods and apparel-specialty store here, announced its purchase yesterday of the Crow's Nest, a New York nautical supply concern, which has a store in Manhattan and a mail-order business.

MOSCOW, May 19--The Soviet Union, after waiting four months, ratified today the treaty banning nuclear weapons in outer space. The treaty was signed here Jan. 27 by the United States, the So- [ viet Union and Britain. Dozens of other nations signed later, and the United States ratified it.
Four mayor lumber associations reported a decrease of 13.5 per cent in production for the week ended May 13, compared with the corresponding 1966 week.
ROCHESTER, Minn., May 19 --Dr. John de J. Pemberton, an early specialist in surgery of the thyroid gland at the Mayo Clinic, died of cancer yesterday at the Methodist Hospital, His age was 80.
ALEXANDRIA, Va., May 19 (AP)--Fourteen of the 20 persons who staged a sit-in at the Pentagon last week protesting the war in Vietnam were found guilty today of loitering.

HUNTINGTON, L.I., May 19 --Mr. and Mrs. George Alexan der Taylor of Lloyd Neck and Nantucket Island, Mass., have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Pamela Wilmerding Taylor, to Airman 2d Cl. Peter Converse McDonald, U.S.A.F. His parents are W. James McDonald of Boston and Mrs. Converse McDonald of Marion, Mass.
The city gave ground yesterday in its fight to compel owners of thousands of apartment houses to close incinerators today or upgrade them in compliance with the new antipollution law.
INDIANAPOLIS, May 19 (AP)--Mike Mosley, 22 years old, of La Puente, Calif., spun and hit the wall in practice today at the Indianapolis Motor Speedway but was uninjured.
In deciding that the Bill of Rights applies to minors as well as to adults, the Supreme Court is forcing needed and long-overdue reforms in the present system for dealing with juvenile delinquents.

THUYBAN, Demilitarized Zone, South Vietnam, May 19-- American marines and South Vietnamese infantrymen fanned out today along the Benhai River, the border of the two Vietnams, in their first offensive within the demilitarized zone.

GARDEN CITY, L.I., May 19 --Arundel Brazin Li'l Raisin, a white toy poodle owned by Judith D. Feinberg of Miami, came from the bred-by-exhibitor class today to win best of breed at the Poodle Club of America's 35th annual specialty show at Adelphi University.
Algur H. Meadows, the Texas oil man who was recently told that his $1-million art collection contained 44 forgeries, has bought another painting.
PROVIDENCE R.I., May 19 --Confidential memos purport ing to outline 40 months of bugged telephone conversations by New England racket figures were made public here today.

A memorial tournament in honor of Dr. Jack Golann will be played tomorrow night, with the proceeds devoted to charity. Play will start at 7 P.M. at the Men's Club of Temple Isaiah, 75-24 Grand Central Parkway, Forest Hills, Queens.
WASHINGTON, May 19 (AP)--President Johnson signed today a bill authorizing a start on a $444-million project to use the power of the atom to turn sea water into fresh water.
The American Jewish Committee reported major progress yesterday in eliminating from Roman Catholic textbooks hostile references to non-Catholics.
GETTYSBURG, Pa., May 19 (AP)--Former President Dwight D. Eisenhower arrived home from Walter Reed Army Medical Center today and immediately went into seclusion.

Some 240 student body presidents across the country are seeking middle-of-the-road alternatives to escalation, trying to offer the President practical ways to avoid a wider war. In this spirit we should strengthen our national effort by a fresh look at its diplomatic component.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 19-- Five Women's Metropolitan Golf Association teams were succesful in a series of seven Long Island section challenge matches today at the Meadow Brook Club. The matches pitted the series leaders against the lowest team in the next higher series.

Soon after an attempt was made to assassinate Frank Costello, a gangland meeting was held in Apalachin, N.Y., apparently to decide how to divide his gambling empire, District Attorney Frank S. Hogan's office disclosed yesterday.
"I felt sorry for him. He looked so innocent, so small. I just couldn't believe he'd done it," said 17-year-old Nestor Laracuente yesterday.

E.P. Dutton Company has chosen "The Fox and the Hound" by Daniel P. Mannix for its $10,000 Animal Book Award. The award, taken from the publisher's earnings on a book, was raised this year from $7,500.
Directors of the Kern County Land Company voted last night to accept a merger proposal by Tenneco, Inc., involving convertible preferred stock valued at more than $430-million.

"No, it didn't surprise me." Hirsch Jacobs, the noted trainer, made that comment at Aqueduct yesterday when questioned about the top weight of 126 pounds his wife's Straight Deal will carry in this afternoon's $50,000 added Top Flight Handicap.

GENEVA, May 19--The leaders of the International Red Cross appealed today to all sides in the war in Vietnam to assure "proper and humane treatment" of prisoners and to conclude a cease-fire to end the civilian population's "intolerable burden of human misery."
Peter J. Spellman, actuary of the United States Life Insurance Company, was elected yesterday to the additional post of vice president.
WASHINGTON, May 19--As drafted, the Administration's bill to reform the American patent system faces the almost unanimous opposition of the Patent Bar.

Sy Unger of 25 Sutton Place South and Mrs. Jacquelyn Gruder of 530 Park Avenue have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Rustine Unger, to Thomas H. Guinzburg, son of Mrs. Harold K. Guinzburg of 480 Park Avenue and Locust Valley, L.I., and the late Mr. Guinzburg.

ATHENS, May 19--Normally, Athens specializes in good political talk about bad politics. These days it is caught in one of those after-dinner situations where a perfectly pleasant conversation has been interrupted, the lights have been turned out and the guests are forced to watch home movies.
A plan to offer welfare recipients a financial incentive to work was announced yesterday by Mayor Lindsay.
MOSCOW, May 19--A Soviet scientist is mobilizing an army of what he calls "microbial detectives" to enable physicians to diagnose quickly and easily a variety of disorders.
MADISON, Wis., May 19 (UPI)--City bus service was halted today when drivers refused to risk getting involved in renewd student rampages over a "wrong-way" bus route.
The city's long-delayed plans for a $100-million traffic-control system have been set back again because the "electronic brains" must be redesigned.

Dr. Hyman Danish, an ear, nose and throat specialist who practiced in Brooklyn since 1920, died yesterday in Victory Memorial Hospital, Brooklyn. He was 76 years old and lived and practiced at 422 81st Street, Brooklyn.
ATLANTA, May l9 (AP)-- Mack Jones belted a two-run homer into the right-field stands to highlight a three-run sixth inning tonight as Atlanta defeated Pittsburgh, 3-2.

HARRISON, N.Y., May 19-- Town officials here worked today on a plan to incorporate Harrison as a city if estate owners in the Purchase corner of town persist in their attempt to incorporate their neighborhood as an independent village.

WASHINGTON, May 19--One of the two bands at last night's 10th annual Opera Ball played so loud and so long that many of the 500 guests left well before the festivities ended at 12:30 this morning, an early curfew for an event that some ballgoers termed a qualified success.

WASHINGTON, May 18 (AP)--The Senate confirmed the promotion of 25 generals in the Air Force Reserve and the Air National Guard after the name of Samuel P. Goddard, former Governor of Arizona, was removed from the list.

WESTBURY, L.I., May 19-- Brooklyn-born Eddie Wheeler, the competent reinsman who now lives in California, rushed into and out of Roosevelt Raceway tonight, but before he departed he drove Kerry Pride to an easy victory in the Volomite Trot.
In the hope of improving its credit rating with the people who lend it money, the city yesterday published its first financial newsletter.

KARACHI, Pakistan, May 19--Pakistan charged today that a force of Indian troops and border security guards crossed into Pakistani territory north of Sialkot, on the Indian-West Pakistan border, and opened fire on Pakistani border security forces, known as Rangers.

Harry F. Guggenheim, presi dent and editor in chief of the newspaper Newsday, has given large ceramic work by Joan Miro to the Solomon R. Guggenheim Museum in memory of his wife, Alicia Patterson Guggenheim. The work, commissioned by Mrs. Guggenheim, is now permanently installed at the museum.
WASHINGTON, May 19-- Europe's first multination satellite will be sent aloft by an American rocket in about 10 days, the space agency said today.

WASHINGTON, May 19-- An influential Western Democrat stepped into the House fight over school legislation today with proposals that, if adopted, could slow Southern school desegregation and strengthen state control over the use of Federal funds.

AT 8 A.M. Thursday morning, Stuart Bossom, 2 years old, was admitted to the Hospital of the Albert Einstein College of Medicine in the East Bronx. By 10:30, he had commandeered a shiny red racing car from the seventh-floor pediatrics ward playroom and discovered, to his infinite delight, that the windows in his room opened out just wide enough to accommodate one shiny red racing car.

AMITYVILLE, L.I., May 19 --Sidney Stacey, who retired in 1959 as chairman of the board of the Pilgrim Laundry Inc. of Brooklyn, died today in Brunswick Hospital at the age of 83. He lived at 41 Horton Street in Malverne.
LONDON, May 19--The five-day sale of Astor family possessions at Cliveden, the great country estate west of London, ended today, having earned 160,156 ($448,437).

Alex Freeman, whose syndicated gossip column, "CloseUp," appeared in more than 60 newspapers throughout the United States, died of cancer Thursday at Park East Hospital. He was 38 years old and lived at 2 Horizon Road, Fort Lee, N.J.
DETROIT, May 19--General Motors Corporation joined other automobile makers today in predicting that the prices of 1968 cars would go up.

WASHINGTON, May 19--The Federal Communications Commission ordered an investigation today of whether American Telephone and Telegraph Company should be forced to permit sharing of its low-cost Telpak services by businesses other than regulated public utilities.
The 1967 maroon Thunderbird stolen from the Police Department's towaway pound at 56th Street and the Hudson River on Wednesday was found shortly before 11 A.M. yester day in Hoboken, N.J.
THE Glass Bells in the window and upstairs galleries of James Robinson Imports, at 12 East 57th Street, form a group of unusually wellmade pieces and are worthy of study.

SCHENECTADY, N.Y., May 19--Dr. Elizabeth M. Cooper of Syracuse, who retired in 1958 as chairman of the mathematics department of Hunter College High School in New York, died Wednesday at the age of 76.

TOKYO, May 19 (AP)--The United States Army has given subsidies to Japanese universities and research institutes doing bacteriological, pathological and physiological research, a high Japanese Government official said today.

LARCHMONT, N.Y. May 19 --The 12th annual Larchmont Yacht Club overnight race for the Edlu Trophy began off the Larchmont breakwater shortly before sunset today with a big fleet heading, eastward on the first leg of the 125-mile passage inside Long Island Sound.

Archbishop Stepinac defeated Cardinal Hayes, 46 to 46 to win the team title yesterday in the 50th annual Athletic Association of Private Schools track and field championship at Downing Stadium, Randalls Island, Hayes was the defender.

A white school principal has requested a transfer from a predominantly Negro and Puerto Rican school in Brooklyn, in the second such incident in a week. The Greatamerica Corporation is maintaining a "restrained degree of optimism" about the possibility of acquiring the Glidden Company, E. Grant Fitts, president of the Dallas-based insurance and bank holding company, told shareholders at the annual meeting at Las Vegas, the site of its home offices.
HOUSTON, May 19 (AP) --Manager Herman Franks of the San Francisco Giants was fined $100 today for a run-in with Umpire Shag Crawford last night.
Samuel Mitchell, a founder of Mitchell Brothers, Inc., manufacturer of ladies' sleepwear, died today at Bellevue Hospital at the age of 81. He lived at 25 Sutton Place South.

PITTSBURGH, May 19 (UPI)--The Rev. L. Doward McBain of Phoenix, Ariz., has been nominated as president of the American Baptist Convention, holding its 60th annual meeting here.

Two physicians left here yesterday for Paris in a single engine Beechcraft plane in an attempt to fly there nonstop as Charles A. Lindbergh did solo 40 years ago today.

SANDWICH, Egland, May 19 --The United States led Britain, 8 matches to 1, with 3 drawn, at the end of the first day's play in the 21st Walker Cup golf competition at Royal St. Georges today. In a near southwesterly gale and cold rain, squals, the Americans played superbly on the home holes to salvage matches apparently lost beyond recall.

WASHINGTON, May 19-- Secretary of the Interior Stewart L. Udall took over the funds, of one of the country's wealthlest Indian tribes today, saying there were "indications of wrong-doing" in the handling of the money by court-appointed guardians of Indian affairs.

A number of conservationists yesterday called for the establishment of a State Department of Recreation.
Two military contracts worth more than $1-billion were awarded yesterday to the McDonnell-Douglas Corporation.
GREENFIELD, Mass., May 19--Theodore Cronyn, an engineer who laid out roads in Yosemite and Kings Canyon National Parks, died yesterday after a short Illness. He was 79 years old.

CAIRO, May 19--The United Nations commander, General Rikhye, told his men grimly at their retreat ceremony today that the end of their mission had come "for reasons of an overriding political nature."

TOKYO, Saturday, May 19 (AP)--A Japanese report from Peking said today that armed battles between supporters and opponents of Chairman Mao Tse-tung had spread to part of Heilungkian. Province near China's Manchurian border with the Soviet Union.

Litton Industries, Inc., the West Coast giant electronics producer, continued to realize records in sales and earnings for the three-month and nine-month periods ended April 30, according to the report issued yesterday by Charles B. Thornton, chairman.

PORTLAND, Ore., May 19-- A $50-million fund campaign, the largest single financial drive in the history of Presbyterianism, has passed its goal with several millions to spare. It will continue through 1968.

ST. LOUIS, May 19 (AP)-- Joseph F. Holland, special assistant to the publisher of The St. Louis Post-Dispatch, died of cancer today in a hospital here. He was 67 years old.

WASHINGTON, May l9-- The Administration was urged by several members of Congress today to try to persuade the United Nations to keep its peace-keeping force in operation between Egypt and Israel despite objections of the United Arab Republic.

Mr. and Mrs. James Collie of Johannesburg, South Africa, have made known the engagement of their daughter, Miss Deirdre Kathleen Collie, to Stephen Matthew Lewin. He is the son of Mr. and Mrs. Joseph A. Lewin of Brooklyn.

ATHENS--The Greek military junta made its coup so rapidly and with such impressive precision that at the far left, where it might have expected resistance, it found none. Flower-Fifth Avenue Hospital, the teaching hospital for New York Medical College, has lost the American Medical Association's approval for its anesthesiology residency training program. The A.M.A. declined to disclose its reasons publicly.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- President Johnson put the United States today in the forefront of a projected global program for reorganizing and enlarging mankind's water resources.

THE glittering pre-eminence of Sandy Koufax blinded most sports followers last year to the fact that other Dodger pitchers contributed 68 victories to the Los Angeles pennant-winning total. It may have appeared like a one-man job but it wasn't, although developments this season make observers wonder ever so slightly if the original impression had elements of accuracy to it.
About 20 meter maids staged a wildcat walkout yesterday to protest alleged harassment by civilians and policemen.

The Harlem Globetrotters, one of the nation's best known entertainment attractions, have been purchased by Metromedia, Inc., owner of a number of TV and radio stations, including Channel 5 and WNEW radio here. The price was reported to be slightly over $1-million.
It was a clear day, but the nuclear ship Savannah headed for the Orient yesterday in a cloud of uncertainty.
MINNEAPOLIS, May 23-- Mrs. Irvin E. Hendryson, a former professional librarian, was elected president today at the 71st annual convention of the National Congress of Parents and Teachers.

Charges of desecrating and defiling the American flag against four Yale University School of Drama students were dismissed yesterday in Criminal Court. Dr. Robert Brustein, dean of the school, who was in court, said he was "delighted" with the dismissal.
The city's Air Pollution Control Department sent out its first violation notices yesterday to building owners whose incinerators did not comply with new antipollution regulations.
MOSCOW, May 23--The Soviet Union blamed Israel today for "aggravating the atmosphere of military psychosis" in the Middle East and pledged "resolute resistance to aggression."

The disclosure that Senator Edward V. Long of Missouri received $48,000 over a two-year period from one of James R. Hoffa's army of lawyers raises disturbing new doubts about the moral climate on Capitol Hill.

R. Gould Morehead, a founder and vice chairman of the board of the Suburban Propane Gas Corporation, died yesterday in the Central Suffolk Hospital, Riverhead, L.I. He was 71 years old and lived on Basket Neek Lane in Remsenburg, L. I.

DETROIT, May 23--Sales of new cars in the middle third of May fell below last year's levels and even the sales in mid-April of this year, putting a slight chilling breeze on what auto makers have called a sunny spring.
BONN, May 23--A West German court acquited today three middle-aged doctors accused of complicity in mass murder for their role in Hitler's euthanasia program.

ALBANY, May 23--The Constitutional Convention waded briefly today into one of its most controversial issues-- whether the state's rigid ban against financial aid to churchsupported schools should be relaxed.

BEACON, N.Y., May 23-- Tension was apparently eased today among 36 narcotics addicts who have been refusing meals at Matteawan State Hospital here since Friday morning. The addicts have been eating only the food they purchased in the commissary or that was sent to them in packages from family and friends.

GENEVA, May 23--"What do you think would be happening in the Middle East right now if either the United Arab Republic or Israel had nuclear weapons!" an expert at the Geneva disarmament conference asked.

CAMP BEARCAT, South Vietnam, May 23--Capt. Earle McCaskill, an assistant judge advocate in the Ninth Infantry Division, is one of 50,000 American Negroes who have served or are serving in South Vietnam.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- The deficit in the Government's comprehensive national income accounts budget in the first quarter of this year was the largest since the recession of 1958, it was disclosed today.

Parents who boycotted a Brownsville school last week to press for the transfer of a white principal said yesterday they were recommending a white, Jewish woman as principal instead. They denied any racism or that they had been demanding a Negro principal.

WINNIPEG, Man.--The PanAmerican Games are a twoweek, 23-sport extravaganza for Western Hemisphere nations in pre-Olympic years. They will be held here, starting July 23, largely because of one man's curiosity, tenacity and sense of humor.

LOS ANGELES, May 23-- Mr. and Mrs. Daniel Farrell Reeves have announced the engagement of their daughter, Miss Sheila Marie Reeves, to John Francis O'Donnell Jr., son of Mrs. Charles Samuel Weil of New York and Mr. O'Donnell of Riverside, Conn.
The growing North Atlantic containership trade appears to have claimed its first victim among the ranks of operators of conventional cargo ship tonnage.
THE young men and women who graduate this season from design schools have no fear that their light will be hidden under a Seventh Avenue bushel.

A new three-year agreement providing for wage increases totaling 15 per cent for 42,000 women's coat and suit workers was announced yesterday by the employers and the New York Cloak Joint Board of the International Ladies Garment Workers Union.

IT ISN'T a bird or a plane zooming into men's fashion--it's a cape. By late summer, the man who grew up with heroes such as Superman or Zorro will be able to swashbuckle out of Ohrbach's downstairs store in a natty tweed cape for daytime or a satin-lined, deep blue one for evening.

R.H. Macy Co., Inc., set a sales record and increased its earnings in the 13 weeks ended April 29. The unaudited report yesterday noted that sales and earnings for the 12 months ended on the same date also set records.
Lloyd K. Garrison, former president of the Board of Education, declared last night it would take "decades of effort" to rebuild the city school system to a point where the city could be proud of it.

PHILLIP and Ellen Viereck's "The New Land" is, strictly speaking, for young people. But this reader found it so handsome to look at, so inviting to read and so engrossing in detail that he feels free to recommend it to all but experts and scholars. The Vierecks, a husband and wife team, have compiled a volume that, as the ...

STUART, Fla., May 23 (UPI) --Lyle C. Wilson, national columnist for United Press International and former vice president and Washington manager of U.P.I., died today in Martin Memorial Hospital here. He was 67 years old.
James Brockman, a song composer and lyricist, died on Monday in Santa Monica, Calif. His age was 80.
RYE, N.Y., May 23--Guthrie Shaw, a financier and a civic leader in Westchester, died yesterday in his home, 2 Manursing Way, at the age of 77.
A change in senior management was announced here yesterday by Grolier, Inc., the publisher of the Book of Knowledge and the Enycylopedia Americana.

THIS season's pack of pure maple syrup is arriving in local markets. The pale golden syrup can sweeten and add its own distinctive flavor to many varieties of desserts, breads, and candies, as well as to pancakes and waffles.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- The House tentatively approved today a proposal that the Secretary of Health, Education and Welfare said would invite "evasion and delay" in school desegregation.
THE Columbia Broadcasting System conducted last night its third annual national drivers test as a safetymotivated prelude to the heavy automobile travel expected over the Memorial Day weekend.
Thirteen persons were injured early today in the derailment of a southbound IRT Seventh Avenue train just south of the Wall Street station.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- Movies from the moon, color pictures of a solar eclipse and other remarkable data returned to earth by the Surveyor 3 spacecraft were displayed here today.

PARIS--The world has been so obsessed with the fighting non-war in Vietnam that it has tended to ignore the non-fighting war in Palestine. Now the paradox ends and the Middle East crisis suddenly brings us nearer catastrophe's brink than the crisis in Southeast Asia.

CAMBRIDGE, Mass., May 23 --A group of Harvard scholars, organized by the Institute of Politics in the Kennedy School of Government, has recommended abolition of special draft deferment for students and teachers.

BRUSSELS, May 23--L'Innovation, Brussels' second biggest department store, was a twisted, smoldering ruin today. Scores of rescue workers, watched by silent crowds behind police barriers, went about the task of counting the dead.
The New York Botanical Garden in the Bronx was in full bloom yesterday, after getting off to a slow start in the recent wave of cool spring weather.

WESTBURY, L. I., May 23 --A lame filly, Pompanette, with 74-year-old Earle Avery saving her speed until the final 400 yards, captured the Proximity Trot for 2-year-old fillies at Roosevelt Raceway tonight.

A FINE defensive play by Irving Kass swung 25 international match points in the finals of the New York Double Elimination Knockout Championship last weekend and helped his team defend its title successfully.
A State Supreme Court Justice has stopped an alleged scheme in this state to sell subdivided parcels of Florida land that are under water during the rainy season.

Likening the shabby 19thcentury Civil Jail to the kind of debtor's prison that Charles Dickens wrote about, Buildings Commissioner Charles G. Moerdler disclosed yesterday a number of violations against the institution.

George G. Leary, vice president of the Borden Foods Company in charge of sales and distribution, died Monday in the Biltmore Hotel. He was 56 years old and lived at 30 Standish Drive, Scarsdale, N. Y. He had become ill in his office at 350 Madison Avenue and had gone to the hotel to rest.

The McCrory Corporation had a net loss of $335,000 in the first quarter ended April 30, against a net profit last year of $46,000, Meshulam Riklis, chairman, reported following the annual meeting yesterday.
Yemen, Aden and oil--rather than war with Israel--appear to be the objectives of President Gamal Abdel Nasser of the United Arab Republic in the new crisis.
WASHINGTON, May 23-- The dominant mood in the Senate today was that the crisis in the Middle East was one for the United Nations to handle.

WASHINGTON, May 23-- The Administration will probably ask Congress for "interim" trade legislation to deal with "routine" matters after the Trade Expansion Act expires June 30, the President's chief trade negotiator said today.

WASHINGTON, May 23--The Air Force displayed today the first known vehicle to have been recovered after a highly maneuverable re-entry flight from space. It said a larger, manned version would be tested in low-altitude flights this year.
BRUNSWICK, Germany, May 23--The Christian Democratic Union unanimously elected Chancellor Kurt George Kiesinger party chairman here today. Associated Press

BONN, May 23--Simplicissimus and Deutsches Panorama, two West German magazines that specialized in biting comment on politics, politicians and the absurdities of German society, disclosed this week that they would cease publication.

ALBANY, May 23--A new superprize of $250,000, to be paid over a 10-year period to help ease the tax burden for the winner, will be added to the forthcoming state lottery, together with several other bonus prizes.
Gardner Ackley, chairman of President Johnson's Council of Economic Advisers, said yesterday that he was disturbed by the recent tendency of interest rates to rise.
